incident.description:
On September 11, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Richard Daniele, Richard Goss and Steve Landi (Plaintiffs) against 10UP, Inc. (Defendant) in the Superior Court of the State of California in and for the County of San Francisco.

According to the complaint, on or about February 24, 2020, Defendant was the target of a massive data breach in which approximately 74,000 SFRERS members were subject to an unauthorized access and exfiltration, theft, or disclosure of their personal identifiable information (PII). Cybercriminals accessed a trove of personal details about SFERS members--such as names, home addresses, dates of birth, designated beneficiary information, 1099-R tax form information, bank account routing numbers, and SFERS website usernames and passwords--stored on one of Defendant's servers. On March 21, 2020, Defendant began notifying affected individuals about the incident. The data breach resulted from Defendant's violation of the duty to implement and maintain reasonable security procedures and practices appropriate to the nature of the PII.

As a result of the breach, Plaintiffs and Class Members now face years of constant surveillance of their financial and personal records, monitoring, and loss of rights. They also suffered invasion of privacy and out-of-pocket expenses.

Plaintiffs brought the action individually and on behalf of all SFERS members and former members residing in California whose PII was accessed or otherwise compromised in the Data Breach, which, according to the Notice of Data Breach provided by SFERS, occurred on or about February 24, 2020.

Plaintiffs sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, an order enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, compensatory and statutory damages, reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On December 8, 2020, Plaintiffs amended their complaint.

On June 2, 2023, Plaintiffs filed their motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the terms of the settlement, all class members can receive a $60 cash payment and a year of free credit monitoring and identity theft protection services offered by IDX. Class members who experienced documented data breach-related losses may be able to recover additional compensation. Affected SFERS members can claim up to $1,000 for extraordinary losses related to the breach, including the costs of fraud, identity theft and up to three hours of lost time (compensated at a rate of $25 per hour).

The aggregate cap on Defendant's aggregate payment obligation is $1.9 million. If Defendant's obligations would otherwise exceed the $1.9 million cap, costs of administration and credit monitoring are paid as a first and second priority, and all other claims, awards, fees, and costs are 'summed and reduced on a pro rata basis' so that the aggregate cost amounts to $1.9 million.

Lastly, Class Counsel will receive an award of reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in an amount not to exceed $500,000, plus litigation costs of $16,116.81. Plaintiffs will be given service awards in the amount not to exceed $10,000 each.

On June 27, 2023, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On November 20, 2023, a motion for final approval of class action settlement was filed.

On January 18, 2024, the Court granted the motion for final approval of class action settlement.

In August 2020, ICU Eyewear Holdings, Inc (ICU) was a victim of a cyber-attack whereby the attacker impersonated a company employee and initiated a bank information change request to a customer.

When the customer processed the change request and attempted to make a payment to the company for PPE product purchases, the payment was instead fraudulently transferred to the attacker's bank account. Investigators with the U.S. Secret Service were able to discover the fraud and recover the funds, which are now the subject of a civil forfeiture action in the Northern District of Texas.

The company filed a petition for remission of the funds. At December 31, 2020, the amount expected to be received of $5,577,234 was recorded as a receivable, which was received in 2021.

The 2gether has revealed a cyberattack in which roughly C1.2 million in cryptocurrency has been stolen from cryptocurrency investment accounts.

Founded in 2017, 2gether offers a cryptocurrency trading platform within the Eurozone for buying and selling without additional fees. The organization's native coin is the 2GT token, which is -- or, at least, was -- due to be issued during 2020 following a pre-sale in Spain.

On July 31, 2020, the trading platform suffered a cyberattack on its servers.

The unknown threat actors reportedly behind the attack made off with C1.183 ($1,396,956.66) million in cryptocurrency in investment accounts, which equates to 26.79% of overall funds.

In a stream of Twitter updates posted by 2together CEO Ramon Ferraz Estrada, the executive was keen to emphasize that general wallets and Euro accounts were not impacted, nor were the financial details of payment cards used to deposit funds.

However, user passwords were also compromised in the security breach, and it is recommended that users change them.

2together has not revealed how the security incident took place. An investigation is underway to find out how the attackers managed to obtain access to the company's servers, as well as the full extent of the damage caused.

Started at 08:26:52 PM +UTC, November 17, 2020, 88mph was attacked by exploiting a business logic error in the DInterest smart contract. The hack results in maliciously minting approximately $100K worth of MPH tokens.

Later, the hacker transferred the funds to the MPH-ETH UniswapV2 pool. With the help of the legendary whitehat, samczsun, the dev team exploited another bug in the MPHMinter contract to drain the Uniswap pool for rescuring existing funds and getting the hacked funds back. Here we elaborate the technical details of these two bugs in this blog post.

In 2020, Acadia Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

On February 2, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Jason Stahl (Plaintiff), in the Superior Court for the State of Washington in and for King County against Accellion USA LLC (Defendant).

According to the complaint, on or about February 1, 2021, the Office of Washington State Auditor (SAO) announced that the personal Information of approximately 1.6 million individuals in the State of Washington was compromised in a data security breach of its file transfer software vendor, Defendant. Beginning as early as December 2020 and continuing in January 2021, attacker exploited vulnerabilities in the FTA software to gain unauthorized access to files that were being transferred using the FTA product. Defendant was aware that FTA was an inadequately secure product yet sold this vulnerable product to SAO for the transfer of Personal Information. Defendant's failure to ensure that the FTA provided adequate security protocols jeopardized and Personal Information of millions of Washington residents, including Plaintiff and the class, fell well short of Defendant's obligations and also fell short of Plaintiff's and other class members' reasonable expectations for protection of their information.

Plaintiff sought for an award of monetary relief including actual and treble damages and penalties, equitable relief, costs of suit and attorneys' fees, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, leave to amend this complaint to conform to the evidence produced at trial and such other and further relief.

On January 14, 2022, Accellion Inc. has reached an $8.1 million deal with a proposed nationwide class to end litigation over a breach.

On January 24, 2022, a complaint was filed by AIG Specialty Insurance Company (Plaintiff) against Accellion, Inc. (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida. The action case was brought in relation to Defendant's alleged breach of contract resulting to exposure of its customers' confidential information, including protected health information (PHI).

According to the complaint, on December 16, 2020 and January 20, 2021, threat actors targeted Defendant's File Transfer Appliance (FTA) as a means of committing an unauthorized access and theft of confidential information. Upon information, The University of Miami (Insured) used Defendant's FTA software to transfer large files including confidential information and PHI. During the breach, Insured's confidential information was accessed and stolen by threat actors. As a result, Insured incurred damages to remediate the effects of the breach and loss of confidential information, including protected health information.

Upon learning of the incident, Defendant reportedly investigated and identified vulnerabilities within FTA. On December 20, 2020, Defendant purportedly released a patch to remediate the vulnerabilities to some customers. However, threat actors had already exploited the vulnerabilities, thereby allowing them to exfiltrate confidential information. On January 12, 2021, Defendant released a statement acknowledging the vulnerability in the FTA and that they have resolved the vulnerability and released a patch within 72 hours to the less than 50 customers affected. Despite knowing the vulnerability in the FTA and the exploitation of that vulnerability on December 16, 2020, Defendant did not report that vulnerability or its exploitation to its customers on December 17, 2020 - thereby allowing its clients to terminate their use of FTA and protect themselves against a breach.

Plaintiff is contractually, legally and equitably subrogated, to its insureds' rights against Defendant to recover for the amounts paid as a result of the loss, as well as to pursue any uninsured losses suffered by virtue of an assignment of such claims, if any. Plaintiff continues to incur losses due to the vulnerabilities in Defendant's systems and failure to timely acknowledge and remedy those vulnerabilities.

Plaintiff sought for a judgement to be entered against Defendant, interest, attorney's fees, costs, other damages incurred by Insured, and further relief as the Court deems equitable and just.

On March 4, 2022, Defendant filed a motion to dismiss Plaintiff's complaint as it fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.

On March 25, 2022, amended complaint was filed by Plaintiff.

On April 7, 2022, Defendant filed a motion to dismiss Plaintiff's amended complaint.

On June 16, 2022, having considered Defendant's motion, the Court granted in part wherein, Plaintiff's counts II and III of the amended complaint are dismissed.

On November 3, 2022, Plaintiff filed its second amended complaint against Defendant.

On December 15, 2022, Plaintiff and Defendant have reached a settlement. According to reports, Defendant offered Plaintiff a $2,500 payment to resolve all claims against the company. Plaintiff accepted the offer, which exposed it to attorney-fee shifting in the event of a loss at trial.

On December 19, 2022, Plaintiff and Defendant stipulated to dismissed all claims with prejudice. Each party will bear its own attorneys' fees and costs. On December 20, 2022, the Court dismissed the case with prejudice. Thus, the case is closed.

On April 24, 2020, Sharon Shibata (Plaintiff) filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado against Accredited Management Solutions, LLC (Defendant) on grounds allegedly violating the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).

Defendant is attempting to collect a consumer debt from Plaintiff, which is allegedly owed by Plaintiff arising from an automobile loan deficiency balance. In February 2020, Defendant began placing automated debt collection calls towards Plaintiff. On or about February 24, 2020, Plaintiff called Defendant and disputed the validity of the alleged debt. Defendant's representative threatened Plaintiff with a lawsuit if Plaintiff did not pay the alleged debt. Plaintiff also received a collection letter from Defendant dated February 25, 2020. There were no payments or other transactions to the alleged debt since 2011. The applicable statute of limitations to bring legal action to collect on the alleged debt is 6 years at most, therefore the Defendant could not sue Plaintiff on the alleged debt.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On September 22, 2021, it was ordered that defendant Accredited Management Solutions, LLC shall pay $700 in statutory damages, shall pay plaintiff's attorney's fees in the amount of $3,758 and shall pay plaintiff's costs in the amount of $574.35.

organization.name: Acuity Brands Inc.
organization.industry: Commercial, Industrial, and Institutional Electric Lighting Fixture Manufacturing

incident.description:
On September 28, 2023, a class action complaint was filed by Melissa Stark, Andrew Smith, and Mackenzie Fairfield (Plaintiffs), on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, against Acuity Brands, Inc. (Defendant) in the State Court of Fulton County, Georgia. The action arises out of Defendant's negligence allowing a date breach to occur.

On December 7, 2021, Defendant became aware of suspicious activity on its networks. Defendant immediately investigated to determine the nature and scope of the suspicious activity. The investigation concluded that an unauthorized person obtained access to some of Defendant's systems on December 7 and December 8, 2021, and copied a subset of files out of its network. In addition, Defendant also discovered evidence of an unrelated incident of unauthorized access that occurred on October 6 and October 7, 2020.

On December 5, 2022, Defendant notified affected individuals stating that the compromised personally identifiable information (PII) included individuals' names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, financial account numbers, and information related to employees' healthcare benefits. Defendant also added that approximately 37,000 individuals were affected. As a result, Plaintiffs and the Class members suffered loss and damages including out-of-pocket expenses, lost or diminished value of PII and increased risk to their PII.

Plaintiffs sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, statutory damages, attorneys' fees and costs, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

In December 2023, the parties have reached a settlement agreement.

Under the settlement terms, class members can claim up to $500 for out-of-pocket costs. Class members may also submit claims for up to three hours of lost time, at a rate of $20 per hour. For those who suffered identity theft due to the breach, the settlement allows for claims up to $3,500 for documented expenses related to the theft.

The proposed Settlement also provides three years of credit monitoring service free of charge to Settlement Class Members who submit a valid Claim Form.

In addition, Plaintiffs' counsel will receive Attorneys' Fees and Expenses in the amount of $235,000. Plaintiffs will also receive Service Awards in the amount of $2,500 each.

On January 18, 2024, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On April 21, 2024, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On May 21, 2024, having reviewed the parties' settlement, the Court granted the final approval of class action settlement. Accordingly, the Court dismissed the case with prejudice and without costs except that the Court reserves jurisdiction over the consummation and enforcement of the Settlement.

On April 4, 2022, Shannon Arbuthnot (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against Acuity - CHS, LLC formerly known as Comprehensive Health Services, LLC (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to take reasonable steps to protect the Personally Identifiable Information (PII) of Plaintiff and Class Members from unauthorized disclosure of data.

According to the complaint, on September 30, 2020, Defendant detected unusual activity within its digital environment following discovery of multiple fraudulent wire transfers. After learning the activity, Defendant engaged a team of cybersecurity experts in an attempt to secure the digital environment and conduct a forensic investigation. On November 3, 2021, Defendant determined that the PII of a number of individuals employed by one or more of its customers was accessed, compromised, and acquired by a malicious actor. PII compromised includes names and Social Security numbers.

To date, Defendant has not revealed most (if not all) of the findings of the investigation it commissioned. Defendant has not revealed when the unauthorized actor first gained access to its network, nor has it revealed the mechanism by which the unauthorized actor used. According to disclosures made to States' Attorney Generals, the unauthorized actor gained access to Defendant's networks on April 9, 2020, and continued to have access until October 22, 2020, well after the September 30, 2020, date that the intrusion was first discovered.

As a result of Defendant's negligence, Plaintiff and the class members suffered out-of-pocket expenses, emotional distress, fear, anxiety, nuisance and annoyance.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons identified by Defendant as being among those individuals impacted by the Data Breach, including all who were sent a notice of the Data Breach.

Plaintiff sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, equitable relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual and statutory damages, attorneys' fees, costs, prejudgment interest, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On April 4, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the terms of the settlement, class members can receive up to $500 for out-of-pocket expenses including bank fees, credit expenses and three hours of lost time at a rate of $20 per hour. Class members who experienced identity theft as a result of the data breach can receive higher payments of up to $3,500 for documented expenses related to their identity theft. All class members, even those who did not experience identity theft or out-of-pocket expenses as a result of the data breach, can receive two years of free credit monitoring services under the settlement.

In addition, settlement will also be used to pay for attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses incurred by Class Counsel in the amount not to exceed $255,000.

On April 6, 2023, the Court ordered to approve the motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

On August 15, 2023, an order granting final approval of class action settlement.

On September 15, 2023, the Clerk of Court is directed to close the case.

organization.name: Bosley, Inc.
organization.industry: Offices of Physicians (except Mental Health Specialists)

incident.description:
On February 1, 2021, Ken Hashemi and Steve Altes (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint against Bosley, Inc (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Central District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's alleged failure to properly secure and safeguard personal identifiable information (PII) and failure to provide timely, accurate and adequate notice to all affected individuals.

According to the complaint, beginning on or about August 17, 2020, the Defendant's network fell victim to ransomware infection. Defendant's investigation revealed that their data sources were accessed by unauthorized, unknown third-parties. The data breach exposed PII, including without limitation, unencrypted and unredacted names, Social Security numbers, financial account and/or payment card numbers, and driver's license numbers. Additional PII may include addresses, dates of birth, email addresses, and supplemental payment card information including expiration dates and CVV verification numbers. Plaintiffs also claimed that they were not notified about the data breach until on or about January 26, 2021.

Plaintiffs brought the action on behalf of all persons residing in the United States whose PII was compromised on the data breach announced by the Defendant on January 26, 2021. Defendant identified thousands of consumers whose PII may have been improperly accessed in the data breach.

Plaintiffs sought for class certification, equitable and injunctive relief, award for damages, including actual, nominal, consequential and punitive damages, attorneys' fees, costs, litigation expenses, prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On May 3, 2021, a first amended class action complaint was filed, adding Sandra Johnson-Foster, Gregory Boute, Rafael Artime, and John Bowden as Plaintiffs.

On December 1, 2021, the parties have reached a settlement in principle.

Under the terms of the Settlement Agreement, Defendant agreed to pay monetary relief capped at $500,000 including reimbursement for ordinary expenses and lost time up to $300 per Class Member, reimbursement for extraordinary expenses up to $5,000 per Class Member, and California Statutory Claim benefits of $50 per California Subclass Member.

On January 7, 2022, Plaintiffs moved for the preliminary approval of Class Action Settlement.

On February 22, 2022, Plaintiffs' motion for the preliminary approval of Class Action Settlement was granted.

location.street: No. 69 Jianguomen Nei Ave, Dongcheng Dist

incident.description:
China's central bank fined six state-owned banks a combined 41.88 million yuan ($6.3 million) Wednesday (October 21, 2020) for infringement of consumers' personal information rights as the country introduces its first national legislation on the protection of personal data.

The six banks are four branches of China Construction Bank ($4,200,000), a branch of Bank of China ($1,050,000) and a branch of Agricultural Bank of China ($1,050,000).

The penalties show that some financial institutions have insufficient awareness of the protection of consumer rights and interests and that the implementation of mechanisms for protection of consumer financial information is not in place, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) said in a Q&A published on its website.

PBOC issued measures to protect the rights and interests of financial consumers that will take effect November 1, 2020. The measures establish the required mechanisms to protect financial consumers' fundamental and long-term interests, require banks and payment institutions to follow the principles of legality, fairness and necessity when processing such information, and add penalties for violations.

On April 23, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed Nanette Katz of Blue Bell against Einstein Healthcare Network over an August 2020 phishing attack that resulted in multiple employee email accounts being accessed by an unauthorized individual.

The investigation into the breach determined the email accounts were subjected to unauthorized access for 12 days between August 5 and August 17, 2020. A review of the compromised email accounts revealed they contained the protected health information of 353,616 patients, including names, dates of birth, account/medical record numbers, medical information such as diagnosis and treatment information and, for some individuals, Social Security numbers and health insurance information.

Patients affected by the breach were notified by mail starting October 9, 2020 while the incident was still being investigated, then further notifications were sent to patients between January 21 and February 8, 2021 when it became clear that more individuals had been affected.

Following the breach, the health system implemented additional security measures to prevent further breaches and retrained the workforce on how to identify suspicious emails. Individuals whose Social Security number was exposed were offered complimentary credit monitoring and identity theft protection services for 12 months.

A law firm Morgan & Morgan filed the suit with Einstein Healthcare patient Nanette Katz of Blue Bell, PA named as lead plaintiff. Plaintiff alleges Einstein Healthcare failed to secure and safeguard the protected health information of patients and had not implemented or followed basic security procedures. As a result of that negligence, the lawsuit alleges sensitive patient information is now in the hands of cybercriminals and patients now face a substantial risk of identity theft. As a result of the breach, patients have had to spend, and will continue to have to spend, a significant amount of time and money protecting themselves against identity theft and fraud.

The plaintiff also alleges the healthcare provider failed to provide timely notifications to patients, with the lead plaintiff first receiving notification about the breach in January 2021, more than 6 months after the breach and alleged theft of her PHI. The lawsuit says the breach response was 'untimely and woefully deficient, failing to provide basic details concerning the data breach.'

Plaintiff sought for monetary damages for the patient and class members, requests the courts order the health system to fully disclose details of the nature and extent of data compromised, and requires the health system to implement reasonably sufficient safeguards to prevent further data breaches in the future.

Morgan & Morgan stood as an ally to those impacted by the breach, and we filed a class-action lawsuit that reached a $2 million verdict on behalf of the victims.

organization.name: Google Belgium
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
Belgium's Data Protection Authority (APD) fined Google Belgium C600,000 (U.S. $670,000) for refusing to delete search results linked to a Belgian public official, a provision of the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) known as the 'right to be forgotten.'

The public official had appealed to the APD to force Google Belgium to delete two search results after the internet giant's subsidiary refused to do so. In response, the APD issued the fine regarding Google Belgium's refusal to delete one search result but agreed with its stance on the other.

The APD considers that the request for dereference is well founded and that Google has expressed a serious breach by refusing it.

The APD ordered Google to stop referencing the pages concerned in the European Economic Area and to adapt its dereference request forms in order to provide more clarity in relation to which entity are responsible for this data processing.

organization.name: Google LLC
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
France's data protection agency, the CNIL, has slapped Google and Amazon with fines for dropping tracking cookies without consent.

Google has been hit with a total of C100 million ($120 million) for dropping cookies on Google.fr domain under the penalty notices issued today.

The regulator carried out investigations of the websites over the past year and found tracking cookies were automatically dropped when a user visited the domains in breach of the country's Data Protection Act.

In Google's case the CNIL has found three consent violations related to dropping non-essential cookies.

'As this type of cookies cannot be deposited without the user having expressed his consent, the restricted committee considered that the companies had not complied with the requirement provided for by article 82 of the Data Protection Act and the prior collection of the consent before the deposit of non-essential cookies,' it writes in the penalty notice.

Under local French (and European) law, site users should have been clearly informed before the cookies were dropped and asked for their consent.

The CNIL's penalty for Google breaks down into a fine of C60 million for Google LLC and C40 million for Google Ireland Ltd.

It says the size of the fines is justified because of the seriousness of the triple breach of article 82 of the Data Protection Act.

The regulator's investigation of Google.fr took place in March 2020.

organization.name: Google LLC
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
On April 27, 2021, Jonathan Diaz (Plaintiff) and all others similarly situated, filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court Northern District of California San Jose Division against Google LLC (Defendant). The case was brought in relation to the Defendant's alleged violation of the California Confidentiality of Medical Information Act (CCMIA).

Defendant co-created the Google-Apple Exposure Notification System (GAEN) to assist state and local authorities deploying apps for mobile devices that conduct COVID-19 contact-tracing and implements GAEN in Android smartphones via Google Mobile Services, a collection of Google apps and APIs (GMS). Google unequivocally assures that it completely safeguards the sensitive information necessarily involved with COVID-19 contact tracing. However, because Google's implementation of GAEN allows a sensitive contact tracing data to be placed on a device's system logs and provides dozens or even hundreds of third parties access to these system logs, Google has exposed GAEN participants' private personal and medical information associated with contact tracing, including notifications to

Android device users of their potential exposure to COVID-19.

According to the complaint, on December 2020, California's Contact Tracing App (CA Notify) was downloaded and installed on Plaintiff's android device manufactured by Samsung on Verizon's mobile network, and all systems settings required for CA Notify to function on his device were enabled. In the interest of preserving his medical privacy, Plaintiff did not here recite his COVID-19 status, but stated that if he had been positively diagnosed with COVID-19, he would have entered his diagnosis into the CA Notify App. If Plaintiff had learned what he now knows about the security of information transmitted by Google's System through CA Notify, he would not have downloaded the app or used it the way he did. System log files from Plaintiff's phone have been received and read by third parties, including Samsung and Verizon. Plaintiff have suffered avoidable invasion of privacy, violations of his dignitary rights, and other significant damages as a result of Google's conduct. Upon belief, there are impracticable similarly situated individuals because the Nationwide and California Classes each encompass millions of individuals, dispersed throughout the United States and California, respectively. Defendant's actions allegedly violated the CCMIA.

Plaintiff and all others similarly situated sought for an order determining that the action may be maintained as a class action, judgement against Defendant for Plaintiffs' and Class Members' asserted claims for relief, equitable and injunctive relief, enjoining Google from including, continuing to copy, and allowing unauthorized parties access to Plaintiffs' and Class Members' personal and medical information to the system logs, requiring Google to ensure that all personal and medical information acquired, created, or otherwise obtained from the system logs is destroyed, statutory damages, punitive damages, exemplary damages, pre-judgement and post-judgement interest, reasonable attorney's fees and costs reasonably incurred, and any other relief as the Court deems just and proper.

On May 6, 2022, a motion for preliminary settlement approval was filed. The Class Counsel will apply for an award of attorneys' fees and reimbursement of expenses in a total amount not to exceed $2 million and based upon their preliminary review, Class Counsel's accrued lodestar is approximately $899,298 based on 1,311.30 of total hours for all relevant timekeepers, and Class Counsel's incurred expenses are approximately $55,349.38. Defendant agrees to pay service awards of $2,500 for each of the two class representatives.

On December 30, 2020, Tracy McPherson (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against American Bank Systems, Inc. for its failure to properly secure and safeguard Plaintiff's highly-sensitive, personally-identifiable information.

According to the complaint, in early November 2020, the group purporting to be behind the Avaddon malware attacks published a 'leak warning' claiming that they had hacked Defendant and taken possession of over 50 gigabytes of data. The group demanded a ransom in exchange for release of the data, coupled with a threat of public disclosure. Avaddon posted that Defendant 'do not want to pay and think that we are bluffing.' The group contemporaneously leaked four gigabytes of the stolen data. Analysis by one news outlet indicated that the sample leak included a variety of highly sensitive information, such as loan documents, login credentials for financial institutions' internal-file-sharing networks, and financial records. In turn, some of the leaked financial documents included banking customers' PII, including names, social security numbers, loan amounts, interest rates, and pertinent loan dates such as origination dates, maturity dates, and pay-off dates. Astonishingly, much of this sensitive data appears to have been stored by Defendant in unencrypted, plain-text files meaning that anyone who gained access to the files could fully read the information (and sensitive PII) therein. Avaddon posted a screenshot of some of the data that was obtained from Defendant and leaked to the public, Defendant's financial-institution customers, including Peoples Exchange Bank of Monroeville, is identified by Avaddon in a screenshot listing the banks and the data that it obtained and leaked. The article indicated that, based on timestamps on screenshots of the leaked files, the breach initially began 'sometime in or before early October.' Defendant apparently did not pay the ransom, and by November 14, 2020, the full gigabytes of stolen data, including Plaintiff's and the Class Members' PII, in the Avaddon group's possession, was leaked publicly. Avaddon also posted a screenshot of the PII, such as customers' names, Tax ID numbers (likely Social Security Numbers), and loans from, Defendant, that was exposed by this breach.

Plaintiff sought an award for statutory damages, award of costs of litigation and reasonable attorney's fees and all other relief as may be just and proper.

On June 29, 2021, settlement agreement and release were made. Under the Settlement, Defendant has agreed to pay $1,700,000 into a Common Fund which will be used to pay all Plaintiff/Settlement Class member distributions, and any Court-approved reasonable Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and expenses, Settlement Administrator's costs and expenses, and Plaintiffs' Service Awards up to $1,500 to each Settlement Class Representative. Two types of claims may be made: 'Documented Loss Claims' and 'Inconvenience Claims.' A Settlement Class Member may make one or both types of claims. The different types of claims are explained later in this notice.

On June 16, 2022, Plaintiff filed an unopposed motion for final approval of class action settlement. Accordingly, the Court approved Plaintiff's motion. In line with the approval, the Court awards Class Counsel $510,000 as an award of reasonable attorneys' fees and $16,946.57 in expenses to be paid out of the Common Fund in accordance with the Settlement.

The Final Approval Hearing will be held on July 29, 2022.

On October 29, 2020, Americold was hit with a cyberattack that led them to shut down their computer systems to prevent the spread of the ransomware attack.

On November 16, 2020, Americold Realty Trust determined that its computer network was affected by a cybersecurity incident. As a precautionary measure, the company took immediate steps to help contain the incident and implemented business continuity plans, where appropriate, to continue ongoing operations. The company has notified and is working closely with law enforcement, cybersecurity experts and legal counsel.

Sources have told BleepingComputer that the attack has impacted numerous systems, including phone, email, order fulfillment, and inventory management. Customers who have attempted to pick up inventory for delivery have been unable to get access to warehouses. Among the compromised data were name of individual, address, social security number information, driver's license number, government-issued id number (e.g. passport, state id card), financial information (e.g. account number, credit or debit card number), medical information, and health insurance information.

Americold said in a statement to BleepingComputer that the security, in all its forms, remains a top priority at Americold, and the company will continue to seek to take all appropriate measures to further safeguard the integrity of its information technology infrastructure, data and customer information.

During the fourth quarter of 2020, the company incurred $7.9 million of costs related to the cybersecurity incident. The costs include third-party fees, as well as any incremental costs, internal and external, incurred to restore operations at their facilities.

Furthermore, during the nine months ended September 30, 2021, the company also incurred $3.5 million of costs related to the cyber event.

According to a SEC Form 10-K filed by the company on December 31, 2023, insurance reimbursement from loss associated with the 2020 cyber incident reached up to $1,436,000.

A poultry farm in Northern England has been fined after a computer glitch caused tens of thousands of chickens to overheat and die.

The tragic incident at Hose Lodge Farm in Colston Bassett, Nottinghamshire, was caused by a 'computer malfunction' in a broiler shed ventilation system on a warm spring day.

Around 50,000 chickens were inside the shed on May 26, 2020, when inlets on the side of the building closed for a scheduled rest period. A fault in the system that regulated airflow to the shed prevented another tunnel ventilation system from opening, turning the shed into a sealed unit.

The temperature inside the shed rose rapidly, causing the birds to suffer heat stress. An investigation into the incident by Leicestershire County Council found that an alarm that should have been set to sound when the temperature inside the building reached 27oC (80.6oF) had been incorrectly set to go off at 37oC (98.6oF). By the time staff at the farm were alerted to the problem, more than half the chickens (27,249) had died.

The firm was fined at Leicester Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, April 27, 2022. District Judge Nick Watson fined the company GBP 44,000 ($55,268.40), and ordered it to pay the county council's costs of GBP 12,634.83 ($15,870.60) and a victim surcharge of GBP 190 ($238.65).

On October 29, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Brigid Poling (Plaintiff) against Artech, LLC (Defendant) in the United State District Court for the Northern District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to provide fair, reasonable, or adequate computer systems and data security practices to safeguard sensitive personally identifiable information (PII).

According to the complaint, on or about September 4, 2020, Defendant began notifying individuals that on January 8, 2020, they received a report of unusual activity relating to an employee's Artech user account. A subsequent investigation determined that an unauthorized actor gained access to certain of Defendant's computer systems between January 5, 2020 and January 8, 2020. Defendant's investigation determined that information accessed and acquired during the data breach potentially included the following: names, Social Security numbers, medical information, health insurance information, financial information, payment card information, driver's license/state identification numbers, government issued identification numbers, passport numbers, visa numbers, electronic/digital signatures, usernames and password information.

Plaintiff's data maintained on Defendant's computer systems and subject to the data breach. Even though Defendant was storing sensitive PII that it knew was valuable to criminals, and vulnerable to exfiltration, Defendant failed to take security precautions necessary to protect Plaintiff's and Class Members' data. Because Defendant failed to take necessary security precautions, Plaintiff's and Class Members' unencrypted PII was accessed and acquired by an unauthorized person or persons as a result of the Data Breach. As a result, Plaintiff and Class Members have been harmed and face an increased risk of future harm.

Plaintiff sought for a class certification, injunctive and other equitable relief, monetary relief, including actual damages, punitive damages, treble damages, statutory damages, exemplary damages, equitable relief, restitution, and disgorgement, pre- and post-judgement interest, attorneys' fees and costs and further relief as the Court deems necessary, just, and proper.

On July 8, 2021, the parties have reached a settlement in principle. Accordingly, the parties requested the Court to stay the case pending determination of their planned motions for preliminary and final approval of a contemplated class-wide settlement. On July 12, 2021, the Court granted the parties stipulation and stayed the case.

On July 16, 2021, an amended complaint was filed adding Dwight Jenkins as Plaintiff.

On January 6, 2022, Defendant filed a notice of joint motion for final approval of class action settlement.

Wherein, under the terms of the Defendant's class action lawsuit settlement, all Class Members are eligible for three years of credit monitoring and identity protection services. Cash compensation is also available for Class Members who experienced fraud as a result of the data breach.

In Tier One Compensation, Defendant will pay aggregated caps of $80.00 for lost time at a rate of $26.67 per hour, capped at three hours. In Tier Two Compensation, up to $10,000 in out-of-pocket losses resulting from the data breach. It includes losses as a result of identity theft or other fraud enabled by stolen data. These payments are available for any claimant who provides documentation of time spent addressing the data breach. Defendant does not oppose service awards of $2,500 to the two named Plaintiffs.

On February 10, 2022, the Court issued an order finally approving the class action settlement. Plaintiffs' counsel was awarded $350,000 but the award includes the two $2,500 service awards and $16,041.95 in costs.

On July 29, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Jason Myers and John Parsons (collectively, Plaintiff) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Arthur J. Gallagher & Co. and Gallagher Bassett Services, Inc. (collectively, Defendant) for failure to follow federal and state government and industry standards to protect their personal information from hackers and failed to adequately notify or help individuals whose information was stolen.

According to the complaint, on or about June 30, 2021, Gallagher began notifying customers and state Attorneys General about a data breach that occurred between June 30, 2020 and September 26, 2020. Hackers obtained information from Gallagher including personally identifiable information ('PII') of thousands of its customers, potential customers, employees and other consumers, including, but not limited to their: names; Social Security numbers; tax identification numbers; driver's license, passport, or other government identification numbers; dates of birth; usernames and passwords; employee identification numbers; financial account information; credit card information; electronic signatures; medical treatment, claim, diagnosis, medication or other medical information; health insurance information; medical record or account numbers; and biometric information. Gallagher informed certain media outlets of the ransomware attack as early as Sept. 29, 2020 but did not take any measures to notify affected individuals until on or about June 30, 2021.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, appoint Plaintiffs and their counsel to represent the Classes, award of compensatory, statutory, nominal and punitive damages, attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses, an order to have regular third-party tests of its network security, improve training of its security personnel, and purchase or provide funds for credit monitoring services for its customers, and such other relief.

On August 26, 2021, the Court consolidated Bock v. Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., et al., Case No. 1:21-cv-04415 (Bock Action) with Myers, et al. v. Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., et al., Case No. 1:21-cv-04056 (Myers Action). All papers filed in the Consolidated Action shall be filed under Myers Action.

On October 29, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their consolidated class action complaint.

On January 10, 2022, the Court released an order that all future filings related to this matter shall be filed to a newly created civil case (22-cv-137, IN RE: ARTHUR J. GALLAGHER DATA BREACH LITIGATION).

On September 12, 2024, the parties settled with the Defendant agreeing to a $21,000,000 settlement fund. From this, $6,000 is allocated for monetary loss reimbursement. Claimants can choose three years of CyEx Identity Defense Total with $1,000,000 fraud insurance or a pro-rata share of the remaining funds after expenses. Class Counsel will request the Court approve attorneys' fees of up to one-third of the settlement, plus expenses. Counsel will also seek service awards of up to $7,500 for deposed Plaintiffs Bock, Horning, and Kroll, and $5,000 for non-deposed plaintiffs Caswell, Copple, Fischer, Marr, May, Mitchell, Parsons, Villalobos, Ward, and Wilson. On September 26, 2024, the Court granted preliminary approval.

In 2020, Ascension Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

organization.name: Aspenpointe, Inc.
organization.industry: Outpatient Mental Health and Substance Abuse Centers

incident.description:
In 2022, Lennie Hall (Plaintiff) filed a class action lawsuit in the 4th District Court, County of El Paso, State of Colorado against AspenPointe, Inc. (Defendant) for failing to protect the patient information of customers.

In November 2020, AspenPointe sent notification letters to its customers including Plaintiff informing them their information may have been compromised in a data breach between September 12 and 22, 2020. During the breach, cybercriminals allegedly accessed AspenPointe's network and gained access to patient data such as names, birth dates, driver's license information, Social Security numbers, bank account data, and healthcare information.

Third-party cybersecurity professionals were engaged to assist with the investigation and recovery efforts and determine the extent to which patient information may have been compromised. A review of the documents potentially accessible to the attackers revealed on November 10, 2020 that patient information had potentially been accessed or acquired.

Plaintiff and the Class members sought an award for statutory damages, actual damages, cost, reasonable attorney's fees, and all other relief as may be just and proper.

On August 17, 2022, Defendant agreed to pay the settlement agreement in the amount of $1.3 million for the class action.

organization.name: Association Des Policieres et Policiers Provinciaux Du Quebec
organization.industry: Labor Unions and Similar Labor Organizations

incident.description:
Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others organizations throughout the world including the Provincial Police Association of Quebec by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

Provincial police released statement Thursday evening that the Provincial Police Association of Quebec notified some members of the SQ on October 26, 2020, that their personal data could have been the target of a ransomware attack.

The Provincial Police Association of Quebec had to pay an estimated amount of $1,014,154.39 as a result of the attack.

On February 28, 2020, The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) proposed fines against AT&T Inc. (AT&T), a wireless carrier, for apparently violating section 222 of the Communications Act and the Commission's regulations governing the privacy of customer information. As a result, AT&T faces a proposed fine of $57,265,625.

FCC find that AT&T apparently disclosed its customers' location information, without their consent, to a third party who was not authorized to receive it. In addition, even after highly publicized incidents put the Company on notice that its safeguards for protecting customer location information were inadequate, AT&T apparently continued to sell access to its customers' location information for nearly a year without putting in place reasonable safeguards-leaving its customers' data at unreasonable risk of unauthorized disclosure.

Athens Independent School District (Athens ISD) was taken in a criminal ransomware attack.

The attack early in July 2020 targeted data stored on district servers, backup systems, and hundreds of computers. As a result, access to data has been blocked including teacher communications, student schedules, grades, and assignments.

Further investigation revealed that no information has been taken, only encrypted to prevent access until a ransom was paid.

Members of the AISD Technology Department are working closely with the Region 10 Education Service Center and the Center for Internet Security to resolve the situation.

An emergency meeting took place, where the Athens ISD Board of Trustees has agreed to pay a $50,000 ransom for school data that was taken in a criminal ransomware attack. The school cannot afford not to pay the ransom to the hackers as all sensitive data related to teacher communications, student schedules, grades and assignments related to the school were locked from access by the cyber crooks.

Athens ISD does have insurance coverage for cyberattacks and a claim is being processed.

On November 30, 2020, Authentic Title Services Inc, a title agent in a real estate transaction receives an email ostensibly from the mortgage lender providing instructions for transferring the loan proceeds into a settlement bank account.  After transferring the funds ($520,000), it becomes apparent that the transfer instructions came from an email address that was one letter off from the mortgage lender's actual email address - it was a scam.  But it's too late, the scammer has already withdrawn the funds from the settlement account and cannot be traced. As a result, Authentic Title Services Inc was a victim of business email compromise.

On December 13, 2020, Avaya Holdings Corporation (Avaya) identified that two servers segmented from Avaya's corporate network had installations of SolarWinds' Orion software, which a likely nation-state threat actor infected with malicious code.

The SolarWinds Orion software containing this malicious code allowed for unauthorized activity on affected servers and their networks. This same threat actor separately had compromised Avaya's cloud e-mail and sharing environment as early as January 2020 with activity through at least December 2020. During that timeframe, the threat actor had accessed 145 shared files, some of which contained sensitive company information, and had accessed and monitored a mailbox for one of Avaya's cybersecurity incident response personnel.

On October 22, 2024, the Securities and Exchange Commission imposed the company a penalty in the amount of $1,000,000 for data security violations.

organization.name: Aviation Specialties Unlimited, Inc
organization.industry: Other Support Activities for Air Transportation

incident.description:
Just like other ransomware operator groups such as Maze, DopplePaymer, REvil, etc. The trending ransomware operator group named Ako recently targeted a well-established supplier of machined components and leaked their confidential data online.

Cyble's researchers verified and reported the names of five more victims who fell into their trap. The names of the remaining victims included the ASU Inc.

In the screenshot provided, AKO actors claimed that ASU Inc. only paid for the decryptor for $350,000. AKO actors added that the payment for the stolen files was not received.

location.street: One Union Square, Suite 2900, 600 University Street

incident.description:
National Securities discovered the second cyber event on April 30, 2020, when an independent contractor, a broker, at one of National Securities' affiliates noticed a potential unauthorized transfer of funds from a client account in the amount of $200,000. Following notification by the broker to his manager, two additional potential unauthorized transfers in the same amount were uncovered. Around the same time, the Help Desk Supervisor detected that forwarding rules had been set up on the broker's O365 e-mail account for the time period of April 15, 2020 to April 30, 2020.

National Asset Management refunded the unauthorized transfers to the appropriate customers but did suffer a resulting loss of $400,000. National Securities' investigation of the Second Cyber Event determined that the broker's O365 account was compromised from March 23, 2020 through April 30, 2020, and the compromise was likely the result of a phishing scheme.

Baltimore County school officials estimate the ransomware attack in November will cost the system at least $7.7 million.

The estimated costs cover a wide range of programs, services, trainings, and licenses that helped Maryland's third-largest school system respond to and recover from the attack, which took place the day before Thanksgiving and canceled two days of online classes for 111,000 students.

The attack is disrupting virtual learning and affecting the district's website, email system and grading system, as well as school offices. The attack was identified late night on November 24, 2020. By the next morning, students and teachers had lost access to everything they depended on for school.

The district has said no personal information was stolen but has not disclosed the extent of the attack nor any ransom demands.

Hackers seized control of county school district systems the day before Thanksgiving, forcing the district to cancel online classes for two days.

Among the largest expenditures was more than $2 million to move computer applications to a cloud-based system and more than $1.4 million for a one-year license on Windows security software, the latter of which was purchased at the strong recommendation of the system's cyber insurance carrier.

During a county school board meeting Tuesday, George Sarris, the school system's executive director for fiscal services, projected the final price tag could top more than $8 million. Sarris was not available for comment this week.

The school board previously approved four contracts representing $1.7 million in services related to the ransomware attack.

The updated figure places the county much closer to what Baltimore City spent on recovery from its own ransomware attack in 2019. The city spent about $10 million on recovery efforts, not including $8.2 million in lost revenues such as taxes, fees, and fines.

Unlike the city, the Baltimore County school system was paying for cyber insurance at the time of the attack. The system's policy covers up to $2 million for direct costs caused by the ransomware attack and $3 million for liability costs.

Some of the remaining bills can be paid out of the system's current budget and federal CARES Act funding, Sarris said during a school board budget committee meeting in April.

Still, the attack has delayed at least one major project school staff were working on this year.

Another major system lost in the attack was the timekeeping program that allows the district to track employee hours and overtime. Officials estimate it will cost $800,000 to restore the system.

As of November 12, 2021, the cost of the ransomware attack is almost $9.7 million. The money has been spent in a number of areas to repair the damage and make the computer system safer. The big-ticket item is $2 million to move data to the cloud.

According to the spokesperson for the district, they have targeted their resources to focus on rebuilding and strengthening the systems. Their work continues however they have established several new processes and security measures over the last year.

The National Supervisory Authority completed on 26.11.2020 an investigation at the operator Banca Transilvania SA and found the violation of the provisions of art. 32 para. (1) and (2) corroborated with art. 5 lit. f) of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

The operator Banca Transilvania SA was fined 487,380 lei (equivalent to 100,000 EURO or $83,988.4).

The investigation was launched following the receipt of complaints regarding the breach of confidentiality and security of personal data.

It was found that the statement requested by the operator from a customer about how he intended to use a certain amount of money that he wanted to withdraw from his account took place in the public space (online). This statement was distributed among several employees of Banca Transilvania on work e-mail addresses. One of the employees listed the e-mail containing the customer's statement, as well as the e-mail containing the internal conversation between the operator's employees. Another employee photographed the listed document with his mobile phone and distributed it through the WhatsApp application. Subsequently, the listed document was posted and distributed on the social network Facebook and on a website.

This situation led to the disclosure and unauthorized access to certain personal data (name and surname, e-mail addresses, behavioral data, personal preferences, financial transaction value, place of work, position and place of work, telephone number service ) of 4 targeted individuals (one client and 3 own employees), although according to art. 5 lit. f) of the General Regulation on Data Protection, the operator had the obligation to respect the principle of integrity and confidentiality of personal data.

The disclosure produced in the public space also proves the inefficiency of the internal training of the operator's employees regarding the observance of the personal data protection norms of the data subjects, although the employee training is an intrinsic part of the technical and organizational measures that the operator was obliged to adopt. security corresponding to the processing risk, thus violating the provisions of art. 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

On February 27, 2023, the Deputy Commissioner of the Data Protection Commission (DPC) released its final decision in which it imposed a fine on Bank of Ireland Group Plc (Bank of Ireland) for violating the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

According to the DPC, they have issued an Inquiry Commencement letter via email and registered post to Bank of Ireland on August 12, 2020, notifying the company that the DPC had commenced an inquiry regarding the data breaches.

The result of an investigation into 10 personal data breaches reported by Bank of Ireland between January 30, 2022 and May 6, 2020. The decision stated that DPC received a personal data protection breach notification from the Bank of Ireland in relation to 10 data breaches relating to the Bank of Ireland 365 banking app, which concerned individuals gaining unauthorized access to other people's accounts via the app.

DPC added that six of those breaches saw unauthorized people granted access to customer accounts online due to staff not following Bank of Ireland procedures correctly. And the other four saw customers receiving unauthorized access due to a 'flaw' in the algorithm of the bank's customer information system.

In total, 136 accounts were left exposed but the bank has said no one suffered a financial loss from the errors.

In conclusion, the DPC imposed an administrative fine of 750,000 on the Bank of Ireland in respect of the infringement of Article 5(1)(f) GDPR.

Police are investigating after thieves hacked three banking machines in the greater Montreal area, making off with an estimated $55,000. The ATMs -- which all belonged to Laurentian Bank -- were located in Saint-Jerome, Saint-Eustache and Terrebonne.

Terrebonne Police stated that on the night of January 26, 2020, a technician with the bank called the police around 11:55 p.m. to report that an ATM near the corner of Moody and des Seigneurs boulevards was compromised. Saint-Eustache police confirmed to Radio-Canada that an ATM there was also affected.

Local police have asked the Surete du Quebec to help with the investigation.

Cybersecurity specialist and president of EVA-Technologies, Eric Parent, told Radio-Canada that it was likely the hackers used a machine to clone cards going into the ATM. The equipment usually includes a hidden camera so the thieves can record someone entering their PIN. The thieves then have access to a copy of the card and the PIN used to access the account, which they can later use to retrieve the money.

On December 17, 2021, Gregg Nelson (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against Bansley & Kiener, LLP (Defendant) in the Circuit Court for the First Judicial Circuit of Cook County, Illinois. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to properly secure and safeguard personal identifiable information (PII).

According to the complaint, on December 3, 2021, Defendant notified state Attorneys General and many participants about a widespread data breach involving sensitive PII of 274,115 individuals. Defendant explained in their required notice letter that they discovered on December 10, 2020 that their network had fallen victim to an unauthorized person. The data security incident resulted in the encryption of certain of their network systems. Encryption of systems is typically a defining characteristic of a ransomware attack. On May 24, 2021, they were made aware that certain information had been exfiltrated from their environment by an unauthorized person. They immediately launched an investigation, and a cyber security firm was engaged to assist.

Plaintiff brought the action on behalf of himself and all persons residing in the United States whose PII was compromised in the data breach.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, equitable and injunctive relief, actual, nominal, consequential, and punitive damages, attorneys' fees, costs and litigation expenses, prejudgment interest, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On September 28, 2022, the Accounting firm Bansley & Kiener agreed to pay $900,000 to resolve claims it mismanaged a 2020 data breach.

organization.name: MI Metals, Inc.
organization.industry: Other Aluminum Rolling, Drawing, and Extruding

incident.description:
Cyberattacks are becoming more common for small businesses, and many aren't prepared to deal with an attack. The risk of an attack has grown dramatically for small businesses over the past couple of years.

In July 2020, MI Metals Inc., an aluminum-manufacturing company based in Oldsmar, Florida was subject to a ransomware attack orchestrated by Maze ransomware crew. Fortunately, MI Metals had cyber insurance that covered a ransomware attack on the business. The insurance company dispatched experts to MI Metals' plants and headquarters, who quickly determined that the attackers hadn't compromised any sensitive information, like employee records or customer accounts.

According to Brook Massey, the company's owner, he was able to rely on a backup of the company system he had on his hard drive at home, and he rejected the attackers' ransom demand.

The insurance company ultimately paid MI Metals about $180,000 to cover attorney fees, hard-drive replacements, forensic experts and the cost of new software.

organization.name: Belden Inc
organization.industry: Other Communication and Energy Wire Manufacturing

incident.description:
On February 4, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Kia Mackey (Plaintiff) against Belden, Inc. (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri over a data breach that was discovered by Belden on November 12, 2020, in which unauthorized users accessed Belden servers that contained personal information of current and former employees and business partners.

According to the complaint, On the evening of November 12, 2020, Defendant IT professionals detected unusual activity involving certain company servers. Forensics experts determined that defendant was the target of a sophisticated attack by a party outside the company. On or about November 15, 2020, defendant learned that the outside party accessed servers that contained personal information of some current and former employees. The personal information involved in this incident may have included your name, birthdate, government-issued identification numbers (for example, social security number), bank account information (for North American employees on Belden payroll), home addresses, email addresses and other general employment-related information. As a result of Defendant's failure to provide reasonable and adequate data security, Plaintiff's and the Class members' PII has been exposed to those who should not have access to it. Plaintiff and the Class are now at much higher risk of identity theft and for cybercrimes of all kinds, especially considering the highly sensitive PII stolen here. Plaintiff also claimed that defendant's failure to keep current and former employees' PII secure are long lasting and severe.

Plaintiff sought for actual damages, punitive damages, treble damages, statutory damages, exemplary damages, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, attorneys' fees, expenses, and the costs, and further relief as this Court deems necessary, just, and proper.

On May 31, 2022, Plaintiff and Defendant provide notice to the Court that they have reached a settlement in principle in the instant action and respectfully request that the Court enter an order staying all pending deadlines.

On August 29, 2022, the Costs of Settlement Administration for which Belden shall be responsible to pay is capped at $865,000.

On October 26, 2022, the Court finds that the proposed settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate, otherwise meets the criteria for approval, and warrants the issuance of notice to the Settlement Class. Accordingly, the proposed settlement is preliminarily approved.

On January 9, 2023, the Plaintiffs move the court to approve an award of attorney's fees and costs in the amount of $425,000 and approve service awards for the class representatives in the amount of $3,500 each, or $7,000 in the aggregate.

On October 20, 2020, Terri A. Goetz (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against Benefit Recovery Specialists, Inc. (Defendant) in the Walworth County Wisconsin Circuit Court. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to adequately protect personal information that resulted to a data breach.

Plaintiff alleged that on or about April 20, 2020 to April 30, 2020, Defendant was the victim of a cyberattack resulting in the disclosure of personal information and protected health information, including names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, medical history information, health insurance information, and other information. Defendant notified affected individuals of the data breach in approximately August 2020.

Affected consumers claimed that the company failed to take reasonable measures to protect their data. As a result of the failure, Plaintiffs and other consumers are allegedly at risk for fraud and identity theft.

On January 14, 2022, the Court granted the Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement.

Under the terms of the settlement, Settlement Class Member may submit one or more claims for reimbursement for documented Economic Losses related to the Data Breach that have not been reimbursed by IDX or other third parties, up to an aggregate total of $2,500.00 per Settlement Class Member and $1,800,000 of maximum amount payable to the Settlement Class for Economic Losses. Class Counsel is seeking an award of attorneys' fees and reimbursement of reasonable expenses of no more than $750,000, and a Service Award of $2,500 to Plaintiff. These awards will be paid by Defendant separately and apart from and without any affect upon or reduction of the Settlement Consideration.

The Final Approval Hearing will be held on July 13, 2022.

Popular decentralized finance (DeFi) protocol Pickle Finance was hacked on November 20, 2020, Saturday, and lost $19.7 million of users' funds in DAI tokens. The attacker exploited the vulnerability of Pickle Finance smart contract called DAI PickleJar using fake swaps.

Notably, the hacker chose to avoid a flash loan scheme used in most similar incidents recently. Instead, they deployed a malicious jar and passed in fake swaps.

Emiliano Bonassi, a founder of DeFi Italy and a white hacker, explained that evil jars deployed during the attack and passed in the swapExactJarForJar. In addition, in the second invocation for swapExactJarForJar, there were passed a target and doing a delegate call to CurveProxyPool.

The Pickle team, and a group of white hat hackers confirmed the exploit and said that 19,759,355 DAI were drained. The attacker used a very complicated scheme involving many components from the Pickle protocol. Currently, the team is working on the solution together with a group of white hackers.

location.street: 512/10, 91 Springboard Business Hub Private Ltd Service Lane

incident.description:
The Cyber Crime police on Tuesday arrested a woman who allegedly stole 64 bitcoins, by accessing the hardware wallet of a cryptocurrency exchange firm where she had worked. Police arrested Ayushi based on a complaint filed by Ashish Singhal, owner of cryptocurrency exchange firm BitCipher Labs in Mahadevapura.

Ashish, Vimal Sagar Tiwari and Govind Kumar Soni were holders of two hardware wallets on behalf of BitCipher Labs LLP. They also held the private keys among. On March 13, they found out that 63.54 bitcoins (worth Rs 3.66 crore or 36,600,000) ($484,906) were transferred through SwapLab between January 11, 2020, and March 11, 2020.

'Investigation revealed the complainant had hardware wallets in which Bitcoins were stored, and a 24-word passphrase (password) was written on a piece of paper and stored securely. Only the complainant and partners had access to the passphrase, which was the key to authenticate bitcoin transactions. The accused hacked into their systems and carried out unauthorised transactions,' a police officer said.

'Since a hardware wallet and passphrase was required for bitcoin transactions, it was suspected that the culprit was someone proficient in using this technology, and who was closely associated with the firm. Police prepared a list of former employees of the company, and short-listed Ayushi. When questioned, she admitted to have carried out the transactions by acquiring the passphrase written on paper,' the senior police officer added.

On August 10, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Brian Lee Bauer (Plaintiff) in the United States Circuit Court of St. Louis against BJC HealthCare (Defendant) for failure to secure and safeguard their and other Missouri residents' private and confidential medical information.

On March 6, 2020, Defendant identified suspicious activity within three employees' email accounts. Defendant said it secured the accounts, and hired a computer forensic firm to investigate. Defendant's investigation found that an unauthorized person accessed the email accounts. Plaintiff alleged that the breach allowed hackers access to information such as names, medical record numbers, account numbers, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and treatment or clinical information, including provider names, visit dates, medications, diagnoses, and testing information (PHI/PII). On May 5, 2020, Defendant published a notice on its website.

It argues that the incident is taking a significant emotional and physical toll on those affected. The case claims patients have incurred significant out-of-pocket costs associated with the prevention, detection, recovery and remediation from identity theft or fraud. Upon information and belief, the number of patients whose information was accessed is unknown, but estimated to be more than 287,000 people.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, actual, punitive and statutory damages, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, other favorable relief as allowable under law or at equity.

On January 28, 2021, case of Tiffany Jew and Jessica Simpson v. BJC, Case No. 2022- CC09315 and the current action was consolidated, In Re BJC Healthcare Data Breach Litigation, Case No. 2022-CC09492.

On April 21, 2022, Plaintiffs and Defendant have reached a settlement agreement to resolve claims its poor cybersecurity led to a 2020 phishing data breach. The settlement benefits individuals who received a notice from Defendant that their information may have been compromised in a data breach on March 6, 2020.

Under the terms of the settlement, class members can be reimbursed for ordinary and extraordinary expenses resulting from the settlement. Ordinary expense reimbursement is capped at $250 per person and includes bank fees, interest, credit monitoring costs, postage, mileage and up to three hours of lost time at a rate of $20 per hour. Larger payments of $5,000 are available for extraordinary expense reimbursement, which includes documented, unreimbursed monetary losses and up to three hours of additional lost time at a rate of $20 per hour.

Defendant will also pay Class Counsel for attorneys' fees, costs and expenses for two Classes of counsel in the amount of $790,000 (Missouri Class Counsel) $415,000 (Illinois Class Counsel). An incentive award will also receive by the named Plaintiffs in the amount up to $2,000.

In addition to providing payments and credit monitoring, Defendant agreed to make changes to its cybersecurity policies to better protect consumer data. New policies, mandatory training and an improved password policy are all included under the new cyber security approach. Additionally, BJC will spend an estimated $2.7 million to implement multifactor authentication for email access -- reducing the risks of phishing.

On April 25, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. On April 29, 2022, the Court granted Plaintiffs' motion.

The final approval hearing for the settlement will be held on September 6, 2022.

On March 6, 2020, BJC Healthcare identified suspicious activity within three employees' email accounts. Defendant said it secured the accounts, and hired a computer forensic firm to investigate. BJC Healthcare's investigation found that an unauthorized person accessed the email accounts.

In May 2020, BJC Healthcare announced it was the target of a phishing cyberattack. In the attack, three employee email accounts were allegedly accessed by a third party after the employees interacted with phishing emails -- emails designed to look legitimate while giving hackers access to sensitive systems.

The breach allowed hackers access to information such as names, medical record numbers, account numbers, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and treatment or clinical information, including provider names, visit dates, medications, diagnoses, and testing information (PHI/PII). Upon information and belief, the number of patients whose information was accessed is unknown, but estimated to be more than 287,000 people.

According to BJC Healthcare settlement agreement, they agreed to make changes to its cybersecurity policies to better protect consumer data. New policies, mandatory training and an improved password policy are all included under the new cyber security approach. Additionally, BJC will spend an estimated approximately $2,688,000, including $1,223,000 in initial implementation costs and $1,465,000 in annual maintenance costs -- reducing the risks of phishing.

In May 2020, Blackbaud, Inc. (Blackbaud) (one of the world's largest providers of financial and fundraising technology to nonprofits), discovered that it was hacked and data from its clients throughout the world was held for ransom by cybercriminals. This was a very sophisticated ransomware attack that included database and donor management system back-up files for its clients Blackbaud Raisers Edge/NXT, beginning on February 7, 2020, and could have been in there intermittently until May 20, 2020.

According to Blackbaud, the criminals did not have access to encrypted credit card information, bank account information, usernames, passwords, or Social Security numbers stored in client databases.
