However, Blackbaud did determine that the compromised information may have contained; contact information (Name, mailing address, phone, and email addresses), Contact demographical information, and history of a donor's relationship with its clients including donation dates and amounts.

As a result of the attack, Blackbaud paid ransom to the criminals after evidence showed that the stolen data had been destroyed. The results of its research and that of forensics experts and law enforcement (the F.B.I.) indicate that it is highly unlikely that the stolen information was ever released, misused, or will be disseminated or otherwise made available publicly. Blackbaud and independent agencies are continuing to monitor the situation.

On May 13, 2020, Blackbaud paid $350,000 for decryption of their files. And these actors wanted more to delete the stolen files.

Blackbaud, Inc are subject to risks and uncertainties as a result of a ransomware attack against the company in May 2020 in which a cybercriminal removed a copy of a subset of data from its self-hosted environment (the 'Security Incident').

Based on the nature of the Security Incident, our research and third party (including law enforcement) investigation, the company have no reason to believe that any data went beyond the cybercriminal, was or will be misused, or will be disseminated or otherwise made available publicly. Blackbaud, Inc investigation into the Security Incident by its cybersecurity team and third-party forensic advisors remains ongoing.

During 2020, Blackbaud recorded $10.4 million of expenses related to the Security Incident and offsetting probable insurance recoveries of $9.4 million.

From January to June 30, 2021, Blackbaud recorded $24.4 million of expenses related to the Security Incident and offsetting probable insurance recoveries of $23.9 million.

As of June 30, 2021, Blackbaud have recorded cumulative expenses related to the Security Incident of $34.2 million and cumulative probable insurance recoveries of $33.3 million. Of the insurance recoveries recorded, $10.0 million had been paid as of June 30, 2021.

As of December 31, 2021, Blackbaud have recorded Security Incident-related costs incurred during the twelve months ended December 31, 2021 of $40.6 million and net of probable insurance recoveries during the same period of $38.7 million. Recorded expenses consisted primarily of payments to third-party service providers and consultants, including legal fees, as well as settlements of customer claims. Not included in the adjustment were costs associated with enhancements to their cybersecurity program.

As of September 30, 2023, Blackbaud recorded an expense of $104,151,000, excluding the multistate settlement and the SEC penalty. Blackbaud recorded cumulative offsetting insurance recoveries of $50,000,000. Recorded expenses consisted primarily of payments for legal fees related to the security incident, claims and investigations, and efforts to further enhance their cybersecurity measures.

For full year 2023, Blackbaud incurred net pre-tax expense of $53.4 million related to the Security Incident, which included $22.4 million for ongoing legal fees. It also includes settlements and additional accruals for loss contingencies of $31 million. Also, for full year 2023, we had net cash outlays of $78 million related to the Security Incident, which included ongoing legal fees, the $3 million civil penalty paid during the first quarter of 2023 related to the SEC settlement and the $49.5 million civil penalty paid during the fourth quarter of 2023 related to the multi-state Attorneys General settlement.

For the three and six months ended June 30, 2024, Blackbaud incurred net pre-tax expenses of $1,822,000 and $12,145,000, respectively, related to the Security Incident, which included $1.8 million and $5.1 million, respectively, for ongoing legal fees and additional accruals for loss contingencies of $0.0 million and $7.0 million, respectively. During the six months ended June 30, 2024, Blackbaud had net cash outlays of $5.8 million related to the Security Incident for ongoing legal fees. In line with the policy, legal fees are expensed as incurred. Not included in these ranges are the previous settlements or current accruals for loss contingencies related to the matters discussed below.

Blackbaud, Inc. is being investigated by regulators over violations of data privacy laws, including the Department of Health and Human Services, the Federal Trade Commission, and internationally by the UK's Information Commissioner's Office and the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada. A joint investigation has also been launched by 49 state attorneys general and the District of Columbia.

The multistate investigation stems from May 2020 ransomware attack that exposed over a million files related to 13,000 Blackbaud customers, including primarily nonprofit entities, and included sensitive information (contact and demographic information, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, financial information, employment and wealth information, donation history, and protected health information) from millions of nonprofit donors and others.

While the total number of victims has not been disclosed by Blackbaud, at least 250 healthcare organizations, non-profits, and educational institutions are known to have been impacted, with healthcare organizations reporting the breach as affecting more than 10 million individuals.

On October 5, 2023, Blackbaud and the 49 state Attorneys General and the District of Columbia have reached a settlement in connection with Blackbaud's data security practices and response to a 2020 data breach that exposed the personal information of millions of consumers across the United States.

Under the terms of the Administrative Orders, Blackbaud has agreed: (i) to comply with state consumer protection laws, data breach notification laws, and the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 ('HIPAA'); (ii) not to make misleading misrepresentations to Blackbaud customers or the individuals whose data is stored by Blackbaud concerning (a) the extent to which Blackbaud protects the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of certain data, (b) the likelihood that data impacted by a security incident may be subject to unauthorized access, disclosure, or other misuse, or (c) the data breach notification requirements; and (iii) to implement and improve certain cybersecurity programs and tools.

As part of the Administrative Orders, Blackbaud also has agreed to pay a total of $49.5 million to the 50 state wherein, the District of Columbia will receive $355,210 of the settlement. Blackbaud expects to pay the full settlement amount to each state and the District of Columbia in October 2023 from its existing liquidity.

The attorneys general of Indiana and Vermont co-led the multistate investigation, assisted by the executive committee consisting of Attorney General Raoul and the attorneys general of Alabama, Arizona, Florida and New York. These attorneys general were joined in the settlement by Alaska, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

In May 2020, Blackbaud, Inc. (Blackbaud), one of the world's largest providers of financial and fundraising technology to nonprofits, discovered that it was hacked and data from its clients throughout the world was held for ransom by cybercriminals. They used a very sophisticated ransomware attack that included database and donor management system back-up files for its clients Blackbaud Raisers Edge/NXT, beginning on February 7, 2020, and could have been in there intermittently until May 20, 2020.

However, soon after, Blackbaud realized that the hacker did access personal data, including Social Security and bank account numbers. Despite this discovery, Blackbaud failed to provide timely and accurate information to those impacted by the breach.

As a result, Blackbaud is being investigated by regulators over violations of data privacy laws. As previously disclosed, the Office of the Attorney General of the State of California did not participate in the Multistate Investigation and has issued a separate Civil Investigative Demand related to the Security Incident, which has not been resolved. Although Blackbaud is hopeful that it can resolve this matter on acceptable terms, there is no assurance that it will be able to do so on terms acceptable to Blackbaud and to the State of California.

On June 13, 2024, California Attorney General Rob Bonta announced a settlement with Blackbaud for violating consumer protection and privacy laws related to its unlawful data security practices. According to their investigation, Blackbaud failed to implement reasonable data security led to a data breach. Blackbaud then made misleading statements about the sufficiency of its data security efforts prior to the breach and about the extent of the breach to its nonprofit customers and the public. These actions violated the Reasonable Data Security Law, Unfair Competition Law, and the False Advertising Law related to data security.

Under the settlement, Blackbaud must pay $6.75 million in penalties and comply with requirements to strengthen its data security and breach notification practices.

On May 19, 2022, the Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante) announced that it had issued its decision against Findomestic Banca SPA on April 7, 2022, in which it imposed a fine of 10,000 for the violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 5(1)(c) of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), following a complaint submitted by an individual on April 23, 2021.

According to the complainant, on October 13 and 19, 2020, Findomestic Banca sent text messages several times to the complainant's spouse, who was the guarantor of one of the three loans that the complainant had borrowed from the former. However, the Garante explained that the debt collection calls in question concerned a loan for which the complainant's spouse did not act as guarantor. Subsequently, the Garante indicated that Findomestic Banca had explained that the contested facts had been the result of an internal misunderstanding which had caused the inclusion in the system of the spouse's telephone number as the main contact for debt collection.

After further investigations, Garante found that Findomestic Banca had violated the principles of lawfulness, fairness, and transparency, and data minimization. Notably, the Garante highlighted that it had clarified, with a general order dated November 30, 2005, that anyone processing personal data in the context of debt collection activities must comply with the principle of lawfulness of the processing, which is violated in case of unjustified communications to third parties (such as family members and work colleagues) concerning a debtor's arrears.

Around January 2021, Louise Prevost, Paul Frederick, Amy Richardson, Jane Doe 1-3 (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint against Roper St. Francis (Defendant) in the Court of Common Pleas for the Ninth Judicial Circuit of South Carolina. The action alleges a breach of private patient data, including financial and medical information, was compromised.

The lawsuit states the data breach happened last year between October 14th and 29th; it alleges that 'negligent acts and omissions' led to a breach of private patient data, including financial and medical information.

The Richter Firm, The Solomon Law Group, Slotchiver & Slotchiver, LLC and Brent Souther Halversen, LLC are part of the class action lawsuit, which was filed March 24th in the ninth judicial circuit for Charleston County.

On November 6, 2023, Roper St. Francis Healthcare has proposed a $1.5 million settlement to resolve the lawsuit. Under the terms of the settlement, individuals who were notified about the data breach by Roper St. Francis Healthcare may claim up to $325 as reimbursement for data breach-related expenses, including credit costs and bank fees, and up to four hours of lost time at $20 per hour. If extraordinary losses have been incurred due to identity theft and fraud, claims may be submitted up to a maximum of $3,250. All class members are entitled to one year of credit monitoring services, in addition to those already offered in the individual notifications about the data breach.

On January 18, 2024, the class action settlement was preliminary approved.

On April 16, 2024, Plaintiffs filed a motion for attorneys' fees, expenses, and service awards. Plaintiffs requested a combined award of reasonable attorneys' fees and case expenses in the amount of $515,000 and a service award for each Class Representative in the amount of $1,500.

On May 2, 2024, the class action settlement was granted final approval.

On February 5, 2022, a class action lawsuit was filed by David Ambrose (Plaintiff), on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated against Boston Globe Media Partners LLC (Defendant or Boston Globe) in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts in violation of the Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA).

According to the complaints, Plaintiff brings this action in response to Defendant's practice of knowingly disclosing its subscribers' personally identifiable information including a record of every video clip they view to Facebook without consent. Boston Globe also uses 'Automatic Advanced Matching.' When activated, the Facebook Tracking Pixel will 'look for recognizable form field and other sources on your website that contain information such as first name, last name and email.' The Facebook Tracking Pixel's code will collect that information, 'along with the event, or action, that took place.' Boston Globe discloses this information so it can better match visitors to their Facebook profiles, which thereby allows Boston Globe to better target its advertisements.

In August 2020, Plaintiff Ambrose purchased a digital subscription to the Boston Globe's website. Plaintiff Ambrose frequently visits Boston Globe to, among other things, watch videos. When Plaintiff Ambrose watched videos on bostonglobe.com, Defendant disclosed to Facebook email address, first name, last name, Facebook ID, browser identifiers, and other identifying information. Plaintiff Ambrose discovered that Boston Globe surreptitiously collected and transmitted his personally identifiable information in January 2022.

Plaintiff and the Class members sought for an award of statutory damages to the extent available; For prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded; For injunctive relief as pleaded or as the Court may deem proper; and for an order awarding Plaintiff and the Class their reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses and costs of suit.

On May 19, 2023, Plaintiff filed a proposed order granting preliminary approval of class action settlement agreement, certifying settlement class, appointing class representative, appointing class counsel, and approving notice plan.

On May 24, 2023, Plaintiff amended their settlement agreement wherein Defendant shall pay $4,000,000 (Settlement Fund), plus the Kind Relief of up to $1,000,000, which totaled $5,000,000.

Under the settlement, each class members will receive payments of approximately $20-$40.

Defendant agrees that Class Counsel shall be entitled to an award of reasonable attorneys' fees and costs out of the Settlement Fund. Class Counsel will limit its petition for attorneys' fees, costs and expenses to no more than one third of the Settlement Benefit ($1,666,666.67). Plaintiff will also receive incentive award in the amount of $5,000.

On May 25, 2023, the Court granted Plaintiff's preliminary approval of class action settlement.

On September 8, 2023, final judgment and order of dismissal with prejudice was granted by the court. Accordingly, the case was closed.

organization.name: Boys & Girls Club of Cleveland County

incident.description:
Money meant to help kids was instead stolen by hackers.

The organization's email was hacked last month, according to a police report. It is unclear how it happened but their IT consultant became suspicious when he noticed 44,000 emails being sent out. It's likely those emails were compromised phishing attempts aimed at tricking the Boys and Girls Club contacts in an effort to steal more money.

On Friday, the Boys and Girls Club suffered a business email compromise and reported that a total of $56,359 was stolen. The money was transferred to credit companies, banks and a phone service. A check was also forged using an Oklahoma address.

Upon learning this, the Club acted immediately by contacting the proper authorities to investigate this serious matter further. In addition, our Board of Directors has initiated an immediate and rigorous evaluation of all management policies and procedures to determine this discrepancy and further strengthen and safeguard the organization's finances and operations as we go forward.

On or about December 16, 2020, Accellion, Inc. (Accellion) learned of SQL Injection and OS Command Execution vulnerabilities in its File Transfer Appliance (FTA), as a result of the exploit tripping the FTA's built-in anomaly detector on a customer's device.

On or about December 22, 2020, Brown Rudnick LLP learned that an unauthorized user had accessed its Accellion FTS and exfiltrated multiple confidential files. These files were exfiltrated after Accellion had issued its December 20, 2020 Critical Customer Alert email.

The law firm subsequently received an $8,000,000 ransom demand from the criminal hacker, threatening to publish the exfiltrated confidential files on the internet if the ransom was not paid. After negotiations with the criminal organization, the law firm and/or its cyber insurance company, ACE American Insurance Company, paid more than two million dollars to the criminal organization on behalf of the law firm in exchange for the criminal organization's agreement not to publish the exfiltrated files, as well as to secure promises from the bad actor to provide a list of all data taken, and also a promise that all data in their possession would be destroyed.

On or about December 16, 2020, Accellion, Inc. (Accellion) learned of SQL Injection and OS Command Execution vulnerabilities in its File Transfer Appliance (FTA), as a result of the exploit tripping the FTA's built-in anomaly detector on a customer's device.

On or about December 22, 2020, Brown Rudnick LLP, a Boston Law Firm, learned that an unauthorized user had accessed its Accellion FTS and exfiltrated multiple confidential files. These files were exfiltrated after Accellion had issued its December 20, 2020 Critical Customer Alert email.

In addition, the law firm incurred $375,000 in expenses and attorney time responding to the breach.

The Butler County Sheriff's Office is investigating after its communications center systems were hacked.

According to Sheriff Richard Jones, once they found the malware activity in the system, they started to investigate and restore operations and the impact of the incident. 911 calls still went through, and investigators don't believe any information was compromised.

The breach mainly impacted the CAD system, which meant dispatchers and the crews they were sending to emergencies had to resort to pulling out maps and pens and paper to get the job done and reports generated. So, they just had to do it all by hand. The public was never compromised.

The department is working with nationally recognized third-party cybersecurity consultants to help in their investigation.

In connection with a recent ransomware attack, an unauthorized party accessed the Sheriff's Office computer network on December 21, 2020, and deployed ransomware on December 23, 2020. A thorough investigation was conducted and learned that the cybercriminal also removed some data from its computing environment.

On March 1, 2021, the cybercriminal posted the data on the cybercriminal's website. On March 8, 2021, the Sheriff's Office learned that the post included name, address, date of birth, Social Security, and driver's license number.

The cyberattack occurred had cost nearly $180,000 to fix, and insurance covered a significant piece. BCSO Finance Director Vickie Barger reveled that the total cost for equipment, repairs and overtime was $179,416, and the county's insurance company paid nearly $70,000.

organization.name: Tiktok Technology Limited
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
TikTok has been fined 345,000,000 ($368,994,750) for breaking EU data law in its handling of children's accounts, including failing to shield underage users' content from public view.

The Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) concluded its investigation into TikTok's practices in September 2023, focusing on a period in 2020. The probe uncovered several critical areas of non-compliance with GDPR. Notably, TikTok was found to have inadequate mechanisms for age verification, which is crucial for protecting minors online.

According to the Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) that the users aged between 13 and 17 were steered through the sign-up process in a way that resulted in their accounts being set to public - meaning anyone can see an account's content or comment on it - by default. It also found that the 'family pairing' scheme, which gives an adult control over a child's account settings, did not check whether the adult 'paired' with the child user was a parent or guardian.

The DPC ruled that TikTok, which has a minimum user age of 13, did not properly take into account the risk posed to underage users who gained access to the platform. It said the public-setting-by-default process allowed anyone to 'view social media content posted by those users'.

The 2023 fine was unprecedented in its size, reflecting a growing trend towards stricter enforcement of data protection laws, especially concerning vulnerable users like children.

Decentralized finance (DeFi) lending project bZx has been able to recover about $8 million in cryptocurrency from an attacker who stole the funds after exploiting a code bug over the weekend.

Paris Fotis, a spokesperson for the project, said bZx had been able to track down the attacker using his or her on-chain activity.

The attacker returned the funds after being exposed, according to Fotis.

bZx said in an incident report that $8 million worth of cryptocurrency had been stolen Sunday, September 13, 2020, by an attacker who exploited a code bug to mint the protocol's interest-earning iToken, which was used to redeem, and walk away with, digital assets held in various lending pools.

bZx's official Twitter account announced earlier today that funds had been restored.

organization.name: California Health & Wellness
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On May 4, 2021, John Harbour, Tami Wisnesky, Joweli Vunisa and J. Doe (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint against California Health & Wellness Plan, Health Net Community Solutions, Inc., Health Net LLC, Health Net of California, Inc., Health Net Life Insurance Company, Accellion, Inc. and Centene Corporation (collectively, Defendants) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. The action arises out of a data breach that affected the Defendant.

According to the complaint, Plaintiffs' sensitive personal information--including but not limited to names, email addresses, phone numbers, home addresses, dates of birth, Social Security numbers (SSN), bank account and routing information, and other personally identifying information (collectively, PII), as well as information used to process health insurance claims, prescription information, medical records and data, and other sensitive personal health information (collectively, PHI)-- was disclosed to unauthorized third parties during a massive breach of Accellion's File Transfer Appliance software.

Plaintiffs brought the action on behalf of all residents of the United States whose PII or PHI was compromised in the Accellion Data Breach that occurred between December 2020 and January 2021.

Plaintiffs sought for class certification, damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, expenses, and other favorable relief as allowable under law or at equity.

On June 23, 2023, the parties have reached a settlement and the Plaintiffs moved for the preliminary approval of class action settlement.

According to the settlement agreement, Health Net Defendants agreed to pay $10,000,000. The Settlement Fund shall be used by the Settlement Administrator to pay for: (i) all Administrative Expenses; (ii) any Taxes; (iii) any Service Payments; (iv) any Fee Award and Costs; (v) Settlement Payments and/or Settlement Benefits, pursuant to the terms and conditions of this Agreement; and (viii) any other Settlement Benefits.

On August 24, 2023, the settlement agreement was preliminarily approved.

On October 31, 2023, the Plaintiffs moved for attorneys' fees and reimbursement of expenses, and award of service payments. According to the motion, the class counsel will receive $2,500,000, reimbursements of litigation expenses in the amount of 37,333.06, and service payments of $1,500 for each of the four Plaintiffs.

On January 16, 2024, the court issued an order granting final settlement approval and granting motion for attorneys' fees and costs. Accordingly, the court issued a final judgment.

organization.name: Canon U.S.A., Inc.
organization.industry: Computer and Computer Peripheral Equipment and Software Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On December 23, 2020, Plaintiffs Brian McCartney, Mike Finnigan, Kristin Serkowski, Tyrone Villacis, Luis Pichardo and Kenneth Buchbinder filed a complaint in the US District Court for the Eastern District of New York, Brooklyn against Defendant Canon USA, Inc. for failing to safeguard confidential information, thousands of current and former Canon employees and their beneficiaries have had their confidential information stolen.

On November 25, 2020, Defendant announced that it became aware of a ransomware attack on its network and systems on August 4, 2020. Defendant stated that the Ransomware Attack resulted in unauthorized access to files on its servers containing personal and confidential information about current and former employees, as well as their beneficiaries and dependents. Defendant further revealed that the exposure and unauthorized access occurred between July 20, 2020 and August 6, 2020. Defendant maintained the Private Information in a reckless manner. The highly confidential PI that was compromised in the Ransomware Attack and Data Breach is considered a valuable treasure trove that can be sold on the Dark Web and/or used to commit identity theft or other fraud for the foreseeable future. There are tens of thousands affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On January 20, 2021, Plaintiffs of the cases Finnigan et al v. Canon U.S.A., Inc and Hamid v. Canon U.S.A., Inc., et al. stipulated the consolidation of the cases, subject to the Courts approval.

On January 25, 2021, the Court granted the consolidation of the cases with Case No. 1:20-cv06239-AMD-SJB as the lead case. Andre Samuel Hamid, Amy Lynn Hamid, Diana Rouse, and Woodrow Moss were added as Plaintiffs. Canon Information and Imaging Solutions, Inc., Canon Software America, Inc., Canon Financial Services, Inc., NT-Ware USA, Inc., Canon Medical Components USA, Inc., Canon Information Technology Services, Inc. and Canon Solutions America, Inc. were added as Defendants.

On February 2, 2023, the parties moved for the preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the terms of the settlement, Class Members are entitled to receive potentially up to $7,500 (along with the value of credit monitoring services), which may lead to some Class Members receiving more than the representatives obtaining incentive awards. For those Class Members who are only entitled to an Ordinary Expense Reimbursement, their recovery maxes out at $300 (plus the value of credit monitoring services), while Class Members who suffered no identifiable or demonstrable financial harm are entitled to the additional credit monitoring services.

Class Counsel will receive an award for attorneys' fees in the amount of $600,000, plus reimbursement of expenses in the amount of $17,985.58. Plaintiffs' will also receive service awards in the amount of $1,000 each for a total of $10,000 (10 Plaintiffs).

On November 15, 2023, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On April 11, 2024, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On May 9, 2024, the Court entered its final judgment of the class action settlement. Thus, the case is terminated.

On July 13, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Christopher Albeluhn and Brian Boog (Plaintiffs) against Capcom Co. Ltd. and Capcom (U.S.A) Inc. (Defendants) in the Supreme Court of British Columbia. The action arises out of Defendants' failure to make reasonable security arrangements to prevent loss, theft and unauthorized access of customers' personal identifiable information.

According to the complaint, at some point prior to November 1, 2020, an unauthorized party accessed the PII of customers from Defendants' information technology systems and posted it on an unauthorized website. On November 4, 2020, Defendants released a press release on their website and began notifying affected customers. Between November 4, 2020 and April 13, 2021, Defendants posted four press release stating that PII was impacted including name, email address, HR information, etc. of 16,406 current and former capcom employees and business partners. Defendants added that their devices were infected with the Ragnar Locker Ransomware.

Due to the incident and Defendants' misconduct, Plaintiffs and the class members suffered loss and damages including violation of privacy, out-of-pocket expenses and psychological distress.

Plaintiffs brought the action on their own behalf and behalf of all Canadians residents whose PII was accessed by unauthorized parties in or as a result of the data breach or who received a notification that their PII may have been accessed.

Plaintiffs sought for punitive damages, injunctive relief and other relief as the Court deems appropriate.

On July 4, 2022, the parties have agreed to settle the case. Defendants have will pay CAD $125,000 to resolve all claims against them. Under the settlement, Class Members can submit claims with supporting evidence for direct losses caused by the Data Breach and will be eligible for reimbursement of such losses. Class Members who submit an approved substantiated claim will also be entitled to receive reimbursement for two hours of lost time, calculated at a rate of CAD $20.00 per hour,

In addition, Class Counsel will receive an attorney' fees in the amount of $29,472.29 plus disbursements of $5,610.86. An honorarium of $1,500 will also be awarded to Plaintiff.

On November 4, 2022, the Court approved the class action settlement.

US corporate travel management firm Carlson Wagonlit Travel (CWT) has suffered an intrusion, and it is believed the company paid a $4.5m ransom to get its data back.

The attack hit the company a week ago, causing a shutdown of all systems while the infection was contained and dealt with.

A Twitter user posted the first indication of a breach, as well as the ransom, on July 30, 2020.

The Register contacted CWT and, in a statement, the company confirmed that they experienced a cyber-incident. They confirmed that after temporarily shutting down their systems as a precautionary measure, their systems are back online, and the incident has now ceased. They immediately launched an investigation and engaged external forensic experts. While the investigation is at an early stage, they have no indication that PII/customer and traveler information has been affected.

It is thought that the nasty involved was Ragnar Locker.

organization.name: Carrefour SA
organization.industry: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

location.street: 33 Avenue Emile Zola ZAC Ile Seguin

incident.description:
French retail giant Carrefour and its banking arm have been fined over C3m ($3.7m) by the local data protection regulator for multiple breaches of the GDPR.

French regulator the Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertes (CNIL) hit Carrefour France with a C2.25m fine and Carrefour Banque received an C800,000 penalty.

CNIL considered the significant remedial action that had been taken by the firm to address its concerns.

Information about data protection was too complicated and imprecise, and hidden in lengthy documents alongside other information. Key info on data retention was also missing.

Cookie use was unlawful, the policy for dealing with data subject requests was too restrictive, Carrefour didn't meet time limits for responding to data subject requests and it transferred data without being fully transparent.

CNIL claimed that a data retention period of four years for customer data after the last purchase was excessive. Plus, it felt there was also insufficient information on data transfers outside the EU and the legal basis for processing on the carrefour.fr website.

On January 10, 2020, Mr. Eric Peres, a rapporteur from the National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms (NCIF), claimed that Carrefour Banque violated the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Data Protection Act (DPA).

According to his report, when a subscriber of a payment card (Pass card) also wishes to join the Carrefour loyalty program, the company Carrefour Banque makes several requests to the company Carrefour France including, in particular, a request to join the Carrefour loyalty program. According to the documents submitted to the delegation, Carrefour Banque also transmits to Carrefour France, the name, mailing address, telephone number and email address of the subscriber of the Pass card.

Peres considers that the company breached the principle of loyalty when they transmitted more personal data concerning the subscribers of the Pass card than those listed exhaustively within the framework of the subscription process.

On November 18, 2020, the NCIF decided to impose an administrative fine of EUR 800,000 against Carrefour Banque for breaching the GDPR and DPA.

organization.name: Carrefour France
organization.industry: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

incident.description:
On January 10, 2020, the National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms (NCIF) had a bailiff served on the company, Carrefour France for violating the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Data Protection Act (DPA).

According to the rapporteur, the company set retention periods in excess of the periods necessary for the purposes of the processing. On the other hand, he accuses the company of having kept personal data for a period longer than those provided. The rapporteur criticized the company for having kept for a period of one to six years the identity documents communicated to them by the persons concerned in the exercise of a right. He considers that this duration is excessive, the data being kept beyond the duration necessary to achieve the purpose for which they are processed. As soon as the request has been granted, the company no longer needs to keep a copy of the applicant's identity document. The sole purpose of providing this document is to justify the identity of the person making the request and it is not necessary to keep it once the identity has been confirmed.

The rapporteur also criticized the company for the time limit within which requests to exercise rights were answered. He claimed that response times vary but can reach nine months, without any information being communicated in the meantime to the people concerned.

Furthermore, the information provided to people subscribing to the company's loyalty program using a paper bulletin was not easily accessible. The company's bulletin summarized the essential information and referred, for more complete information, to the home page of the carrefour.fr site without further details.

On November 18, 2020, the NCIF imposed an administrative fine of EUR 2,250,000 against Carrefour France for breaching the GDPR and DPA.

On October 9, 2020, Michael Warshawsky and Michael Steinhauser (Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint against cbdMD, Inc. and CBD Industries, LLC (collectively, 'CBD' or 'Defendants') in the U.S. District Court for Western District of North Carolina (Charlotte) for failure to safeguard customers' personal and financial data allowed the information to be exposed to unauthorized third parties and has placed affected customers at a heightened risk of identity theft and fraud, over two data breaches that reportedly occurred between March and May 2020.

According to the complaint, the Defendants who sell hemp products used for pain relief and general health for both humans and pets, notified the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on September 25, 2020 that an unauthorized party had modified the ecommerce platform underlying cbdmd.com to include 'malicious code' that 'scraped' customers' personal identifying information (PII) through the site from March 30, 2020, through May 8, 2020, and again from May 14, 2020, through May 18, 2020.

On December 18, 2020, Plaintiffs amended their complaint against Defendants.

Plaintiff sought relief for damages, attorney's fees, costs and other relief.

On April 30, 2021, a settlement agreement was reached. The Settlement will reimburse people who submit claims for (1) Out-of-pocket expenses and documented lost time that resulted from the Security Incident up to $210; and (2) Extraordinary expenses up to $2,500 that were likely caused by the Security Incident. Total reimbursement under the Settlement is subject to an aggregate cap of $300,000 for all claims. Class Counsel will request the Court's approval of an award for attorneys' fees and reasonable costs and expenses of $135,000. Class Counsel will also request approval of service award of $2,500 for each of the Representative Plaintiffs, Michael Warshawsky and Michael Steinhauser.

Any amount that the Court awards for attorneys' fees, costs, expenses, and an incentive award will be paid separately by Defendants and will not reduce the amount of payments to Class members who submit valid claims.

On January 3, 2022, the Court preliminary approval the settlement.

On July 19, 2022, Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement.

On August 9, 2022, having reviewed the terms of the Settlement Agreement submitted by the parties, the court granted final approval of the settlement. Furthermore, Class Counsel's application for attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses in the amount of $135,000.00, and the request for service awards to each of the Representative Plaintiffs in the amount of $2,500 were also granted.

organization.name: San Giorgio Jonico Srl
organization.industry: Offices of Real Estate Agents and Brokers

incident.description:
The Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante) has received a complaint from Mr. XX regarding the illegitimate dissemination of his personal data online by the Municipality of San Giorgio Jonico.

The aforementioned documents (determination and relative attachment containing the writ of summons) clearly reported personal data and information of the complainant in the subject and body of the text.

The Municipality of San Giorgio Jonico responded to the Office's request for information and confirmed the removal of the complainant's personal data from the URLs indicated in a note dated XXth.

In addition, with a note of the XXth, the Data Protection Officer appointed by the Municipality also provided feedback to the Guarantor, who however limited himself to recalling the general obligations carried out by the body, without going into the merits of the violation of personal data complained of in the complaint.

On March 5, 2020, Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante) detected the unlawfulness of the processing carried out by the Municipality of San Giorgio Jonico pursuant to art. 58, par. 2, lett. i) and 83 of the RGPD, as well as art. 166 of the Code for violation of art. 5, par. 1, lett. c; and 6, par. 1, lett. c) and e); par. 2 and par. 3, lett. b), of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), as well as art. 2-ter, paragraphs 1 and 3, of the Code in the terms set out in the motivation;

The Municipality of San Giorgio Jonico, in the person of the pro-tempore legal representative, with registered office in Via Salvo D'Acquisto - 74027 San Giorgio Ionico (TA) - CF 80009010739 to pay the sum of C 3,000.00 ($3,545.57) as a pecuniary administrative sanction for the violations mentioned in the motivation; it is represented that the offender, pursuant to art. 166, paragraph 8, of the Code, has the right to settle the dispute by paying, within 30 days, an amount equal to half of the sanction imposed.

organization.name: Cder
organization.industry: Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology)

incident.description:
An accounting company in Chalons-en-Champagne, CDER, was victimized of a business email compromise stemming from a 'false president scam' causing damage of several million euros. A flagrant investigation into organized gang fraud and money laundering is underway. With around ten transactions between the end of November and the end of December 2020. The incident was the biggest attack of its kind in France. During the annual general meeting of CDER on February 18, 2021, moderated by the president Herve Jacquinet and the director of the accounting firm Eric Folliet, the company announced that 14.7 million euros or $17,709,384 was stolen as a result of the fraud scheme.

CDER would like to point out that the method is known and is not in itself a cyber-attack. The scammers use fake emails, investigate a company, and find out who is responsible for making transfers with an identical scenario. Then, they tell the person they want to manipulate that the company is about to buy another company and it's confidential. The person who made the transfers was fired for serious misconduct.

For the case of CDER, the crooks stated that the transaction was carried out under the control of the financial market's authority. Through exchanges by email, WhatsApp and by telephone, and with false invoices.

On or before Thursday, Oct. 22, 2020, staff and administration at Cedar County Memorial Hospital became aware of an online data breach, followed by an apparent attempt to extort the hospital for a financial payment for the return of said data.

The cyber intrusion utilized a dark web program labeled as 'Ragnarok' ransomware, which consisted of an alleged capturing of data, along with a threat to disseminate it, unless a ransom was paid to a veiled or unnamed entity.

On the morning of Wednesday, Oct. 28, the Cedar County Republican obtained an email regarding an ongoing cyber security incident within the hospital and immediately responded to CCMH chief executive officer Jana Witt via telephone for comment.

According to documents obtained by CCR staff, several insurance entities and nationally known law firm BakerHostetler all are involved with the early stages of the data breach.

Through the initial discovery and response to the web-based intrusion, online and digital forensics entity Speartip has been consulted, and Coveware, a ransomware, data recovery and negotiation support company, both have taken a role within the developing situation surrounding the breach and attempted extorsion.

Supporting documents show one of CCMH's liability carriers already has OK'd an 'extorsion payment of up to $15,000,' with a caveat noting the decision to pay the ransom ultimately wholly remained with CCMH.

It is unknown if the hospital would be reimbursed for the funds, as insurance documents obtained by CCR staff state the hospital's retention (essentially a deductible) is $25,000 and has a coverage ceiling of $1,000,000, in the event of a cyber liability meaning the alleged ransomware's financial demand likely falls under the minimum amount of monies deemed the obligation of an insurer.

Between May 2020 and January 2021, Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others throughout the world by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

When RCMP searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

On February 1, 2022, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Cegep St. Felicien in the amount of $999,239.

organization.name: Magellan Health, Inc.
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On June 29, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Chris Griffey, Bharath Maduranthgam Rayam, and Michael Domingo (Plaintiffs) against Magellan Health, Inc. (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the District of Arizona. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to take steps necessary to secure the identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI) from a data breach.

According to the complaint, in April 2020 Defendant was hit with an email phishing scheme expressly designed to gain access to private and personal data stored by Defendant. The breach was detected by Defendant on April 11, 2020 when files were encrypted on its systems. The investigation into the attack revealed the attacker had gained access to its systems following a response to a spear phishing email sent on April 6. An employee of Defendant inappropriately responded to the email phishing scheme, allowing unauthorized actors to gain access to the employees' email accounts.

On or about May 12, 2020, Defendant notified affected persons and various governmental agencies of the breach. At least 163,654 individuals were impacted by the breach. Information compromised in the breach included names, contact information, employee ID numbers, and W-2 or 1099 information, including Social Security numbers or taxpayer identification numbers, treatment information, health insurance account information, member IDs, other health-related information, email addresses, phone numbers, physical addresses, and additional PII. As a result, Plaintiffs and Class members suffered out-of-pocket expenses, anxiety, emotional distress, and loss of privacy.

Plaintiffs brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons whose PII and PHI was compromised as a result of the Ransomware Attack that Defendant discovered on or about April 11, 2020.

Plaintiffs sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, equitable relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual damages, compensatory damages, statutory damages, attorneys' fees and costs, pre- and post-judgment interest, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On October 6, 2020, Plaintiffs filed a motion to consolidate case Ranson, et al. v. Magellan Health, Inc., Case No. 2:20-cv-1350-MTL to Griffey, et al. v. Magellan Health, Inc., Case No. 2:20-cv-01282-MTL (Lead case). On October 8, 2020, the Court granted the motion. All future filings related to these cases shall be filed on the Lead case.

On October 29, 2020, Plaintiffs filed a consolidated class action complaint.

On December 11, 2020, an amended consolidated class action complaint was filed.

On October 21, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their second amended consolidated complaint.

On June 20, 2023, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

The settlement includes two separate groups. provides for up to $2,250,000 in benefits for the Claims-Made Settlement Class Members, and a $1,500,000 non-reversionary common fund for the Common-Fund Settlement Class Members.

As per agreement, Claims-Made Settlement Class members whose Social Security number was not compromised in the breach can file for up to $750 in documented expense reimbursement, including up to three hours of lost time reimbursement at a rate of $20 per hour, and 12 months of identity theft protection.

Common-Fund Settlement Class Members will receive a $100 cash payment that may be adjusted up or down based on the number of claims approved and in lieu of any other benefits. Class members can also file for up to $5,000 in documented expense reimbursement for data-breach-related expenses, including five hours of time reimbursement at a rate of $25 per hour.

The total potential value of the settlement is capped at $3,750,000.

In addition, Plaintiffs will separately seek an award of attorneys' fees not to exceed $1,250,000, as well as reimbursement of their reasonable costs and litigation expenses incurred. Any attorneys' fees, costs, and/or Service Awards awarded by the Court shall be paid by Defendant. Such costs are subject to $2,250,000 Claims-Made Benefits cap.

On August 9, 2023, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

Cybercriminals launched a NetWalker (Mailto) ransomware attack against the Illinois Champaign-Urbana Public Health District (CUPHD) website, according to The News-Gazette. The health district's email accounts, environmental health records and patient electronic medical records were unaffected by the cyberattack.

The NetWalker attack was discovered last week as CUPHD officials tried to deliver Coronavirus (COVID-19) updates to Champaign-Urbana residents, The News-Gazette reported. It temporarily prevented health district employees from accessing certain files.

CUPHD's website is currently up and running. In addition, CUPHD is working with the FBI, U.S. Department of Homeland Security, and global risk consulting service Kroll to investigate the ransomware attack.

Health district employees became aware of the ransomware attack Tuesday when they lost access to files.

The hackers were demanding a ransom to restore the system.

The district agreed to meet the hackers' demands because it didn't have the time to wait or restore its system on its own, which could have taken months, Vaid said. Its cyber insurance paid more than $300,000 in ransom, and the district had to cover its $10,000 deductible.

Since the coronavirus pandemic began, cybersecurity experts say they have seen an uptick in attempted ransomware and other hacking attempts on hospitals, health care systems, clinical labs, and research centers.

Delaware County District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer announced Friday that an international thief or thieves stole approximately $3 million from the Chester Upland School District last year using a Florida woman as a 'money mule,' but said it might have been much worse if not for the intervention of officials with the Department of Treasury.

'Thanks to quick action by the (Pennsylvania) treasurer's office, this audacious attempt to steal from the schoolchildren of Chester and the taxpayers of the commonwealth was thwarted,' said Stollsteimer. 'The scope and complexity of the scheme are, however, alarming and remind us all of the importance of keeping our technology protected, as well as the perils of conducting financial transactions with -- or on behalf of -- individuals unknown to you.'

According to Stollsteimer , thieves attempted to steal a total of $13.3 million from the district, but were thwarted when a single $8.5 million payment request sent up red flags and allowed Treasury to claw back $10.3 million before it could be washed through multiple banks and sent overseas.

Had that gone through, teachers may not have been paid, he added.

The investigation determined that personal information was compromised as a result of the breach, including names, date of birth, Social Security numbers, and/or health insurance information.

On July 15, 2021, the District provided notice of the incident to 1,245 affected individuals including 1 Louisiana, 3 Connecticut, 6 New York, 2 North Carolina, 47 New Jersey and 10 Maryland residents.

The District provided 2 years of complimentary credit monitoring and identity protection services.

The Office for Civil Rights (OCR) at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services announces the resolution of its twentieth investigation in its HIPAA Right of Access Initiative. OCR created this initiative to support individuals' right to timely access their health records at a reasonable cost under the HIPAA Privacy Rule.

OCR launched an investigation on Jan. 3, 2020 and found the failure to provide the parent with timely access to the requested health data was a potential violation of the HIPAA Right of Access standard. The investigation resulted in the patient receiving all requested records from CHMC on June 20 and July 16, 2020.The privacy regulation requires a covered entity or business associate to act on patient access requests within 30 days, or within 60 days if an extension is applicable.

Children's Hospital & Medical Center (CHMC) has agreed to take corrective actions and pay $80,000 to settle a potential violation of the HIPAA Privacy Rule's right of access standard. CHMC is in Omaha, Nebraska, and provides pediatric health care services.

In May 2020, a parent filed a complaint with OCR alleging that CHMC had failed to provide her with timely access to her minor daughter's medical records. CHMC provided some records but did not provide all the requested records to the parent's multiple follow-up requests.

OCR initiated an investigation and determined that CHMC's failure to provide timely access to the requested medical records was a potential violation of the HIPAA right of access standard, which requires a covered entity to act on an access request within 30 days of receipt (or within 60 days if an extension is applicable). As a result of OCR's investigation, the parent finally received all the requested records.

'Generally, HIPAA requires covered entities to give parents timely access to their minor children's medical records when the parent is the child's personal representative. OCR's Right of Access Initiative supports patients' and personal representatives' fundamental right to their health information and underscores the importance of all covered entities' compliance with this essential right,' said Acting OCR Director Robinsue Frohboese.

In addition to the monetary settlement, CHMC will undertake a corrective action plan that includes one year of monitoring.

China's central bank fined six state-owned banks a combined 41.88 million yuan ($6.3 million) Wednesday (October 21, 2020) for infringement of consumers' personal information rights as the country introduces its first national legislation on the protection of personal data.

The six banks are four branches of China Construction Bank ($4,200,000), a branch of Bank of China ($1,050,000) and a branch of Agricultural Bank of China ($1,050,000).

The penalties show that some financial institutions have insufficient awareness of the protection of consumer rights and interests and that the implementation of mechanisms for protection of consumer financial information is not in place, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) said in a Q&A published on its website.

PBOC issued measures to protect the rights and interests of financial consumers that will take effect November 1, 2020. The measures establish the required mechanisms to protect financial consumers' fundamental and long-term interests, require banks and payment institutions to follow the principles of legality, fairness and necessity when processing such information, and add penalties for violations.

China's central bank fined six state-owned banks a combined 41.88 million yuan ($6.3 million) Wednesday (October 21, 2020) for infringement of consumers' personal information rights as the country introduces its first national legislation on the protection of personal data.

The six banks are four branches of China Construction Bank ($4,200,000), a branch of Bank of China ($1,050,000) and a branch of Agricultural Bank of China ($1,050,000).

The penalties show that some financial institutions have insufficient awareness of the protection of consumer rights and interests and that the implementation of mechanisms for protection of consumer financial information is not in place, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) said in a Q&A published on its website.

PBOC issued measures to protect the rights and interests of financial consumers that will take effect November 1, 2020. The measures establish the required mechanisms to protect financial consumers' fundamental and long-term interests, require banks and payment institutions to follow the principles of legality, fairness and necessity when processing such information, and add penalties for violations.

A new report by the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) has revealed that Baltimore city was tricked out of hundreds of thousands of dollars last year by a cyber-criminal posing as a vendor.

The OIG launched an investigation after receiving information from Baltimore's Bureau of Accounting and Payroll Services (BAPS) in October 2021 regarding an alleged fraudulent Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT).

The alarm was raised over a contractor who had received funds from the Mayor's Office of Children and Family Success (MOCFS).

A fraudster claiming to be associated with an employee from the vendor company emailed BAPS and MOCFS twice to request a change to the vendor's EFT remittance information.

The fraudster asked for the bank details kept on file for the vendor to be updated to a different bank account at another financial institution.

'The OIG later determined that the email account associated with the Vendor Employee was compromised by a malicious actor, who established rules within the Vendor Employee's email account as a result of a phishing attack,' noted inspector general Isabel Mercedes Cumming.

She added: 'Therefore, the malicious actor was able to correspond directly with City employees without the Vendor's knowledge.'

On December 21, 2020, BAPS complied with the fraudster's change request and altered the bank details on file for the vendor company. BAPS made an electronic funds transfer to the new account the next day.

The bank detected that the transfer was fraudulent and returned the funds to the city's banking institution.

On January 5, 2021, the fraudster contacted MOCFS and BAPS again, asking for the money to be transferred to a different account at a third financial institution. The fraudster supplied a bank letter and copy of a voided check whose details matched the third account as verification.

Believing the fraudster's claims, BAPS paid $376,213.10 into the third account on January 7, 2021.

OIG determined that BAPS had no list of authorized signatories for vendors, and instead of independently authenticating information and requests, BAPS relied on MOCFS and accepted an incoming phone call from an individual claiming to be the Vendor's chief financial officer (CFO).

The vendor is yet to be paid by the city but did get $50,000 from its insurance company.

In 2020, East Barton Rouge Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

An Alabama city is paying over a quarter of a million dollars to cyber-criminals to recover data encrypted in a ransomware attack.

Florence became a victim of the DoppelPaymer ransomware gang on June 5 in an attack that shut down the city's email system. The gang demanded 38 bitcoin, equivalent to USD $378,000, and threatened to publish or sell data stolen from Florence if the city didn't pay up.

A security firm hired by Florence in the wake of the attack was able to negotiate the ransom down to 30 bitcoin, worth around $291,000.

City mayor Steve Holt said that Florence had elected to pay the ransom despite not knowing for certain what data the cyber-criminals had stolen and encrypted.

The mayor theorized that attackers gained access to the city's computer system via a phishing attack.

Holt told KrebsOnSecurity that the DoppelPaymer gang appeared to have compromised the networks of four further victims within an hour of striking Florence, including another municipality that he declined to name.

Krebs contacted Holt's office in late May after receiving a tip from Hold Security that Florence's information technology systems had been infiltrated by hackers who specialize in deploying ransomware.

Fresno's loss to an online phishing scam totaled more than $600,000, was part of a larger scheme targeting multiple municipalities nationwide and the FBI has identified an American suspect, Mayor Jerry Dyer announced in a news conference at City Hall on Thursday.

Some details Dyer reported differed from the information he shared the day prior. Dyer said he spoke to a special agent Wednesday evening and learned new information, but there were some details he wasn't sharing so as not to further compromise the federal investigation. 'This was part of a much larger scheme that was occurring,' Dyer said. Dyer spent a large portion of the news conference explaining why his administration didn't reveal the loss earlier, saying it was out of respect for the FBI investigation. He also explained how the Fresno City Attorney's Office handled a December public records request from The Bee and why records were not released. 'There's nothing more that I cherish as a public official, whether that was my time as police chief or now as the mayor, than earning the trust of this community,' he said. 'Once that trust is violated, I lose credibility as the leader of this organization. So, I want to reiterate at no time was there ever an attempt to hide information from the public or to deceive any media outlet on a public records request.'

The Bee broke the news of the phishing scam Wednesday after Dyer and Fresno City Councilmember Miguel Arias confirmed it. TIMELINE OF EVENTS In the news conference Thursday, Dyer said two payments totaling $613,737 were made in January and March of 2020 through wire transfers. The city received two fake invoices that looked identical to invoices from a city contractor working on the construction of the southeast Fresno police station. The fraud was discovered in April when the contractor threatened to walk off the job due to not receiving payment, Dyer said. The fraud was then reported to the Fresno Police Department, and eventually the investigation was handed over to the FBI in November 2020.

The city of Keizer's computer system was hacked on Wednesday, June 10, and officials were only able to regain access to the data by paying the perpetrators a $48,000 ransom.

About 11:45 a.m., Wednesday, June 17, city employees finally regained access to all emails and files. Those concerned that previous attempts to contact city employees did not reach the intended recipient should call 503-390-3700 or attempt to resend the communication.

The digital strike was discovered when city employees could not access some data and programs the morning of Wednesday, June 10.

The city 'engaged appropriate authorities' to assist in data recovery, but it soon became clear that the only way to regain access to information stored on the city's computers was to pay a ransom to the hacker or hackers responsible.

On July 27, 2020, computer system of City of Lafayette was hit with a ransomware attack that disabled network services resulting in disruptions to phone service, email, and online payment and reservation systems. 9-1-1 and emergency dispatch services were not affected. Staff detected the infection and ransom notification at approximately 6:50am and disabled all network connections to contain the malware spread. Mutual aid from neighboring jurisdictions was brought onsite to assist, and a cybersecurity analyst was contracted to provide forensic investigation and recovery.

Preliminary investigation indicates the ransomware entered the City's network through a phishing scam or brute force and looks to be a random attack.

Financial data appears to be recoverable from unaffected backups. Personal credit card information was not compromised, as the City uses external PCI-certified payment gateways. There is no evidence to suggest personal data was compromised, but out of an abundance of caution, residents and employees are advised to be vigilant to monitor accounts for suspicious activity. The City sends a security breach notification to individuals who have personal information residing on the City's network.

The ransomware that invaded the City's system was used by criminals to block access to the City's computer data until a sum of money is paid. City officials opted to pay $45,000 ransom to retrieve a 'key' to unlock encrypted data rather than risk further delay or damage to the municipality's online operations.

Scammers posing as three merchants were able to defraud the city of LeClaire of $222,373. Scammers cleverly disguised and edited emails that resembled authentic emails from legitimate companies, directing the payments to three fraudulent accounts.

According to City Administrator, Ed Choate, LeClaire has recovered about $120,618 by freezing the accounts. The city is continuing to work with the FBI, the city's bank, and its insurance carrier to recover and/or reach a settlement for the remaining about $102,000.

The scam occurred over a four-month period from November 2020 to February 2021. The city discovered the cyberattack because the actual vendors contacted the city to alert, they hadn't received payment, the city clerk discovered the fraud and contacted the vendor.

The city installed multifactor authentication and other security software applications to prevent email compromises in the future, Choate said.

An attempt over the summer by Eastern European hackers to enter the City of Methuen's computer system with its information about taxpayers, employees and much more was nearly successful, according to city officials, but quick action helped keep the information secure.

On September 22, 2020, Mayor Neil Perry said Tuesday the hacking attempt was one of the reasons city councilors held an executive session July 13, during which they voted to spend $272,000 in emergency funds to buy hardware and software to combat the threat. The funding was also used for a forensic audit of the entire IT system to determine if there were other hidden threats.

Mayor Neil Perry, along with several city councilors and City Solicitor Richard D'Agostino, outlined the details of the hacking threat in a Zoom call with The Eagle-Tribune, while also justifying why they had to take the vote behind closed doors.

On July 8, 2020, he reported, the city learned that hackers had sent an email to an unsuspecting employee, who then opened an attachment that contained ransomware.

The city was facing a deficit brought on by the COVID-19 crisis and any kind of ransom paid to hackers would have made matters much worse.

The City of Paducah has regained access to servers and records impacted by a recent ransomware attack.

A third-party used malicious software compromised the City of Paducah's systems and encrypted numerous data files. Officials learned the unauthorized intrusion into the IT systems on February 1, 2020, Saturday.

The hacker then contacted the City and demanded money in exchange for decryption keys.

With help from outside security experts, the Kentucky League of Cities, and the city's insurance provider, the city decided to rebuild certain systems from scratch and also purchase decryption keys from the hacker.

The city ended up paying about $30,000 to the hacker for the decryption keys.

According to Paducah City Manager Jim Arndt, the city's IT systems and file storage are back up and running, and no information was stolen from the city in the hack.

Russian hackers developed RYUK Ransomware is said to have hit the servers operating in the city of Port Lavaca on February 3, disrupting almost all the critical servers of the City Hall. However, Mayor Jack Whitlow has assured that no data was compromised in the incident and the activity to re-build the data from backups was already going on full swing.

The billing systems and auto-pay systems of the city hall were reportedly badly disrupted in the incident and a malware clean up is due to be done by the end of this week.

No servers related to water, sewer, police department, and other essential services were affected by the Ryuk ransomware in the incident. As there is a need to buy new hardware and software to rebuild the systems, access to data can be expected to be restored by early next month.

News is out that the City Hall of Port Lavaca has already incurred a $50,000 bill due to the incident, which might be covered by the insurance cover. The city approved to retain a law firm and authorized an amount up to $10,000 from the emergency contingency funds to be allocated to the services required that the city's insurance does not cover. Secondly, the Council authorized $45,000 from the contingency funds to be allocated towards the purchases of services and hardware related to the IT network and infrastructure.

City of Prince George loses $375,000 to fraudsters after electronic payments were diverted. Fraudsters stole $700,000 from the City and less than half the funds have been recovered.

According to police, the city had directed two electronic payments to a contractor, but the money never arrived.

The city reported the scam to RCMP, and investigators were able to work with financial institutions to recover some money, but $375,000 is still missing.

The fraud was reported in September.

Police say there is no indication the city was hacked, or personal information compromised, and the crime appears to be the result of a 'sophisticated computer-based fraud.'

The City of Saint John has confirmed that the recent cyber-attack against it was ransomware.

At a news conference Tuesday afternoon, the city said there's no evidence that anyone's personal information was stolen. They advised people to keep an eye on their bank accounts, just to be sure.

Saint John's website remains down, and online payments are not possible. Parking, for example, is currently cash only.

There is no timeline yet for the restoration of their services. No decision has been made about whether to give in to the hackers' ransom demands. The city wouldn't say whether a specific amount was named in the ransom demand or details about how the attack was first discovered late Friday, November 13, 2020.

Critical city functions are still operational, including transit, water and waste-water treatment services. Most 'routine' operations are also still functioning, such as recreational facilities, solid waste management, public works, and customer service. Some have had to return to a more old-school approach with manual processing. Building permits, however, will not be issued until a manual system can be developed.

A cyberattack that held Saint John's network hostage and forced the city to rebuild its network from scratch will cost taxpayers $400,000 after insurance covers most of the $2.9 million bill.

The $2.9 million the city spent included: $1.1 million to Bulletproof Solutions for containment and recovery, $220,000 to FireEye Mandiant for forensic investigation and $52,000 to CYPFER for ransomware recovery and payment facilitation.

organization.name: Citywide Home Loans, A Utah Corporation

incident.description:
On October 5, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Marjorie Curtis (Plaintiff), individually, and on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated against Citywide Home Loans, LLC (Defendant or Citywide) in the Third Judicial District Court for Salt Lake County, State of Utah. This class action arises out of Defendant's failure to adequately protect Plaintiff's and similarly situated persons' personally identifiable information allegedly compromised during the Data Incident.

According to the lawsuit, Defendant was negligent in failing to protect its internal systems, leading to a data breach November 18, 2020. During the breach, an unauthorized person allegedly gained access to the Citywide systems and deployed ransomware, resulting in the encryption of certain systems and the alleged compromise of the personally identifiable information of current and former employees of Citywide.

The Action brought class claims for negligence, breach of contract, invasion of privacy and breach of fiduciary duty, and sought monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief.

On February 24, 2023, a class action settlement agreement has been filed.

Under the settlement, Defendant will provide the option to enroll in two years of credit monitoring and identity theft protection services (including $1,000,000 in identity theft insurance) through Kroll Associates, Inc., at no cost; Defendant will pay valid claims submitted for Economic Losses (up to $5,000.00) and Lost Time (up to $200) you experienced related to the Data Incident. If valid claims exceed $1,225,000.00 payments to Class Members will be reduced pro rata.

Class Counsel will ask the Court for attorney's fees and expenses of up to $575,000.00, and service awards to the Plaintiff for $2,500.00, all to be paid by the Defendant.

On May 9, 2023, Plaintiff filed an amended preliminary approval order.

On August 11, 2023, an order granting final approval of class action settlement.

Within the framework of the Italian SA's enforcement activities regarding telephone operators, Wind Tre SpA was fined about EUR 17 million on July 9 on account of several instances of unlawful data processing that were mostly related to marketing. The Italian SA had already issued a prohibitory injunction against the company, on account of similar infringements that had occurred when the previous data protection law was in force.

The fine was imposed following complex investigations and inspections. Complaints were received from users against unsolicited marketing communications made without their consent via texting, emails, faxes, and automated phone calls. In several cases, the complainants had declared they had not been enabled to exercise their right to withdraw consent or object to the processing of their data for marketing purposes, partly on account of the inaccurate contact information provided in the information notices. In yet other cases, users' personal data had been included in public phone listings despite the (at times reiterated) objections made by those users thus violating the General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR).

The investigation showed that the MyWind and My3 apps had been configured in such a way as to require the user to consent, on each access, to processing for various purposes including marketing, profiling, communication of data to third parties, data enrichment and geolocation; withdrawal of such consent was allowed after 24 hours.

The pleadings submitted by Wind Tre and the corrective measures implemented by the company, as also related to the centralized approach applying to marketing campaigns, were found inadequate by the Italian SA, which accordingly fined Wind Tre EUR 16,729,600 (18, 600,000 USD) and prohibited any further processing of the data they had acquired without consent. The Italian SA also ordered the company to take technical and organizational measures to ensure effective oversight of their business partners, along with implementing procedures to respect users' indications to be left alone.

On July 31, 2020, Julia Rossi (Plaintiff) filed a class action Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois, County Department, Chancery Division, against Claire's Stores, Inc. (Defendant).

According to the complaint, hackers infiltrated Claire's systems through its Salesforce cloud. Through this access, third parties were reportedly able to insert a code onto Claire's e-commerce platform that allowed hackers to steal payment card data.

On June 12, 2020, they identified and removed computer code that had been added to the site by an unauthorized person. The added code was capable of obtaining information entered by customers during the checkout process and sending that information out of our system. They also reinforced the security of the site.

Plaintiffs claim Claire also mishandled the breach by failing to identify and resolve the threat in a timely fashion. As a result of the company's alleged negligence, consumers' first and last names, addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, payment card numbers, expiration dates, and card verification codes for the payment card have been overwhelmed with phishing emails as result of stolen data.

Plaintiffs, individually and on behalf of other individuals, respectfully request the court order relief and enter judgment in their favor and against Defendants as follows, a judgment awarding Plaintiffs and other individuals appropriate monetary relief, including actual damages, punitive damages, treble damages, statutory damages, exemplary damages, equitable relief, restitution, and disgorgement, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, attorneys' fees, expenses, and the costs of this action, all other and further relief as this court deems necessary, just, and proper

On August 28, 2020, the case was transferred to the Northern District of Illinois Eastern Division.
