On October 26, 2020, a consolidated amended complaint was filed adding Delilah Parker and Kevin Holmes as named Plaintiff case number 1:20 cv 5574.

On June 16, 2021, Plaintiffs filed a motion for an unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement and certification of the settlement class, and according to the settlement, Defendant has agreed to pay $350,000 this will not include the 165,000 for an award of attorney's fees and cost. The settlement benefits consumers whose personal information may have been compromised in Claire's data breach between April 7 and June 17, 2020.

On March 28, 2022, the court entered an order certifying the settlement class and granting preliminary approving class action settlement.

Club Deportivo Sansueia Sl has added Director of the Spanish Agency phone number to a WhatsApp group without requiring your consent. On July 31, 2021, Club Deportivo Sansueia Sl is notified of the agreement of initiation of this procedure, converting said agreement into a resolution proposal in accordance with articles 64.2.f and 85 of Law 39 on October 1, 2015, on the Common Administrative Procedure of Public Administrations (LPACAP), at the Failure to make the claimed allegations within the indicated period.

This offense may be sanctioned with a fine of a maximum of 20,000,000 or, in the case of a company, an amount equivalent to a maximum of 4% of the total annual global business volume of the previous financial year, opting for the of greater amount, in accordance with article 83.5 of the RGPD.

On June 17, 2020, Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation (Cognizant) informed that they recently discovered that they were a victim of a Maze ransomware attack carried out by international cyber criminals through which personal information was impacted.

On April 20, 2020, Cognizant learned that the attackers staged and likely exfiltrated a limited amount of data from Cognizant's systems. Based on investigation, they understand that this activity occurred between April 9 and 11, 2020.

They have determined that the personal information involved in this incident included name, Social Security number and/or other tax identification number, financial account information, driver's license information, and/or passport information.

Cognizant have no reason to believe personal information has been misused. Cognizant offers a complimentary 12-month credit and dark web monitoring service provided by ID Experts, which also includes identity theft insurance coverage and managed identity restoration services.

Additionally, in the second quarter of 2020, they incurred $24 million in costs related to the ransomware attack, and they incurred significant incremental costs for the remediation of the security incident and investments to enhance their overall security environment.

On June 17, 2020, Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation (Cognizant) informed that they recently discovered that they were a victim of a Maze ransomware attack carried out by international cyber criminals through which personal information was impacted. On April 20, 2020, Cognizant learned that the attackers staged and likely exfiltrated a limited amount of data from Cognizant's systems. Based on investigation, they understand that this activity occurred between April 9 and 11, 2020.

As a result of the fulfillment challenges caused by the ransomware attack, the company's year over year revenue growth for the second quarter of 2020 was negatively impacted by approximately 90 basis points. While they anticipate that the revenue impact related to the issue will be largely resolved by the middle of the quarter, they do anticipate the revenue and corresponding margin impact to be in the range of $50 million to $70 million for the quarter.

Ms. Paula Disberry (Ms. Disberry) worked for Colgate-Palmolive from December 1993 to March 2004. In 1998, she became eligible to participate in the company's Employees Savings and Investment Plan and she was diligent about saving for retirement.

In or around August 2020, Ms. Disberry attempted to access her Plan account online to review her Plan balance. However, her attempts to access her account were blocked, and the website said she was entering the incorrect username ID and password. She then contacted Colgate-Palmolive and the Benefits Information Center to request access and information about her Plan account.

On September 14, 2020, Ms. Disberry was informed that the entire balance of her Plan account, totaling $751,430.53, had been distributed from the Plan in a single taxable lump sum, even though at no point had she authorized or received any such distribution.

Ms. Disberry later learned that her Plan account was distributed to an individual with an address and bank account in Las Vegas, Nevada in March 2020. According to information from Alight Solutions, LLC (Alight), the fraudster first contacted the Benefits Information Center by telephone on January 29, 2020. She falsely identified herself as Ms. Disberry, and requested to update Ms. Disberry's contact information that was on file with the Plan. Alight sent a temporary personal identification number (PIN) by mail to Ms. Disberry's South Africa address. The fraudster, and/or others working in conjunction with her, intercepted Ms. Disberry's mail and stole the temporary PIN.

On February 24, 2020, the fraudster again contacted the Benefits Information Center. The fraudster used the temporary PIN and then created a new permanent PIN. The fraudster then requested to change the personal information on the account including phone number, email address, Ms Disberry's online user ID, password. The fraudster also added information for direct deposit for a Bank of America branch with a Las Vegas Address and requested a distribution of the entire Plan account on March 17, 2020.

On March 20, 2020, the distribution of $751,430.53 was processed to the fraudster at the Las Vegas, Nevada address and it was cashed on March 27, 2020.

After a 'cyber disturbance' that took out internet and phone lines in the Columbus County school system, the superintendent says they're moving in the right direction, but still need plenty of help.

After weeks of help from the National Guard, the school system is now getting its security cameras systems back in place. Some equipment used in classrooms have been recovered, but they're still in need of 1,500 pieces of equipment.

On February 17 meeting, the school district told the commissioners they're about $900,000 in the hole because of the unexpected breach. Nearly $100,000 of that comes from staff overtime devoted to help fix the equipment. Commissioners approved reimbursing the school district $100,000 on Monday night. Around $800,000 is yet to be recouped. County commissioners have voted to ask the state for help for the rest.

On June 2, 2020, The Commonwealth of Kentucky Personnel Cabinet announced that its state health plan suffered two cyberattacks in April and May, exposing the health information of 971 members and resulting in fraudulent gift card redemption of more than $107,000.

The security incident was related to a malicious attack against StayWell's portal, which occurred in two rounds: an initial round taking place from April 21-27, 2020 and a secondary round taking place from May 12-22, 2020.

During the first attack, 971 KEHP members accounts were accessed by a 'bad actor' who used valid login information to infiltrate StayWell, a third-party vendor utilized by KEHP members for their well-being and incentive portal.

After investigation by the Commonwealth Office of Technology, the Personnel Cabinet and the StayWell IT team, it was determined that while the attacker was unable to access important financial and personal information on the portal, such as birthdays, Social Security numbers or addresses, they were able to view biometric screening and health assessment data..

The attacker was able to redeem points that members had accumulated on the platform in the form of gift cards. According to Russell Goodwin, executive director for the Personnel Cabinet, the fraudulent gift card redemption amounted to a total of $100,000.

After the first attack, StayWell took its site down in order to introduce new security enhancements.

The second data breach, occurring from May 12 to 22, was a direct result of the first. StayWell estimates that 42 of the original 971 targeted members also had their Commonwealth email accounts infiltrated in the second attack. An additional $7,700 in fraudulent gift card redemptions resulted from it.

In response to the attacks, StayWell sent communications to the affected members informing them of the incident and encouraging them to both use strong passwords and avoid recycling them across programs and websites. StayWell also implemented additional user controls to ensure added security for members.

location.street: B-Dul Dacia Nr. 140 Et. P, Sectorul 2

incident.description:
On July 15, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP) completed an investigation at the operator of the Romanian National Post Company (RNPC) and found that it violated the provisions of article 32 of the General Regulation on Data Protection (GDPR), regarding the security of processing.

The breach of the security and confidentiality of personal data consisted in the fact that the controller did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures (e.g. pseudonymization), both when establishing the means of processing and in the processing itself, so as to effectively implement the principles of data protection and integrate in them the guarantees necessary for the processing, so that the requirements of the GDPR are fulfilled and the rights of data subjects are protected.

The operator of RNPC was sanctioned because it did not take the appropriate technical and organizational measures to prevent unauthorized access to personal data (e-mail addresses and telephone numbers) at https://awb.posta-romana.ro belonging to the RNPC, which led to the compromise of the confidentiality of the personal data of 81 data subjects.

On July 30, 2020, the ANSPDCP announced, that is has imposed a RON 9,686.60 ($2,350.91) fine on Romanian Post National Company for its failure to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to safeguard personal data under Article 32 of the GDPR.

organization.name: Connor Group
organization.industry: Offices of Real Estate Agents and Brokers

incident.description:
On April 15, 2022, a class action lawsuit was filed by Belicia Cruz (Plaintiff) individually and on behalf of all others mutually situated against The Connor Group, LLC (Defendant) in the Circuit Court of Kane County, Illinois, Sixteenth Judicial Circuit in violations of the Illinois' Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).

According to the complaint, Defendant collected, stored and used without first providing notice, obtaining informed written consent or publishing data retention policies to the handprints and associated personally identifying information of hundreds or thousands of its employees (and former employees), who are being required to 'clock in' with their handprints. The practice or requiring employees to clock in using their handprints was in place at least since January of 2020. Plaintiff was 'clocking in' using her handprints during her tenure of employment with Defendant in approximately May of 2020. Further, to the extent Defendant uses an outside vendor to process its payroll, there is a significant risk Plaintiff's biometric identifier have already been disseminated without her knowledge or consent. If Defendant's database of digitized handprints were to fall into the wrong hands, by data breach or otherwise, the employees to whom these sensitive and immutable biometric identifiers being could have their identities stolen, among other serious issues.

In violation of BIPA, from at least approximately January 2020 to May 2020, Defendant did not have written, publicly available policies identifying its retention schedules or guidelines for permanently destroying any of these biometric identifiers and/or biometric information.

Plaintiff sought for an award of statutory damages, attorney's fees and costs and any other relief that this Court deems appropriate.

On April 15, 2022, a Notice of Removal was entered notifying that the case was transferred to United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.

On October 21, 2022, Plaintiff's filed for unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. The parties have reached a proposed settlement.

A settlement fund of $237,600 was created. Under the settlement fund, each Settlement Class Member will automatically receive a pro rata cash payment from the Net Settlement Fund, estimated to be approximately $563 per Settlement Class Member; Plaintiff may receive a service award of up to $5,000 from the Settlement Fund.

On October 26, 2022, Plaintiff's preliminary approval of class action settlement was granted.

On December 19, 2022, a declaration of Philip L. Fraietta in support of Plaintiff's unopposed motion for attorney's fees, costs, expenses, and service award.

On September 1, 2020, Windward Software Systems Inc. was subject to a cyberattack, resulting in the exfiltration of records and the unauthorized encryption of some organizational infrastructure. The incident was discovered the same day, September 1, 2020; however, data exfiltration was confirmed 8 days later September 9, 2020 after records were discovered on the dark web.

The information involved in the breach may have included name, address, date of birth, social insurance number, and bank account information.

On February 1, 2022, Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins was convicted by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid. Upon information, Netwalker ransomware gang was the one who attacked the Windward Software Systems.

When Canadian authorities searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

Accordingly, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Windward Software Systems in the amount of $91,966.02.

organization.name: Corcoran Real Estate Group LLC
organization.industry: Offices of Real Estate Agents and Brokers

incident.description:
In February, Barbara Corcoran, founder of real estate brokerage firm Corcoran Group and judge on ABC's 'Shark Tank,' was nearly scammed out of $400,000.

The scammers emailed Corcoran's bookkeeper pretending to be her assistant and got their business email compromise. The message contained an invoice supposedly authorized by her assistant to pay for an investment property in Europe that needed renovations.

However, the investment property it referred to was not real and Corcoran's assistant hadn't actually sent the email.

Corcoran became aware of the scam when her assistant was copied in an email from the bookkeeper about the wire transfer. The scammers had created a fake email address for her assistant by leaving out one letter of her name. Corcoran and her team realized the trick when her bookkeeper added her assistant to the conversation using her real email address.

'No one reads their email addresses that carefully that you see day in and day out, and the scammers knew it,' says Corcoran.

Though the money was already gone from Corcoran's account, her bank in New York froze the money before it made its way to the scammers in China, and she was able to get it all back.

organization.name: Corporation of the County of Essex, The

incident.description:
A 16-step play-by-play has been provided to Windsor city councillors, who've been demanding details about how the Essex Region Conservation Authority was scammed for almost $300,000 in taxpayer money last summer.

Certainly, the board and administration of the ERCA were most distraught to discover that our security had been breached and our organization had been violated in this way.

Late in the evening of Aug. 27, ERCA administration discovered 'we had been the victim of a complex and sophisticated social engineering incident (a phishing scam), whereby fraudsters infiltrated our system, impersonated a staff member, and forged documents,' the letter to council says. Several investigations concluded, 'unequivocally, that this crime was perpetrated by individuals outside of the organization.'

The letter lays out the subsequent actions taken, including efforts to be publicly transparent about the phishing scam and the multiple security measures and staff training undertaken to ensure it doesn't happen again.

The chronology of events provided by ERCA mentions that Byrne was appointed interim general manager/secretary treasurer on Sept. 4, eight days after the scam was discovered. Wyma's departure was announced three weeks later Sept. 25.

organization.name: Cotiviti, Inc.
organization.industry: Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services

incident.description:
On May 6, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Steven K. Farmer (Plaintiff) against Humana Inc. and Cotiviti, Inc. (collectively, Defendants) in the Circuit Court for the Twelfth Judicial Circuit, in and for Sarasota County, Florida. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to properly secure and safeguard personal and sensitive information in violation of the Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA).

According to the complaint, on or before December 22, 2020, Defendant Humana learned that personal identifiable information (PII) and personal health information (PHI) of approximately 62,000 members had been exposed to unauthorized individuals through personal Google Drive account. Defendant Humana determined that the breach occurred because Defendant Cotiviti, with Humana's authorization and approval, collected the PII and PHI from medical providers and then shared with a subcontractor, Visionary, from October 12, 2020 through December 16, 2020. Thereafter, the PII and PHI was disclosed to unauthorized individuals to promote personal business endeavor.

Defendant Humana admits that the unencrypted PII and PHI exposed to unauthorized individuals included names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, treatment related information, and/or actual images (x-ray, photographs, etc.). Upon belief, the exposed PII and PHI of Plaintiff and Class members can be sold on the dark web. Hackers can access and then offer for sale the unencrypted. Unredacted PII and PHI to criminals. As a result of Defendants' negligence, Plaintiff and the Class suffered loss and damages including significant risk of identity theft, lost or diminished value of PII and PHI, out-of-pocket expenses and anxiety.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons in the United States whose PII was compromised in the data breach that is the subject of the Notice of Privacy Incident that Defendant Humana sent on or around March 1, 2021.

Plaintiff and the putative class sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, equitable and injunctive relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual, nominal and consequential damages, attorneys' fees and costs, pre-judgement interest and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On June 17, 2021, the case was removed from the circuit court to the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida.

On February 4, 2022, the parties jointly moved the Court to stay the case pending completion of the mediation. On February 7, 2022, the Court granted the parties' motion and stayed the case.

On March 16, 2022, Plaintiff and Defendants have reached a class action settlement.

On May 23, 2022, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Wherein, Defendant Cotiviti has agreed to provide an aggregate cap of $500,000, for the following general categories of relief; the reimbursement of ordinary expenses, the reimbursement of other extraordinary expenses, and credit monitoring and identity protection. The settlement also required Defendant Cotiviti to separately pay for all costs for notice to the Settlement Class, Costs of Claims Administration and costs of Dispute Resolution.

Under the terms of the settlement, class members can receive a maximum of $5,250 in payments for out-of-pocket losses. The settlement allows up to $250 for ordinary losses, such as fees, credit monitoring and three hours of lost time at a rate of $20 per hour. Class members can collect a larger payment of up to $5,000 for extraordinary losses, such as unreimbursed fraudulent charges and identity theft. In addition, Costs of Claims Administration and costs of Dispute Resolution are expected to be approximately $80,057.

Defendant Cotiviti will also separately pay the attorney's fees, costs, and expenses of Proposed Class Counsel in the amount of $300,000 and a service award to Class Representative in the amount not to exceed $2,500.

On June 23, 2022, the Court preliminarily approved Plaintiff's motion of Class Action Settlement. Final Approval Hearing of the Class Action Settlement will be held on February 8, 2023.

Delaware County has resolved a cyberattack on its government computer network by paying the hacker.

On September 10, 2020, a county employee received a phishing email that contained malware by a hacker, the threat actor, and it was downloaded into the system. During the period between September 10 and November 21,2020 the threat actor was most likely stealing credentials, identifying sensitive data, and exfiltrating the information from the county's operating environment. Sometime within that period, the hacker activated a ransomware application. On November 21, an IT staff member identified abnormalities in the county government's network.

The county's elected officials were made aware of the intrusion, as was the Department of Homeland Security and the county's insurance agent, which provided contacts for a cyber-forensics team and outside legal counsel with expertise in cybersecurity.

The hacker made it known fairly early on that their intent was to hold the county's system for ransom, with a threat to release data like personal identifying information should their demands not be met.

It was previously reported that the sum sought was $500,000, but Delaware County spokeswoman Adrienne Marofsky did not confirm that figure because it remains an ongoing investigation.

Delaware County Executive Director Howard Lazarus recommended that council pay the ransom because working with the hacker would allow for faster system restoration and prevent information from being published. The county paid a $25,000 deductible to their insurers, and the insurers paid a ransom of an unknown amount.

According to Delaware County Chief Information Officer Frank Bilotta, upon payment of the ransom, the threat actor provided the decryption tool necessary to unlock the county's systems, a list of the files that were exfiltrated, and a general description of how the cyberattack commenced.

All county systems have since been restored and IT staff is pursuing various initiatives to build a more secure network in the future.

Delaware County, Pennsylvania has paid a $500,000 ransom after their systems were hit by the DoppelPaymer ransomware.

Delaware County has resolved a cyberattack on its government computer network.

On September 10, 2020, a county employee received a phishing email that contained malware by a hacker, the threat actor, and it was downloaded into the system. During the period between September 10 and November 21, the threat actor was most likely stealing credentials, identifying sensitive data, and exfiltrating the information from the county's operating environment. Sometime within that period, the hacker activated a ransomware application. On November 21, an IT staff member identified abnormalities in the county government's network.

The county's elected officials were made aware of the intrusion, as was the Department of Homeland Security and the county's insurance agent, which provided contacts for a cyber-forensics team and outside legal counsel with expertise in cybersecurity.

According to Delaware County Chief Information Officer Frank Bilotta, all county systems have since been restored and IT staff is pursuing various initiatives to build a more secure network in the future. These include rebuilding server infrastructure, updating operating systems and applying security patches, and removing vulnerabilities identified by outside support agencies.

The actions would require continued use of outside resources, including the cybersecurity firm, upgrading security software, and engaging a third-party project manager to supplement existing staff.

To that end, council approved a $254,400 one-year contract with cyber security firm Kroll Inc., paid for out of the general fund, and a $150,000 professional services agreement with Judge Inc. to oversee Kroll and manage other potential technology and security projects, which will come from the IT budget.

The county should also pursue additional measures, such as moving data storage to a more secure, off-site location; continually evaluating back-up systems; ensuring all security applications are systematically upgraded across the network; and providing for cyclic upgrades to old software and hardware through the Capital Improvement Program.

Delaware County, Pennsylvania, officials on Wednesday, August 11, 2021, agreed to spend nearly $1.6 million on cybersecurity measures following a ransomware attack last November that cost the county $25,000.

The cash infusion topped off by an additional $858,957 to improve air conditioning, server space and power supply units for the county health department's data center was spurred by an on the county last fall by hackers using the DoppelPaymer ransomware. (Actors affiliated with the DoppelPaymer malware have also in recent years struck at the Illinois attorney general's office; Torrance, California; and Azusa, California.)

The $1.6 million the County Council approved will support 12 new IT positions, including four support jobs, three applications staff, two health department IT staff and three new hires for cybersecurity, audio-visual support and web development.

organization.name: Kokomo Howard County Public Library South Branch

incident.description:
The Kokomo-Howard Public Library (KHCPL) fell victim to a ransomware attack in 2020, costing the government entity nearly $5,000.

A ransomware attack occurred on September 25, 2020 and the situation was reported to the FBI. Kroll, a division of the consulting firm Duff and Phelps, was retained to resolve the situation, which shut down the library and its services for a few days in late September.

According to the report, the investigation determined a 'bad actor' gained access to the library's computer systems and deployed a computer code known as ransomware.

Based on investigations by the consulting firm, the ransomware the library experienced had 'historically and typically been interested in revenue accumulation through ransom payments,' instead of collecting sensitive information, like personal or business data that the library may have in its system.

The firm reported that no personal data, such as patron information, was accessed or acquired by the threat actor.

A negotiation team from the cybersecurity firm Coveware initiated contact with the threat actor, whose initial ransom requested four bitcoin, or approximately $43,000. Coveware was successful in negotiating the number down to 3.36 bitcoin, or $36,000, in exchange for the decryption of the library's software. The team was able to successfully decrypt the library's system and fully restore operations.

KHCPL used its cyber insurance policy to cover costs for the incident. In total, the incident cost the KHCPL $4,848, which was paid out of the library's operating fund.

On December 16, 2020, Matthew Mauser, an individual and as successor in interest to Christina Mauser; Penelope Mauser, a minor, by and through her guardian Matthew Mauser; Thomas Mauser, a minor, by and through his guardian Matthew Mauser; and Ivy Mauser, a minor, by and through her guardian Matthew Mauser (collectively, Plaintiffs) commenced a lawsuit in the Superior Court of the State of California for the County of Los Angeles against County of Los Angeles (County), Los Angeles County Fire Department (LACFD), Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department (LASD), and Sheriff Alex Villanueva (Sheriff Villanueva) (collectively, Defendants).

The claims arise from the January 26, 2020 fatal helicopter crash in the foothills of the Santa Monica mountains in Calabasas, California, wherein unauthorized photographs of human remains were taken, shared and disseminated by Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department deputies for personal, non-law-enforcement purposes.

According to the complaint, Plaintiffs claimed that members of LASD and LACFD improperly took and shared photos of the crash site, including photos that depicted the remains of their loved ones. Plaintiffs alleged that LASD and LACFD personnel violated their constitutional rights to control the death images of their loved ones and their privacy rights, by taking and sharing photos of their loved ones' remains, and that the County is responsible for its employees' actions.

Plaintiffs alleged that they suffered an invasion of privacy, emotional distress, humiliation and anxiety from the realization that photographs of their loved ones were wrongfully taken, shown and discussed.

Plaintiffs sought for compensatory damages, additional general, specific, consequential, or incidental damages in an amount to be proven at trial, punitive damages, nominal damages, costs of suit incurred herein, including attorneys' fees, according to proof, pre-judgment and pre-trial interest, according to proof, and r such other and further relief as this Court may deem just and proper.

On October 12, 2021, Notice of Settlement was filed.

On November 2, 2021, Recommendation to settle the lawsuit was filed. Under the proposed settlement, Plaintiffs would receive $1.25 million. According to attorney Skip Miller, of Miller Barondess, who represents the county, they believe the proposed settlement is reasonable and fair to all concerned.

Plaintiffs allege that LASD and LACFD personnel violated their constitutional rights to control the death images of their loved ones and their privacy rights, by taking and sharing photos of their loved ones' remains, and that the County is responsible for its employees' actions.

Plaintiffs alleged that they suffered an invasion of privacy, emotional distress, humiliation and anxiety from the realization that photographs of their loved ones were wrongfully taken, shown and discussed.

Plaintiffs sought for compensatory damages, additional general, specific, consequential, or incidental damages in an amount to be proven at trial, punitive damages, nominal damages, costs of suit incurred herein, including attorneys' fees, according to proof, pre-judgment and pre-trial interest, according to proof, and r such other and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On November 2, 2021, Recommendation to settle the lawsuit was filed. Under the proposed settlement, Plaintiffs would receive $1.25 million. According to attorney Skip Miller, of Miller Barondess, who represents the county, they believe the proposed settlement is reasonable and fair to all concerned.

On November 30, 2020, Christopher L. Chester, Riley Chester and Hayden Chester (collectively, Plaintiffs) commenced a lawsuit in the U.S District Court for the Central District of California against County of Los Angeles (County), Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department (LASD), Sheriff Alex Villanueva (Sheriff Villanueva), and Los Angeles County Fire Department (LACFD).

The claims arise from the January 26, 2020 fatal helicopter crash in the foothills of the Santa Monica mountains in Calabasas, California, wherein unauthorized photographs of human remains were taken, shared, distributed and showed the photographs of the decedents in circumstances that were unrelated to any investigation of the crash.

The complaint alleges that Sheriff Villanueva, LASD, LACFD and the County acted with deliberate indifference to the constitutional rights of the Plaintiffs through its failure to train and supervise adequately the personnel of both the LASD and LACFD to ensure they do not take or share photos of human remains for personal use; failure to establish a policy or procedure addressing the treatment of human remains, including a strict prohibition on the taking or sharing of photos of human remains; and its failure to investigate adequately and discipline the personnel of both the LASD and LACFD who have unnecessarily taken and/or shared photos of human remains.

Plaintiffs alleged that they suffered an invasion of privacy, emotional distress, humiliation and anxiety from the realization that photographs of their loved ones were wrongfully taken, shown and discussed.

Plaintiffs are claiming a violation of their Fourteenth Amendment rights, negligence, invasion of privacy, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and negligent infliction of emotional distress.

Plaintiffs sought for compensatory damages, additional general, specific, consequential, or incidental damages in an amount to be proven at trial, punitive damages, attorney's fees and costs, prejudgment and post judgment interest, and further relief as the Court deems just and proper.

On May 3, 2021, Plaintiffs filed an amended against County of Los Angeles (County), Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department (LASD), Los Angeles County Fire Department (LACFD), Joey Cruz, Rafael Mejia, Michael Russell, Raul Versales, Arlin Kahan, Brian Jordan and Tony Imbrenda (collectively. Defendants).

On August 13, 2021, Defendant Brian Jordan was dismissed from the case.

On October 21, 2021, a stipulation was filed dismissing R.C. and H.C., who are both minor Plaintiffs.

On August 31, 2022, the Court entered judgement in favor of Plaintiff Chester and against Defendants. Wherein, Defendant Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department will pay an amount of $9,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs. Defendant Los Angeles County Fire Department will pay $6,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs. County of Los Angeles will pay a total of $15,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs.

It is furthered ordered that any post-judgment interest owed by Defendants to Plaintiff Chester shall be computed daily from the date of entry of the judgment until such judgment is paid in full and shall be compounded annually. The judgment is without prejudice to any application for attorney's fees and related nontaxable expenses filed by Plaintiff.

On September 17, 2020, Vanessa Bryant (Plaintiff) filed a complaint against County of Los Angeles, Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, Alex Villanueva, DOES 1-10, inclusive, Los Angeles County Fire Department, Joey Cruz, Rafael Mejia, Michael Russell and Raul Versales (collectively, Defendants) in the Superior Court of the State of California for the County of Los Angeles.

After the January 26 crash, reports surfaced of graphic photos of the victims were being shared. Vanessa Bryant was 'shocked and devastated' by the reports.

The victims died when the helicopter crashed into a hillside in Calabasas, northwest of Los Angeles, during cloudy weather. They were traveling to a youth basketball tournament at Bryant's sports facility in Thousand Oaks. The National Transportation Safety Board has not concluded what caused the crash on the outskirts of Los Angeles County but said there was no sign of mechanical failure in the Sikorsky S-76. helicopter.

Sheriff Alex Villanueva previously told news media that eight deputies took, or shared graphic photos of the scene and he ordered the images deleted. The Los Angeles Times first reported the allegations that the graphic photos had been taken and disseminated in February.

The suit seeks damages for negligence, invasion of privacy and intentional infliction of emotional distress.

On October 19, 2020, the case was removed from the Superior Court to the United States District Court for the Central District of California.

On August 31, 2022, the Court entered judgement in favor of Plaintiff Bryant and against Defendants. Wherein, Defendant Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department will pay an amount of $9,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs. Defendant Los Angeles County Fire Department will pay $6,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs. County of Los Angeles will pay a total of $15,000,000 in damages, plus post-judgment interest at the rate of 3.33%, along with costs.

It is furthered ordered that any post-judgment interest owed by Defendants to Plaintiff Bryant shall be computed daily from the date of entry of the judgment until such judgment is paid in full and shall be compounded annually. The judgment is without prejudice to any application for attorney's fees and related nontaxable expenses filed by Plaintiff.

On February 28, 2023, Plaintiff Bryant amended her complaint.

Accordingly, the Los Angeles County agreed to pay Vanessa Bryant and three of her daughters 28,850,000 to settle all claims and potential claims over the sharing of graphic photos of the January 2020 helicopter crash that killed Plaintiff's husband.

The settlement includes $15,000,000 after a jury awarded Plaintiff in August, with additional funds to settle potential claims from her daughters.

On May 31, 2023, it is hereby stipulated by and between the parties to this action through their designated counsel that the action be and hereby is dismissed.

An employee in the Lucas County Auditor's Office fell victim to an email scam, sending more than $600,000 in public funds to what the employee thought was a construction contractor.

The office discovered the breach and theft on December 2, 2020, Wednesday, and contacted law enforcement as well as financial institutions. The county's goal is to recover the funds through those institutions since they were fraudulently obtained, but it's unclear if the county will recover all that was stolen.

The office's internal system was shut down when the theft was discovered, and all employees were interviewed.

An employee in the office received one or more emails that appeared as invoices from Gerken Companies. Since county contracts are public, scammers can find out who a governmental agency has contracts with and mimic their letterhead or other information to appear legitimate.

The payments, which appear to be about $625,000, were made over a period of two months. The Auditor's Office is reviewing all transactions during that period.

Sedgwick County employee scammed into buying purported gift cards with taxpayer money.

According to according to the Sedgwick County Sheriff's Office, Sedgwick County employee was duped into using $800 in taxpayer money to buy gift cards in a phishing scam.

The email asked the person to buy gift cards to 'recognize employees in the Sedgwick County Public Safety.' According to Lt. Tim Myers, the employee, who works in the Public Safety Department, was on a county computer and used a county credit card to buy four $200 purported gift cards and his personal credit card to purchase another $200 fake gift card.

Several employees received emails asking to 'make various financial transactions'. It was reported to the sheriff's office before noon after it was discovered an employee took the bait.

Sedgwick County employees are not allowed to use county credit cards to purchase gift cards. The employee will be disciplined.

On January 26, 2020, Coventry School District was forced to pay nearly $200,000 to bad actors. Ransomware was used in cyberattack against school. Coventry School District took measures to mitigate future damage.

organization.name: Communications & Power Industries LLC
organization.industry: Radio and Television Broadcasting and Wireless Communications Equipment Manufacturing

incident.description:
A major electronics manufacturer for defense and communications markets was knocked offline after a ransomware attack, TechCrunch has learned. A source with knowledge of the incident told TechCrunch that the defense contractor paid a ransom of about $500,000 shortly after the incident in mid-January, but that the company was not yet fully operational.

California-based Communications & Power Industries (CPI) makes components for military devices and equipment, like radar, missile seekers and electronic warfare technology. The company confirmed the ransomware attack. CPI are working with a third-party forensic investigation firm to investigate the incident. The investigation is ongoing, said CPI spokesperson Amanda Mogin. We have worked with counsel to notify law enforcement and governmental authorities, as well as customers, in a timely manner.

According to the source, a 'domain admin', a user with the highest level of privileges on the network clicked on a malicious link while they were logged in, which triggered the file-encrypting malware. Because the thousands of computers on the network were on the same, unsegmented domain, the ransomware quickly spread to every CPI office, including its on-site backups. The source described the company in 'panic mode,' as only about one-quarter of its computers are back up and running as of the end of February.

Short staffing is hampering the effort, the source said. Some computers containing sensitive military data have been recovered using the decryption key, which the company obtained by paying the ransom. One system is said to have files related to Aegis, a naval weapons system developed by Lockheed Martin

CPI becomes the latest victim in a spate of attacks targeting large companies in the past month.

Tshepang Phohole received a R5.7 million payout of Covid-19 relief from the UIF which was supposed to go to 1,400 workers. Instead, he and his family allegedly defrauded the state and went on massive spending spree.

The UIF payment was originally meant to go to CSG Resources, labour brokerage company, but instead, the funds landed up in Phohole's account.

Thobile Lamati, the directory-general of the labour department informed parliament's standing committee on public accounts on June 26, 2020 that Phohole create a new profile as an employer using CSG'sUIF number and entered his own banking details into the system.

On the day that the money was paid into Phohole's account, he transferred the money into a number of different accounts according to court documents.

R1-million to his father, R980,000 to his sister, R2.3-million to his brother-in-law and R1.25 million to Taetso Zulu. The following 2 days saw the money being exchanged between the accounts. This was an attempt to obfuscate the source of the funds and confuse investigators.

A U.S. travel management firm CWT paid $4.5 million this week to hackers who stole reams of sensitive corporate files and said they had knocked 30,000 computers offline, according to a record of the ransom negotiations seen by Reuters.

The attackers used a strain of ransomware called Ragnar Locker, which encrypts computer files and renders them unusable until the victim pays for access to be restored.

The ensuing negotiations between the hackers and a CWT representative remained publicly accessible in an online chat group, providing a rare insight into the fraught relationship between cyber criminals and their corporate victims.

CWT confirmed the attack but declined to comment on the details of what it said was an ongoing investigation.

CWT said it had immediately informed U.S. law enforcement and European data protection authorities.

The Danish Data Protection Agency has reported Danske Bank to the police and fined the bank DKK 10 million (USD 1,479,800). This follows on from the fact that in November 2020 the Authority initiated a case of its own motion, after the bank itself had stated that they had identified a problem with the deletion of personal data, which there was not necessarily a commercial justification for continuing to process.

In connection with the Danish Data Protection Agency's investigation, it has emerged that the bank in more than 400 systems has not been able to document that rules have been laid down for deletion and storage of personal data, or that manual deletion of personal data has been carried out. These systems process personal data of millions of people.

'One of the basic principles of the GDPR is that you can only process information you need - and when you no longer need it, it must be deleted. When it comes to an organization the size of Danske Bank, which has many and complex systems, it is particularly crucial that you can also document that the deletion actually takes place,' says Kenni Elm Olsen, specialist consultant at the Danish Data Protection Agency.

organization.name: Deloitte Consulting LLP
organization.industry: Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services

incident.description:
On May 21, 2020, Paul Culbertson, William Gibson, Timothy Sylvester (Collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against Deloitte Consulting LLP. The case was brought in relation to Defendant's failure to protect applicants Personal Identifiable Information (PII).

On May 17, 2020, officials from IDES confirmed that IDES was aware of a software 'glitch' in the new PUA system designed and maintained by Defendant that made some private information publicly available for a short time and worked to immediately remedy the situation. On May 18, 2020, officials from CDLE confirmed that it too experienced a data access issue with the new PUA system, which allowed strangers to view applicants' PII. On May 20, 2020, ODJFS notified PUA program claimants by email that a security vulnerability in the PUA system designed and maintained by Deloitte allowed third party access to their names, social security number, and home address. Upon belief, there are approximately 38.6 million individuals filed for unemployment.

Plaintiffs brought the case on behalf of all persons whose personal information was compromised as a result of the PUA portal data breach.

Plaintiffs sought for the action be certified as class, compensatory and punitive damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, attorneys' fees, costs, pre- and post-judgment interest, and further relief the Court deems just and proper.

On June 23, 2020, the Court consolidated the Culbertson, Alexander, Burns, and Neal cases.

On July 24, 2020, Paul Culbertson, Kathy Neal, Kelly Allison-Pickering, Jessica Haiman, Alexander Cabot, Briana Julius, Nichelle Newland, Bernadette Nolen, and Alexandria Polichena, filed a Consolidated Class Action Complaint, asserting thirteen counts against Deloitte Consulting for its alleged failure to protect Plaintiffs' and class members' personally identifiable information.

On August 18, 2021, Plaintiffs and Defendant have agreed to enter into a Settlement Agreement to avoid further burden, expense, and uncertainty of protracted litigation. To settle the case, Defendant will establish a Settlement Fund of $4,950,000, with no right to reversion, that will compensate Eligible Claimants, pay costs of notice and claims administration, and pay Court approved reasonable attorneys' fees and costs and service awards to the class representatives.

On August 30, 2021, Deloitte Consulting LLP's $4,950,000 deal to resolve claims that websites it designed for state employment agencies in Illinois, Ohio, and Colorado were unreasonably vulnerable to security breaches has won preliminary approval. If finally approved, the settlement will release claims for 237,675 people who, between roughly May 18, 2020, and May 21, 2020, received letters notifying them that personal information they supplied to claim pandemic-related unemployment assistance may have been exposed because of a security incident.

In addition to the settlement, Class counsel will receive payment in the amount of $1,649,835 for attorney fees (33.33% of the settlement fund) and $21,091.31 for reimbursement of expenses. Class Representative will also service award in the amount of $2,000 each.

On January 10, 2022, Plaintiff filed a motion for final approval of the class action settlement.

On February 16, 2022, the Court granted the final approval of class action settlement and all motions with regards to the settlement. Accordingly, the Court dismissed the case with prejudice on the merits and without costs to any party or person, except as otherwise provided herein or in the Settlement Agreement. Thus, the case is closed.

On July 28, 2020, David Vaccaro (Plaintiff) individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, filed a class action complaint in the Superior Court of the State of California for the County of Los Angeles against Delta Drugs II, Inc., and Does 1-10 (Defendants) for allegedly invading their privacy.

According to the complaint, in or around June and July of 2020, Defendant placed multiple calls to Plaintiff's cell phone number and during the process, Defendant contacted and communicated with Plaintiff via telephone. During the call, Defendant recorded the calls without ever disclosing to Plaintiff that the call was being recorded. The contents of the call/s between Defendant and Plaintiff were recorded by Defendant were confidential in nature due to the fact that Plaintiff's private medical information was discussed, for which Plaintiff had an expectation of privacy.

Defendant's agent did not inform Plaintiff that the call was being recorded until well into the conversation between the agent and Plaintiff. Plaintiff then explicitly told the agent that he did not consent to be recorded and promptly ended the conversation and also all persons in California whose inbound and outbound telephone conversations were recorded without their consent by Defendants or its agent/s within the one year prior to July 28, 2020.

Plaintiff requested relief against Defendant for actual damages, statutory damages, cost of suit, statutory costs, and attorney fees.

On April 4, 2022, a notice of settlement was filed by Plaintiff. The settlement benefits California residents who placed phone calls to Delta Drugs between Jan. 1, 2020, and May 25, 2022, that were recorded.

On May 25, 2022, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, and the court ordered granting the motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Pursuant to the settlement, Defendant has agreed to pay $300,000, to resolve claims it recorded phone calls with California residents without consent. It was anticipated that after the deduction of attorneys fees, costs, administration expenses, and service awards, there will be $130,000 in residual class member settlement benefits to be distributed to claimant Class Members.

On January 19, 2021, Ursula Lenhardt (Plaintiff) filed a complaint against Democratic Party HQ, Joseph Biden, Barack Obama, Elizabeth Warren, Hillary Clinton and Kamala Harris (Defendants) in the United States District Court for the District of Kansas. The action arises out of Defendants' alleged violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

On March 29, 2021, Plaintiff filed an amended complaint.

According to the amended complaint, within the last year before the presidential elections of November 3, 2020, Plaintiff received about 300 of these unwanted auto-dialed text-messages from Defendants to her cell-phone number. Plaintiff had to delete the first 200 in order to have space on her cellular phone for her own private use, but Defendants continued to send these messages requesting Plaintiff to donate for, to volunteer for, or to vote for the Democratic Party. When the election day was near, Plaintiff received an increased amount of these unwanted messages, causing her cellular phone to be blocked for some days. Plaintiff could not open it anymore and was not able to make an urgently needed private phone call. Defendants did not have any established business and was never a member or customer or a voter of Defendants. In addition, Defendants did not have prior express consent from Plaintiff to receive unsolicited text-messages. As a result of Defendants' conduct, Plaintiff was harmed, her privacy was invaded and suffered emotional distress. The foregoing acts and omissions of Defendants constituted numerous violations of the TCPA.

Plaintiff sought for statutory damages, treble damages and all other relief that the Court deems just and proper.

On October 28, 2021, a motion for default judgement was filed requesting the Court to enter judgement in favor for Plaintiff.

On January 12, 2022, the Court entered judgement against Defendants awarding Plaintiff in the amount of $60,000, plus post-judgment interest. Plaintiff may also apply to recover costs by complying with the procedure for filing a bill of costs.

On January 6, 2022, Niki Paras, Regina Rosario, Jennifer Sillah, Christian Stephens, Evelyn Wallace, and Tanya Wildrick (Plaintiffs) on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated, filed a class action complaint in the State Court of Fulton County State of Georgia against Dental care Alliance LLC (Defendant or DCA) for allegedly violating the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).

According to the complaint, on or about October 11, 2020, Defendant became aware of a cybersecurity incident on its network. In order to obtain dental health care services or employment, Plaintiffs and other individuals provided Private Information to their respective dental practices and employers, including patient names, addresses, dental diagnoses, treatment information, account numbers, billing information, bank account numbers, and health insurance data and employee names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, Employee Identification numbers, and financial account numbers.

Defendant engaged a cybersecurity firm to investigate the incident. The investigation then determined that for nearly a month between September 18, 2020, and October 13, 2020, there had been unauthorized activity on Defendant's network and that confidential files belonging to 1 million patients had been accessed.

Plaintiff requested relief against Defendant for compensatory damages, nominal damages, statutory damages, and statutory penalties, in an amount to be determined, as allowable by law, an award of attorney's fees, and costs, and any other expense, including expert witness fees and such other and further relief as this court may deem just and proper.

On July 27, 2022, Plaintiffs reached a settlement with Defendant, pursuant to Plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement, and Defendant has agreed to pay $3,000,000 million to settlement on this class action lawsuit. The settlement benefits individuals who were notified of the Dental Care Alliance data breach from September 2020 to April 2021.

DCA has agreed not to object to a request by Class Counsel for attorneys' fees, inclusive of any costs and expenses of the Litigation, subject to Court approval, in an amount not to exceed $850,000.00. Class Counsel, in their sole discretion, shall allocate and distribute any number of attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses awarded by the Court among themselves.

Subject to Court approval, DCA has agreed not to object to a request for a service award in the amount of $1,500 to each named Plaintiff (for a total payment of $9,000).

organization.name: Cosmote Mobile Telecommunications Single Member S.A.

incident.description:
On January 27, 2022, the Hellenic Data Protection Authority (DPA) fined Cosmote Mobile Telecommunications S.A. a total of EUR 6,000,000 for violations of the General Data Protection Regulation.

Greece's telecoms operator Cosmote said the telephone data of thousands of Greek citizens have reportedly been stolen in a massive hacking operation that took place from September 1 to 5, 2021, through the OTE telecommunications network.

This file contained details of the calls made or received by mobile subscribers during those five days, specifically the phone number, the day and time of the call and its duration. Names were not included. The list also included information on the device type, the International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), the age, gender, average revenue per user (ARPU), base station coordinates and mobile subscriber program.

The Hellenic DPA investigated the circumstances under which the breach took place and examined the lawfulness of record-keeping in relation to leaked data, as well as the security measures applied. The investigation revealed that Cosmote infringed the principle of legality on the protection of personal data, privacy in the electronic communication sector, and transparency due to the provision of unclear and insufficient information to subscribers.

The complainant received unsolicited emails from the controller Magyar Telekom Plc., a hungarian telecommunications company. After the receipt of such emails, the complainant requested the controller to delete his email address several times.

The controller continued to send unsolicited messages and required the complainant to register on its webpage to unsubscribe from its newsletter. However, the complainant was unable to unsubscribe from the newsletter since the website asked for customer data, that the complainant (not a customer of the company) could not provide.

The controller argued that the availability of the contact data of the complainant was an individual mistake due to an unknown third party providing their email address. It was therefore not caused by any inadequate internal policies or processes.

The Hungarian DPA found that the controller had not confirmed the entitlement of the third-party data provider to use the complainant's data. Moreover, it was the controller's decision to introduce unnecessary obstacles to unsubscribe from their newsletter. In this regard, the controller only deleted the email address after being informed about the DPA's investigation. The DPA hold, that the controller failed to implement measures to facilitate the exercise of data subject rights and fined them approximately 28,000 (10,000,000 HUF) for violating Articles 12 and 25 GDPR.

On December 1, 2020, Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) (Plaintiff) filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against DMB Financial LLC (Defendant) on grounds allegedly violating the Telemarketing Sales Rule (TSR) and the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 (CFPA).

On May 17, 2021, CFPB announced that it entered into a proposed settlement of its lawsuit against debt settlement company DMB Financial, LLC (DMB), alleging that the company engaged in deceptive acts or practices in violation of the TSR and the CFPA. The proposed order would impose a judgment of $7,700,000 against DMB, which would be suspended upon its paying $5,400,000 in restitution to consumers.

CFPB alleged that DMB engaged in deceptive acts or practices in conjunction with its fees and disclosures, violating both the TSR and the CFPA. To support this claim, the CFPB alleged that DMB represented to consumers that they would not charge fees for services until settlement payment was made to a creditor yet collected fees in cases where there was either no settlement or the consumer did not make a settlement payment.

DMB requested and received fees based on consumers' debt amounts at a point in time after their program enrollment, instead of the debt amount at the time of enrollment.

DMB failed to disclose in a clear and conspicuous manner, prior to enrollment, of the time frame by which DMB would make a bona fide settlement offer to a consumer's creditors.

DMB's employees also have initiated phone calls to prospective customers in at least 24 states to persuade them to enroll in its debt-settlement programs.

In addition to paying monetary relief, DMB must refrain from the deceptive acts or practices alleged in the complaint regarding fees and disclosures and may not use or obtain a consumer's credit report unless for an authorized purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

On May 19, 2021, the case was terminated, and the court has enforced an order.

organization.name: Axion Network Limited
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
Axion Network launched its new token, AXN, on November 2, 2020. However, its price crashed down as soon as it went live due to a suspected exploit. According to their Telegram channel, Axion Network's COO reported this was due to a minting exploit in the contract with regards to staking, adding that $500K has been stolen.

'Do not buy AXN right now, do not interact with the dashboard.'

The token, as claimed by Axion Network, was not some utility token or an attempt at replacing fiat currencies. It was launched as an investment vehicle that was aimed at one of the biggest untapped markets left in the crypto world: mainstream income investors.

On May 15, 2020, a complaint was filed by Danish Data Protection Authority (Datatilsynet) (Plaintiff) against JobTeam A/S (Defendant) for violating the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Plaintiff considers that in a case on the right of access, Defendant has not complied with the basic requirements of the (GDPR) that personal data must be processed legally, reasonably and transparently. When a data controller deletes information about the citizen in immediate connection with a request for insight not being granted, the data controller unlawfully cuts off the citizen the opportunity to verify whether he or she has the right to access the information at Plaintiff and the courts. It is a violation of the citizen's fundamental rights and is not an expression of good data processing practice.

Plaintiff has decided to report Defendant to the police and recommends that a claim be filed that the company be fined.

Defendant has been reported to the police and set a fine of DKK 50,000 ($7,929.18). The company had deleted personal information covered by a register's request for insight in the period after the request was made and before the company responded.

organization.name: Easy Healthcare Corporation
organization.industry: Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On January 21, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Jane Doe (Plaintiff) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division against Easy Healthcare Corporation (Defendant).

According to the complaint, Defendant is one of the largest on-line providers of home and workplace healthcare products selling various devices such as thermometers, oximeters, pregnancy tests, drug tests, etc. As part of its business operations, Defendant created and offers an application ('app') for PEDs called 'Premom'4 on the internet and various on-line stores (e.g., Google Play, Apple's App Store) for persons such as the Plaintiff to download free of cost. This app acts as an ovulation tracker, period calendar, and fertility tool. Purchasers of Defendant's healthcare products, like Plaintiff, are encouraged to utilize Defendant's Premom app. Also, users of Defendant's Premom app are solicited to purchase Defendant's healthcare products to assist in their fertility.

Sometime during February 2020, Plaintiff Jane Doe downloaded the Defendant's Premom app onto her One-Plus PED using the Android operating software system while in Virginia and began using this app. Plaintiff had learned about the Premom app when she was purchasing online healthcare products offered by Defendant. Like all others downloading Defendant's Premom app on their PEDs, once this app was downloaded by Plaintiff, the Plaintiff and Defendant entered into and agreed to a 'Terms of Service Agreement' (hereafter 'TSA') provided by Defendant. The TSA or Privacy Policy was drafted solely by the Defendant with no input from Plaintiff or other Premom app users. These agreements emanated from Defendant's Illinois location and were posted on its website and Premom app from there. In this Privacy Policy, the Plaintiff and other app users provide express consent to Defendant to collect, use, and disclose their personal information, but only in the manner described in the Privacy Policy. In the Privacy Policy, the Defendant further states 'you explicitly consent to the following use by us and disclosure by us of your information. When it comes to sharing Plaintiff and other Premom app users' Personal Data, the Privacy Policy II states that Defendant will only 'share Personal Data when we have your consent.

On or soon after August 20, 2020, Plaintiff learned that Defendant had been sharing her and other Premom App users' personal information and location data from their Android operating software system PEDs with three Chinese entities. This data sharing began as of the Premom app's availability for download in 2017. This was being done in secrecy without Plaintiff or other Premom app users' knowledge and consent and in violation of Defendant's Privacy Policies. Three Chinese entities were formed and are located in China. These entities store all the Premom app users' data set forth herein on servers located in China. Under Chinese law, all of this data is accessible by the People's Republic of China, and in turn the Communist Party of China. Defendant deceived the Plaintiff and other Premom app users because, unknowing to them, it directly worked with these three Chinese entities prior to launching the Premom app. Plaintiff estimates that the proposed class includes at least 50,000 persons.

Plaintiff sought for damages, judgment, costs and attorneys' fees, punitive damages and all further relief as the court deems just and equitable.

On May 16, 2023, Plaintiff filed an Unopposed Motion for Preliminary Approval of Stipulation of Settlement Agreement and Release.

On August 23, 2023, an order granting conditional class certification & preliminary approval of stipulation of settlement was granted by the court.

Easy Healthcare agreed to pay $750,000 to resolve claims that it shared Premom app user information with third parties without first getting consent.

The settlement benefits consumers who are registered to use Easy Healthcare's Premom app on their Android or iOS smartphones, tablets or laptops and who purchased a new device due to privacy concerns.

According to the class action lawsuit, the Premom app shared personal information and device data with third parties without user consent. The app allegedly shared advertising IDs, router IDs, serial numbers and other device data, forcing consumers to get entirely new devices or routers in order to keep their information private.

On November 13, 2023, deadline for exclusion and objection.

On December 20, 2023, schedule for hearing for the settlement final approval.

organization.name: Emac Professional Srl Pasta Concept & Equipement

incident.description:
On June 5, 2021, the complaint presented to the Authority by Mr. XX against against E-Mac Professional srl (hereinafter 'the Company'), an application aimed at obtaining access to all personal data for which it is processing, a copy of the same and all the information provided for links, copies or reproductions of personal data relating to the processing in progress.

The complainant also specified that he had purchased products from the Company and that, in the context of the controversy that subsequently arose, the latter 'recalled personal data referring to Mr. XX, of which the latter requested an account through the request in question'. However, the request, duly notified to the Company on October 7, 2020, was not found within the terms. With the note dated January 7, 2021, the Office invited the Company to provide observations on what is represented in the complaint and to comply with the complainant's requests.

The Company, with a note dated July 15, 2021, produced a copy of the information from which to infer the main information relating to the treatments put in place and confirmed to be in possession of the personal data referring to the complainant, undertaking to 'prepare the necessary material as soon as possible by charging a fee', this is because 'the request of the interested party is manifestly unfounded and aimed at causing damage to the company.

In the same note, the Company communicated to the Authority and to the complainant the categories of personal data being processed, including data relating to Mr. XX consisting of name and surname, e-mail address and telephone number, and data relating to the commercial activity exercised by them including headquarters and company name.

On April 7, 2022, E-Mac Professional srl pay the sum of EUR 10,000.00 ($10,902.10) as a pecuniary administrative sanction.

Between May 2020 and January 2021, Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others throughout the world by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

When RCMP searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

On February 1, 2022, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Endoceutics Inc. in the amount of $72,503.43.

On November 16, 2020, DJO Global, Inc. (DJO) learned that an attacker staged and likely exfiltrated a limited amount of data from DJO's systems. DJO investigated and reviewed the affected data and learned on November 25, 2020 that some personal information was affected.

Based on the investigation, DJO understand that this activity occurred between November 8, 2020 and November 9, 2020. The personal information within the exfiltrated files varies by individual and it includes Name, Social Security number, driver's license number or other government-issued identification number, medical or health insurance information, benefits enrollment information, health care claims information, financial account/payment card information, birth or marriage certificate, digital/electronic signature, work-related evaluations, and date of birth.

In response to the incident, DJO have further reviewed and strengthened their data security measures to protect against further incidents.

On January 21, 2021, DJO submitted a proof of losses, costs and expenses amounting to $6,143,777.

On May 13, 2021, Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data (GPDP) imposed a fine of 20,000 ($20,078.8) against Synlab Med srl. On May 19, 2020, Dr. XX sent positive reports of 32 interested parties, of which 31 do not belong to the same ASL XX, due to a mere clerical error. The proof that it was a mere material error, however isolated, is that on that day the anomaly occurred only the ASL XX, which received both the documentation of its competence and that relating to the other ASLs. At the e-mail addresses communicated by the Region belonging to the other territorial ASLs, only the positive reports of the interested parties correctly related to each individual territorial ASL were sent, without therefore sharing with the ASLs any type of health documentation not within their competence.

Dr. XX was verbally reminded by Synlab to pay the utmost attention in observing the privacy procedures of Synlab as well as those communicated by the ASL with reference to the execution of the Tests and the transmission of the related reports. In relation to the results of the investigation, the Office produce defensive writings or documents to the Guarantor or to ask to be heard by the Authority. With a note dated on October 27, 2020, the Company sent its defense briefs, which additional elements were represented that they became aware of the fact only after receiving the request for information from the Authority, will provide for the execution of targeted training in relation to the processing of health data to its laboratory staff by 31 December 2020, has already scheduled the execution of a targeted audit at the laboratory of the Faenza headquarters, the place where the material error occurred, by 31 December 2020.

Taking into account the statements made by the data controller during the investigation and considering that, unless the fact constitutes a more serious crime, anyone, in a proceeding before the Guarantor, falsely declares or certifies information o circumstances o produces false deeds or documents is liable pursuant to art. For these reasons, the unlawfulness of the processing of personal data carried out by the Company Synlab Med Srl under the terms set out in the motivation, for violation of articles 5, par. 2, lett. a) and c) and 9 of the Regulations, as well as art. 2 sexies of the Code.

The Guarantor for the protection of personal data ordered Synlab Med Srl to pay the sum of 20,000 ($20,078.8) as a fine for the violations indicated in the provision.

A leading supplier of video delivery software solutions is reportedly the latest victim of the Sodinokibi Ransomware, who has posted images of data they claim to have stolen from the company during a cyberattack.

SeaChange International, Inc., a Waltham, Massachusets company with locations in Poland and Brazil, is an on-premises or remotely managed video-on-demand and streaming platform provider. In an update to their data leak site, Sodinokibi (REvil) has created a new victim page for SeaChange where they have published images of some of the documents that they have stolen during an alleged attack. These images include a screenshot of folders on a server they claim to have had access to, a bank statement, insurance certificates, a driver's license, and a cover letter for a proposal for a Pentagon video-on-demand service.

BleepingComputer learned of the attack on SeaChange's servers during April 20, 2020 when a ransomware gang named REvil (aka Sodinokibi) posted screenshots of files they claimed to have stolen from the company's servers. A cover letter with a Pentagon video-on-demand service proposal was found among those screenshots. The incident occurred on April 17, 2020 to April 20, 2020.

According to SeaChange's SEC filing, as of April 30, 2020, they have recorded a loss contingency of $0.8 million within accrued expenses. At April 30, 2020, SeaChange also recorded a corresponding receivable for expected insurance recovery proceeds of $0.8 million included within prepaid expenses and other current assets.

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On July 1, 2020, EyeMed Vision Care LLC (EyeMed) discovered that an unauthorized individual gained access to an EyeMed email mailbox and sent phishing emails to email addresses contained in the mailbox's address book. EyeMed took immediate action to block the unauthorized individual's access to the mailbox and secured the mailbox. EyeMed immediately launched an investigation into the incident and engaged a cybersecurity firm to assist in its efforts.

It was determined that the unauthorized individual first gained access to the mailbox on June 24, 2020, and that access terminated on July 1, 2020. The mailbox contained information about individuals who formerly or currently receive vision benefits through EyeMed.

This contained information such as full name, address, date of birth, phone number, email address, vision insurance account/identification number, health insurance account/identification number, Medicaid or Medicare number, driver's license or other government identification number, passport number, full or partial social security number, birth or marriage certificate, medical diagnoses and conditions, treatment information, and financial information.

Although EyeMed could not fully determine if any personal information were viewed or acquired by the unauthorized individual. EyeMed initially notified Covered Entity of possible impact on July 30, 2020 and confirmed impact to Covered Entity's members on August 14, 2020.

On January 24, 2022, EyeMed shall pay to the State of New York Six Hundred Thousand Dollars ($600,000).

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
EyeMed reported a Cybersecurity Event to the Department on October 9, 2020. EyeMed discovered that an unauthorized individual gained access to an email account used by EyeMed to process enrollment on July 1, 2020, when phishing emails were sent to the email addresses contained in the Mailbox's address book. The Mailbox was used internally and externally by some EyeMed group clients to communicate. Nine EyeMed employees shared access to the Mailbox using the same username and password. EyeMed immediately blocked the unauthorized access upon discovery of the incident, launched an investigation, and retained outside breach counsel.

The intrusion, which lasted from June 24, 2020, until July 1, 2020, allowed the threat actor access to, and the ability to view, emails and attachments containing consumer non-public information (NPI) dating back six years prior to the attack. The investigation was not able to determine how the unauthorized individual gained access to the Mailbox, but EyeMed believes that it was likely a result of a successful phishing scheme. The investigation confirmed that the threat actor had the ability to exfiltrate the documents and information within the Mailbox during the time that the threat actor was accessing the account. On September 28, 2020, EyeMed began to notify the affected individuals and file regulatory notices.

The Superintendent of Financial Services Adrienne A.
