Harris announced on October 18, 2022, that EyeMed Vision Care LLC ('EyeMed') will pay a $4.5 million penalty to New York State for violations of DFS's Cybersecurity Regulation that contributed to the exposure of hundreds of thousands of consumers' sensitive, non-public, personal health data, including data concerning minors.

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On May 16, 2023, Matthew J. Platkin, Attorney General of New Jersey announced a $2.5-million multi-state settlement with EyeMed Vision Care (EyeMed) that resolves an investigation into a data breach that compromised the personal and medical information of approximately 2.1 million people, including more than 52,000 from New Jersey.

The investigation found deficiencies in EyeMed's data security program that contributed to the breach in violation of state consumer protection and personal information protection laws and the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Among other security lapses, several EyeMed employees were sharing a single password to an email account used by EyeMed employees to communicate sensitive consumer information, including information related to vision benefits enrollment and coverage, to EyeMed clients.

An unauthorized user gained access to the EyeMed email account on June 24, 2020, exposing approximately six years of personal and medical information, including Social Security numbers, full names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, vision insurance account/identification numbers, medical diagnoses and conditions, and treatment information. After the unauthorized user gained access, approximately 2,000 phishing emails were sent from the compromised email account.

Under the settlement, EyeMed has agreed to implement additional privacy and security measures to improve the protection of consumers' information.

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On May 17, 2023, Attorney General Ellen Rosenblum announced that the State of Oregon has joined a $2.5 million multi-state settlement that resolves an investigation into a data breach that compromised the personal and medical information of approximately 2.1 million people, including more than 11,000 Oregonians. Oregon will receive $750,000 from the settlement.

An unauthorized user gained access to the EyeMed email account in June 2020, exposing approximately six years of personal and medical information, including Social Security numbers, full names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, vision insurance account/identification numbers, medical diagnoses and conditions, and treatment information. After the unauthorized user gained access, approximately 2,000 phishing emails were sent from the compromised email account.

The multi-state investigation found problems in EyeMed's data security program, which contributed to the breach in violation of state laws and the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA).

Under the settlement, EyeMed has agreed to implement additional privacy and security measures to improve the protection of consumers' information, including continuing to develop, implement, and maintain a written Information Security Program that will comply with applicable laws and regulations, maintaining reasonable policies and procedures governing its collection, use, and retention of patient information, etc.

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On May 16, 2023, the Attorney General of New Jersey along with 3 states including Florida, announced a $2.5 million multi-state settlement with EyeMed Vision Care (EyeMed) that resolves an investigation into a data breach that compromised the personal and medical information of approximately 2.1 million people.

The investigation found deficiencies in EyeMed's data security program that contributed to the breach in violation of state consumer protection and personal information protection laws and the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Among other security lapses, several EyeMed employees were sharing a single password to an email account used by EyeMed employees to communicate sensitive consumer information, including information related to vision benefits enrollment and coverage, to EyeMed clients.

An unauthorized user gained access to the EyeMed email account on June 24, 2020, exposing approximately six years of personal and medical information, including Social Security numbers, full names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, vision insurance account/identification numbers, medical diagnoses and conditions, and treatment information. After the unauthorized user gained access, approximately 2,000 phishing emails were sent from the compromised email account.

Under the settlement, EyeMed has agreed to implement additional privacy and security measures to improve the protection of consumers' information. EyeMed will comply with the state Consumer Protection Acts, the state Personal Information Protection Acts, and the federal HIPAA law. Continuing to develop, implement, and maintain a written Information Security Program that will comply with applicable laws and regulations. Maintaining appropriate controls to manage access to all accounts that receive and transmit sensitive information, including, but not limited to, instituting appropriate authentication measures, etc.

organization.name: Eyemed Vision Care LLC
organization.industry: Direct Health and Medical Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On May 16, 2023, the Attorney General of New Jersey along with 3 states including Pennsylvania, announced a $2.5 million multi-state settlement with EyeMed Vision Care (EyeMed) that resolves an investigation into a data breach that compromised the personal and medical information of approximately 2.1 million people.

The investigation found deficiencies in EyeMed's data security program that contributed to the breach in violation of state consumer protection and personal information protection laws and the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). Among other security lapses, several EyeMed employees were sharing a single password to an email account used by EyeMed employees to communicate sensitive consumer information, including information related to vision benefits enrollment and coverage, to EyeMed clients.

An unauthorized user gained access to the EyeMed email account on June 24, 2020, exposing approximately six years of personal and medical information, including Social Security numbers, full names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, vision insurance account/identification numbers, medical diagnoses and conditions, and treatment information. After the unauthorized user gained access, approximately 2,000 phishing emails were sent from the compromised email account.

Under the settlement, EyeMed has agreed to implement additional privacy and security measures to improve the protection of consumers' information. EyeMed will comply with the state Consumer Protection Acts, the state Personal Information Protection Acts, and the federal HIPAA law. Continuing to develop, implement, and maintain a written Information Security Program that will comply with applicable laws and regulations. Maintaining appropriate controls to manage access to all accounts that receive and transmit sensitive information, including, but not limited to, instituting appropriate authentication measures, and more.

Evanston Township High School (ETHS) officials got scammed out of more than $48,000 during a months long data breach that also exposed the personal information of more than 1,100 Illinois residents.

The fraudulent payment was reported to Evanston police, and the data breach was disclosed to the Illinois Attorney General's Office.

District officials reported the payment of a fake vendor's invoice to police on June 5, 2020. ETHS Chief Financial Officer Mary Rodino called police to report that someone had 'hacked' the email address of David Futransky, the district's executive director of alumni relations and senior director of institutional advancement.

Futransky's email account sent an invoice dated April 13, 2020 requesting a $48,570 payment as a 'professional fee' for a 'Detailed analysis of current situation and development for Evanston Township High School' to Development Specialist Karen Jones, who works under Futransky in the district's alumni department.

The invoice was received on May 22, paid on May 29, and discovered to be fraudulent on June 4, 2020. The invoice was paid out and did not raise any red flags because ETHS employees work remotely and the Information Technology Department at ETHS confirmed the hack.

An internal district investigation found that 10 email accounts were accessed without authorization between March 17, 2020, and June 14, 2020, according to a legally required data breach notification sent to the attorney general's office on behalf of the district.

Evaston determined that an email or attachment contained personal information that includes Social Security Number, driver's license number, financial account number, payment card number, username and password for an online account and some medical or health insurance information -- had been exposed to potential hackers during the breach.

On October 16, 2020, Plaintiff Cheryl Gaston filed a class action complaint individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated in the US District Court for the Central District of California, Los Angeles against Defendant FabFitFun, Inc.

Defendant's technical team recently discovered that an unauthorized third party inserted malicious code on portions of our website that may have enabled them to capture certain information in connection with customer sign ups. Based on their forensic investigation, this incident concerns the new member sign up pages of their website during the period between April 26, 2020 and May 14, 2020, and between May 22, 2020 and August 3, 2020.

The incident would have involved emails and Defendant passwords for customers that signed up using PayPal or Apple Pay. For customers using credit or debit cards, the information involved would also have included name, address, payment card account number, card expiration date, and card verification code. Please note that because we do not collect highly sensitive personal information like Social Security Numbers, this type of information was not affected by this incident. There are hundreds of thousands affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On January 26, 2021, the parties have reached a settlement.

On January 29, 2021, Plaintiff amended her complaint adding Renate Garrison as Plaintiff.

On February 19, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Wherein, Defendant has agreed to pay and create a Settlement Fund of $625,000, which shall be paid for al individuals settlement payments to class members, attorneys' fees and costs, claims referee fees, service awards, and settlement administration costs.

As per the settlement's terms, Class Members will have the option to of claiming on of three basic awards or a reimbursement award of up to $5,000. Tier 1 Basic awards will initially be set at $55 for the approximately 130,293 class members. Tier 2 will initially be set at $25 for the approximately 68,807 class members. And Tier 3 will be initially set at $12 for approximately 245,000 class members.

In addition, a service award will be given to class representatives in the total amount of $10,000. Plaintiffs' counsel will receive attorneys' fees in the amount of $156,250 plus $10,000 as reimbursement for reasonable costs. An identified sum for claims referee and $83,720 in settlement administration costs.

On April 2, 2021, the preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On September 3, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement.

On December 6, 2021, the Court approved the Final Approval of Class Action Settlement.

On December 27, 2021, the Court closed and terminated the case.

A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Finance Giant Ltd for sending unsolicited direct marketing messages.

Between 1 and 30 November 2020, Finance Giant Ltd instigated the sending of a confirmed total of 505,759 unsolicited direct marketing messages that were received by subscribers' contrary to regulation 22 of PECR.

On April 13, 2022, Finance Giant Ltd has been fined GBP 48,000 (62,477.3 USD) by the ICO.

Miklos Daniel Brody was sentenced to 24 months in prison on December 11, 2023 for a network intrusion and for making false statements to a government agency.

Brody worked as a cloud engineer for a bank headquartered in San Francisco until March 11, 2020, when he was fired for violating company policy. Later that evening, and continuing into the following morning, Brody used his company-issued laptop, which he failed to return upon being fired, to access the bank's computer network without authorization and to cause substantial damage. Among other things, Brody deleted the bank's code repositories, ran a malicious script to delete logs, left taunts within the bank's code for former colleagues, and impersonated other bank employees by opening sessions in their names. He also emailed himself proprietary bank code that he had worked on as an employee, which was valued at over $5,000.

FRB estimates that the total cost of this damage exceeded $220,000. The damage breakdown and personnel costs associated with repair are direct personnel cost $72,622; indirect/idled personnel cost $145,200; and mac-book pro (2018 Touch Bar) $2,799.

In addition to sentencing Brody to prison, Judge Orrick ordered him to pay restitution totaling $529,266.37.

Miklos Daniel Brody (Brody) was sentenced to 24 months in prison on December 11, 2023 for a network intrusion and for making false statements to a government agency.

Brody worked as a cloud engineer for San Francisco-based First Republic Bank (FRB) until March 11, 2020, when he was fired for violating company policy. Later that evening, and continuing into the following morning, Brody used his company-issued laptop, which he failed to return upon being fired, to access the bank's computer network without authorization and to cause substantial damage.

Among other things, Brody deleted the bank's code repositories, ran a malicious script to delete logs, left taunts within the bank's code for former colleagues, and impersonated other bank employees by opening sessions in their names.

FRB estimates that the total cost of this damage exceeded $220,000. The damage breakdown and personnel costs associated with repair are direct personnel cost $72,622; indirect/idled personnel cost $145,200; and mac-book pro (2018 Touch Bar) $2,799.

On March 30, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Grace Beyer (Plaintiff) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against Flagstar Bancorp, Inc. and Accellion, Inc., (collectively, Defendants).

On December 23, 2020, Defendant Accellion confirmed to numerous clients that it experienced a massive security breach whereby criminals were able to gain access to sensitive client data via a vulnerability in its FTA platform. According to reports, the criminals exploited as many as four vulnerabilities in Defendant Accellion's FTA to steal sensitive data files associated with up to 300 of Defendant Accellion's clients, including corporations, law firms, banks, universities, and other entities.

On March 5, 2021, Defendant Flagstar publicly confirmed that the Personal Information of Defendant Flagstar customers was compromised in the Data Breach, by releasing a statement on its website. On its webpage dedicated to the Defendant Accellion breach, Defendant Flagstar provides scant details regarding the Data Breach.

Defendant Flagstar has confirmed that it has stopped using Defendant Accellion's jeopardized FTA services, but unfortunately for Plaintiff and Class members, the damage is already done. On information and belief, Defendant Flagstar failed to make the switch to kiteworks and knowingly continued to use FTA, exposing its customers' (and potentially employees') Personal Information to the risk of theft, identity theft, and fraud. The harm caused to Plaintiff and Class members by the Data Breach is already apparent. The Data Breach creates a heightened security concern for Plaintiff and Class members because SSNs and other banking and tax information was potentially disclosed.

Despite the known risk of data breaches and the widespread publicity and industry alerts regarding other notable (similar) data breaches, Defendants failed to take reasonable steps to adequately protect Defendant Accellion's FTA from being breached and to properly phase out the unsecure FTA platform, leaving Defendant Accellion's clients and its clients' customers and employees exposed to risk of fraud and identity theft. Upon information and belief, classes appear to include many thousands of members who are geographically dispersed.

Plaintiff sought for actual and statutory damages, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses and such other favorable relief as allowable under law or at equity.

On August 2, 2021, Plaintiff filed a notice of settlement.

On September 3, 2021, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Defendant agreed to pay $5,900,000.

organization.name: Flosports, Inc.
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
On September 13, 2022, a class action lawsuit was filed by Christopher J. Fiorentino (Plaintiff) on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated against FloSports, Inc. (Defendant or FloSports) in the US District Court for the District of Massachusetts in violation of the Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA).

According to the complaints, FloSports installed Facebook Pixel, thus making the knowing choice to track subscribers' PII and send it to Facebook. FloSports allows consumers to become digital subscribers to its streaming-video platform and content through its website. To subscribe, the consumer must provide his or her name, email address, billing address, and credit- or debit-card information. After completing the subscription process and gaining access to Defendant's videos, FloSports discloses to Facebook, through Facebook Pixel, the FID of the subscriber and the specific video the subscriber viewed. Defendant knew that the Facebook Pixel disclosed PII to Facebook.

Plaintiff Christopher J. Fiorentino is a FloSports subscriber and is a Facebook user. He subscribed to FloSports beginning in 2021. Plaintiff consistently paid FloSports a subscription during his subscription period and had a Facebook account during the time he was a FloSports subscriber. Mr. Fiorentino requested or obtained video content through his FloSports subscription, including but not limited to while logged into his Facebook account, in the two years preceding the filing of this action. FloSports disclosed to Facebook Mr. Fiorentino's FID coupled with the title of the videos he requested or obtained and the URLs to access those videos.

By disclosing Plaintiff's and Class members' PII, FloSports violated Plaintiff's and Class members statutorily protected right to privacy in their video-watching habits.

Plaintiff sought for award Plaintiff and Class members liquidated damages they are entitled to under the VPPA; award Plaintiff and Class members pre- and post-judgment interest; award Plaintiff and Class members reasonable litigation expenses and attorneys' fees as permitted by law; and such other and further relief as the Court deems necessary and appropriate.

On July 26, 2023, Plaintiff filed an unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the proposed Settlement, FloSports will create a $2.625 million non-reversionary cash fund for the benefit of the Settlement Class. Class Counsel may also seek a Service Award of up to $2,000.00 for the Class Representative for his service in helping to bring and settle the case.

On August 23, 2023, the court issued an order granting preliminary approval.

On December 6, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On March 5, 2024, the court issued a final judgment. Accordingly, the court has ordered that the payment of attorneys' fees and costs in the aggregate amount of $875,000. The court also approved the service award to the Class Representative in the amount of $2,000. Defendant will pay $2,625,000 to the class who are Facebook users that signed up for access to FloSports' services, and requested or obtained any prerecorded videos available on any FloSports website, during September 13, 2020 through August 23, 2023.

On April 21, 2021, the Italian data protection authority (Garante) has imposed a fine of EUR 15,000 on Tor Vergata Polyclinic Foundation in Rome for the unlawful processing of personal data violating the Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

In February 2020, a data subject filed a complaint with Garante alleging a breach of data protection laws in relation to the booking services for medical specialists offered by the controller. In order to book a relevant appointment on the booking portal, visitors had to fill out an online form in which various personal data was requested.

As the DPA found, the controller had not implemented adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the protection of data processing. In addition, the controller did not comply with its information obligations pursuant to Art. 13 GDPR, as it had not properly informed the data subjects about the processing of their personal data at the time of the data collection.

The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) announced, on June 28, 2023, that it had issued an enforcement notice to Fortis Insolvency Limited and a monetary penalty notice, in which it fined the same 30,000 for violation of the Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003 (PECR).

In particular, the ICO stated that between July 26, 2020, and July 26, 2021, there were 527,481 direct marketing SMS messages received by subscribers, with a total of 558,354 direct marketing messages sent without valid consent, whereby the data used to send marketing messages had been captured by third party websites. Additionally, the ICO specified that this had come to its attention through its analysis of '7726 data', whereby mobile users can report the receipt of unsolicited marketing text messages to the Mobile UK's Spam Reporting Service by forwarding the message to 7726 (spelling out 'SPAM').

Notably, the ICO imposed the aforementioned fine on Fortis Insolvency and instructed the same to neither transmit, nor instigate, the transmission of unsolicited communications for the purposes of direct marketing by means of electronic mail, unless the recipient of the electronic mail has previously notified it of their consent to such communications being sent by, or at the instigation of, the company, within 30 days of the date of the notice.

A ransomware attack at Forward Air, a trucking and freight transportation logistics, left a dent of in its Q4 financial results.

The ransomware incident, which discovered on December 15, 2020, and was identified as an attack with the Hades ransomware, forced the company to take all of its IT systems offline to deal with the intrusion. The incident led to huge disruptions to ForwardAir's operations as drivers and employees couldn't access the necessary documents to clear transports through customs.

According to FreightWaves, the attack has led to business disruption as the paperwork required to release freight from customs was stored on the shutdown systems and is not available. Forward Air's website was down and just displaying a message about the IT security incident and that the site is down while they restore affected systems.

Forward Air's investigation of the incident determined that certain Forward Air systems were accessible in November and early December 2020. It was also identified that the information affected is related to current and former employees. The information that could have been subject to unauthorized access includes name, address, date of birth, Social Security number, driver's license number, passport number, or bank account number.

While Forward Air's systems recovery efforts are completed and its operations are fully functional, the incident did result in a loss of revenue as well as incremental costs for the month of December which will adversely impact the Company's fourth quarter 2020 results. Forward Air loss an estimated $7.5 million of LTL revenue as a result of the incident primarily because of the Company's need to temporarily suspend its electronic data interfaces with its customers.

Trucking and freight logistics company Forward Air has suffered a ransomware attack by a new ransomware gang that has impacted the company's business operations.

On December 15, 2020, Forward Air detected an IT security incident that impacted the functionality of certain computer systems. Per its information security protocols, Forward Air immediately took its systems offline, notified law enforcement and engaged several third-party experts to assist in conducting an internal investigation. The company IT team is working diligently to restore the affected systems and services and bring them back online as soon as possible.

They contained the incident and recovered from it, resuming normal operations with their customers within several days of the incident. However, operations are adversely affected by the inefficiencies caused by the Ransomware Incident and fourth quarter 2020 revenue was also adversely affected as they are unable to fulfill a portion of customer demand during the quarter.

According to FreightWaves, the attack has led to business disruption as the paperwork required to release freight from customs was stored on the shutdown systems and is not available.

Forward Air's investigation of the incident determined that certain Forward Air systems were accessible in November and early December 2020. It was also identified that the information affected is related to current and former employees. The information that could have been subject to unauthorized access includes name, address, date of birth, Social Security number, driver's license number, passport number, or bank account number.

Researchers later revealed that the attack was likely conducted by members of the Evil Corp cybercrime gang, who routinely perform attacks under different ransomware names, such as Hades, to evade US sanctions.

For the year ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, expenses related to the Ransomware Incident were $434,000 and $1,560,000, respectively, which were recorded in 'Other operating expenses' in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income. Expenses include costs to investigate and remediate the Ransomware Incident and legal and other professional services related to the incident.

Fresenius, Europe's largest private hospital operator and a major provider of dialysis products and services that are in such high demand thanks to the COVID-19 pandemic, has been hit in a ransomware cyber attack on its technology systems. The company said the incident has limited some of its operations, but that patient care continues.

On Tuesday, a KrebsOnSecurity reader who asked to remain anonymous said a relative working for Fresenius Kabi's U.S. operations reported that computers in his company's building had been roped off, and that a cyber attack had affected every part of the company's operations around the globe.

The reader said the apparent culprit was the Snake ransomware, a relatively new strain first detailed earlier this year that is being used to shake down large businesses, holding their IT systems and data hostage in exchange for payment in a digital currency such as bitcoin.

Fresenius spokesperson Matt Kuhn confirmed the company was struggling with a computer virus outbreak.

Fresenius declined to answer questions about specifics of the attack, saying it does not provide detailed information or comments on IT security matters. It remains unclear whether the company will pay a ransom demand to recover from the infection. But if it does so, it may not be the first time: According to my reader source, Fresenius paid $1.5 million to resolve a previous ransomware infection.

location.street: 104, Vasan Udyog Bhavan, Senapati Bapat Road,

incident.description:
Nykaa, a domestic retailer of beauty and fashion products, was tricked by scamsters into sending money meant for its Italian supplier to some other bank account.

In March 2020, the vendor told the company that the order was ready and sent an invoice. As flights were suspended due to coronavirus lockdown, Nykaa couldn't import the material and informed the vendor that it would not be able to receive the consignment. Once they spoofed the email ID, the cybercriminals asked Nykaa to transfer payment for the consignment to a different bank account. They claimed it is for taxation purposes. Nykaa was informed that all future transactions will be conducted through the account.

Nykaa officials discovered that they have been duped after the 'original' vendor told them that the bank account they made the payment to was not theirs. Nor the email ID from where the payment request came from.

Nykaa loses Rs 62 lakh to the cybercriminals.

organization.name: Garmin Ltd.
organization.industry: Radio and Television Broadcasting and Wireless Communications Equipment Manufacturing

incident.description:
Garmin Ltd., a multinational tech company, was the victim of a cyber attack that encrypted some of their systems on July 23, 2020. As a result, many of their online services were interrupted including website functions, customer support, customer facing applications, and company communications.

Garmin services began to slowly return on July 27, 2020, Monday morning, after the company was hacked and allegedly held to ransom by Russian group Evil Corps, who demanded $10 million to restore their operation. Garmin is yet to comment on the service return or the hacking claims amid reports they were ordered to pay the ransom.

On August 14, 2020, cshub.com, although not verified by the U.S. corporation, reported that Garmin Paid $10 Million to ransomware hackers who rendered systems useless.

organization.name: General Electric Co
organization.industry: All Other Miscellaneous General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing

incident.description:
On April 8, 2020, Steven Fowler and Maher Baz (Plaintiffs) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against Canon Business Process Services, Inc. et al (Defendants), the action arises after the Defendants failed to safeguard the Personal Information of its employees and customers.

GE contracts with Canon to process documents of GE employees, former employees and beneficiaries entitled to benefits. Pursuant to that contract, Canon acts as GE's authorized agent for processing and storage of certain documents of GE employees, former employees, and beneficiaries entitled to benefits. GE learned that, between approximately February 3 - 14, 2020, an unauthorized party gained access to an email account that contained documents of certain GE employees, former employees and beneficiaries entitled to benefits that were maintained on Canon's systems.

Canon informed GE that the affected documents, which contained certain PII. The data consisted of a wealth of GE employees', former employees' and beneficiaries' PII such as direct deposit forms, driver's licenses, passports, birth certificates, marriage certificates, death certificates, medical child support orders, tax withholding forms, beneficiary designation forms and applications for benefits such as retirement, severance and death benefits with related forms and documents, and may have included names, addresses, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, bank account numbers, passport numbers, dates of birth, and other information contained in the relevant forms. On or about February 28, 2020, GE notified affected consumers and various governmental agencies of the Data Breach.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On August 15, 2022, the parties have reached a settlement.

According to the Settlement Agreement, claims for Attested time and reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses are subject to a combined aggregate cap of $3,500.00 per Settlement Class Member. All Settlement Class Members who submit a Valid Claim using the Claim Form are also eligible to receive reimbursement of $18 per hour for up to four (4) hours of lost time in connection with efforts to remedy issues fairly traceable to the Data Incident. Furthermore, Defendants' payment for Valid Claim expenses shall not exceed $350,000.00, in the total aggregate, for all claim payments for all Settlement Class Members. If the total amount of otherwise Valid Claims exceeds $350,000.00, all Valid Claims shall be reduced pro rata.

All Costs of Claims Administration as required and the costs of Dispute Resolution shall be paid by the Defendants and are estimated to be approximately $35,000.00.

As DataBreaches.net reported in the past, the data from the GeniusU leak wound up being given away for free on a Russian-language forum. They were first leaked there in November, 2020. In January, 2021, another user of the same forum offered a leak that they claimed included Email Addresses, First Names, Last Names, Website Activity, Social Links (twitter,google+,linkedin), Genders, Passwords, Country Locations. The data are no longer available from the file-sharing site.

The personal data of approximately 1.26 million users were affected.

On April 21, 2022, the Personal Data Protection Commission imposed a $35,000 financial penalty against GeniusU.

On September 1, 2020, Plaintiffs Alabama Doe 1, Indiana Doe, and Missouri Doe filed a Class Action Complaint in the Superior Court of the State of California, for the County of San Mateo against Gilead Sciences, Inc. (Defendant).

Plaintiffs alleged in their Class Action Complaint that confidential medical information belonging to Plaintiffs and the Settlement Class Members was disclosed by Gilead to third parties through a mailing of an envelope with the words 'HIV Prevention Team' on the face of the envelope in the return address between April 15 and April 30, 2020 (the 'Mailer'). The Class Action Complaint further alleged that Gilead was responsible for all harm caused by the Mailer under various theories of liability.

On August 25, 2021, Plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint (the 'Complaint') that added Plaintiffs Alabama Doe 2 and Florida Doe, and added Lahlouh, Inc. as an additional defendant.

Plaintiffs subsequently agreed to dismiss the claims against Lahlouh, Inc. without prejudice following Lahlouh's production of documents. The Court granted Plaintiffs' request to dismiss Lahlouh on February 23, 2022.

On October 21, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. According to the settlement, Gilead shall pay the non-reversionary cash amount of $4,000,000. The Parties agree that the amount for attorneys' fees shall not exceed onethird of the $4 million Settlement Fund (i.e., $1,333,333.33). In addition, Co-Lead Class Counsel's out-of-pocket costs shall not exceed $60,000. In recognition of their service to the Settlement Class, the Motion for Fees, Costs, and Service Awards may request the Court to approve service awards of $5,000 each to the Class Representatives subject to the approval of the Court.

On January 19, 2023, the court issued an order granting the preliminary approval of class action settlement.

On April 10, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for attorneys' fees, costs, and class representative service awards. In the said motion, Plaintiff request for attorneys' fees in the amount of $1,333,333.33, reimbursement of Co-Lead Class Counsel's out-of-pockets expenses in the amount of $31,000, and Service Award for each Class Representative in the amount of $5,000 ($25,000.00 total).

Accordingly, the court granted the motion for attorneys' fees, costs, and class representative service awards.

On January 18, 2024, the court granted final approval of the class action settlement.

organization.name: Global One 2015
organization.industry: Lessors of Residential Buildings and Dwellings

location.street: No 4 Gateway Mews Ringway Bounds Green

incident.description:
A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Global One 2015 for instigating a total of 573,000 unsolicited direct marketing messages, resulting in total of 548 complaints.

Between 24 April 2020 and 23 May 2020 Global One instigated the transmission of 573,000 unsolicited direct marketing texts contrary to Regulations of PECR. This resulted in a total of 539 complaints being received via the 7726 service and 9 via the Commissioner's online reporting tool. The Commissioner was therefore satisfied from the evidence she has seen that Global One did not have the necessary valid consent to instigate the sending of the direct marketing messages.

On June 15, 2021, Global One 2015 has been fined GBP 10,000 (14,106.9 USD) by the ICO.

On February 13, 2020 the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator Vodafone Romania SA and found that it violated the provisions of Law no. 506/2004 on the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector, as subsequently amended and supplemented.

The operator of Vodafone Romania SA was sanctioned with two fines totaling 20,000 lei ($4,936.21).

The sanctions were applied to the operator as a result of a notification regarding the fact that Vodafone Romania SA violated the security and confidentiality of personal data.

Thus, a petitioner of the Authority claimed that she requested an offer by phone, through the website of the operator Vodafone Romania SA and that, subsequently, she received on her e-mail address, a contract concluded by the operator with another natural person. , the petitioner suspected that her personal data could have been disclosed to this person.

As a result of the investigation carried out at the operator, the Authority found that Vodafone Romania SA did not comply with the provisions of art. 3 para. (1) - (3) of Law no. 506/2004, as subsequently amended and supplemented, according to which the provider of an electronic communications service intended for the public has the obligation to take appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of personal data processing, that they must ensure a proportionate level of security with the existing risk, taking into account the latest technical possibilities and the costs of implementing these measures and comply with at least the following conditions: to guarantee that personal data may be accessed only by authorized persons, for the purposes authorized by law, to protect personal data stored or transmitted against accidental or unlawful destruction, against accidental loss or damage and against unlawful storage, processing, access or disclosure and to ensure the implementation of the security policy developed by the provider regarding the processing of personal data.

Court documents have revealed that hackers had fraudulently claimed pandemic benefits using the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) accounts of 12,700 individuals. In August 2020, the CRA was forced to temporarily shut down its online services after it had suffered two cyberattacks. The attacks were suspected to be 'credential stuffing' incidents; hackers used stolen credentials to log into the MyCRA online service and attempt to fraudulently claim Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) payments under victims' names.

It was initially reported that the cyberattack compromised the personal data of only 5,500 Canadians, but a month after the attack, the government admitted that forensic analysis had uncovered that there were 'suspicious activities' on as many as 48,500 accounts.

Hackers were able to successfully log in to CRA profiles using the proper credentials during the breach. Of these, 21,860 did not see more fraudulent activity following the unauthorized login. But in the case of 12,700 taxpaying Canadians, their CRA direct deposit information was successfully changed. Sometimes, multiple CERB applications were submitted through a single profile. The hackers even managed to make monetary claims.

While the court document does not reveal the total value of fraudulent benefit claims made, The National Post has suggested that at least $25.4 million was stolen, assuming each of the 12,700 victims took out one CERB payment worth $2,000.

All persons whose personal or financial information in their Government of Canada Online Account was disclosed to a third party without authorization between March 1, 2020, and December 31, 2020 were included as affected individuals.

organization.name: Great Northern Docks, Inc.
organization.industry: All Other Miscellaneous Wood Product Manufacturing

incident.description:
Cybercriminals are targeting small business, and many aren't prepared to deal with an attack. As they have accelerated their adoption of new technologies for remote work, communication, production and sales during the pandemic, their expanded computer networks have created new vulnerabilities to phishing and ransomware attacks. But many small businesses still don't expect to be targeted by hackers, so preparing for a cyberattack is well down their list of priorities.

In 2020, Great Northern Docks in Naples, Maine was subject to a cyberattack after the hackers drained almost $250,000 from the company's bank account. The insurance didn't cover most of the attack because they only had commercial insurance plan when hackers attacked, which ended up costing Great Northern $218,000, including money lost, legal fees for negotiations with the bank, the hiring of forensic specialists to figure out what had happened and how it could be prevented in the future, and the cost of new IT infrastructure.

According to the co-owner, Dawn Merriam, in addition to the financial loss, figuring out next steps in the attack's aftermath was difficult and she felt like there was no one to help them through the nightmare.

organization.name: Grindr LLC
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
Norway's data privacy watchdog issued gay dating app Grindr with a notice of intention to fine it NOK 100 million (U.S. $11.7 million) for sharing personal data with third parties without users' consent.

The Data Protection Authority kicked off an investigation after registering a complaint by the Norwegian Consumer Council claiming that personal data was shared illegally for marketing reasons. A previous report in 2020 found that Grindr and other dating apps leaked personal information to advertising technology companies for targeted ads and in doing so breached the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation. Even though Norway is not currently a member of the EU its data protection legislation is almost identical to GDPR rules.

Grindr has until February 15 to submit feedback for consideration in the final decision. The amount of the fine was approximately 10% of the U.S. company's global revenue for the previous financial year, the highest possible fine for a breach of this nature.

The preliminary conclusion released by the watchdog stated that Grindr shared user data with several third parties in an illegal manner including GPS location, user profile information as well as the fact that users are on Grindr, which could reveal their sexual orientation. The data protection authority said in its notice to Grindr that the consequences of this include putting someone at risk of being targeted. The statement said: 'A Grindr user may lead to prejudice and discrimination even without revealing their specific sexual orientation.'

Unidentified hackers attacked the servers of Noida-based Haldiram's Snacks private limited with ransomware, stealing sensitive data and demanding a ransom of Rs 7.5 lakh ($9,544.64) to release the information. A case was registered at Noida Sector 58 police station on October 14, 2020.

The incident occurred on the intervening night of July 12 and 13 when issues were reported with the company server which later turned out to be ransomware attacks.

According to the complaint filed by the company's deputy general manager (DGM), IT, technicians were called in after the corporate office located in Noida's sector 62 was alerted about the problem.

'It was found that the company's data was being diverted through the cyber-attack following which the server connection with other branches was cut off. However, by then, substantial data had already been stolen. By 3 am, the ransomware had spread via the corporate network. A complaint was then raised with a cyber security company, but all sensitive data had already been encrypted by the by then,' said DGM, Aziz Khan, in his complaint to Noida cyber cell.

Officials said that the data stolen included financial and employee information, data on payroll, retail sales, purchases, inventory of the company.

'This was a pre-planned conspiracy and the hackers not only stole the data but also tried to extort money in exchange for returning it. They left a message on the servers about the ransomware attack and proposed decrypting and returning the data for a ransom of Rs 7.5 lakh,' said the complainant.

Company officials also said that the data theft can lead to losses and has already disrupted the company's daily functioning. The hackers also deleted the backups from the servers, spelling more trouble for the company. Officials have provided IP addresses, of servers from where the ransomware appeared to have originated, to the police.

A fined was filed by Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Halfords Group PLC for breaking the law governing nuisance marketing.

In July 2020, the bike shop chain sent 498,179 emails to people regarding a 'Fix Your Bike' government voucher scheme, according to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). The marketing email encouraged recipients to book a bicycle assessment and then redeem a 50 ($61.6305) government voucher towards the cost of repairs at its stores. The retailer apparently tried to rely on the 'legitimate interest' defense to explain why it had sent the email to so many recipients without their informed consent.

According to ICO, because the email clearly advertised a service provided by the company that it would generate income from, 'legitimate interest' could not be used as an alternative to consent.

Head of investigations at the regulator, Andy Curry, confirmed that it is against the law in the UK to send marketing emails or texts to people without their permission.

The ICO has fined Halfords Group PLC in the amount of GBP 30,000 (34,917.9 USD), under the Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR).

On July 24, 2020, Terri Pepper (Plaintiff) filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas against Hard Tack, LLC et al (Defendants) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA), the Telemarketing Sales Rule (TSR) and the Texas Business and Commercial Code (TBCC).

Defendant Matrix Warranty Solutions (MWS) provides extended warranty services to consumers and generate business using telemarketing services conducted by third parties. Beginning February 17, 2020, Hard Tack began calling Plaintiff's cellphone, attempting to sell them Defendant's MWS' automobile warranty. Plaintiff never sought information about a motor vehicle warranty and did not consent to the calls from Hard Tack that were also for non-emergency purposes. Defendants have called Plaintiff from February 17 to April 22, 2020, despite her being in the DNC list since 2004.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On September 14, 2020, the case with Defendant Matrix Warranty Solutions, Inc., Matrix Financial Services, LLC and SING for Services, LLC was terminated.

On February 16, 2021, Plaintiff filed a motion for default judgment in the amount of $70,465.50.

On September 28, 2021, the court issued an order granting Plaintiff's motion for default judgment.

Harvest Finance was exploited early morning on Monday UTC. The company took to Twitter to explain what happened. The company claim that hackers exploited a DeFi ecosystem vulnerability present in the Curve's Y pool mechanism and stole approximately $24 million. Later the attacker returned around $2.5 million to the project for unknown reasons. The entire feat took about 7 minutes only. Harvest Finance also revealed some of the bitcoin addresses of the hacker.

The National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing announced, on June 18, 2020, its decision to fine Enel Energie Muntenia SA for its failure to implement sufficient measures to prevent unauthorized disclosure of personal data

The Data Protection Authority found the violation by the controller, Enel Energie Muntenia SA, of the provisions of Article 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and sanctioned it by a fine amounting to 19,368.4 RON (approximately EUR 4,000).

The investigation was initiated as a result of a complaint by which the petitioner notified the violation of the security and confidentiality of personal data by Enel Energie Muntenia SA, by sending documents containing his personal data to another Enel customer, via e-mail.

During the investigation, the Data Protection Authority found that the controller did not take sufficient security and confidentiality measures to prevent accidental disclosure of personal data to unauthorized persons, violating the provisions of Article 32 of the GDPR. At the same time, the corrective measure was applied to the controller to ensure the compliance with the GDPR of the collection and further processing of personal data, by implementing adequate and efficient security measures, both from a technical and organizational point of view.

organization.name: Ing Bank N.v. Amsterdam Sucursala Bucuresti

incident.description:
On December 7, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority (ANSPDCP) completed an investigation at the operator ING Bank NV Amsterdam - Bucharest Branch and found the violation of the provisions of art. 5 para. (1) lit. a) -d) reported to art. 6 para. (1) of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The sanction was applied to the operator as a result of the fact that he processed the personal data of a natural person after the conclusion of the contractual relationship with ING Bank.

During the investigation, the ANSPDCP found that the operator sent to the e-mail address of a natural person messages regarding the updating of his personal data, although he had requested on November 24, 2017 the closure of the last bank product held, respectively a current account.

It was also found that, as a result of a system error, this request to close the current account did not have the effect of closing the business relationship with the operator, which was still maintained in 'active' status.

This situation led to the processing of personal data (e-mail address, name and surname, date of expiration of the identity card).

On December 30, 2020, ANSPDCP announced that it had imposed a fine of RON 14,619.90 (approx. C3,000) (3,673.47) on ING Bank, following its investigation into the bank.

Noida (UP), Dec 14 () Critical and classified data of a Noida-based private company, providing technology solutions to the country's defence forces, has been allegedly hacked, leading to theft of confidential information, police said on Monday. The company, ELCOM Innovations, claimed that the cyber attack has caused it an estimated loss of Rs 50 crore (6,261,466 USD).

An FIR has been lodged in connection with the case at the Sector 39 police station, while an investigation has been launched by the Cyber Cell, a police official said.

'It is, hereby, informed that on account of the hacking of my emails along with the emails of other members of my department, the company has incurred heavy financial losses and irreparable damage to its reputation,' a senior executive of the firm alleged in the FIR lodged on Saturday.

'It may also be noted that our company, ELCOM Innovations Private Limited, exclusively deals with the Defence Forces, Para Military Forces and Intelligence Agencies of the country, thereby, having access to critical and classified data,' according to the FIR, a copy of which is available with.

The executive claimed that majority of the hacked emails were of 'extremely sensitive' nature and 'of substantial financial value', owing to the fact that most of the company's solutions are customised for the agencies served.

The company could not be immediately contacted for its response.

According to the police, the FIR has been lodged against an identified accused under Indian Penal Code section 420 (cheating) and section 66 of the Information Technology Act.

The police suspect the role of a company insider in the case, but a detailed investigation is underway, an official privy to the probe said.

On July 13, 2020, a website that connects users with babysitters, caretakers and pet-sitters will pay $1 million to settle a consumer protection lawsuit jointly brought on by San Francisco District Attorney Chesa Boudin and Marin County District Attorney Lori Frugoli.

Prosecutors alleged that Care.com, a Massachusetts-based company, falsely represented its purchased background checks for service providers by claiming the checks included a search of the National Sex Offender Registry. Care.com unlawfully enrolled its customers in auto-renewal subscriptions without getting customers' consents and without providing disclosures of the subscription as required by law. By misrepresenting their sex offender background checks, Care.com gave families a false sense of security about the stranger they were inviting into their homes.

Under the settlement, Care.com will pay $700,000 in civil penalties and $300,000 in restitution to California customers who purchased the higher-priced background checks. Additionally, Care.com won't be allowed to claim National Sex Offender Registry checks and will now be required to state that its background checks may not state a person's entire sex offender history.

In February 2022, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the IAMSAT Muntenia SA operator and found a violation of the provisions of the General Data Protection Regulation. The operator was sanctioned for minor offenses, fine in the amount of 9,892.4 lei, the equivalent of 2,000 euros and fine in the amount of 4,946.2 lei, the equivalent of 1,000 euros.

The investigation was initiated following a complaint lodged by a data subject who complained that IAMSAT Muntenia SA continued to process his personal data after the termination of his employment contract in 2020. By a request, this person informed the operator that he/she does not consent to the use of his/her e-mail address and that he/she opposes the processing of his/her personal data by IAMSAT Muntenia SA and / or third parties, natural or legal, after the termination of the employment contract. During the investigation, it was noted that IAMSAT Muntenia SA did not present evidence regarding the prior and complete information of its employees, including the data subject, before starting the processing of personal data of these persons by means of video surveillance installed in their place. of work, put into operation from the middle of 2020, although the operator had the obligation to inform the employees. At the same time, it was noted that IAMSAT Muntenia SA did not resolve the request of the data subject and did not communicate an answer regarding the measures adopted following the exercise of the right of opposition within the legal deadlines.

On April 14, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator Banca Comerciala Romana SA, finding the violation of the provisions regarding the security of processing, respectively art. 32 para. (4) in conjunction with art. 32 para. (1) and para. (2) of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator Banca Comerciala Romana SA was sanctioned with a fine of 24,163.50 lei, the equivalent of 5,000 EURO ($5,916.95).

The investigation was initiated following the receipt of a complaint, and during its conduct, the National Supervisory Authority found that Banca Comerciala Romana SA did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of processing. At the same time, the controller has not taken steps to ensure that any natural person acting under his authority who has access to personal data only processes them at his request, unless this obligation is incumbent on him under the law. Union or national law.

organization.name: Compania Nationala De Transporturi Aeriene Romane Tarom Sa

location.street: CALEA BUCURESTILOR NR 224 F Calea BUCURESTILOR Nr 224 F Sector 0

incident.description:
On June 7, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator SC CNTAR TAROM SA, as a result of the transmission by the operator of a notification regarding the violation of personal data security, finding the violation of the provisions of art. 32 para. (4), art. 32 para. (1) lit. b) and para. (2) of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

Data breach was the fact that the operator did not implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure that any person acting under the authority of the operator that has access to personal data not process them except at his request, which has led to the loss of the confidentiality of personal data through unauthorized access to data belonging to a number of five (5) TAROM passengers, as well as to the unauthorized disclosure of their data .

The corrective measure was also applied to the operator to review and update the technical and organizational measures implemented as a result of the risk assessment for the rights and freedoms of individuals, including working procedures related to the protection of personal data and the implementation of measures. on the regular training of persons acting under its authority (employees).

The National Supervisory Authority imposed a fine of 24,182.50 lei (approx. 5,000 Euros) ($5,645.10).

The National Supervisory Authority completed on April 23, 2020 an investigation at the operator Telekom Romania Communications SA and found the violation of the provisions of art. 32 of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

The operator Telekom Romania Communications SA was sanctioned with a fine of 14524.2 lei, the equivalent of 3,000 EURO ($3,545.87).

The investigation was initiated following the receipt of complaints by which the petitioner complained about the fraudulent use of his personal data when concluding contracts on his behalf by Telekom Romania Communications SA.

During the investigation, the National Supervisory Authority found that the operator did not implement sufficient security measures to include the verification of the accuracy of personal data collected by telephone (remotely) in order to conclude contracts.

This fact led to an illegal processing of the petitioner's data by concluding subscription contracts in his name, using the personal data from the pre-existing contract, without verifying their correctness, contrary to the obligations provided by art. 32 of the RGPD. In this sense, art. 32 provides, among others, at par. (1) lit. b) and the obligation of the operator to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures, including the ability to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, availability and ongoing resilience of processing systems and services.

On February 14, 2020, the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) issued a resolution in proceeding against Iberdola Clientes, S.A.U. AEPD fined the company 50,000 for violating Article 6(1) of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Particularly, the resolution indicated that Iberdola Clientes, an electricity utility company, terminated the contract of the individual claimant without their consent, registered three new contracts with the same, unlawfully processed their data and communicated the claimant's personal data to a third party without a legal basis.

The company was asked to provide the AEPD with specific information in relation to a complaint. However, the company had not replied to the data protection authorities request within a certain time frame.

organization.name: Ibex Ltd
organization.industry: Telemarketing Bureaus and Other Contact Centers

incident.description:
On March 3, 2022, a class action complaint was filed by Monique Sanders et al (collectively, Plaintiffs) in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against Ibex Global Solutions, Inc. et al (collectively, 'IBEX' or 'Defendant') for failure to protect consumers from a 2020 data breach.

According to the complaint, Ibex failed to protect consumer information during a 2020 data breach. Plaintiffs in the case claim that Ibex could have prevented or mitigated the data breach through reasonable cyber security measures. The Ibex data breach was a malware attack that took place between July 27, 2020 and August 17, 2020. The breach compromised personal identifying information.

Plaintiff sought for an order certifying the action as a class action, appointing the undersigned as Class counsel, and finding that Plaintiffs are proper representatives of the Class, a judgment in favor of Plaintiffs and the Class awarding them appropriate monetary relief, including compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorney fees, expenses, costs, and such other and further relief.

On October 24, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary class action settlement. According to the settlement, Defendant agreed to pay $2,400,000. Under the terms of the settlement, class members can collect up to $5,000 for lost time and out-of-pocket expenses. The settlement provides compensation for up to five hours of lost time at a rate of $25 per hour. Class members can also collect compensation for credit-related expenses, bank fees, communication charges, fraudulent losses and other expenses related to the data breach. Consumers who experienced actual or attempted identity theft or misuse of their data can receive a $100 payment, subject to the $5,000 settlement payment maximum.

In addition, Defendant agrees not to oppose Class Counsel's request for a service award not to exceed $4,000 per representative, for a total of $12,000. Furthermore, Ibex agrees not to oppose Class Counsel's request for an award of attorneys' fees in the amount of $672,000 and $10,039.44 in expenses.

On November 18, 2022, the Court issued an order granting preliminary class action settlement.

On February 24, 2023, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of the class action settlement.

On March 10, 2023, the Court finally approved the class action settlement.

On May 5, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Lisa Chapman (Plaintiff) in the United States Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Department of Health and Insight Global, Inc (Defendant).

Over a period of months in 2020 and 2021, employees of Insight contacted residents of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania including Plaintiff and the proposed Class, and obtained sensitive and protected health information including but not limited to name, gender, phone number, sexual orientation, gender presentation, family size, and health data (hereinafter, collectively, PHI). Insight failed to secure the PHI of the individuals it contacted. These documents were widely available to the public through a Google search and did not require a password, log in, or any kind of authentication in order to be viewed. Insight was aware that its employees were using unsecured data storage and communications methods as early as November 2020. DOH was notified of this breach as early as February 2021. Neither DOH nor Insight took any action to secure the PHI of Plaintiff or other class members until at least April 21, 2021. As a result of the DOH and Insight's failures, Plaintiff and Class members are at substantial risk of suffering identity theft and fraud or misuse of their PHI. While the exact number of Class Members is unknown to Plaintiff at this time, based on information and belief, the Classes consists of at least thousands of people whose data was compromised in the Data Breach.

Plaintiff sought for equitable relief, actual damages, compensatory damages, statutory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, costs, pre- and post-judgment interest and such other and further relief as this court may deem just and proper.

On August 12, 2021, the parties jointly stipulated the dismissal of Plaintiff's claims are dismissed without prejudice against Defendant Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Department of Health.

On August 27, 2021, an amended complaint was filed by Plaintiff against Defendant.

On August 27, 2021, the court denied Defendant's motion to dismiss.

On October 19, 2022, a settlement agreement was made and entered among the parties.

Under the settlement agreement, all Settlement Class Members are eligible to receive reimbursement for documented out-of-pocket losses not to exceed $250; Settlement Class Members are also eligible to receive extraordinary expense reimbursement, not to exceed $5,000 per Settlement Class Member.

Proposed Class Counsel have agreed to request, and Insight Global has agreed to pay, subject to Court approval, the amount of $300,000 to Proposed Class Counsel for attorneys' fees and costs and expenses and Insight Global has agreed to pay a service award in an amount approved by the Court up to $2,000 to the Representative Plaintiff.

On October 27, 2022, an order preliminarily approving class action settlement.

On February 9, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On April 6, 2023, the Court granted the final approval of the class settlement and dismissed the case with prejudice.

On May 1, 2024, the U.S. Department of Justice announced a settlement with Insight Global LLC for exposing the private medical information of about 72,000 people while assisting with COVID-19 contact tracing during the height of the pandemic

On July 30, 2021, a complainant filed an action concerning Insight Global's inadequate security measure. The United States' investigation found that from November 2020 through January 2021, Insight Global managers received complaints from their staff that such information was unsecure and potentially accessible to the public. Certain personal health information and/or personally identifiable information of contact tracing subjects was transmitted in the body of unencrypted emails, staff used shared passwords to access such information, and such information was stored and transmitted using Google files that were not password protected and were potentially accessible to the public via internet links.

Insight Global started mitigating the issue in April 2021, including by securing such information, investigating the cause and scope of the incident, strengthening internal controls and procedures, adding more data-security resources and issuing a public notice regarding the scope of the potential exposure and offering free credit monitoring and identity protection services to those affected. Insight Global also cooperated with the United States' investigation.

As a result of the violation, Insight Global has agreed to pay $2.7 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by failing to implement adequate cybersecurity measures to protect health information obtained during COVID-19 contact tracing. The settlement also provides for the whistleblower, Terralyn Williams Seilkop, a former Insight Global staff member who worked on the contact tracing at issue, to receive a $499,500 share of the settlement amount.

organization.name: MTS Systems Corporation
organization.industry: Other Measuring and Controlling Device Manufacturing

incident.description:
On October 28, 2020 to November 27, 2020, the MTS Systems Corporation was subject to an external system breach which compromised Social Security Number that affected 126 individuals including 2 New York residents. The state of New York was notified of this breach on December 14, 2020.

The company incurred expenses of $739,000 related to the ransomware attack.

An encryption attack unleashed on Imperial Community College District (ICCD) computer system on August 6, 2020, brought down critical systems that remained offline and will likely continue until further notice.

College officials sent out a press release around August 10, 2020, the release stated that key campus systems remain offline, it was not specified which systems those are. Additionally, the telephone communications system is down, and, currently, the college is unable to receive or place calls. The college was working on gathering and processing as much information as possible to assess what systems and files have been affected.

The college computer system was shut down as a precaution mid-morning August 6, 2020, when ransomware was detected. The personal information that could have been viewed by the unauthorized individual(s) may have included first and last name, in combination with Social Security number, tax identification number, financial account information, health information, and/or a username and password.

After careful consideration, ICCD decided to work with its cyber insurance provider to pay a fee to the ransomware attacker. The decision to pay the ransom was made with students and employees in mind because it provided the fastest and most cost-effective resolution. The ICCD paid $55,068 at the time of the transaction. The college has a cyber insurance policy in place and is responsible for the deductible of $75,000.

In December 2020, the automotive services provider, Inchcape Australia was the subject of ransomware attack by the Windows Ransomexx ransomware, with the cyber criminals who hit the company leaking some data that they stole, on the dark web. The effect of the attack on the business was significant. The primary server was encrypted, primary and offsite backups were deleted and malicious software was deployed to user computers. The leaked documents are in four lots and relate to administration, customer fulfilment and client information.

Inchcape made a claim under its Financial Institutions Electronic and Computer Crime Policy with Chubb, its insurance company, seeking costs incurred in: investigating and responding to the ransomware attack; repairing and replacing hardware and data; the costs of recovering data, including actually reproducing damaged or destroyed data; and additional staffing costs.

Reports indicate the value of Inchcape's claim on the policy was approximately $2.3 million and the overall losses were in the order of $4 million.

organization.name: Indeck Power Equipment Co.
organization.industry: Industrial Machinery and Equipment Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On February 19, 2021, Plaintiff Matthew LaPrade filed a class action complaint individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois County Department, Chancery Division against Defendant Indeck Power Equipment Company in violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).

Defendant scanned and collected, and then indefinitely stored in an electronic database, digital copies of each employee's fingerprints during the employee onboarding process from at least March 2020 to at least October 2020, and on each occasion an employee clocks in or out of Defendant's Cook County, Illinois-based headquarters - all without ever informing anyone of this practice in writing.

Plaintiff began working for Defendant at Defendant's facility in Wheeling, Illinois, in or around March 2020. During the course of Plaintiff's employment, Defendant required Plaintiff to place his fingers on a fingerprint scanner, at which point Defendant scanned and collected, and stored in an electronic database, digital copies of Plaintiff's fingerprints.

Plaintiff worked for Defendant until approximately October 2020. During his employment tenure, Plaintiff was required to place his fingers on a fingerprint scanner, which scanned, collected and stored his fingerprints each time he 'clocked' in and out as part of the timekeeping system. There are hundreds affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On February 3, 2023, the parties have reached a settlement. According to the settlement agreement, the Defendant agreed to pay $66,825. Subject to Court approval, Indeck agrees to pay attorneys' fees not to exceed 40% ($26,730) of the settlement fund and a service award of $2,500 for Plaintiff.

On March 10, 2023, the settlement agreement was preliminary approved.

On June 29, 2023, the court enter a final approval of the class action settlement. Accordingly, the court dismissed the case with prejudice.

The Norwegian Data Protection Authority has fined the Municipality of Indre Ostfold EUR 20 000 (NOK 200,000 or $23,631.30) for a confidentiality violation. Personal data that should have been restricted was available to unauthorized persons.

The Municipality of Indre Ostfold, formerly the Municipality of Askim, published the records file of a former pupil on its municipal website. This file included confidential personal data.

The background for this incident was that the pupil needed his record file in connection with his further studies and asked the municipality to send it to them. The municipality routinely enters such Access to Information requests in the public record. This process also entails the document to which access has been requested, being scanned and made available for public access.

The pupil's file was available on the municipality's website from Friday September 27 to Monday September 30, 2020. The municipality was made aware of the incident by a journalist from the local newspaper Smaalenenes Avis. The documents were removed from the public record and exempted from public access as soon as they were discovered. The affected person was then notified.

organization.name: Mercadona Sa
organization.industry: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

incident.description:
AAA (hereinafter, the claimant), dated December 31, 2020, filed a claim with the Spanish Data Protection Agency. The claim is directed against MERCADONA SA, with NIF A46103834 (hereinafter, MERCADONA or the claimed party), due to the lack of attention to the right of access to the personal data of the claimant, as the request was not answered within a period of one month.

The claimant states that she suffered an accident in an establishment and with the purpose of claiming damages, she exercised the right of access to the images of the security cameras, using for this the request form available on the website of the claimed party. After a month without receiving a response, she sent an email to the entity's DPO, who responded by denying receipt of the request for access and that the images had been deleted. The claimant sent the proof of sending request of access, without receiving any other response.

On April 16, 2021, the Director of the AEPD agrees to admit the claim for processing.

On July 5, 2021, the General Subdirectorate for Data Inspection accesses the information available on the entity claimed in 'Axesor'. It is known that this entity belongs to the 'Commerce' sector.

On July 19, 2021, the Director of Spanish Agency for Data Protection agreed to initiate sanctioning against the entity MERCADONA.

On July 29, 2021, this Agency received a document submitted by the representative of the claimant.

On March 16, 2022, a resolution proposal was formulated, that the MERCADONA entity be sanctioned for an infraction of article 12, in relation to article 15), both RGPD and classified as minor for the purposes of prescription in article 74.c) of the LOPDGDD, with a fine of 70,000 Euros ($85,976.8). And that the MERCADONA entity be sanctioned, for an infraction of article 12, in relation to article 15), both the RGPD, and classified as very serious purposes of prescription in article 72.1.b) of the LOPDGDD, with a fine of 100,000 Euros ($122,824).

Finally, it is pointed out that in accordance with the provisions of art. 90.3 a) of the LPACAP, the final administrative decision may be provisionally suspended if the interested party expresses his intention to file a contentious-administrative appeal. If this is the case, the interested party must formally notify this fact by writing to the Spanish Agency for Data Protection, presenting it through the Agency's Electronic Registry.

On February 14, 2020, Cindi Degeyter (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas against Eldercare Insurance Services, Inc. and Integrity Marketing Group, LLC (Defendants) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

In March 21, 2019, Plaintiff has been registered in the Do Not Call list to avoid receiving unwanted calls. Despite this Plaintiff still received automated telemarketing calls from the Defendants in mid-January to January 27, 2020. All calls made by the Defendants to Plaintiff were without her prior express consent and were not made for emergency purposes. Plaintiff has not been in a business relationship with the Defendants. Upon belief, there are a thousand affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On June 19, 2020, Plaintiff filed an Amended Complaint.

On August 18, 2020, the case was dismissed in favor of Plaintiff by awarding the amount of 10,000 for damages inclusive of attorneys' fees and costs.

A fined was filed by Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Interserve Group Limited for failing to keep personal information of its current and former staff secure.
