Between 18 March 2019 and 1 December 2020, Interserve Limited failed to process personal data in a manner that ensured appropriate security of the personal data using appropriate technical and organizational measures as required by General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). This rendered Interserve vulnerable to a cyber-attack which took place in the period 30 March 2020 to 2 May 2020, and affected the personal data of up to 113,000 employees of Interserve.

According to a statement, the ICO provided details of the May 2020 breach. An Interserve employee forwarded a phishing email to another employee. Interserve's system failed to quarantine or block the email. The employee opened it and downloaded its content, resulting in malware being installed onto the employee's workstation.

The ICO investigation found that Interserve failed to follow up on the original alert of suspicious activity, used outdated software systems and protocols, and had a lack of adequate staff training and insufficient risk assessments, which ultimately left it vulnerable to a cyber attack.

Interserve took extensive steps to resolve the incident, engaging leading cyber response companies, and made significant investments across its operating companies to mitigate the potential impacts of the cyber incident on its past and present staff.

On October 24, 2022, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has fined Interserve Group GBP 4,400,000 (4,970,900 USD).

organization.name: IOTA Stiftung
organization.industry: Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology)

incident.description:
An IOTA executive is personally reimbursing victims of February's Trinity wallet hack to 'preserve' the project's runway, he told CoinDesk.

The founder of the distributed ledger network, David Sonstebo, said he would repay people affected by the $2 million hack from his own IOTA holdings. The 'main motivation for the decision' had been to 'safeguard the IOTA Foundation's runway' over the next 12 months, he added.

The foundation was forced to suspend the IOTA network in February after hackers stole more than 8.5 million in IOTA's native token MIOTA, worth approximately $1.4 million at the time of writing. The network only came back online again on Tuesday.

As announced on February 19, 2020, ISS was the target of an IT malware attack on February 17, 2020, and March 20, 2020.

There is no indication that any customer data or sensitive personal employee data has been compromised as a result of the malware attack.

They have now regained control of most of their IT infrastructure and have relaunched business-critical systems in most operations.

As previously announced, incremental costs in 2020, including software write-downs related to the IT malware attack, are estimated to be around DKK 850 million ($133,422,000) reported within Other income and expenses, net.

The combined net negative impact on free cash flow related to the IT security incident in 2020-2021 is estimated to be around DKK 750 million. Approximately DKK 500 million of the impact is expected in 2020.

organization.name: Kemper Corp
organization.industry: Direct Property and Casualty Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
On April 8, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Irma Carrera Aguallo, Dror Hertz and Kelvin Holmes (Plaintiffs) against Kemper Corporation and Infinity Insurance Company (Defendants) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois over a data breach of the consumers' personal information.

According to the complaint, on or about March 16, 2021, Infinity began notifying customers and state Attorneys General about a data breach that occurred on December 26, 2020 (the 'Data Breach'). Hackers obtained information from Kemper and its subsidiaries including personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of its current or former employees and customers, including, but not limited to, their names, addresses, Social Security Numbers, driver's license numbers, medical leave information, and workers' compensation claim information. Hackers accessed and then either used or offered for sale the unencrypted, unredacted, stolen PII to criminals. Plaintiffs stated that defendants failed to adequately protect its current or former employees' and customers' PII, warn them of their inadequate information security practices, and effectively monitor their websites and platforms for security vulnerabilities and incidents. Upon information and belief, Defendants have identified thousands of customers whose PII may have been improperly accessed in the data breach and are apparently identifiable within defendants' records.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, an order enjoining Defendants from engaging in the wrongful conduct, compensatory, statutory, nominal and punitive damages, reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses, and further relief as this Court may deem just and proper.

Defendants have proposed to settle the class action stemming from two data breaches in a deal valued at about $17.6 million. The two breaches were believed to have compromised the personal information of an estimated 6.1 million customers and employees.

The Plaintiffs have accepted the settlement, but it must still be approved by the Court.

Under the settlement, all affected customers will be provided with automatic access to 18 months of credit monitoring and financial account protection without the need to file a claim. In addition to that, every class member has the opportunity to make a claim for up to $10,000 in reimbursement for out-of-pocket losses. For California class members who alleged violations of California's Consumer Privacy Act, every member can claim additional benefits of up to $50.

On December 23, 2021, the Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement.

On March 18, 2022, the Court granted the final approval of class action settlement, including attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses in the amount of $2,500,000 and $1,500 to each of the Representative Plaintiffs. On the same day, the case was terminated.

On September 17, 2021, the Department of Justice reached a $50,000 settlement with Portland accountants Gustafson & Co. (Gustafson) after a 2020 data breach that the Oregon State claimed compromised the personal and financial information of nearly 1,900 Oregonians.

According to Jim Mullaney (Mullaney), one of the firm's founders, Gustafson agreed to the settlement at the behest of its insurance company, but Gustafson disputes the state's conclusions.

Mullaney also stated that was an insurance company decision, not theirs. They wanted to fight the case. The state did not present any evidence during their investigation, and the insurance company decided to settle.

According to the Department of Justice, Gustafson was breached in January 21, 2020 by an electronic message that appeared to contain a client's tax information but actually contained malware. Scammers then filed several fraudulent tax returns in clients' names.

Gustafson identified the malware after a week and removed it from their network, according to settlement documents filed in Multnomah County Circuit Court. But the state stated that Gustafson it took until March 2020 for Gustafson to hire a forensic investigator to assess the damage.

The state also claimed that Gustafson didn't notify clients until May 2020, five months after the digital intrusion. But the firm didn't actually know the breach came from within their own systems - rather than those of its tax software provider - until its investigation was complete in April 2020, according to Mullaney.

Gustafson immediately set about reporting the issue and that they, by law, timely notified their clients and all the necessary state and federal authorities. Security of Gustafson clients' information is a top priority.

On August 28, 2020, Mark W. Dobronski (Plaintiff) filed a complaint in the State of Michigan in the Circuit Court for the 22nd Judicial Circuit against Keroles Enterprises LLC et al (Defendants) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) and the Fair Debt collection Practices Act (FDCPA).

In April 1, 2020, Plaintiff started receiving automated telemarketing calls from Defendants. On April 7, 2020, Plaintiff answered one of Defendants calls and asked the representative about the company, to speak with one of the attorneys of the company and where the company of the Defendants was located so that Plaintiff could send a cease and desist letter but all his inquiries were refused. Defendants calls were without Plaintiff's prior express consent and were not made for emergency purposes.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On September 25, 2020, the case was transferred to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.

On November 18, 2020, Defendant filed a motion to dismiss.

On December 18, 2020, Plaintiff filed a Motion to Stay.

On January 8, 2021, Plaintiff filed a motion for judgment.

On September 2, 2021, the court issued an opinion and order denying motion to dismiss and granting motion for judgment.

On July 6, 2022, the court entered a judgment in favor of Plaintiff and against Defendant in the sum of $40,500.

On May 27, 2020, CIRCOR International, Inc. discovered an external systems breach in their network server. The information that has been impacted were Name of individual, Social Security Number Information, Driver's License number, Government-issued ID number (e.g. passport, state ID card), and Financial Information (e.g. account number, credit or debit card number).

According to a SEC Filing, the company incurred $0.7million of costs related to the cyber incident.

On April 23, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed by Alma Fidela Cercas, Kaitlyn Nakagoshi and Judy Anne Grause (Plaintiffs) in the United States District Court Central District of California against Ambry Genetics Corp. (Defendant).

On or about April 15, 2020, Defendant sent over 230,000 patients a Notice of Data Breach involving sensitive personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI) of its patients. The exposed sensitive Information included patients' names, dates of birth, health insurance information, medical information, and for some patients, Social Security Numbers, and other sensitive PII and PHI. Although the Data Breach occurred between January 22, 2020 and January 24, 2020 and Defendant reported the Data Breach to government authorities in March 2020, Defendant waited three months before notifying patients. Defendant neglected to implement industry security standards, leading to a cybersecurity incident involving unauthorized access to an employee's email account.

Plaintiffs sought for an award of compensatory, statutory, and punitive damages, equitable relief, reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses, order enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct and other relief.

On September 21, 2020, a consolidated complaint was filed by Plaintiffs. On the same day Plaintiff Judy Anne Grause, Consol Plaintiff Cynthia Mnich, William Duckett, Nancy Van Tine-Scinto and Annette Demmink was terminated.

On November 2, 2020, a Notice of Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs' Consolidated Complaint was entered.

On December 9, 2020, a First Amended Complaint against Defendants was filed by Plaintiffs.

On April 7, 2021, an order of the Court granting defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' First Amended Consolidated Complaint. For the foregoing reasons, Defendant's motion to dismiss is granted, and plaintiffs' claims are dismissed with fourteen days leave to amend.

On April 21, 2021, a second amended complaint was filed by Plaintiffs.

On May 20, 2021, a notice of motion and motion to dismiss second amended consolidated class action complaint were filed by Defendants.

On October 18, 2021, an order granting in part and denying in part of Defendants' motion to dismiss second amended consolidated class action complaint

On November 1, 2021, a third amended complaint was filed by Plaintiffs.

On November 15, 2021, a notice of motion and motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' third amended consolidated class action complaint were filed by Defendants.

On December 13, 2021, a fourth amended complaint was filed by Plaintiffs.

On September 9, 2022, a notice of motion and motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement were filed by Plaintiffs.

On October 5, 2022, the Court granted Plaintiff's unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the settlement, Defendant has agreed to establish a $12,250,000 Settlement Fund to pay for credit monitoring and identity theft insurance services, cash payments to Class Members for reimbursement of certain out-of-pocket costs and up to $30 per hour for up to ten hours for time spent addressing or remedying issues fairly traceable to the Data Breach, an additional cash payment to Class Members who were a resident or citizen of California or Illinois sometime between January 22, 2017 and October 5, 2022, and the costs of the settlement administration (estimated at about $340,000). Upon information, approximately 225,370 patients are identified on the Settlement Class List.

Class Counsel will receive an award for attorneys' fees and expenses of up to $4,900,000. Class Representatives will also receive service awards in the amount of $2,500 to each.

On or about April 15, 2020, Ambry Genetics Corp. (Ambry) sent over 230,000 patients a Notice of Data Breach involving sensitive personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI) of its patients. The exposed sensitive Information included patients' names, dates of birth, health insurance information, medical information, and for some patients, Social Security Numbers, and other sensitive PII and PHI.

Although the Data Breach occurred between January 22, 2020 and January 24, 2020 and Ambry reported the Data Breach to government authorities in March 2020, Ambry waited three months before notifying patients. Ambry neglected to implement industry security standards, leading to a cybersecurity incident involving unauthorized access to an employee's email account.

Approximately 225, 370 individuals were affected from January 22, 2017 to October 5, 2022.

As a result of the incident, and described in the settlement, Ambry has spent in excess of $800,000, and potentially up to $1.4 million, to provide notice to affected individuals of the data breach, including offering certain credit monitoring services; complete its investigation into the cause and scope of the data breach; implement additional security-related measures to ensure continued compliance with state and federal authorities; enhance policies, procedures, and training to staff on how to appropriately manage PHI; continue annual security-awareness training and individual training to certain employees and individuals handling PHI; enhance restrictions in the company to access to PHI, and continuing to require that Ambry's Chief Compliance Officer or the Chief Compliance Officer's delegate(s) approve employee access to PHI by employee type and/or by employee; institute prominent red-flag warnings for emails that come from an external source; enhance security applications, by replacing old applications and adding additional security systems; and retain vendors that ensure Ambry meets all SOC 2-certification requirements, perform third-party risk assessments, penetration testing, and phish-testing emails to all employees.

On July 14, 2020, Plaintiff William Riggs filed a class action complaint on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated in the US District Court for the California Northern District, San Francisco against Defendants Kroto, Inc. and iCanvas.

From May 10 to 28, 2020, a data breach occurred. Hackers not only 'scraped' many of Defendants' customers' names from Defendants' website by infecting the ecommerce platform with malware, hackers also stole customers' payment card numbers, CVV security codes, credit card expiration dates, addresses, telephone numbers and email addresses (PII). The criminals obtained everything they needed to illegally use Defendants' customers' payment cards to make fraudulent purchases, and to steal the customers' identities.

Not only did hackers skim Defendants' customers' PII, on information and belief the stolen names and payment card information are now for sale on the dark web. That means the Data Breach worked. Hackers accessed and then offered for sale the unencrypted, unredacted stolen PII to criminals. Because of Defendants' Data Breach, customers' PII is still available on the dark web for criminals to access and abuse. Defendants' customers face a lifetime risk of identity theft. There are thousands affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On September 30, 2020, this case was transferred to the US District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Chicago.

On October 5, 2020, an amended complaint was filed.

On June 7, 2021, Plaintiff moved for preliminary approval of class action settlement and provisional certification of settlement class.

On July 8, 2021, Plaintiff's motion for preliminary approval was granted.

On October 29, 2021, the court approved the settlement fund of $383,600 including $126,588 in attorneys' fees, reimbursement of $8,421.47 in expenses, and $5,000 to Plaintiff as a service award for his service as a class representative

organization.name: Cashaa Technologies Ltd
organization.industry: Financial Transactions Processing, Reserve, and Clearinghouse Activities

incident.description:
Cyber-criminals have compromised a British cryptocurrency exchange, making off with over $3m in Bitcoin.

Cashaa has halted all its crypto-related transactions after cyber-criminals stole more than 336 Bitcoin from its exchange. The company has said that prima facia users have not been impacted by the theft.

In a media brief shared with Cointelegraph, Cashaa's CEO Kumar Gaurav said: 'We are still investigating the damage caused by the incident and suspend all the withdrawals for 24 hours.'

Kumar said that the theft occurred after malicious hackers compromised one of the exchange's digital wallets. Once access had been gained, the hackers sent the cryptocurrency contained within the wallet to themselves.

Guarav said that he had reason to believe that the cyber-criminals who hit Cashaa are based in East Delhi, India. Acting on this suspicion, the exchange has filed a cyber-crime incident report with the Delhi crime bureau under the cryptocurrency crime category.

Cashaa said it believes that to carry out the theft, cyber-criminals installed malware onto a computer used to make exchange transfers like user withdrawals. This malware sent a notification to the cyber-criminals at 1:23pm on July 10, 2020 when an employee logged into the account and made two transfers from a Blockchain.com wallet. It was this wallet that was then compromised and illegally relieved of over 336 Bitcoin.

The company is now taking steps to prevent the cyber-criminals who hit Cashaa from selling the stolen cryptocurrency on exchanges. On Twitter, Cashaa posted the Bitcoin address of the hacker in hopes of tracking any movement of the illegally acquired funds.

organization.name: Larsen & Toubro Infotech Limited, Singapore Branch

incident.description:
On November 29, 2020, the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) received a complaint against Larsen & Toubro Infotech Limited (LTI).

On November 25, 2020, an LTI employee had emailed the complainant a set of sample forms which contained the personal data of a past job applicant. The LTI employee had sent the complainant those sample forms to assist him in filling up his own forms correctly. Subsequently, on December 3, 2020, another LTI employee sent an email reminder to the complainant and 53 other job applicants to complete their application process. In total, 13 past job applicants' forms were disclosed by 10 of LTI's employees to 74 other job applicants. The personal data disclosed in the forms includes name, signature, email address, national identification/passport number, date of birth, address, contact number, medical health status, employment history, salary information and criminal records disclosure.

The Deputy Commissioner for PDPC finds that LTI negligently contravened the Protection Obligation under section 24 of the Personal Data Protection Act 2012 by failing to provide adequate instructions to its employees dealing with recruitment matters on how to handle personal data. LTI also negligently contravened the Consent Obligation under section 13 of the Personal Data Protection Act 2012, by disclosing the names and email addresses of all job applicants in its email sent to the 54 job applicants on December 3, 2020, including the complainant.

The PDPC found that LTI had not put in place reasonable security arrangements to prevent unauthorized disclosure of personal data and the disclosure of the personal data of job applicants without their consent.

On June 10, 2021, the PDPC imposed a fine of SGD 7,000 on Larsen & Toubro. The PDPC outlined that Larsen & Toubro must make payment of the financial penalty within 30 days from June 10, 2021 and will not be required to take any further action to address the gaps in the security of its arrangements.

On June 30, 2020, a complaint was filed by Danish Data Protection Authority (Plaintiff) against Lejre Municipality (Defendant) for violating the Data Protection Act.

The case showed that Defendant's department, Center for Children and Young People, has had a fixed practice, according to which meeting minutes containing personal information of a very sensitive and protected nature, including whether citizens under 18, have been uploaded on the municipality's employee portal. On the employee portal, there was potential access to the information for a large part of the municipality's employees, regardless of whether the employees in question worked with this type of case.

Defendant has been fined DKK 50,000 ($7545.08) for failing to comply with its obligation as data controller to implement appropriate security measures.

On December 13, 2022, Lowell Parker (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint in the Superior Court of the State of California for the County of San Diego against Metromile, formerly known as Metromile, Inc. (Defendant) who alleges that from July 2020 through January 2021, hackers obtained information from Defendant including the personally identifiable information (PII) of over one hundred thousand consumers.

According to court documents, Plaintiff alleges that between July 2020 and January 2021, criminal actors accessed information from Defendant, including the PII of over one hundred thousand consumers, including, but not limited to, their driver's license numbers (referred to as the Data Incident). Plaintiff alleged that, as a result of the Data Incident, an unauthorized user or users gained access to Plaintiff's personally identifiable information, including, but not limited to, his name, and driver's license number. Plaintiff also alleged that Defendant failed to prevent and manage this data breach due to a failure to implement cybersecurity measures.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, actual damages, attorneys' fees, costs and other relief that the Court deems appropriate.

February 22, 2023, a settlement agreement was entered between the parties. Defendant will pay $775,000 into a Settlement Fund including $298,050 for attorneys' fees and $10,000 for reimbursement of costs and expenses. Class Counsel will move the court for a Service Award to the Class Representative of up to $2,500.

Under the terms of the settlement, consumers can receive up to $5,000 in reimbursement for out-of-pocket expenses related to the data breach. This reimbursement covers unreimbursed losses, credit expenses, lost time and other losses. Instead of this reimbursement, class members can choose to receive a flat-rate payment of $30.

The settlement also includes two years of free credit monitoring services through Experian. These services include dark web scanning, user notifications, fraud-resolution tools and a $1 million identity theft insurance policy.

On August 23, 2023, the court issued an order granting preliminary approval of class action settlement and certified the class.

On February 8, 2022, Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) issued a penalty against Quoine Pte Ltd. for alleged violation of the Personal Data Protection Act 2012.

On 17 November 2020, Quoine Pte Ltd informed the Personal Data Protection Commission that its domain manager had transferred control of its domain hosting account to an external actor, who accessed and exfiltrated the personal data of 652,564 of its customers. The Commission subsequently received a complaint from an individual believed to have been affected in the Incident.

On 13 November 2020, a staff member of the Organization received an email from the Domain Provider stating that changes had been made to the settings of the Organization's domain hosting account with the Domain Provider. Staff members also received password reset emails for accounts on the Organization's other file-sharing and office productivity services. As the Organization had not requested the changes, the Organization followed up with the Domain Provider, who acknowledged that the Organization's email accounts on its domain with the Domain Provider were no longer routed to the Organization. As a result of social engineering attacks on employees of the Domain Provider, an employee of the Domain Provider incorrectly transferred control of the Organization's Domain Hosting Account to an external actor. This allowed the external actor to change the registered email address on the Organization's Domain Hosting Account and subsequently affect a password reset on the account to take control of the Domain Hosting Account.

According to PDPC Decision, the personal data of 652,564 of the Organization's customers were accessed and exfiltrated in the Incident, comprising the following, First name and surname, Address, Email address, Telephone number, and Photo-image of documents provided by 362,035 customers for KYC purposes before October 13, 2018, namely, NRIC number, passport number or other identification documents, proof of address document, and photograph, Financial information of Japanese customers of Quoine Corporation, a Japanese company related to the Organization, Transaction information, fiat deposits, and crypto withdrawals, and a 2018 record of balances prior to the launch of the current Liquid Exchange and for customers depositing and withdrawing fiat currencies, Bank account, and other information, namely, name of the bank, account number, and name of the account holder.

The Commission has repeatedly highlighted that an organization should design and organize its security arrangements to fit the nature of the personal data held by the organization and the possible harm that might result from a security breach and implement robust policies and procedures for ensuring appropriate levels of security for personal data of varying levels of sensitivity. As stated in the commission's Advisory Guidelines an organization can use to protect personal data by adopting appropriate access and measures that an organization can use to protect personal data including adopting appropriate access control considering stronger authentication measures where appropriate and installing appropriate computer security settings.

The Commissioner hereby requires the Organization to pay a financial penalty of SGD$67,000 (US$49,815.8).

location.street: Towne Centre Plaza, 26632, 26642 & 26672 Towne Ctr Dr

incident.description:
On December 22, 2021, Shelly Latimer, Thomas Capon and Marjan Shansab (collectively Plaintiffs) filed a complaint against Loan Depot, LLC (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Central District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's alleged violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

According to the complaint, Defendant is a company that engages in telemarketing in order to solicit direct-to-consumer loans. In January 2020, Defendant placed a series of telemarketing calls and text messages to Plaintiffs in order to solicit direct-to-consumer loans. Plaintiffs claimed they were registered on the Federal Do-Not-Call registry and that the calls utilized an automatically generated and/or pre-recorded voice. Plaintiff also claimed that they did not consent to receive any calls or texts from Defendant. The foregoing acts and omissions of the Defendant allegedly violated the TCPA.

Plaintiffs sought for actual, statutory, and treble damages, reasonable attorneys' fees, witness fees, court costs and other litigation costs, injunctive relief, and any other relief as the Court deems appropriate.

On November 08, 2022, Judgment is entered in favor of Plaintiff and against Defendant on all of Plaintiff's claims in this action. Defendant shall pay Plaintiff in the amount of $8,000.00, inclusive of all costs of suit and attorney's fees otherwise recoverable in this action by Plaintiff.

organization.name: Continental Casualty Company
organization.industry: Direct Property and Casualty Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
Between May 2020 and January 2021, Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others throughout the world by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

When RCMP searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

On February 1, 2022, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Elite Group (Continental Casualty Company) in the amount of $725,963.52.

Lolland Municipality has been fined DKK 50,000 for not having implemented basic security measures in the form of unavoidable requirements for access codes on the municipality's mobile devices. Betty Husted, deputy in the Danish Data Protection Authority said that municipalities process large amounts of sensitive information about citizens, and therefore they also have a responsibility to look after this information properly. Mobile devices are occasionally stolen, forgotten or lost, and if unauthorized persons can easily access the information on them, then you are not living up to that responsibility. The Danish Data Protection Authority became aware of the situation through a report from Lolland Municipality in December 2020, when an employee in the municipality had a work phone stolen. Via the phone, there was access to the employee's work email account, which contained information about several citizens' names, social security numbers, health information and abuse. The phone was not protected by a code as it was switched off. Therefore, there was access to the information that was on the phone. The municipality stated that over a number of years it had been possible for employees to remove the otherwise mandatory access codes, so that telephones could be used without the use of a code. The municipality had immediately initiated restorative measures in the form of new precautions and changes in the technical set-up of handed out telephones. The Norwegian Data Protection Authority finds that Lolland Municipality's processing of personal data was not in accordance with the rules on adequate security. In the assessment, the Danish Data Protection Authority has, among other things, emphasized that a data controller must assume that not all employees at all times follow internal guidelines that mobile devices must always be protected by a password. Really effective protection is thus dependent on such a password not being bypassed, e.g. in that the individual user can switch off the code. It is also the Danish Data Protection Authority's assessment that, in general, stolen mobile devices are examined for personal data to a greater extent than previously, such as e.g. credit card information and social security numbers before these are disposed of, e.g. on resale.

The UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) said its investigation into the 2020 ransomware incident, highlighted a lack of proper security and processes to protect personal data at the London Borough of Hackney (LBoH).

This included failing to ensure that a security patch management system was actively applied to all devices, and not changing an insecure password on a dormant account still connected to Hackney Council servers which was exploited by the attackers.

In the October 2020 attack, threat actors infiltrated LBoH computer systems and accessed, encrypted and exfiltrated records containing personal data.

This included highly sensitive information on residents' racial or ethnic origin, religious beliefs, sexual orientation, health data, economic data and criminal offence data. In addition, personally identifiable information (PII) such as names and addresses were accessed in the attack, which was traced to the Pysa/Mespinoza ransomware group.

Nearly 10,000 records are believed to have been exfiltrated by the attackers, with LBoH acknowledging a meaningful risk of harm to 230 data subjects.

The incident also caused huge disruption to local services, including land searches for property transactions, business rate and council tax payments, and disbursement of COVID support and energy rebate funds.

It was reported that LBoH was forced to spend over 12m ($15.6m) in recovery costs as a result of the attack.

Stephen Bonner, Deputy Commissioner at the ICO, commented that it was a clear and avoidable error from LBoH, one that has resulted in a mass loss of data and has had a severely detrimental impact on many residents.

On April 10, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator Estee Lauder Romania SRL and found that it violated the provisions of art. 6, art. 7 and art. 9 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator Estee Lauder Romania SRL was sanctioned with a fine in the amount of 14483.4 lei, the equivalent of 3,000 EURO ($3,550.58).

The sanction was applied to the controller following a complaint alleging illegal data processing by disclosing and collecting personal data (name, surname, telephone number, date of birth and health information), respectively, without consent, or another legal basis.

At the same time, the corrective measure was applied to the operator to ensure compliance with the General Regulation on Data Protection of operations of collection and further processing of personal data, by regular training of its staff on the importance of compliance with the rules of personal data processing of its employees. , in each situation of personal data processing, in order to avoid their illegal disclosure, reported to art. 58 para. (2) lit. d) of the RGPD).

On September 21, 2020, The National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at SC Marsorom SRL, finding the violation of art. 25 and art. 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator SC Marsorom SRL was sanctioned with a fine in the amount of 14574.9 lei, the equivalent of the amount of 3000 Euro ($3,551.53).

The investigation took place as a result of a complaint claiming that some personal data of its customers could be viewed on the operator's website.

During the investigation it was found that the operator SC Marsorom SRL violated the provisions of art. 25 and 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation as it did not adopt sufficient security measures to prevent unauthorized access and disclosure of personal data of customers who placed orders on this site.

At the same time, the operator was recommended to establish a shorter storage period of personal data related to customer accounts in order to comply with the principle of storage limitation provided by art. 5 para. (1) lit. e) of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

On May 25, 2022, a class action complaint was filed by Michael Wilson and Mosanthony Wilson (Plaintiffs) against Maxim Healthcare Services, Inc. (Defendant) in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of San Diego. The action was brought concerning to Defendant's failure to establish reasonable and adequate security practices to safeguard the confidentiality of the patients' information.

According to the complaint, on November 4, 2021, Defendant announced a breach of its information system's security that compromised its patients' private information. Defendant's investigation revealed that a malicious actor gained access to its employees' email accounts between October 1, 2020 and December 4, 2020. The malicious actor gained access to emails and attachments which contained patients' private information including names, addresses, dates of birth, contact information medical history medical condition or treatment information, medical record number, diagnosis code, patient account number, Medicare/Medicaid number, username/password, and social security numbers. According to the public records, the breach affected at least 65,267 individuals.

Defendant waited at least 335 days before beginning to notify the affected individuals. Additionally, Plaintiffs believe that there were no measures taken by Defendant to determine the scope of the breach or to restore integrity of their computer systems. As a result of Defendant's conduct, Plaintiffs suffered substantial harm and continue to be at heightened risk for medical fraud and identity theft.

Plaintiffs brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons in the California whose private information was compromised, accessed, or viewed in the data breach first announced by Defendant on or about November 4, 2021.

Plaintiffs sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, attorneys' fees and costs, pre- and post-judgement interest, equitable relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual compensatory damages, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On July 7, 2022, the case was removed from the Superior Court to the United States District Court for the Southern District of California.

On October 5, 2022, after the parties reached a settlement in principle, Plaintiffs and Defendant jointly dismissed the case without prejudice. On October 12, 2022, the Court granted the motion and dismissed the case without prejudice. Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney fees Thus, the case is closed.

On November 16, 2022, the parties have reached a settlement. Under the terms of the settlement, class members can receive up to $5,000 cap on compensation from Maxim. Defendant agreed not to oppose an order from the Court awarding $195,000 class counsel settlement. Defendant also agreed not to object to Plaintiffs' request for a service award in an amount not to exceed $2,500 to the Class Representative.

On April 17, 2023, the settlement agreement was preliminarily approved.

On November 16, 2022, a class action complaint was filed by Michael Wilson, a person lacking legal capacity, by Mosanthony Wilson, his conservator (Plaintiff) in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of San Diego against Maxim Healthcare Services, Inc. (Defendant).

According to the complaint, on November 4, 2021, Defendant disclosed a data breach that compromised its patients' private information. Defendant's investigation revealed that a malicious actor gained access to its employees' email accounts between October 1, 2020 and December 4, 2020. The malicious actor gained access to emails and attachments which contained patients' private information including names, addresses, dates of birth, contact information medical history medical condition or treatment information, medical record number, diagnosis code, patient account number, Medicare/Medicaid number, username/password, and social security numbers. According to the public records, the breach affected at least 65,267 individuals.

Defendant was aware that patients unencrypted personal information was, or was reasonably believed to have been, acquired by an unauthorized person no later than December 4, 2020, but did not notify regulatory authorities or begin to mail notification letters to Plaintiff and the Class until November 4, 2021. Additionally, Plaintiffs believe that there were no measures taken by Defendant to determine the scope of the breach or to restore integrity of their computer systems. As a result of Defendant's conduct, Plaintiffs suffered substantial harm, out-of-pocket costs, and anxiety.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons in the California whose private information was compromised, accessed, or viewed in the data breach first announced by Defendant on or about November 4, 2021.

Plaintiff sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, attorneys' fees and costs, pre- and post-judgement interest, equitable relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual compensatory damages, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On December 20, 2022, Plaintiff amended his class action complaint.

On February 2, 2023, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of the class action settlement.

The settlement provides reimbursement of up to $5,000 for extraordinary expenses incurred as a result of the data breach, and lost time expenses for up to three hours at $20 per hour, for a maximum of $60. Class members must submit a claim form and reasonable documentation showing the data breach caused the costs in order to receive reimbursement.

The settlement also provides a flat monetary benefit of approximately $100 for class members who were California residents between October 1, 2020, and December 4, 2020. The amount can be combined with a claim for documented extraordinary expenses but cannot be combined with the lost time expense reimbursement. All Settlement Class Members who make a Valid Claim shall be subject to the $5,000 per-Settlement-Class-Member cap on compensation from Defendant.

In addition, Class Counsel will receive an award attorneys' fees and costs in the amount of $195,000. Plaintiff will also receive service award in the amount of $2,500.

On April 17, 2023, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

MDIS Corporation was fined by Personal Data Protection Commission S$10,000 ($7,290.57) for breaching data privacy laws.

The information of more than 300 people, who had provided their personal data to register for its courses, was publicly available on its website. The slip-up came to light when one of those affected discovered that she was able to access a spreadsheet containing the information through a Google search of her NRIC number.

The UK's data watchdog has fined a company u8,000 for sending 84,000 direct marketing emails without consent to people who had provided their personal data for contact tracing purposes.

The Reg readership will have no problem in calculating this in their heads but for anyone feeling a bit slow today, that's just over 9.5 pence charged by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) for each email that reached its target.

The business came to the attention of the ICO in November last year when a member of the public complained of an email sent by TML concerning a digital health passport. The mail thanked the individual for scanning into a business using TML's QR code and promoted a related app. The person who received the email said they had not provided consent to be sent it.

There was no link to a privacy notice and no further information was provided, the ICO said. 'The only indication an individual had as to who operated the page was a small 'tested.me' logo at the bottom of it.'

The ICO said it did not believe TML deliberately intended to break PECR rules but should have been aware of its responsibilities and should have taken reasonable steps to avoid the contravention.

'Taking into account all of the above, the Commissioner has decided that a penalty in the sum of GBP 8,000 (9,761.13 USD) is reasonable and proportionate given the particular facts of the case and the underlying objective in imposing the penalty,' the ICO concluded.

AAA (hereinafter, the complaining party) dated January 30, 2020, filed a claim with the Spanish Data Protection Agency. The claim is directed against MERCEDES GERENCIA, SL with NIF B87950697 (in below, the claimed party). A.A.A complaining party requesting for information, but Mercedes Gerencia did not comply thus, violating GDPR.

There are indications of a possible non-compliance with the provisions of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Regulation of Data Protection, hereinafter RGPD), which has motivated the opening of the procedure E / 02296/2020.

On July 3, 2020, the claim was admitted for processing submitted by the complaining party, under the provisions of article 65.5 of the LOPDGDD.

On June 1, 2021, the Director of the Spanish Agency for Data Protection agreed to initiate a sanctioning procedure against the claimed party.

On August 10, 2021, a resolution proposal was formulated, proposing that the Director of the Spanish Data Protection Agency sanction MERCEDES GERENCIA, SL, with NIF B87950697, for an infraction of the Article 58.1 of the RGPD, typified in Article 83.5 of the RGPD, a fine of 3,000 Euros ($3,400.69).

Finally, it is pointed out that in accordance with the provisions of art. 90.3 a) of the LPACAP, may provisionally suspend the final resolution through administrative channels if the interested party expresses his intention to file a contentious-administrative appeal. If this is the case, the interested party must formally communicate this fact through writing addressed to the Spanish Agency for Data Protection, presenting it through of the Electronic Registry of the Agency.

Around December 2020, T.D. (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against Mercy Hospitals East Communities doing business as Mercy Hospital St. Louis (Defendant) in the Circuit Court of the County of St. Louis. The action arises out of a data breach that affected the Defendant.

On October 7, 2020, Defendant learned that on one or more prior occasions, an employee of the Defendant accessed medical record information that was not needed by the employee for patient care purposes. The information accessed by the employee included names, addresses, dates of birth, other demographic information, medical record number, treatment and other clinical information and/or radiological images. For a very small number of individuals, health insurance identification numbers were accessed. Credit card numbers and other financial information were not accessed.

On November 21, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a consolidated class action petition against Defendant, asserting various causes of action as a result of the incident.

On November 30, 2023, the Parties' counsel met in person and conducted arms-length settlement negotiations for a full day. After coming to an agreement in principle, the Parties have finalized the terms of this Settlement Agreement

According to the settlement agreement, the Class members could receive benefits from a $1.8 million settlement. $600,000 of the fund will be allocated as an award for attorney's fees, costs, and expenses.

On March 29, 2024, the settlement agreement was preliminarily approved.

CMA CGM S.A. announced on September 28, 2020 that it had suffered a ransomware attack. The unauthorized access impacted certain of their shipping subsidiaries' IT systems. Upon discovery of the unauthorized access, management immediately decided to suspend temporarily access to core IT system in order to prevent further contamination of the malware. The management also promptly notified the French data protection authority (ANSSI) and engaged independent cybersecurity experts, who, together with ANSSI and the Group's cybersecurity team, started investigating the cyber-attack and working to analyze the cyberattack and rebuild as needed their IT infrastructure.

The e-commerce platforms were particularly affected by the cyber-attack. Consequently, many online customer services (for example, e-booking, bills of lading and invoice printing) were unavailable from the date of the cyber-attack until October 11, 2020. During this period, manual orders were possible as well as through Direct Electronic Data Interchange, INTTRA and certain other third-party e-booking portals. However, such alternative solutions did not fully compensate for the bookings that are usually made on their e-commerce platforms, as they had an adverse impact on the efficiency and speed with which customer transactions are usually handled.

The loss of bookings was attenuated to some extent by the timing, the national holiday of Golden Week in China so fewer bookings due to factory closures, as well as by the rapid response put in place.

Further, the impact resulting from the incident can be estimated to be below $50 million. The Group's cyber liability insurance may cover part of the financial loss, but it is currently too early to predict the extent and timing of any cyber liability insurance pay-out.

To date, all operations and all material software have been put back to a normal service.

In May 2020, MGP Ingredients, Inc. was affected by a ransomware cyber-attack that temporarily disrupted production at its Atchison facilities.

MGP Ingredients' financial information was not affected and there is no evidence that any sensitive or confidential company, supplier, customer or employee data was improperly accessed or extracted from our network.

MGP Ingredients estimates that the ransomware attack adversely impacted gross profit by $1,728,000 primarily as a result of the business interruption.

The Company has insurance related to this event and is seeking to recover a portion, if not all, of any profit impact including the profit associated with any loss of revenue resulting from this event. The Company will record insurance recovery when it is probable of collection.

Following the attack, MGP implemented a variety of measures to further enhance our cybersecurity protections and minimize the impact of any future attack.

On February 25, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator Enel Energie Muntenia SA and found that it violated the provisions of art. 32 of the General Regulation on Data Protection, regarding the security of processing.

The operator Enel Energie Muntenia SA was sanctioned with a fine of 14,423.7 lei, the equivalent of 3,000 EURO ($3,545.87).

The violation of the security and confidentiality of personal data consisted in the fact that the operator Enel Energie Muntenia SA sent on the e-mail address of a client a natural person, personal data (name and surname, address, e-mail address, customer code, eneltel code) of another client.

The operator Enel Energie Muntenia SA was sanctioned for not implementing adequate technical and organizational measures in order to ensure a level of security appropriate to the processing risk generated, accidentally or illegally, by unauthorized disclosure or unauthorized access to personal data.

The National Supervisory Authority carried out the investigation following a notification submitted by a customer of the operator, which was accompanied by conclusive evidence regarding those reported.

The operators of the NetWalker (Mailto) ransomware have announced today that they've infected the network of Michigan State University, one of the US' oldest educational institutes.

The ransomware gang has given MSU administrators a week to pay an undisclosed ransom demand to decrypt their files. In case MSU officials refuse to pay or choose to restore from backups, the ransomware gang is prepared to leak documents stolen from the university's network on a special website the group is operating on the dark web. The attack may have occurred on May 25, 2020.

NetWalker operators have already published five images on the site to support their claims. These include two images showing a directory structure allegedly from the university's network, a passport scan for a student, and two scans of Michigan State financial documents.

Netwalker demands $6 million ransom but the University leadership did not pay the ransom, but the total remediation cost was estimated to be $1.09 million. The costs included IT response and recovery time, legal bills, notification of identity theft risk, and two years of credit monitoring and identity repair for personally identifiable information that was taken and published online by the attackers.

On June 11, 2020, Melissa Atkinson and Katie Renvall (Plaintiff) residents of the State of California, filed a class action lawsuit against Minted, Inc (Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to implement reasonable security measures and to properly encrypt certain personal information.

According to the complaint, to purchase goods and services on Defendant's website, customers create and populate user profiles with personally identifiable information (PII) such as first and last name, email address, password, home address, telephone number, and payment card information. Minted customers trust that their PII will be maintained in a secure manner and kept from unauthorized disclosure to third parties as outlined in Defendant's Privacy Policy.

On May 6, 2020, a computer hacking group using the pseudonym Shiny Hunters1 burst onto the 'dark web' scene when it attempted to sell more than 73.2 million records containing personally identifiable information from the user databases of eleven different companies, including Defendant.

On May 28, 2020, Defendant notified affected customers that their PII had been disclosed to unauthorized and malicious third parties. The breach compromised the consumers' name, email address, 'hashed' or 'salted' password, and telephone number, billing address, and shipping address(es). The two consumers claimed that Defendant has failed to maintain reasonable security controls and systems appropriate for the nature of the PII it maintains as required by the California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 and other common and statutory laws. Defendant also failed to maintain proper measures to detect hacking and intrusion.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, compensatory damages, punitive damages, statutory or civil penalties, injunctive or other equitable relief that directs Defendant to implement reasonable security procedures and practices to protect customers' PII that conform to relevant federal and state guidelines and industry norms, reasonable costs and expenses incurred in this action, including attorneys' fees and expert fees, and other relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On June 29, 2021, the top-class actions reported that the settlement will provide $5 million to provide compensation and other benefits for Defendant users who were affected by a data breach that occurred on or about May 6, 2020 and resulted in the theft of users' personal identifying information.

organization.name: Musculoskeletal Institute Chartered
organization.industry: Offices of Physicians (except Mental Health Specialists)

incident.description:
On June 30, 2020, Ray Stoll and Heidi Imhof (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action lawsuit against Musculoskeletal Institute, Chartered d/b/a Florida Orthopaedic Institute (FOI or Defendant) in the Circuit Court of the Thirteenth Judicial Circuit in and for Hillsborough County, Florida. The action arises out of Defendant's failure to properly secure and safeguard protected health information.

According to the complaint, as one of the largest orthopaedic conglomerates, Defendant collects, stores, and maintains a massive amount of protected health information and other personally identifiable data on its customers and/or patients. As a condition of providing health care services, Defendant requires that its patients entrust it with certain personal information. In its ordinary course of business, Defendant maintains personal information, including the name, address, zip code, date of birth, Social Security number, personal medical information, and protected health information of each current and former patient. Plaintiffs and current and former patients, relied on Defendant to keep their PII confidential and securely maintained, to use the information for business purposes only, and to make only authorized disclosures of the information.

On or about April 9, 2020, Defendant's computer system suffered a ransomware attack that encrypted the data stored on its servers. Defendant acknowledged that personal information of its patients was exposed during the incident containing personal and protected information, including Plaintiffs' PII (Data Disclosure). On June 18, 2020, Defendant finally publicly revealed the incident to current and former patients. The letter failed to advise of the actual date of the Data Disclosure, only when it was discovered, or why Defendant waited more than two (2) months after discovering the incident to notify patients of the Data Disclosure. Plaintiffs received Defendant's letters on or about June 27, 2020 nearly 3 months after the security incident was discovered.

Allegedly, Defendants failed to secure Plaintiffs' PII and also failed to adequately investigate the breach to determine the scope and expanse of the breach and failed to notify its patients within a reasonable time. As a result of the delayed response and notification, Plaintiffs and other affected individuals had no idea their PII had been compromised, and that they were, and continued to be, at significant risk to identity theft and various other forms of personal, social, and financial harm. As a consequence of the Data Disclosure, Plaintiffs suffered damages by taking measures to both deter and detect identity theft.

Plaintiffs brought the case on behalf of themselves and all individuals in the United States who are current or former patients or customers of Defendant, whose PII was exposed and accessed, and who suffered injury or harm resulting from the dissemination of their PII (Class Members).

Plaintiff sought for class certification, equitable relief enjoining Defendant from engaging in the wrongful conduct, actual, nominal, and consequential damages, attorneys' fees, costs, litigation expenses, prejudgment interest, and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On August 3, 2020, the case was removed from the Circuit Court to the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida.

On October 8, 2021, Plaintiffs amended their complaint.

On March 16, 2022, Plaintiffs filed their motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Defendant has agreed to pay and create a Settlement Fund of $4,000,000.

Under the terms of the settlement, class members can receive a cash payment for out-of-pocket loss reimbursement and lost time. Class members can claim up to $15,000 for out-of-pocket expenses. Class members can also claim up to five hours of lost time at $25 per hour.

The settlement also provides three years of identity restoration services through Aura. Class members can also receive identity theft Protection Services through Aura's Identity Guard Total, which typically retails at $196 per person and includes $1 million in identity theft insurance, credit bureau reports and other features.

In addition, Class Counsel will receive an award of Attorneys' Fees not to exceed one-third (33.33%) of the Settlement Fund or $1,333,333 and $17,307.21 in litigation costs. Unfortunately, no service/incentive awards will be given to the Plaintiffs.

On May 16, 2022, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On September 8, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On November 14, 2022, the Court granted the final motion for class action settlement and entered its final judgment directing to close the case.

In June 2020, NanoVibronix Inc experienced a cybersecurity incident. Specifically, NanoVibronix Inc believes that one or two unauthorized third parties were able to use an email domain similar to the company's to convince two of NanoVibronix Inc's customers to send payments in the aggregate amount of approximately $308,000 to unauthorized bank accounts that should have been sent to the company. The total amount of customer payments has been recovered and received by the company.

Accordingly, NanoVibronix Inc was a victim of business email compromise.

The Personal Data Protection Authority met, at his invitation Its President, in a regular meeting in the composition of the Department at its headquarters on 17/2/2021 and time 10.00, in order to examine the case mentioned in its history of this. The meeting was attended by George Batzalexis via video conference, Deputy Chairman, disabled by the President of the Authority, Konstantinos Menoudakou, and the alternate members Evangelos Papakonstantinou and Grigorios Tsolias, as rapporteur. They did not attend due to disability, although they were summoned legally in writing the regular members Charalambos Anthopoulos and Konstantinos Lambrinoudakis. The meeting was attended by order of the President without right Haris Symeonidou, Specialist Scientist - Auditor as Assistant Rapporteur and the Irini Papageorgopoulou, employee of the Administrative Department of the Authority, as secretary.

According to the first above complaint, the complainant, upon return product he had purchased from the Company in installments on his credit card, issued by the National Bank of Greece, and after finding that the installments continued to charge each month and credited the next, protested on Company and in communication it had with its representatives via facebook, was informed that a request for maturity of the installments has been submitted to the Bank. Following this, according to the complaint, on 26/6/2020 the complainant asked him to notify the Company of the request to the Bank regarding the obligation of installments of his credit card.

The complainant, on 22/7/2020 contacted the Company via a message to Facebook stating that the total amount of the purchase on the card had not been released but the installments were countered on a monthly basis (ie that the charge was not deducted in full) of the canceled transaction but there was a charge and automatic credit of each installment each month).

Imposes on the complained company under the name Dixons Southeast Europe KOTSOVOLOS the effective, proportionate and dissuasive administrative a fine appropriate to the case in accordance with special circumstances of this, amounting to 20,000 euros ($22,671.20) for the above Violations.

organization.name: National Research Corp
organization.industry: Marketing Research and Public Opinion Polling

incident.description:
The National Research Corporation was the target of an external ransomware attack in February 2020 which resulted in a temporary suspension of our services to clients. Since then, we have fully restored our services.

We recorded an insurance receivable of $2.8 million for incremental costs related to the cyber-attack that our insurer has confirmed as reimbursable. We are expecting reimbursement of $2.4 million of this amount in the quarter ending June 30, 2020. We expect the remaining $400,000 of costs to be paid directly by the insurer to our vendors. This $400,000 is also recorded in accrued expenses since we are the primary obligor of these costs. In addition, we incurred other expenses related to the incident including but not limited to professional fees and information technology costs amounting to approximately $285,000.

In 2020, The National Research Corporation received $3.3 million in insurance recoveries, and $447,000 was paid directly to certain vendors from the insurer related to a cyber-attack in February 2020 (the February incident).

organization.name: National Research Corp
organization.industry: Marketing Research and Public Opinion Polling

incident.description:
The National Research Corporation were the target of an external ransomware attack in February 2020 which resulted in a temporary suspension of our services to clients. Since then, we have fully restored our services.

Since then, the company have fully restored their services. Due to the attack in the three-month period ended March 31, 2020, we also recognized revenue adjustments decreasing revenue by approximately $280,000 for our estimate of variable consideration related to subscription-based services that could not be performed. These revenue adjustments and costs will be further evaluated and submitted as a loss claim to the insurer. We will record any insurance recovery when it is probable of collection. Due to insurance recoverability, we do not believe the cyber-attack will have a significant impact on our consolidated financial statements.

The National Research Corporation recorded $533,000, representing reimbursement for lost revenues, as insurance recoveries, and the remainder as a reduction to operating expenses.

On February 16, 2021, a class action complaint was filed by Mildred Baldwin (Plaintiff) against National Western Life Insurance Company (Defendant) in the Circuit Court of the 18th Judicial Circuit, Pettis County, Missouri.

According to the complaint, on or about August 15, 2020, Defendant discovered that an unauthorized person had gained access to its computer systems. The unauthorized person stole 656 gigabytes worth of confidential and protected personally identifiable information (PII), which included the PII of Defendant's former and current policyholders. Days later, the unauthorized person began publishing the leaked PII online. In the first of a series of posts, the unauthorized person published a screen shot of what appears to be a file containing Data Breach victims' credit card information. A few days later, on or about August 23, 2020, the unauthorized person posted screenshots of policyholders' Social Security numbers, dates of birth, full names, dates of death, addresses, policy numbers, and policy termination dates.

On January 25, 2021, Defendant began sending notices informing them that they have discovered a malware incident impacting certain company systems and that on December 21, 2020, they have confirmed that personal information was included in the impacted data. As a result of the incident, Plaintiff sustained loss and damages in the form of monetary losses, lost time, anxiety, and emotional distress.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons in the United States whose data was compromised in the Data Breach announced on January 25, 2021 and who were mailed the Notice Letter.

Plaintiff sought for a class certification, enjoining Defendant from further deceptive and unfair practices, punitive damages, statutory damages, pre- and post-judgment interest, attorneys' fees, costs, and further relief as may be appropriate under the circumstances.

On April 1, 2021, the case was removed from the Circuit Court to the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri.

On June 1, 2021, Plaintiff amended his complaint adding Douglas Dyrssen Sr. as Plaintiff.

On January 19, 2022, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Wherein, Defendant will create and provide a Settlement Fund in the amount of $4,400,000.

Under the settlement, Defendant provides for one year of Financial Shield, valued at $135 per person per year. The settlement also provides for five types of payments to each class member who submits a valid claim: (1) payment for up to 4 hours of self-attested time and 8 hours of documented lost time at $20 per hour; (2) reimbursement of up to $120 for credit monitoring services purchased after August 7, 2020 and before the date of Notice; (3) reimbursement of ordinary out-of-pocket expenses incurred as a result of the Incident up to $120 and (4) reimbursement for extraordinary out-of-pocket expenses up to $5,000 per Class Member. Members of the California Subclass may make a claim for an additional $50 payment.

In addition, Class Counsel will receive award of attorneys' fees and costs in the amount of $1,314,900. Plaintiffs will also receive service awards in the amount of $3,000 each.

On April 6, 2022, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On June 22, 2022, the Court entered an order granting the final approval of class action settlement.

On July 15, 2020, Neptune Wellness Solutions Inc. (Neptune Wellness) experienced a cybersecurity incident which was reported to the authorities. Neptune Wellness incurred other costs associated with the cybersecurity incident, including legal fees, investigative fees, costs of communications with affected customers and credit monitoring services provided to the corporation's current and former employees. Neptune Wellness expects to continue to incur costs associated with maintaining appropriate security measures and otherwise complying with its obligations. The expenses related to the cybersecurity incident totaled $1,983,286 in the three-month and six-month periods ended September 30, 2020, and are recorded under selling, general and administrative expenses in the condensed consolidated interim statement of loss and comprehensive loss.

Neptune continues to evaluate its protection and monitoring on a regular basis to reduce attacks and future risk of cyber incidents. Neptune Wellness has no indication of improper use of any of the data of the corporation or personal information of its employees in connection with the cybersecurity incident, however there can be no assurances that the corporation will not face future contingencies.

On January 29, 2021, the county sent a notification to 8,700 clients of its Family Health Division letting them know that their data may have been accessed on or around December 2, 2020.

Netgain Technology LLC, a vendor that provides technology services to Ramsey County, advised the county that its security had been breached by a hacker seeking to extort payment through a ransomware scheme.

Upon learning of the incident, Ramsey County said it suspended all use of Netgain's application, moved to manual backup procedures, and performed an extensive technical analysis of possible exposure of its clients' data. Law enforcement and the federal Office for Civil Rights were notified of the incident. The county also consulted with other local governments that were affected.

Upon learning of the incident, Ramsey County said it suspended all use of Netgain's application, moved to manual backup procedures, and performed an extensive technical analysis of possible exposure of its clients' data. Law enforcement and the federal Office for Civil Rights were notified of the incident. The county also consulted with other local governments that were affected.

About a month later, Netgain began alerting clients that service may be sluggish due to a ransomware attack. The company began shutting down certain data centers to try to isolate the malware.

The January 13, 2022 breach report filed by Entira to the Maine attorney general notes that the breach occurred and was discovered on December 7, 2020.

Netgain reportedly paid $2,300,000 ransom for the keys to decrypt data and prevent any further disclosures of data.

organization.name: North Shore Pain Management
organization.industry: Offices of Physicians (except Mental Health Specialists)

incident.description:
On October 14, 2020, Michael Scott Kappotis (Plaintiff) filed an amended class action complaint against North Shore Pain Management, LLC, Resolve I.T. Inc., and Resolve I.T. LLC (collectively, Defendants) in the Essex County Massachusetts Superior Court.

The lawsuit alleged that on or about April 16, 2020, Defendant resolve was the victim of a ransomware attack resulting in access by an unauthorized third party to certain computer servers. The data stolen in the Defendant North Shore Pain data breach included personal and protected health information belonging to North Shore patients. The breach exposed the information of about 12,000 patients. Upon information, the unauthorized access was discovered on or about April 21, 2020. As a result, Plaintiff and the class suffered damages.

Plaintiff sought for actual damages, costs and fees, and other relief the Court deems appropriate.

On October 28, 2022, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Wherein, Defendants have agreed to pay up to $200,000 of cumulative compensation to class members for payments of valid claims for Lost Time in the amount of $150 per member and documented Economic Losses in the amount of up to $1,500 per member, as well as to provide a comprehensive 3-year Credit Monitoring Product.

In addition, Class Counsel will seek attorney's fees in the amount not to exceed $225,000, plus reasonable litigation expenses. Plaintiff will also receive incentive award in the amount of $2,500.

On November 1, 2022, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On August 23, 2022, a class action lawsuit was filed by Kevin Curry and Christine Curry (collectively, Plaintiffs), and on behalf of all others similarly situated Novant Health, Inc., (Defendant) in the US District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina. This class action arises out of Defendant for its willful disclosure of its patients' personally identifiable information (PII) and personal health information (PHI).

According to the complaint, in May 2020, Defendant has engaged in a campaign to encourage its patients to use its digital healthcare platform and tools such as the MyChart patient portal, which allows patients to schedule and attend doctors' appointments, renew their prescriptions, view test results, and access virtual care options. Defendant's campaign involved the use of Facebook advertisements and Facebook's tracking pixels to monitor how patients interacted with Novant's website and patient care portal ('Facebook Pixel'). The Facebook Pixel is a piece of code that 'tracks the people and type of actions they take.' When a user accesses a website hosting the Facebook Pixel, Facebook's software script surreptitiously directs the user's browser to simultaneously send a separate message to Facebook's servers. The information sent to Facebook by Novant includes which pages the patient visits, which buttons are clicked, the specific information users enter forms (e.g., name, home address, phone number, email address), and other information including a patient's IP address.

Plaintiffs and Class Members were unaware that their PII and PHI were being surreptitiously transmitted to Facebook as they communicated with their healthcare provider. Indeed, Defendant has only now just started notifying Plaintiffs and Class Members about the disclosure of their PII and PHI to Facebook, meaning their information has been in the possession of and utilized by Facebook for possibly years before Defendant warned them.

As a proximate result of Defendant's acts and omissions, the private and sensitive PII and PHI of Plaintiffs and the Class Members was disclosed to a third party without authorization, causing Plaintiffs and the Class to suffer damages.

Plaintiffs and the Class Members sought for an award of damages, including, but not limited to, actual, consequential, punitive, and nominal damages; for an award of attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses; for prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded; and such other and further relief as this Court may deem just and proper.

On October 4, 2022, Plaintiffs request the Court consolidate all cases under the first-filed action, Curry, et al., v. Novant Health, Inc., Case No. 1:22-cv-00697 and caption the consolidated action as In re: Novant Health, Inc., Case No. 1:22-cv-00697.

On October 19, 2022, an order granting Plaintiff's motions to consolidate cases, (1:22-cv-00697 Doc. 13; 1:22-cv-00700 Doc. 5; 1:22-cv00709 Doc. 5; 1:22-cv-00799 Doc. 4), and these cases are hereby consolidated into the first filed action, Curry, et al., v. Novant Health, Inc., Case No. 1:22-cv-00697 and entitled In re: Novant Health, Inc.

On November 18, 2022, Plaintiffs filed their amended consolidated class action complaint.

On October 12, 2023, Plaintiffs filed their motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Defendant will establish a $6,660,000 non-reversionary Settlement Fund.

Class Counsel shall request the Court to approve an award of attorneys' fees not to exceed thirty-three percent (33% or $2,220,000.00) of the Settlement Fund plus reasonable Litigation Expenses not to exceed $30,000.00. Class Counsel shall request the Court to approve a service award of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each of the named Plaintiffs, which award is intended to recognize Plaintiffs for their efforts in the Litigation and commitment on behalf of the Settlement Class ('Service Award').

On November 6, 2023, the Court granted the parties' preliminary approval of class action settlement.

On June 17, 2024, the plaintiffs' unopposed motion to approve the class action settlement is granted.

organization.name: One Way Private Company
organization.industry: All Other Travel Arrangement and Reservation Services

incident.description:
On August 12, 2021, complaints were submitted to the Personal Data Protection Authority using the special form of the Authority, concerning the making of illegal telephone calls to promote products or services of the company Zenith communication with the complainants through One Way Private Company as its executor processing.

ZENITH carries out, both itself and through external partners, phone calls to potential customers to inform them for new products, any discounts and benefits. ZENITH has a position controller, and external partners (call centers) have a position processing the personal data of the subjects for

account of ZENITH during the exercise of the above activity.

ZENITH during the selection of its partners, who assist in promoting products and services uses

strict criteria, binds the processor under a special contract, as required by Article 28 of the GCC, and conducts it regular controls/inspections to verify that the conditions of the relevant legislation.
