ZENITH has contracted with One Way Private Company and, in addition, has signed with the company, as an executor processing, private personnel data processing contract character in which the context of staff processing is described data of the subjects and its obligations in relation to issues compliance with the relevant legal framework.

The period during which this omission occurred is on November 28, 2020, until December 18, 2020, and December 20, 2020, until February 3, 2021. The crowd of numbers called by One Way Private Company on its behalf ZENITH during the months of November and December were 851,972 and 732,322 respectively. The answered calls were 408,041 and 343,303 respectively. The exclusion process was automated soon after the error was detected from the lists of numbers in the register referred to in Article 11 so that it is no longer possible for a similar error to occur.

The Authority, after examining the data in the file, after hearing him rapporteur and clarifications from the assistant rapporteur, who attended without and withdrew after the hearing of the case and before

the conference and decision-making, after a thorough discussion.

The Authority requires the One-Way Private Company processor to effective, proportionate, and dissuasive administrative fine which appropriate to the case, according to the specific circumstances amounting to 30,000 euros or $33953.55.

organization.name: Picanol
organization.industry: Plastics and Rubber Industry Machinery Manufacturing

incident.description:
On January 13, 2020, Picanol Group, a large Belgian manufacturer of high-tech weaving machines, fell victim to a massive ransomware attack, which severely disrupted operations at the company's manufacturing plants in Belgium, Romania, and China.

The attack was discovered during the night when Picanol employees in China were unable to access IT systems. As the company's entire production process is managed by computers, large segments of their production came to a standstill.

Together with external experts, Picanol Group has made every effort to solve the attack and to minimize the impact on its activities and employees. The relevant authorities have been advised of the ransomware attack and they also supported Picanol Group in solving the problems.

Whilst the attack caused a serious disruption of the group's activities, production activities were restarted on a step-by-step basis with effect from Monday morning, January 20.

The relevant authorities and services have been informed about the ransomware attack on Picanol.

According to Picano's news release on January 31, 2020, the financial impact of the attack largely limited to the costs of external experts who were called in to repair the IT systems. Picanol Group expects the costs to be less than 1 million euros.

This morning, August 5, 2020, at approximately 4:00 AM PT, they became aware of an exploit on the Opyn ETH Put contracts via a user report in our Discord chat. This exploit allowed an attacker to 'double exercise' oTokens and steal the collateral posted by certain sellers of these puts.

At the time of this post, they've found 371,260 USDC that has been stolen from these contracts, but this amount may change as our investigation continues. 439,170 USDC from outstanding vaults was successfully recovered by a white hat hack that the Opyn team conducted on the Convexity Protocol to mitigate further loss.

On December 13, 2020, Check Point Software Technologies Ltd. (Check Point) identified two servers on its network that had versions of SolarWinds Orion software, which had been infected with malicious code by a persistent and reportedly nation-state-supported threat actor that allowed for unauthorized activity on affected computers and their networks (SolarWinds Compromise).

Shortly thereafter, a third-party vendor also notified Check Point of potential unauthorized activity in the Check Point environment. After an internal investigation, which commenced shortly after the discovery of the unauthorized activity, Check Point determined that the malicious activity in the Check Point environment related to the SolarWinds Compromise occurred at specific points during a four-month period from July through October 2020, and that this activity included communications with the threat actor's command-and-control server and execution of unauthorized software, including data compression software often used before data exfiltration. Through the internal investigation, Check Point further determined that two Check Point corporate accounts had been compromised. The investigation also revealed instances of the threat actors attempting to move laterally in the Check Point environment.

On October 22, 2024, the Securities and Exchange Commission imposed the company a penalty in the amount of $995,000 for data security violations.

Origin Protocol is scrambling to recover $7 million worth of stolen Origin Dollar (OUSD) after the recently launched 'stablecoin' project was hacked.

The San Francisco-based blockchain company disabled deposits to the vault after detecting a so-called re-entrancy attack that took place this morning (November 17).

Origin co-founder Matthew Liu, who tweeted news of the attack two hours after it took place, said the pilfered funds included $1 million 'deposited by Origin and our founders and employees'.

organization.name: Real Sporting De Gijon, Sa D

incident.description:
On June 16, 2020, the Director of the Spanish Agency for Data Protection (AEPD) agreed to initiate a sanctioning procedure to Real Sporting Degijon, S.A.D (claimed).

In particular, the Resolution outlines that the form submitted by Real Sporting de Gijon to members of the club did not comply with the applicable legislation, since consent did not consist in an affirmative action, and was therefore ambiguous. In fact, the Resolution highlights that the form aimed to collect data subjects' consent through their inaction, since they had to tick the relevant boxes in order to deny their consent to the sending of commercial communications.

Moreover, the Resolution found that Real Sporting de Gijon's conduct amounted to a violation of Article 7 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

On July 23, 2020, AEPD issued, a resolution in proceedings No. PS/00134/2020, fining El Real Sporting de Gijon S.A.D. C5,000 ($5,778.73) for unlawfully collecting data subjects' consent for the purpose of sending direct marketing communications.

A former Orting School District IT employee who resigned after being accused of improperly using district money now has been charged with first-degree computer trespass and third-degree malicious mischief.

Charging papers filed Monday in Pierce County Superior Court accuse 43-year-old Jason Irvin Rudolph of changing the password to his former wife's work email account, deleting five years of messages and setting an auto-reply message that she no longer worked there.

Someone accessed their son's gaming account and changed the son's email password in June from an IP address that belonged to Rudolph. This was after child custody disputes between Rudolph and his ex-wife.

There also was an online attack on the company's server. The business lost more than $10,000 as a result.

On January 27, 2022, the Hellenic Data Protection Authority (DPA) fined Ote Group, Inc a total of EUR 3,250,000 for violations of the General Data Protection Regulation.

Greece's telecoms operator Cosmote said the telephone data of thousands of Greek citizens have reportedly been stolen in a massive hacking operation that took place from September 1 to 5, 2021, through the OTE telecommunications network.

This file contained details of the calls made or received by mobile subscribers during those five days, specifically the phone number, the day and time of the call and its duration. Names were not included. The list also included information on the device type, the International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), the age, gender, average revenue per user (ARPU), base station coordinates and mobile subscriber program.

Ote was found to have infringed the GDPR due to inadequate security measures taken in relation to the infrastructure used in the context of the breach.

On October 28, 2021, an injunction order was filed against Otto srl by Garante per la protezione dei dati personali (The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data).

The injunction order was a result of the assessment by the Administrative and Social Police of the Palermo Police Headquarters wherein during the investigation, the presence of a video surveillance system was detected, consisting of 3 active and functioning cameras- two placed inside the room and one outside- suitable for identifying the interested parties. The company, despite having been informed of the possibility of producing defensive writings or documents in relation to the sanctioning procedure against it, has not sent any documentation.

Additionally, the use of surveillance video systems can determine the processing of personal data. The treatment must be carried out in compliance of the principle of transparency which presupposes that 'interested parties must always be informed that they are about to enter a video surveillance are'.

The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data sanctioned the company 2000 EUR for the violation of article 13 of the Regulation.

organization.name: Virgin Mobile Polska Sp Z O O

incident.description:
On December 3, 2020, The President of the Personal Data Protection Office (UODO) imposed a fine of PLN 1.9 million ($513,620) on Virgin Mobile Polska for the lack of implemented appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of the processed data.

UODO stated that the company infringed the principles of data confidentiality and accountability specified in the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Virgin Mobile did not carry out regular and comprehensive tests, measurements and evaluations of the effectiveness of the technical and organizational measures applied to ensure the security of the data processed. Activities in this regard were only undertaken when there were suspicions of vulnerability or in connection with organizational changes. Moreover, no tests were carried out to verify safeguards related to the transfer of data between applications related to the servicing of buyers of prepaid services. In addition, the vulnerability associated with data exchange in these systems was used by an unauthorized person to obtain data from some of the company's clients.

In connection with a data breach, as a result of which an unauthorized person obtained customers data from one of the databases, the Supervisory Authority carried out the inspection at the company. As a result of the irregularities found, the authority instituted administrative proceedings finalized with the imposition of a fine.

On September 29, 2020, the Authority received a complaint from XX, against the Company Palumbo Superyacht Ancona Srl for allegedly violating the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Inconstancy of an employment relationship with Palumbo started in April 2018, the same, on June 23, 2020, without any notice or communication, was inhibited from using their company account (XX), remaining deprived of the possibility of accessing their company account (XX), remaining deprived of the possibility of accessing it.

The account in question was still active, in fact, warnings/requests to enter the new password to re-enter it continued to be received on one's computer and telephone; in particular, the password was changed remotely without the person concerned having known or authorized it and without, however, being allowed to back up all correspondence.

On June 23, 2020, after receiving a message from the server in which it was communicated that the password had changed, he immediately communicated the circumstance to Palumbo, requesting the timely restoration of the account, essential for business communications and to be able to properly fulfill the contractual obligations assumed with the Company. The Company has never provided any feedback to the aforementioned requests sent by certified e-mail, persisting in denying access to a said e-mail address.

The documented requests had been sent not only to the Company but also to the lawyer of the same, both via e-mail and via WhatsApp, asking to know why they continued to keep their personal account active.

On April 7, 2022, Palumbo Superyacht Ancona Srl was ordered to pay the sum of EUR 50,000 ($54,510.50) as a pecuniary administrative sanction.

In 2020, Grant Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

In 2020, Rapides Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

PENNCREST School District was hit by a ransomware attack. PENNCREST's system was attacked through the remote desktop of a former employee that hadn't been used in several years, according to Glasspool. The district's technology director detected unusual network activity and identified associated pop-up messages stating that files were encrypted on February 24, 2020.

The district contacted Carnegie Mellon University Cyber Terrorism Division and disabled the compromised account. A suspicious connection associated with the attack was traced back to Russia. A subsequent digital forensic investigation concluded that no data had been exported from the system and that there had been no unauthorized access to sensitive information.

The ransomware intrusion involved 'older server files that weren't frequently used by anybody,' according to Superintendent Timothy Glasspool.

Glasspool declined to comment on whether any of the money was paid to the Russian hackers believed responsible for the attack.

Unlocking the data that had been encrypted cost the district $10,000 -- the amount of the deductible on its cyber insurance policy, Glasspool said. The district's insurance company, AXIS Capital, paid out nearly $75,000, including costs for investigations into the attack.

location.street: Iancu De Hunedoara Nr 8 Bloc H3 Etaj 4 Sector 1

incident.description:
The National Supervisory Authority (ANSPDCP) completed an investigation at the operator SC Viva Credit IFN SA, finding the violation of art. 12 para. (3) and (4) of the General Regulation on Data Protection, by reference to art. 17 of the same Regulation.

In particular, the ANSPDCP highlighted that the operator had not provided the applicant with information on the actions taken following the request within one month (or up to three months if a reason for the delay is provided). In addition, the ANSPDCP noted the obligation, under Article 12(3) of the GDPR, to respond to data subject requests without undue delay and at the latest within one month from the receipt of the request. Therefore, the ANSPDCP requested that the company respond to the data subject request.

On July 30, 2020, the ANSPDCP announced, that it had imposed a RON 9,680 (approx. C2,000) ($2,350.91) fine on SC Viva Credit IFN SA for failure to adequately respond to a data subject's request for erasure of its data under Article 17 of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

organization.name: Pennsylvania Adult Teen Challenge
organization.industry: Residential Mental Health and Substance Abuse Facilities

incident.description:
On April 02, 2021, Kris Reese and Tod Saylor filed a class action complaint in the Pennsylvania Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia County against Teen Challenge Training Center Inc. d/b/a Pennsylvania Adult & Teen Challenge (Defendant). The action arises out of Defendant's failure to properly secure and safeguard customers' personally identifiable information (PII) from a 2020 data breach.

According to the complaint, Defendant is an addiction treatment facility that offers both inpatient and outpatient treatment programs. Defendant failed to adequately safeguard its patients electronically stored personally identifiable information and protected health information in connection with a cybersecurity incident that Teen Challenge experienced on or about between July 27, 2020 and July 30, 2020.

On March 27, 2023, preliminary approving class action settlement was granted by the court.

On August 29, 2023, an order granting Plaintiff's motion for approval of attorneys' fees, expenses and service awards.

The court approves those payments and orders Defendant to pay $250,000 to Class Counsel as attorneys' fees and expenses and to pay $1,500 to each of the named Plaintiffs, Kris Reese and Todd Saylor, as a service award pursuant to and in accordance with the terms of the settlement.

Perlberger Law Associates, P.C. (PLA) loss funds due to a money laundering scheme through business email compromise.

On June 8, 2020, a man identifying himself as Julio Gomez, President of Tools & Equipment Supply, LLC, contacted PLA, seeking legal representation in order to collect on a debt, purportedly owed by a customer, Derbyshire Machine & Tool Co. (Derbyshire), a company based in Philadelphia, to whom equipment had been sold, but not paid for.

The initial contact was by telephone and then followed up with a series of emails, transmittal of a fee agreement, and a request that, before initiating a suit, Derbyshire be informed that, short of immediate payment of the full amount, litigation would follow, in which legal fees would be demanded.

Without initiating suit, Derbyshire, wrote a letter on June 15, 2020, and accompanied said letter with a purported Citibank issued bank check in the amount of $199,550, made out to PLA.

PLA deposited with Wells Fargo. on June 23, 2020, upon notice that the funds were available, PLA authorized distribution to its purported client, but unbeknownst to PLA, the client's wiring instruction would transfer the money to a Nigerian bank.

A Philadelphia food bank has been scammed out of nearly $1m following a classic business email compromise (BEC) attack, it has emerged.

The nature of the theft was left unsaid in Philabundance's statement Tuesday, December 1, 2020 but CEO Loree Jones told the Inquirer the thieves used a phishing scam to take close to a million dollars.

According to the Inquirer report, cyber thieves infiltrated the group's email server and then mimicked a construction company that had done work for Philabundance. The thieves emailed a fake invoice with instructions leading to a bank account controlled by the thieves. Someone then sent the thieves the payment about $923,000.

Despite that concern, the nonprofit reassured donors that their data was secure. It said its online donation system was unaffected and no personal data was breached.

The phishers who targeted Philabundance were sophisticated, spoofing an email that the nonprofit was expecting to receive.

organization.name: Phoenix Emergency Medical Supply LLC
organization.industry: Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On November 23, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed by Dr. David Simai (Plaintiff), individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, in the United States District Court Eastern District of New York against Phoenix Emergency Medical Supply, LLC and John Does 1-10 (Defendants) for violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

According to the complaint, between April 10, 2020 through May 26, 2020, Plaintiff received the unsolicited fax advertisement on his facsimile machine. Plaintiff, a doctor with a medical practice, would be the target of an unsolicited fax advertising the sale of medical masks and medical gowns to medical practitioners. Defendants either negligently or willfully violated the rights of Plaintiff and other recipients in sending the faxes. Plaintiff had no prior relationship with Defendant and had not authorized the sending of fax advertisements to Plaintiff.

Plaintiff alleges on information and belief, based on the generic nature of the fax, that there are more than 40 members of the class.

Plaintiff sought for an award of statutory damages, costs of suit and such other or further relief.

On March 19, 2021, Cogan District Judge deemed Plaintiff's response to the Court's Order to Show Cause of March 12, 2021 to constitute his late motion for a default judgement. The motion for default judgment is therefore granted. On March 23, 2021, the Court ordered and adjudged that the motion for default judgement is granted and that judgement is entered in favor of Plaintiff and against Defendant in the amount of $12,000.

organization.name: Razer Inc
organization.industry: Computer Terminal and Other Computer Peripheral Equipment Manufacturing

incident.description:
Gaming hardware maker Razer has accused an IT vendor for allegedly causing a widely reported cyber-security breach in 2020 that resulted in a leak of its customer and sales data. The data leak, which took place over three months from June 18, 2020 to September 10, 2020, made headlines when a security researcher revealed that the personal information of about 100,000 Razer customers could have been exposed.

Experts appointed by both companies agreed that the cybersecurity breach on June 18 was caused by a security misconfiguration, security settings for the ELK Stack being manually disabled, that same day. The management team became aware of the breach on September 9, 2020.

Razer is claiming at least US$7 million (S$9.85 million) in losses from the vendor, French multinational info-technology company Capgemini. It includes a significant loss of profits, costs incurred in investigating and responding to the incident and costs incurred by corresponding and dealing with regulators.

According to The Straits Times, Razer incurred US$6.1 million in loss of profits from Razer's e-commerce platform.

organization.name: Razer Inc
organization.industry: Computer Terminal and Other Computer Peripheral Equipment Manufacturing

incident.description:
Gaming hardware maker Razer has accused an IT vendor for allegedly causing a widely reported cyber-security breach in 2020 that resulted in a leak of its customer and sales data. The data leak, which took place over three months from June 18, 2020 to September 10, 2020, made headlines when a security researcher revealed that the personal information of about 100,000 Razer customers could have been exposed.

Experts appointed by both companies agreed that the cybersecurity breach on June 18 was caused by a security misconfiguration, security settings for the ELK Stack being manually disabled, that same day. The management team became aware of the breach on September 9, 2020.

Razer is claiming at least US$7 million (S$9.85 million) in losses from the vendor, French multinational info-technology company Capgemini. It includes a significant loss of profits, costs incurred in investigating and responding to the incident and costs incurred by corresponding and dealing with regulators.

According to The Straits Times, Razer paid US$60,000 for a forensic expert to investigate the incident, about US$320,000 to engage a law firm to deal with regulators, and a US$2,000 payment to cyber-security consultant Bob Diachenko, who discovered the breach.

On December 9, 2021, the Warsaw University of Technology received a fine of PLN 45,000 ($11,232.63)for failure to apply appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure the ability to continuously ensure the confidentiality of processing services, also for failure to regularly test, measure and evaluate the effectiveness of measures. The university also did not consider the risk related to data processing in the application.

Proceedings against the University were initiated after notification of a data protection breach was received by the Office for Personal Data Protection Urzad Ochrony Danych Osobowych (UODO). As indicated, an unauthorized person downloaded a database containing the personal data of students and lecturers (over 5,000 people) from the university's IT network resources.

As it was established during the administrative procedure, the organizational unit of the University of Technology used an application created by university employees, which was used to sign up for courses and allowed access to the history of teaching, grades, or payment of fees. The application was modified depending on the administrator's needs. At the beginning of January 2020, an unauthorized person used the functionality of placing files in the application, having access to credentials. In turn, at the beginning of May 2020, an unauthorized collection of personal data was performed.

It was also noted that the GDPR, the general regulation on data protection, obliges the controller to regularly test, measure, and evaluate the effectiveness of technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of processing. The administrator should actively and at every stage check the security of personal data. According to the findings of the Personal Data Protection Office, the University of Technology did not periodically verify the measures applied.

Professional Business Systems Inc, which does business as Practicefirst Medical Management Solutions and PBS Medcode Corp, had its systems hacked in November 2020. The threat actor exfiltrated sensitive data from its systems and then deployed ransomware to encrypt files. As proof of data theft and to pressure Practicefirst into paying the ransom, files were uploaded to the threat actor's dark web data leak site. The leaked data included screenshots of 13 patients' protected health information. Practicefirst's investigation confirmed the threat actor exfiltrated files from its systems, which contained names, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, Social Security numbers, diagnoses, medication information, and financial information.

On May 23, 2023, New York Attorney General Letitia James fined $550,000 to the medical management company for failing to protect New Yorkers' personal information, including health records. Practicefirst's failure to make a timely software update made their networks susceptible to a cyberattack, which affected more than 1.2 million individuals nationwide, including over 428,000 New Yorkers. Practicefirst's data security failures violated both state law and the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). As a result of agreement, Practicefirst has agreed to pay $550,000 in penalties to New York, strengthen its data security practices, and offer affected consumers free credit monitoring services.

On August 28, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed by Flo-Tech Mechanical Systems, Inc. (Defendant) and on behalf of all others similarly situated in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois Eastern Division against Progressive Business Funding, Inc, d/b/a Shamrock Business Capital (Defendants) for violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) and Illinois Consumer Fraud Act (ICFA).

According to the complaint, on August 13, 2020, Defendant transmitted an unsolicited facsimile advertisement to Plaintiff's Facsimile Number. The Subject Facsimile was sent by Defendant without Plaintiff's prior express invitation or permission, in writing or otherwise. The Subject Facsimile promotes business loans. Defendant promoted business loans through the composition of and sending of similar unsolicited advertisements to consumers in this State. The transmission of the Subject Facsimile interrupted and disturbed Plaintiff's right of privacy and right to not be disturbed with unsolicited advertising facsimiles.

Plaintiff sought for an award Plaintiff and the class an amount to be determined to reimburse Plaintiff and the class members for the amount of harm caused by Defendant's violations of ICFA, punitive damages, attorney's fees and costs, declare that Defendant vicariously liable for the conduct of and third-party, enjoin Defendant from additional violations of ICFA, award pre-judgment interest, costs, and such further relief.

On October 19, 2020, judgment by default is entered in favor of Plaintiff and against Defendant with $ 1,500.00 in statutory damages, $ 3,275.00 in attorney fees and $578.25 in costs.

The National Supervisory Authority completed on June 23, 2020 an investigation at the operator Proleasing Motors SRL and found the violation of the provisions of art. 32 para. (1) and (2) of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator Proleasing Motors SRL was sanctioned with a fine in the amount of 72,642 lei, the equivalent of 15,000 Euro ($16,839.6).

The security breach consisted in the fact that, on the Facebook page on which the operator carried out an online contest to attract customers participating in the car service, a document was posted with a capture from the source code of the website in which the access password to the forms filled in by the contest participants was also included.

This situation led to the unauthorized viewing and access to the personal data of a number of 436 customers of the operator, on the website of Proleasing Motors SRL, and to the unauthorized disclosure of these data, contrary to the obligations provided by art. 32 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The corrective measure was also applied to the operator to review and update the technical and organizational measures implemented as a result of the risk assessment for the rights and freedoms of individuals, including electronic communications procedures, so as to avoid similar incidents of unauthorized disclosure. of the personal data processed, reported to art. 58 para. (2) lit. d) of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

On February 19, 2021, Joshua Lander (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California against QuickRecruit, LLC (Defendant) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

Plaintiff is not a customer of the Defendant nor has he done business with them. Nonetheless, Around December 21, 2020, Defendant sent automated telemarketing text messages to Plaintiff. Plaintiff had not given any prior express consent to be contacted by Defendant and the text messages sent were for non-emergency purposes.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On May 7, 2021, Plaintiff filed a Notice of Settlement.

On June 21, 2021, Judgment is entered in favor of Plaintiff Joshua Lander in the amount of $4,000.

On October 19, 2020, Noreen Pfeiffer, Jose Contreras, and Susan Wright (Plaintiffs) individually, and on behalf of all others similarly situated, filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court Central District of California against RadNet Inc. (Defendant) for failure to provide adequate data security of individuals' PII that has been exposed to those who should not have access to it.

According to the complaint, on or about July 18, 2020, an unknown third party gained unauthorized access to a RadNet server that was used to store certain employee data and copied files to an external server. The unlawful access information included employee names, social security numbers, driver's license numbers, and additional data such as dates of birth, addresses, and passport numbers.

On or about September 28, 2020, Plaintiffs Pfeiffer, Jose Contreras, and Wright received a letter titled 'Notice of Data Breach,' dated September 21, 2020, from RadNet. The letter stated that their PII may have been compromised. Upon information and belief, there are 22,970 individuals were identified their personal information may have been implicated in the security incident.

Plaintiff and the Class members sought an award for statutory damages, actual damages, cost, reasonable attorney's fees, and all other relief as may be just and proper.

On February 22, 2022, the court approved the settlement agreement of $2.6 million which includes the award of class counsel $650,000 and $49,489.39 in costs and expenses. The court also awards service awards of $1,500 to each of the Class Representatives.

location.street: Str. Dr. Staicovici Nr. 2 Et. 7, Sectorul 5

incident.description:
The National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP) completed an investigation at the operator Qualitance QBS SA and found the violation of the provisions of art. 32 of the General Regulation on Data Protection.

In particular, the ANSPDCP noted that its investigation was prompted by complaints alleging that the organization had sent information by email to 295 persons, thereby disclosing the email addresses of other recipients. In this regard, the ANSPDCP concluded that the organization did not implement enough security measures to ensure the confidentiality of personal data.

On December 29, 2020, ANSPDCP announced, that it had imposed a fine of RON 4,867.50 (approx. C1,000) ($1,221.40) on Qualitance QBS SA.

organization.name: Railworks Corporation
organization.industry: Other Heavy and Civil Engineering Construction

incident.description:
On March 19, 2020, Cornelius Coleman and Linda Horan (Plaintiff) individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court Southern District of New York against Railworks Corporation, Kevin Riddett, and Bob Cummings (Defendants).

According to the class complaint, on or about January 27, 2020, an unauthorized third party encrypted Defendants' servers and systems resulting in the Data Breach and exposure of the PII of thousands of persons. Some Plaintiffs received an email notification on or about January 30, 2020 and/or February 7, 2020, from Defendants informing them of the Breach. Other Plaintiffs received or should have received correspondence at varying points throughout March 2020, and dated on or about February 27, 2020, informing them of the breach. Therefore, Defendants did not inform some of the Plaintiffs for over a month following the Breach. The correspondence received by Plaintiffs informed them that as a result of the Breach, their PII was compromised, which could include their name, address, driver's license number and/or government issued ID, Social Security number, date of birth and date of hire/termination and/or retirement. By disclosing Plaintiffs' PII to cybercriminals, Defendants put all Plaintiffs at risk. Plaintiffs seek to hold Defendants responsible for the harm caused by its negligence.

Plaintiffs' and the members of the putative class sought for an injunctive relief and/or declaratory relief, including an Order requiring Defendants to properly secure and fully encrypt all confidential information, statutory damages, reasonable attorney's fees and costs, and any other relief as the Court deems just and proper.

On December 4, 2020, Plaintiffs moved for class certification and for the preliminary approval of Settlement Agreement. The Defendants offered to pay for credit monitoring and identity theft protection through April 1, 2023, for all Class Members who previously signed up for one year of credit monitoring and identity theft protection when offered by the Defendants in connection with the January 2020 security incident before the lawsuit was filed, without the need for filing a claim form.

The monitoring was also made available to Class Members who submitted a claim form seeking identity theft protection within 30 days of the final judgment.

Those who have spent time remedying issues related to identity theft directly caused by the Defendants' data breach were also eligible for reimbursement. Class Members must submit a claim form with supporting documentation for up to five hours at a rate of $10 per hour, for a maximum of $50.

On January 4, 2021, the preliminary approval of class action settlement was granted.

On April 22, 2021, Plaintiffs moved for the final approval of class action settlement.

On May 13, 2021, the Court approved Plaintiffs' motion for final approval and adopted all defined terms set forth in the Settlement Agreement for the Final Judgment. The Defendants shall pay $493,000 in attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses and $5000 each as incentive payments to Plaintiffs Cornelius Coleman and Linda Horan for being Class Representatives. On the same day, the case was terminated.

The Norwegian Data Protection Authority (NDPA) has imposed an administrative fine of EUR 47,500 ($56,329.8) to Raelingen Municipality. The fine is imposed after data concerning health of children with special needs was processed using the digital learning platform Showbie.

The case started when NDPA received a notification of a personal data breach from the municipality. Upon further investigation of the case, it appeared that the level of security of the application was not proportionate with the risk, says Director-General of the Norwegian Data Protection Authority, Bjorn Erik Thon. - This is obviously a significant issue, as it has to do with both children and personal data concerning health.

The infringement affects 15 children with special needs. The application Showbie has been used to send health related personal data between the school and the homes of the children.

The necessary risk and data protection impact assessments and testing have not been completed before the application was put to use. Lack of security measures when logging in to the application has made it possible to obtain information about other children in the group.

organization.name: Military Advantage, Inc.
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
On May 24, 2023, a class action lawsuit was filed by Darrick Young, Jeremy Lam and David Ramirez (collectively, Plaintiffs), individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated against Military Advantage, Inc. d/b/a Military.com (Defendant) in the State of Illinois in the Circuit Court of the 18th Judicial Circuit County of Dupage for violation of the federal Video Privacy Protection Act (VPPA).

According to the complaint, Defendant collects and shares the personal information of visitors to its website and mobile application ('App') with third parties. Defendant does this through cookies, software development kits ('SDK'), and pixels. In other words, digital subscribers to Military.com have their personal information disclosed to Defendant's third-party business partners. The Facebook pixel is a code Defendant installed on the Military.com website allowing it to collect users' data. More specifically, it tracks when digital subscribers enter the Military.com website or App and view Video Media. Thus, without telling its digital subscribers, Defendant profits handsomely from its unauthorized disclosure of its digital subscribers' Personal Viewing Information to Facebook.

Defendant chose to disregard Plaintiffs' and hundreds of thousands of other Military.com digital subscribers' statutorily protected privacy rights by releasing their sensitive data to Facebook.

Plaintiffs and on behalf of the Class, sought for punitive damages; for prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded; for an order of restitution and all other forms of equitable monetary relief; for injunctive relief as pleaded or as the Court may deem proper; and for an order awarding Plaintiffs and the Class their reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses and costs of suit.

On July 21, 2023, a settlement agreement has been reached. Defendant will pay or cause to be paid a total of up to $7,350,000 in cash. Settlement class members includes users who have a Facebook account and who accessed a video through Military.com on the same browser they used to access Facebook between June 8, 2020, and November 1, 2022.

Under the Settlement agreement, class members can receive an equal share of the net settlement fund. Based on the class definition, each class member is expected to receive up to $30. Military Advantage has also agreed to stop using Facebook Pixel tracking for at least two years in order to respect user privacy.

Class Representative Ramirez may request a Service Award of $5,000, and Class Representatives Young and Lam may request Service Awards of $2,500 each. Class Counsel may receive, subject to Court approval, attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses not to exceed one-third of the Settlement Fund $2,450,000.

On July 26, 2023, the Court released an order granting preliminary approval of class action settlement agreement.

On October 26, 2023, Plaintiffs filed a motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On November 9, 2023, final judgment and order dismissal with prejudice was granted by the Court.

On March 16, 2021, Kyle Rodriguez (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against River City Bank (Defendant) in the Superior Court of the State of California in and for the County of Sacramento. The action arises out of a data breach incident involving the Defendant.

According to the complaint, on September 29, 2020, Defendant discovered some unauthorized activity performed by a Bank employee. This individual downloaded customer data to a personal storage drive and later sent the information to a third party. In doing so, the employee exceeded their authorized access, which was limited to accessing the Bank's data for legitimate bank purposes. Plaintiff claimed that the Defendant did not inform their customers of the breach until November 2020.

On June 29, 2022, the Defendant agreed to pay $140,000 to resolve the claims.

On August 5, 2020, a cyber-attack on a council's computer systems is estimated to have cost more than GBP 10m.

About 135,000 people were without online public services after Redcar and Cleveland's website and computers were targeted in February. The local authority has been in discussions with the government over covering the cost of the attack. It said it had made 'improvements' to its cyber-defences 'with further upgrades planned'.

The council, which has been under pressure to reveal the cost of the incident, gave the figure in a budget update report.

Online appointment bookings, planning documents, social care advice and council housing complaints systems were among services knocked offline and experts from the UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) were drafted in to help restore them.

A figure of GBP 10.4m (USD 13,581,900) has been given to the government along with other information to assist with a due diligence process. Extensive recovery or replacement work to the IT infrastructure and systems made up u2.4m of the overall cost, the Local Democracy Reporting Service said.

The cost to individual departments amounted to u3.4m, while computer systems being out of action led to a reduction in enforcement income and lower collection levels for council tax and business rates and caused a further u1m impact, the council said.

The report said that at the time of the attack the council had industry standard tools deployed to secure its computer network, which had been configured to provide optimum protection.

On September 8, 2021, the Danish Data Protection Agency has reported the Central Jutland Region to the police for not ensuring a sufficiently high level of security around the region's storage of patient records in an archive in Livstilscenter Braedstrup. The Danish Data Protection Agency has set a fine of DKK 400,000 for violating the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

On June 12, 2020, the Danish Data Protection Agency received a report of a breach of personal data security from the Central Jutland Region. The report stated that all patients and staff in a lifestyle center had had access to a building where up to 100,000 physical patient records were kept, containing health information and social security number information. In addition, it was possible for passers-by to see the cover of some of the records - where the social security number, name and specialty appeared - through a window to the building.

The unintentional access was due to the fact that the key cards that employees and patients were handed out gave access to all three buildings in Livstilscenter Braedstrup, regardless of whether the user had a need for this. In addition, the windows to the building were not frosted or the like.

In this connection, the Danish Data Protection Agency found that the Central Jutland Region had not established appropriate security measures regarding the storage of personal data.

Overall, the Danish Data Protection Agency found that the Central Jutland Region had not established appropriate physical security measures regarding the storage of the physical patient records, including that the region had not established sufficient guidelines for access restrictions in the production of key cards and that the region had not performed appropriate regular testing, assessment and evaluation. safety measures.

On March 2, 2021, the Lithuanian State Data Protection Inspectorate (SDPI) imposed a fine of 15,000 or $18,000, on the State Enterprise Center of Registers (State Enterprise) for improper implementation of technical and organizational data security measures.

State Enterprise was fined for breaches of Article 32 (1) (b) and (c) GDPR, i.e. failure to ensure the integrity, availability and resilience of data processing systems and services and failure to restore access to personal data in the event of a physical or technical incident within the legal deadline.

Starting in July 2020, the SDPI conducted an investigation of a data breach in the systems maintained by the State Enterprise in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The investigation determined that registers and state information systems maintained by the State Enterprise that were affected during the personal data security breach including: Electronic health services and collaboration infrastructure information system; Real estate register; Real estate cadastre; Register of Legal Entities; Population Register of the Republic of Lithuania; Register of Seizure Acts; Mortgage Register of the Republic of Lithuania; Register of wills; Register of marriage contracts; Register of credentials; Register of Inactive and Limited Persons; Register of Contracts; Information system for participants in legal entities; Bailiffs information system; License information system; Money Restriction Information System; Legal aid information system; Information services information system; Electronic signature and time stamping service; Register Center Document Management System; Personnel administration system of the Center of Registers; Accounting software of the Register Center.

Considering that the State Enterprise is the data processor and / or data controller of these 22 registers and information systems, taking into account the level of development of technical possibilities, implementation costs and the nature, scope, context and objectives of data processing, as well as data processing costs.

SDPI points out that ensuring the security of personal data is not only the direct responsibility of the data controller, but also the data controller, as provided for in Article 32 of the BDAR. The controller is directly responsible for non-compliance or improper performance of this obligation.

In January 2021, Reserve Bank of New Zealand reported a data breach of a third-party file sharing software application-Accellion FTA-that we used to share and store information. Following this malicious attack, the software application was secured and closed. Reserve Bank of New Zealand current focus is on addressing the reports' recommendations and continuing to support stakeholders affected by the breach.

Reserve Bank of New Zealand estimate the final cost of the breach response, including internal resources, will be around $3.5 million. This excludes any process improvement initiatives we are likely to take as a result of the lessons learnt. All costs associated with the breach were covered under its baseline budgets.

The main details of the costs include: 17,500 hours of internal resources redirected to help with the response, $1,800,000 spent on specialist external resources, these being individuals to supplement its staff on the stream activity or organizations delivering a defined piece of work, and services related to physical facilities including the setup of a response room to allow co-location of the response team. Additional physical security was also required onsite.

On August 20, 2020, Robert Raslavsky (Plaintiff), individually and in behalf of others similarly situated filed a class action complaint in the Superior Court for the County of Suffolk of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts against NewRez LLC d/b/a Shellpoint Mortgage Servicing (Defendant) for the violation of the Consumer Protection Act and the Massachusetts Debt Collection Regulations.

Shellpoint is a mortgage servicing lender that manages mortgage loans after they are originated. According to the servicer's website, Shellpoint manages payments from over 1.7 million homeowners across the country. Unfortunately, Shellpoint may violate debt collection laws when collecting payments from its customers by by placing more than two debt collection calls in one seven day period. The plaintiff in the case says that he received an excess of two calls within a seven day period from Shellpoint when the payment was over 30 days past due. This allegedly happened several times during a period of four years. The plaintiff maintains that these repeated calls were a distraction, inconvenient and caused him to become angry, frustrated and anxious. Shellpoint hasn't admitted any wrongdoing but agreed to pay $361,660 to resolve these class action allegations. The settlement benefits Massachusetts residents who received more than two debt collection calls from Shellpoint within a seven day period.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

Shellpoint agreed to pay over $361,000 to resolve claims that it placed harassing debt collection calls to consumers.

On March 5, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Daniel Beckman (Plaintiff) against Robinhood Financial, LLC, Robinhood Markets, Inc. and Robinhood Securities, LLC (Defendants) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's negligence and failure to maintain adequate infrastructure.

According to the complaint, Defendant is an online brokerage firm founded in 2013 that touts itself as a pioneer in commission-free investing. Defendant's customers place securities trades through the firm's website, by using a web-based application. Unfortunately, on March 2, 2020, Defendant's trading systems completely crashed and experienced a total outage of its operating systems. On March 3, 2020, a spokesperson of Defendant admitted that the cause of the outage was instability in a part of their infrastructure that allows their systems to communicate with each other.

According to Defendant's blog post, the cause of the outage was stress on their infrastructure which struggled with unprecedented load. That in turn led to a 'thundering herd' effect triggering a failure of our DNS system. Multiple factors contributed to the unprecedented load that ultimately led to the outages. The factors included, among others, highly volatile and historic market conditions; record volume; and record account sign-ups.

As a result of the outage and Defendant's conduct, Plaintiff and the class suffered losses in their trading accounts and damages and continues to expose them to harm. Upon information, Class members number in the hundreds of thousands and up to ten million.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all customers of Defendant within the United States who were not able to execute trades on options that expired during the Outage.

Plaintiff sought for an order certifying the case as a class action, declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin Defendant from engaging in the unlawful practices, compensatory damages, punitive damages, pre- and post-judgment interest, reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses and costs of suit and further relief as the Court may deem proper.

On July 14, 2020, the Court consolidated related cases: 3:20-cv-01769-JD, 3:20-cv-01800-JD, 3:20-cv-01877-JD, 3:20-cv-01909-JD, 3:20-cv-02286-JD, 3:20-cv-02343-JD, 3:20-cv-02352-JD, 3:20-cv-02594-JD, 3:20-cv-02665-JD, 3:20-cv-02669-JD, 3:20-cv-03218-JD and 3:20-cv-03550-JD to the current proceeding (20-cv-01626-JD).

On August 21, 2020, a consolidated class action complaint was filed by the Plaintiffs.

On May 26, 2022, the parties have jointly notified the Court that they have reached a settlement in principle resolving the action.

On August 5, 2022, a Motion for Preliminary Approval of Proposed Class Action Settlement was filed by Plaintiffs. Wherein, Defendant has agreed to pay $9,900,000 non-reversionary cash settlement on behalf of approximately 150,000 investors who experienced losses associated with the March 2020 outages.

Under the settlement agreement, the Class Members will recover just under 50% of their calculated losses. The Settlement Administration Expenses shall not exceed $400,000 and will be paid out of the Settlement Fund. Plaintiffs will seek Service Awards no more than $2,500 per Plaintiff, which amounts to $37,500 in total. Class Counsel will also receive Attorneys' Fees and Expenses no more than 30% of the Settlement Fund (or no more than $2,970,000) in Attorneys' Fees and up to $1,120,000 in unreimbursed expenses.

On December 2, 2022, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On March 27, 2023, Plaintiffs filed their notice of motion for final approval of the class action settlement.

On March 2, 2020, Robinhood experienced an outage that resulted to a complete crash on its trading platform. On March 3, 2020, a spokesperson of Robinhood admitted that the cause of the outage was instability in a part of their infrastructure that allows their systems to communicate with each other.

According to Robinhood's blog post, the cause of the outage was stress on their infrastructure which struggled with unprecedented load. That in turn led to a 'thundering herd' effect triggering a failure of our DNS system. Multiple factors contributed to the unprecedented load that ultimately led to the outages. The factors included, among others, highly volatile and historic market conditions; record volume; and record account sign-ups.

The customers claimed that they were harmed by the service outages and lost around $20.4 million because they were unable to complete transactions.

On June 30, 2021, Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) announced that it had fined Robinhood Financial LLC $57 million and ordered the firm to pay $12.6 million in restitution, plus interest, to thousands of harmed customers. FINRA considered the widespread and significant harm suffered by customers, including millions of customers who received false or misleading information from the firm, millions of customers affected by the firm's systems outages in March 2020, and thousands of customers the firm approved to trade options even when it was not appropriate for the customers to do so.

The sanctions represent the largest financial penalty ever ordered by FINRA and reflect the scope and seriousness of the violations. FINRA found in its investigation that, despite Robinhood's self-described mission to 'de-mystify finance for all,' during certain periods since September 2016, the firm has negligently communicated false and misleading information to its customers. The false and misleading information concerned a variety of critical issues, including whether customers could place trades on margin, how much cash was in customers' accounts, how much buying power or 'negative buying power' customers had, the risk of loss customers faced in certain options transactions, and whether customers faced margin calls.

On April 6, 2023, the North American Securities Administrators Association (NASAA) announced that Robinhood Financial LLC will pay a monetary penalty for operational and technical failures that harmed main street investors.

The investigation was triggered due to outages in March 2020, on Robinhood's platform, where hundreds of thousands of investors were relying on the Robinhood app to make trades. NASAA's investigations uncovered that the platforms' systems had other flaws prior to March 2021. Among them were claims that Robinhood unwittingly gave clients bad information about margin trading and risks linked to certain option spreads, insufficiently supervised core technology, and failed to conduct due diligence prior to approving certain options accounts.

NASAA also said Robinhood failed to have 'reasonable' customer identification systems or systems to address client complaints or questions. Furthermore, Robinhood did not report investor complaints to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority or state agencies when required. The investigation was led by Alabama along with Colorado, California, Delaware, New Jersey, South Dakota and Texas.

As a result of the lapses, Robinhood contained several alleged violations, such as negligent dissemination of inaccurate information to customers and failure to have 'a reasonably designed' customer identification programmed.

NASAA imposed a fine of $10,200,000 for the violations Robinhood committed.

On January 8, 2021, Siddharth Mehta (Plaintiff), individually and on behalf of other similarly situated individuals filed a class action complaint in the Superior Court of the State of California for the County of Santa Clara against Robinhood Financial LLC and Robinhood Securities LLC (Defendants) for failure to protect customer data from a data breach.

When customers open accounts in Defendant, the authorized Defendant access to one or more bank accounts and deposit funds directly in to a Defendant investment account of which Defendant is the custodian. Customers additionally grant Defendant access to sensitive information including but not limited to their names, social security numbers, and dates of birth, mailing addresses, telephone numbers, bank account numbers, and details of their income, bank account balances, financial transactions histories, credit histories, tax information and credit scores.

On July 22, 2020, Defendant negligently and illegally allowed a third-party access to Melta's personal and financial information, access to the funds Mehta had deposited into a Defendant account, and control of securities positions Mehta purchased through Defendant. As a consequence of the incident, Mehta lost tens of thousands of dollars. Defendant neglected to inform Mehta of the breach and only acknowledged the breach occurred after Mehta has spent hours of his own time attempting to research and remedy the loss and securing his other assets and information from further breach.

In the summer of 2020, perhaps even earlier, unauthorized users accessed approximately 2,000 Defendant customer accounts. Upon accessing the accounts, these users obtained Defendant's customers sensitive personal and financial information and looted funds. Panicked customers who saw their accounts draining attempted to contact Defendant by email, as Defendant offers no phone number for customer service, and were left waiving for days or weeks while more funds were depleted from their accounts. The breach cost Defendant 's customers millions of dollars. Rather than freezing the accounts and alerting its customers of the breach right away, Defendant did nothing. Only when the news outlets reported on the breach did Defendant acknowledge it had occurred. On October 16, 2020, after breaches had been widely reported by news outlets, Defendant sent push notifications to customers encouraging them to enable two-factor authentication, which is a security setting requiring the use of a password combined with a temporary passcode sent to a mobile device to log on. On information and belief, approximately 2,000 Defendant customers were subject to unauthorized use of their accounts.

Plaintiff sought monetary and equitable relief as a class action, actual and compensatory damages, restitution, pre- and post-judgement interest, attorney's fees, costs, expenses and further relief as the Court my deem just and proper.

On February 9, 2021, the case was removed from the Circuit Court to the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.

On February 26, 2021, Plaintiff Mehta amended his complaint adding Kevin Qian and Michael Furtado as Plaintiff.

On May 20, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their second amended class action complaint.

On July 1, 2022, Plaintiffs filed their motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement. Defendants have agreed to pay all individuals currently residing in the United States whose Robinhood accounts were accessed by unauthorized users from January 1, 2020, through April 27, 2022, or who notified Robinhood that their Robinhood accounts were accessed by unauthorized users from January 1, 2020, through April 27, 2022. The settlement provides common benefits to the class with a total value of $20,000,000.

Under the settlement agreement, Settlement Class Members who submit a valid claim will receive up to $100 for out-of-pocket expenses resulting from unauthorized access to their accounts. Class Members who submit a valid claim will also receive up to $100 for reimbursement of money paid by the Class Member for credit monitoring or identity theft protection products or services. And all Settlement Class Members who submit a valid claim are eligible to receive reimbursement for lost time resulting from unauthorized access to their accounts. The reimbursement will be paid at $20 per hour for a maximum of three (3) hours (for a maximum payment of $60). The maximum aggregate number of claims for which Robinhood shall be responsible to pay is $500,000 plus two years of credit monitoring and identity theft protection services to all Class Members.

Additionally, Class Counsel will receive attorneys' fees $484,540 and reimbursement of litigation costs totaling $15,460. Plaintiffs Qian and Furtado will also receive service awards in the amount of $5,000 each. The settlement will also be used to pay administration costs for approximately $55,000 to $65,000.

On August 29, 2022, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement.

On March 17, 2023, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of the class action settlement.

On May 16, 2023, the Court finally approved the class action settlement and fees. Thus, the Court administratively close the case.

Between May 2020 and January 2021, NetWalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others throughout the world by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

When RCMP searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

On February 1, 2022, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Robson Carpenter LLP in the amount of $2,500.

On April 20, 2020, the HHS Office for Civil Rights (OCR) investigation found that Saint Joseph's Medical Center ('SJMC') impermissibly allowed a reporter from the Associated Press (AP) to observe three (3) patients who were being treated for COVID. The evidence supports that SJMC allowed the reporter access to the patients and their clinical information.

The disclosures were not made pursuant to a permissible purpose under or as required by the Privacy Rule and were made without first obtaining valid authorizations from the affected individuals. SJMC impermissibly disclosed the protected health information of its patients to a reporter from the Associated Press.

On April 28, 2020, HHS notified SJMC of HHS' investigation regarding SJMC's compliance with the Privacy Rule based on information contained in the AP article.

On November 20, 2023, the HHS Office for Civil Rights (OCR) reached a settlement with Saint Joseph's Medical Center with $80,000 resolution amount and the implementation of a corrective action plan requiring the facility to develop written policies and procedures that comply with the HIPAA Privacy Rule. Saint Joseph's Medical Center also agreed to train its workforce on the revised policies and procedures.

For the next two years, OCR will monitor Saint Joseph's Medical Center to ensure compliance with the corrective action plan and the HIPAA Privacy Rule.

On July 23, 2020, Plaintiffs J.P. and S.P. on behalf of themselves and similarly situated individuals, filed a class action lawsuit in Monterey County Superior Court, State of California against Defendant Salinas Valley Memorial Healthcare System for its failure to fulfill its legal duty to adequately secure and safeguard the information of its customers.

Subsequently, Plaintiffs amended their complaint and added Vanessa Colvin and A.J. as co-Plaintiffs.

On April 30, 2020, Defendant determined that the email account of one of its employees had been compromised.

On May 7, 2020 and June 5, 2020 respectively, Defendant subsequently determined that email accounts of a contractor and three other employees were also compromised. These five email accounts were compromised through Outlook Web Access, Defendant's browser-based email access solution.

The personal information in the email in the affected inbox may have included identifying information, such as name, hospital account number or medical record number, in combination with health information such as service location and attending physician's information. The personal information about the e-mail did not includes social security, driver's license or bank account numbers.

In response to this incident, Defendant disabled access and then reset the passwords to the affected email accounts. Further, Defendant implemented additional security measures such as two-factor authentication to Outlook Web Access for all Defendant email accounts. Individuals who may have been affected by this incident are being mailed notices.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On May 27, 2022, the Court granted Plaintiffs' unopposed Amended Motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement. Wherein, Defendant has agreed to pay and create a Settlement Fund of $340,000 as part of a class action settlement over claims its security system did not protect patients from a data breach. The estimated 2,384 class members must file a valid claim form by August 26, 2022 to receive a payment. Each member can receive up to $750.

In addition to the settlement, Class Counsel will seek an award of attorneys' fees of no more than $113,333.33 and costs and expenses not to exceed $5,000, all to be paid by Defendant. Class Representative will also receive a service award of more than $2,000 as consideration for their efforts in prosecuting the action.

The Final Approval Hearing shall be held on October 28, 2022.

On May 25, 2021, Nadine Ferrer, using the pseudonym Jane Doe (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against San Diego Family Care (Defendant) in the Superior Court of California, County of San Diego. The action arises out of Defendant's negligent and failure to properly create, maintain, preserve, and/or store confidential, medical and personal identifying information.

According to the complaint, in December of 2020, Defendant was subject to a data breach causing unauthorized access, viewing, exfiltration, theft, and disclosure of unencrypted medical and personal identifying information of its patients after they became that their information technology hosting provider experienced a data security incident that resulted in the encryption of certain data aware. On May 7, 2021, Defendant notified affected individuals of the incident that certain information may have been compromised including name, date of birth, medical diagnosis or treatment information, health insurance information.

Plaintiff brought the action individually on behalf of all persons to whom Defendant sent a letter entitled 'Notice of Data Breach' regarding a data security incident that occurred in December 2020.

Plaintiff and the class sought for nominal damages, actual damages, injunctive relief, class certification, attorneys' fees and costs, and further relief as the Court deems necessary, just, and proper.

On August 30, 2021, Plaintiff filed a motion to consolidate Case No. 37-2021-00026758-CU-BT-CTL and appointing Case No. 37-2021-00023006-CU-BT-CTL as the lead class action case.

On January 12, 2022, Plaintiffs and Defendant have reached a settlement. Defendant agreed to create a settlement fund in the amount of $1,000,000 to cover claims from affected individuals. Claims may be submitted for a base payment of up to $100 per person, up to $1,000 for ordinary out-of-pocket expenses, and up to $5,000 for extraordinary out-of-pocket expenses. The settlement also provides free identity theft protection services that must be redeemed within 90 days of receiving a code from Experian.

Additionally, Class Counsel will ask the Court to approve payment of the Settlement Administration Costs, up to a maximum amount of $150,000, for the fees and costs incurred by the Settlement Administrator, including the costs of the mailing of class notices. Class Counsels' Fees and Expenses in the amount not to exceed $500,000, including Incentive award which shall not exceed a total amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000) to each Class Representative.

On March 29, 2022, the Class Representatives filed a Motion for Preliminary Approval of the Class Action Settlement.

On April 1, 2022, the Court granted preliminary approval of the settlement.

The Final Approval Hearing will be held on July 29, 2022.

organization.name: San Felipe Del Rio Consolidated Independent School District

incident.description:
A business email compromise scheme targeted San Felipe Del Rio CISD that resulted to the theft of funds from the school district. According to the Superintendent statement, the school district's computer system was hacked, therefore, funds intended to cover the payment of three bond issues were compromised.

On February 18, 2020, the district learned that funds intended as payments to a bank for the district's debt service, were electronically transferred via ACH (Automatic Clearing House) to a fraudulent account instead of the proper account. Upon discovering the fraud, the district immediately contacted authorities, including FBI, and began an internal review. The district has suspended electronic funds transfer, doing check only payments for the time being.

The said scheme has successfully stolen $2.14 million. San Felipe Del Rio CISD has been forced to reallocate the amount to make up for the enormous loss.

organization.name: San Juan Regional Medical Center, Inc.

incident.description:
On October 7, 2021, Jeremy Henderson (Plaintiff) on behalf of himself and other affected individuals, filed a class action lawsuit against San Juan Regional Medical Center (Defendant) in Eleventh Judicial District Court in New Mexico to address Defendant's inadequate safeguarding of Class Members' Private Information that they collected and maintained, and for failing to provide timely and adequate notice to Plaintiff.

The class action complaint levies multiple accusations against the Defendant, going at times into extreme detail to describe how the unauthorized access to the hospital's network has adversely affected tens of thousands of its patients.

According to the lawsuit, Plaintiff was notified of the data breach and that his private information was compromised in the letter dated September 13.

It was a year earlier, on September 7 to 8, 2020, when the hospital learned 'an unauthorized individual' removed information from its network.

The lawsuit alleged that victims of the data breach had their names, dates of birth, addresses, email addresses and phone numbers accessed, along with Social Security numbers, financial account numbers, passport numbers, driver's license numbers, health insurance information and medical information. It also claimed letters were not sent out for people with stolen Social Security numbers and financial information until September 13, 2021.

It also alleges that Plaintiff and other impacted individuals have been exposed to substantial risk of identity theft and fraud and will have to closely monitor their medical and financial information to protect themselves.

The lawsuit also accused Defendant of failing to properly implement basic data security practices and of failing to implement safeguards required by Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPPA) regulations.

The lawsuit sought unspecified damages for relief from the alleged damages.

On September 30, 2022, a settlement agreement and release was entered in to the court. It also include the notice of proposed class action settlement, proposed order granting preliminary approval of class settlement and unopposed motion for final approval of class settlement agreement.

According to the proposed settlement agreement, Defendant will provide two years of the single-bureau Identity Defense Complete identity protection and credit monitoring service free of charge; unreimbursed losses, up to $2,500 per settlement subclass member, which includes up to 3 hours lost time at a rate of $17.50 per hour; attorneys' fees to class counsel in an amount not to exceed a total of $230,000 and a service award not to exceed $2,500 to each Plaintiff for the time and effort Plaintiffs expended on behalf of the settlement class.

On October 13, 2022, an order granting preliminary approval of class action settlement was entered into the court.

On 1 April 2020, the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) received a complaint that SAP Asia Pte. Ltd. (SAP Asia) had disclosed the payroll information of some of its former employees to the wrong email recipients. Thereafter, PDPC commenced investigations into the Incident.

According to the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC), SAP Asia had engaged an external vendor to provide IT solutions for their human resources and payroll system (HR System). SAP Asia's process of issuing payslips to their employees had been automated as part of the HR System. However, when payslips needed to be issued to individuals who had already left the company, this could not be done via the HR System. SAP Asia was keen to automate the process of issuing payslips to former employees as part of the HR System, and sometime around April 2019, requested the Vendor to develop a new program within the HR System for this purpose.

On March 31, 2020, SAP Asia executed the new program to generate and deliver payslips to 43 former employees at their personal email addresses. As the program had not been designed to be able to properly execute multiple payslip issuance, the execution of the new program resulted in 29 out of the 43 former employees receiving their own payslip as well as the payslips of other employees. The personal data of 43 former employees of SAP Asia was improperly disclosed in the incident. The disclosed personal data comprised each of the former employees' name, NRIC or FIN number, employment number, bank account number, monthly basic salary, detailed breakdown of current payment, and year-to-date earnings and deductions.

On July 30, 2021, a financial penalty of $13,500 was imposed on SAP Asia for failing to put in place reasonable security arrangements to protect personal data of its former employees.

On April 13, 2020, despite its robust cybersecurity program, Sapiens was the victim of an encryption virus attack carried out by a sophisticated cyber attacker. The Israeli software company fell victim to a ransomware attack. Sapiens hired forensic analysts to investigate and concluded that customer information was not impacted, but that limited employee information may have been compromised including medical information and Social Security Numbers. The investigation has not uncovered any evidence that personal information has been misused.

The company, which is based out of the Tel Aviv suburb of Holon did not report the matter to the American or Israeli exchange authorities. Sapiens neither confirmed nor denied the details.

Sapiens was forced to pay $250,000 ransom in Bitcoin to hackers that threatened to shut down its computers, according to Israeli business publication Calcalist.

An unnamed Plaintiff filed a lawsuit against (Defendant) Scalable Capital, one of the best-known German robo-advisors at the Munich Regional Court in February 2021, for alleged violation of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

According to the complaint, the plaintiff from southern Germany is one of the 33,200 Scalable customers whose e-mail addresses, copies of ID cards, photos, and account numbers ended up in the Darknet between April and October 2020 as a result of a data leak. Plaintiff noticed on a day at the end of September 2020 that there had been a total of ten 'failed login attempts at his email provider'.
