After Defendant informed about the data breach in mid-October, the plaintiff felt permanently exposed to the risk that his personal data could be used for identity theft or 'other attempted fraud'.

On December 9, 2021, a judgment was entered where Defendant has to pay the plaintiff, represented by consumer organization EuGD Europaische Gesellschaft fur Datenschutz mbH, 2,500 ($2,833.43) in damages for non-material damage because he was affected by the Scalable data leak.

organization.name: Scottish Environment Protection Agency
organization.industry: Administration of Air and Water Resource and Solid Waste Management Programs

incident.description:
Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) said its digital systems have been severely affected by a ransomware attack since Christmas Eve. Threat actors have locked agency's emails and contact centers and are demanding a ransom to unlock them.

National Cyber Security Centre and Scotland Police are investigating the whole incident and it is believed that the international cybercriminal group is behind the ransomware attack. Cybersecurity experts have unearthed that threat actors have stolen nearly 1.2 GB of data which suggests threat actors may have accessed and stolen 4,000 files.

SEPA said they must start from scratch and build a whole new system following a 'significant cyber-attack'. Agency further stated that essential services regarding food forecasting and warnings have not been hit by cyber-attack. Though it remains highly unlikely that 1,300 employees will be able to secure access to their old emails and online documents.

Scotland's environmental regulator has termed this attack as an 'incredibly sophisticated attack' and warned threat actors to face the consequences. We are aware that threat actors are demanding a ransom to unlock the agency's system, but they will not succeed in their plan.

The Conti ransomware group asserted the attack and has already leaked sensitive information on its site. The stolen information includes personal information associated with SEPA employees and information associated with commercial work with international allies.

Figures released to BBC Scotland under freedom of information laws show a total of GBP 790,000 ($1,085,452.10) has been spent on Sepa's response and recovery actions so far. This includes GBP 458,000 on stabilizing the watchdog's business IT platform. Sepa has restored most of its key services, such as flooding forecasting, but it is expected a full recovery from the attack will take up the remainder of 2021-22.

A public relations firm called 3X1 Group was paid GBP 136,000 for public communication, employee and stakeholder engagement in a 12 month contract. Sepa initially claimed that the contract was worth GBP 246,000 but they amended the figure. A social media agency called We Are Hydrogen was paid GBP 36,000 for comms support - social media.

According to SEPA's press release on April 5, 2022, they recovered 80% of the data illegally encrypted by criminals, they published two significant compliance and reporting datasets, and they worked on next steps. They've also confirmed the detailed cost of the cyber-attack at GBP 4,400,000, with GBP 1,100,000 investment brought forward for future years.

On January 16, 2022, Jeffrie Alan Summers II (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated in the King County Superior Court Clerk against Sea Mar Community Health Centers (Defendant). The case was brought in relation to Defendants alleged violation of HIPAA.

On June 24, 2021, Sea Mar was informed that certain Sea Mar data had been copied from its digital environment by an unauthorized actor. Upon receipt of this information, Sea Mar immediately took steps to secure its environment and commenced an investigation to determine what happened and to identify the specific information that may have been impacted. In so doing, Sea Mar engaged leading, independent cybersecurity experts for assistance. As a result, Sea Mar learned that additional data may have been removed from its digital environment between December 2020 and March 2021. Sea Mar thereafter began collecting contact information needed to provide notice to potentially affected individuals, which was completed on August 30, 2021. Sea Mar determined that your name, address, Social Security number, date of birth, client identification number, medical / vision / dental / orthodontic diagnostic and treatment information, medical / vision / dental insurance information, claims information, and / or images associated with dental treatment may have been impacted in connection with this incident.

On October 29, 2021, at least four months after it learned of the Data Breach, Defendant posted a Notice of Data Security Incident on its website and began notifying Plaintiff and Class Members of the Data Breach. On or about October 30, 2021, Defendant reported to the Department of Health and Human Services that, during the Data Breach, the attacker compromised the unprotected health information of more than 688,000 current or former patients of Defendant.

Plaintiff sought for an award of damages, including actual, consequential, nominal, and statutory damages, as allowed by law in an amount to be determined; award of attorneys' fees, costs, and litigation expenses, as allowed by law; For prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded; and such other and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On May 4, 2022, Plaintiff and Sea Mar stipulate to remand of this action to King County Superior Court and respectfully request that the Court enter an Order remanding the case to state court. On May 5, 2022, the court directed to remand the case to King County Superior Court.

Sea Mar Community Health Centers agreed to pay $4.4 million as part of a settlement to resolve claims a 2020 and 2021 data breach compromised sensitive patient data.

organization.name: Sn Servicing Corporation
organization.industry: Other Activities Related to Credit Intermediation

incident.description:
On May 5, 2021, a class action was filed by Desiree Schmitt and James Furth (Plaintiffs) and on behalf of all others similarly situated against SN Servicing Corporation, an Alaska Corporation (Defendant) in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of San Francisco. The action arises from Defendant's failure to securely maintain the personal and financial information.

According to the Complaint, on or about October 14, 2020, an unauthorized successfully exfiltrated a number of digital files maintained by Defendant. Based upon an investigation by a third-party cybersecurity forensics investigator hired by Defendant, the exfiltration of data from Defendant is believed to have ended on October 15, 2020.

Despite learning of the data breach, Defendant did not send a data breach notification letter to Plaintiffs and Class members until January 14, 2021.

Plaintiff Schmitt alleges that SN Servicing sent her a Data Breach Notification letter notifying her that some of her personal and financial information had been acquired by the Unauthorized Party responsible for the Data Breach. According to the Data Breach Notification letter, the data acquired by the Unauthorized Party includes Schmitt's March 2018 billing statements and fee notices that contain Schmitt's personal and financial information including, among other information, Schmitt's name, address, loan number, balance information, and billing information such as charges assessed, owed, and/or paid.

Defendant failed to securely maintain the personal and financial information of Plaintiffs and other Class members, the unauthorized party was able to exfiltrated a large amount of personal and financial information. As a result of Defendant's actions and inactions, the personal and financial information of approximately 20,155 borrowers has been obtained by the unauthorized party.

Plaintiff and the class suffered any damages as a result of the alleged breach.

Plaintiff sought for statutory damages, attorneys' fees and cost and any other relief deemed appropriate by the Court.

On May 5, 2021, a Notice of Removal was entered notifying that the case was transferred to United States District Court for the Northern District of California.

On February 25, 2022, the parties reached an agreement on all material terms of the class action settlement.

On May 24, 2022, Plaintiff moved for the preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the settlement agreement, Defendant agreed to fund a Settlement Fund in the amount of $900,000.00 and provided the injunctive relief. The Settlement Fund shall be the only source of payment for all costs of the settlement, including: (a) payments to Settlement Class Members submitting valid Settlement Claims; (b) costs of Claims Administration; (c) the Attorneys' Fees and Expenses Award, if any, to Class Counsel; and (d) the Service Award, if any.

On July 8, 2022, Plaintiff unopposed motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement was granted.

On August 17, 2022, Plaintiff filed a motion for attorneys' fees in the amount of $270,000, reasonable litigation costs and expenses in the amount of $7,317.81, and service award to the Representative Plaintiff in the amount of $5,000.

Mrs. XX (the Complainant) complained to the Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data about the publication, on the institutional website of the Municipality of Urago d'Oglio, which contained personal data, also relating to health.

According to the complaint, complainant's personal data unlawfully disclosed by the Municipality of Urago d'Oglio. Complainant said It emerged on the institutional website of the Municipality of Urago D'Oglio,

The Office noted that the Municipality has published on the institutional website the deeds and documents containing personal data referring to the interested party, consisting of detailed information relating to events that have concerned her during the work as well as data relating to pathologies that have arisen over time:

In the documentation sent, the Municipality reiterated that it had removed the personal data of the interested party and illustrated to the Guarantor the initiatives it intends to take to prevent situations similar to the case being complained of in the future.

In light of the aforementioned assessments, the unlawfulness of the processing of personal data carried out by the Municipality of Urago d'Oglio, for having disclosed the employee's personal data and information, in the absence of suitable regulatory conditions, the violation of the aforementioned provisions makes the administrative sanction envisaged by art. 83, par. 5, of the Regulation, as also referred to by art. 166, paragraph 2, of the Code.

On the basis of the aforementioned elements, assessed as a whole, it is believed to determine the amount of the pecuniary sanction also taking into account the phase of first application of the sanctions pursuant to art. 22, paragraph 13, of the d. lgs. 10/08/2018, n. 101, to the extent of 4,000.00 euros or $4,360.03 for the violation of Articles 5, par. 1, lett. a) and c) and 6, par. 1, lett. c) and e), par. 2 and par. 3, lett. b), of the Regulations.

On April 29, 2021, the Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data has imposed a fine 2,000.00 (1,997.38 USD) to Comune Di Santa Ninfa (Municipality of Santa Ninfa) in relation to the unlawful processing of personal data in violation of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The Authority has received a complaint from Mr. XX, with which a violation of the legislation on the protection of personal data was contested. The publication was negligent due to a technical update of the software house. In fact, the publication in the 'resolutions' section for the purpose of transparency 'does not provide for the dissemination of the document but only for information extracted from the same. Several times in 2020, training was carried out with the DPO and at the same time communicated to the software house (data processor) to check any document attachments relating to publications by extract. 2020, was very demanding given the covid emergency, it was certainly an involuntary violation. Even though the offices were closed, they immediately notified the offices to contact the technicians and / or software houses to delete / correct and publish the document immediately.

In light of the checks carried out on the basis of the elements acquired and the facts that emerged as a result of the preliminary investigation, as well as the subsequent assessments, the Office has ascertained that the Municipality of Santa Ninfa by publishing online document has carried out a processing of personal data that does not comply with the relevant regulations on the protection of personal data contained in the RGPD. With a subsequent e-mail of the XXth, the Municipality sent the Guarantor a notification of a violation of personal data pursuant to art. 33 of the RGPD which does not present elements of novelty with respect to what has already been ascertained by the Office and previously represented by the body.

Finally, with an e-mail dated the XXth, the administration confirmed the obscuring of all the web addresses indicated from which the deed object of the complaint could be downloaded.

Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante) has received a report from Mr. XX regarding the publication on the institutional website of the Municipality of Colledara of personal data and information, contained in the rankings relating to the XX public competition.

With a subsequent investigation by the Office carried out on XX, it was verified that the personal data of competitors who had not been admitted to the competition or who were not winners were still visible (but who had only been admitted, even if only with reserve, to take the written tests ), contained in the documents including name, place and date of birth of XX subjects.

On January 30, 2020, the Municipality of Colledara ordered to pay the sum of 4,000.00 (four thousand) euros ($4,402.83) as a pecuniary administrative sanction for violations indicated.

On July 9, 2020, the Italian Data Protection Authority decided to impose on the school 'Crucoli Torretta' a fine of C2,000. The school uploaded on their website a list of students (minors) containing lots of personal information, also special categories of data, and failed to comply with Art. 5, 6 and 9 GDPR and Art. 2-ter and 2-septies of the Italian Privacy Code.

The school 'Crucoli Torretta' wrongly uploaded on their website a list containing personal data of the students applying for the school project named POR Calabria funded by the Region of Calabria. More specifically, this list contained, among others, information related to their financial status, disabilities and their insufficient educational situation. However, the school has replaced the list with a new one containing the score gained by each student only.

The Italian DPA hold that the school made an unlawful dissemination of personal data, infringing the principles of data minimization, lawfulness fairness and transparency.

However, since such unlawful data processing operations were made by mistake and the school has replaced the list and therefore removed the unnecessary information, the Italian DPA issued a minor fine of EUR 2,000 ($2,260.40).

On December 22, 2021, the Spanish Data Protection Authority (AEPD) published its decision in which it imposed a fine of 5,000 on Hubside Iberica SL, which was subsequently reduced to 4,000, for violations of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), following a claim regarding unlawful processing of personal data.

In particular, on September 19, 2020, the AEPD received a claim from a claimant on grounds that Hubside had processed their bank details without the claimant's consent and without any legitimate grounds to do so. Upon information, On June 18, 2020, the claimant went to Hubside's store from the shopping center, and proceeded to registration of your personal data. The point of sale signed in the internal company applications said data, which have been deleted in their entirety from the database.

More specifically, the AEPD stated that the claimant stated that their bank account was charged with several transactions by Hubside for services not contracted for, after they had entered their personal data at a point of sale to contract the service of Hubside before subsequently changing their mind. In addition, the AEPD stated the claim highlighted that, after the claimant changed their mind, they were informed that their personal data, already added into Hubside's database, would be deleted.

After the reviewing the claim, on January 25, 2021, the AEPF began its investigation to clarify the facts of the dispute. After reviewing the facts, the AEPD stated that it found that Hubside had processed the personal data of the claimant without any legitimacy to do so, since it failed to prove that the claimant had contracted the services of Hubside.

The Sheldon Independent School District paid nearly $207,000 in ransom after hackers locked out officials from critical software systems last spring.

The ransomware attack happened in March. District officials could not access emails, important staff data or security cameras.

The Board of Trustees told ABC13 they were faced with a choice - pay 65 Bitcoins, which was equivalent to $350,000 at the time, to regain access or lose everything and have to start over.

In the end, the district, which is home to 10,000 students, negotiated and paid the hackers $206,931. Its insurance company spent another $100,000 on negotiations.

organization.name: Shellpoint Partners LLC
organization.industry: Other Activities Related to Credit Intermediation

incident.description:
On May 5, 2021, Ross Dutcher (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against Shellpoint Partners et al (Defendants) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

Plaintiff's residential mortgage is serviced by Defendants. Defendants place solicitation telephone calls to their customers' and other consumers' cellular and residential telephone lines to promote mortgage-lending and refinancing services and collect payments for existing mortgages. Around October 27, 2020, Plaintiff received such solicitation calls where Defendants' representative informed Plaintiff that he might be eligible to refinance his mortgage. During the call, Plaintiff revoked his consent to be contacted by Defendants. On or about November 2, 2020, Plaintiff called Defendants regarding his mortgage. Defendants' customer representative told Plaintiff that his loan had been approved for forbearance under the CARES Act, although Plaintiff never requested nor assented to such program. Despite Plaintiff's multiple revocation of consent, Defendants had continued to contact him, including calls from December 18, 2020 to April 1, 2021. Upon belief, there are a thousand affected individuals.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On April 21, 2022, the parties proposed a class settlement agreement of $500,000 and $5,000 for Plaintiff's individual TCPA claims and class representative award.

The Slovakian crypto exchange suffered a targeted hack attack on Monday night (September 7, 2020).

Eterbase, a Bratislava, Slovakia based cryptocurrency exchange was attacked, and a whopping $5 million were stolen. The notorious cybercriminals emptied several of its Hot Wallets and stole different types of cryptocurrencies.

Eterbase confirmed the news on its Telegram and Twitter channels on Tuesday, stating that six hot wallets of the exchange containing ether (ETH), ERC-20 tokens, bitcoin (BTC), XRP, Algorand (ALGO), and Tezos (XTZ) were compromised.

In its official announcement, the exchange has also confirmed assets worth approximately $ 5.4 million were stolen. According to reports, the majority of the stolen crypto, roughly $3.9m, were stored in ERC-20 tokens and Ethereum. The second most affected cryptocurrency is XTZ since the value of stolen currency amounts to $417,000.

Eterbase has suspended its trading operations until 10 Sep and has informed all 'centralized exchanges' that may receive the stolen funds.

In March 2020, SIRIUS lawyers reported a breach of personal data security to the Norwegian Data Protection Authority after they were exposed to a hacker attack. In the attack, hackers gained access to and encrypted the law firm's servers, which contained information about the company's clients and counterparties. This created a serious risk of the information about the persons falling into unauthorized hands, with potential damage to the persons concerned as a result.

SIRIUS lawyers have been fined DKK 500,000 (USD 67,509) for not having implemented basic security measures when setting up remote access to the company's IT systems with personal data of a particularly protective nature.

Hackers struck Sky Lakes Medical Center in Klamath Falls, Oregon on October 27, 2020. The hospital's director of information services, John Gaede, learned of the hack in a phone call from his staff. They raced to contain the malware, but within hours decided to shut down the hospital's entire network.

That halted the spread of the malware but left doctors and nurses without access to computerized medical records. Results from magnetic-resonance imaging and other scanning equipment that doctors use to diagnose diseases were also taken offline.

Because of the malware attack, the staff made paper records of critical patient information for weeks. The hospital's pharmacy scrambled to find paper prescription pads, and photocopiers ran low on toner as staff churned out documents.

The hospital temporarily halted some nonessential surgeries to ease the burden on staff.

The hospital fully restored access to the records about a month later, after rebuilding its network with new servers and 2,500 new computers. According to Chief Executive Officer Paul Stewart, estimated costs and lost revenue from the hack totaled about $10 million. Nearly 800 of about 1.5 million diagnostic images couldn't be recovered. Sky Lakes is working with doctors to identify which patients need to return for new scanning.

On December 13, 2020, SolarWinds Corporation, a network management software firm, acknowledged that hackers had inserted malware into a service that provided software updates for its Orion platform.

According to SolarWinds' SEC filing on December 14, 2020, roughly 33,000 of its more than 300,000 customers were Orion customers, and that fewer than 18,000 customers may have had an installation of the Orion product that contained the malicious code.

SolarWinds has been advised that the incident was likely the result of a highly sophisticated, targeted and manual supply chain attack by an outside nation state, but SolarWinds has not independently verified the identity of the attacker. SolarWinds has retained third-party cybersecurity experts to assist in an investigation of these matters, including whether a vulnerability in the Orion monitoring products was exploited as a point of any infiltration of any customer systems, and in the development of appropriate mitigation and remediation plans.

Based on its investigation, SolarWinds has evidence that the vulnerability was inserted within the Orion products and existed in updates released between March and June 2020, was introduced as a result of a compromise of the Orion software build system and was not present in the source code repository of the Orion products.

SolarWinds is cooperating with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. intelligence community, and other government agencies in investigations related to the incident.

SolarWinds announced that it was retaining a new security consulting business founded by Chris Krebs, a former Homeland Security cybersecurity official, and ex-Facebook security chief and Stanford University professor Alex Stamos to assist with crisis response.

Stamos became one of the first high-profile industry figures to publicly blame the SVR - also known as APT29 or Cozy Bear - for the attack. The SVR typically gathers intelligence that can't be used immediately or for destructive attacks.

On April 14, 2021, Yahoo reported that SolarWinds Corp said the sprawling breach stemming from the compromise of its flagship software product has cost the company at least $18 million in the first three months of 2021.

According to SEC Filing, through December 31, 2020, SolarWinds recorded $3.485 million of pretax expenses related to the Cyber Incident.

For the three months ended March 31, 2021, SolarWinds recorded $20.4 million of pretax gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident, partially offset by $10.2 million of expected insurance proceeds.

For the three months ended June 30, 2021, SolarWinds recorded pretax gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $13.6 million, partially offset by insurance coverage of $2.9 million.

Expenses include costs to investigate and remediate the Cyber Incident, and legal and other professional services related thereto, and consulting services being provided to customers at no charge, all of which were expensed as incurred.

For the year ended December 31, 2021, SolarWinds recorded pretax gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $49,124,000, partially offset by insurance receipts and expected insurance proceeds for costs they believe are reimbursable and probable of recovery under cybersecurity insurance coverage of $16,010,000. They have included $2.2 million of these gross expenses in cost of recurring revenue, $1.6 million in sales and marketing expense and $45.3 million in general and administrative expense in our consolidated statements of operations.

For the six months ended June 30, 2022, SolarWinds recorded pretax gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $34.0 million, partially offset by proceeds under our insurance coverage of $13.1 million, for pretax net expenses of $20.9 million. For the six months ended June 30, 2021, they have included $1.5 million of these gross expenses in cost of recurring revenue, $1.5 million in sales and marketing expense and $31.0 million in general and administrative expense in the condensed consolidated statements of operations.

For the 9 months ended September 30, 2022, SolarWinds recorded pretax gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $46,293,000, with $26,000,000 of it received or expected to be received under their insurance coverage.

For the whole year of 2022, SolarWinds recorded total gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $56,435,000, reduced by insurance coverage proceeds received or expected to be received in the amount of $30,202,000.

For the first quarter of 2023 ended March 31, 2023, the company incurred an additional $2,028,000 for response costs related to the cyber incident.

For the nine months ended September 30, SolarWinds recorded gross expenses related to the Cyber Incident of $15,509,000, with $19,798,000 proceeds received or expected to be received under insurance coverage.

As of December 31, 2023, total gross expenses related to the cyber incident reached $123,273,000 with $66,010,000 received or expected to be received under their insurance coverage.

European IT services group Sopra Steria is battling a suspected ransomware attack on its network. The firm, whose biggest customers in the financial sector include Societe Generale, BNP Paribas, La Banque Postale, HSBC, Credit Agricole, RBS, Huyndai Capital and the Bank of China, issued a terse statement confirming a cyberattack on its IT network on the evening of 20th October.

The Group's teams are working hard for a return to normal as quickly as possible and every effort has been made to ensure business continuity.

Sopra Steria has been tightlipped about the precise nature of the hack, but French media reports claims that the company is facing extortion demands having fallen victim to a ransomware attack.

According to Sopra Steria, the secure remediation plan launched on 26 October is nearly complete. Access has progressively been restored to workstations, R&D and production servers, and in-house tools and applications. Customer connections have also been gradually restored

The Group's teams are working hard for a return to normal as quickly as possible and every effort has been made to ensure business continuity.

On November 25, 2020, French IT services giant Sopra Steria said in an official statement that the October Ryuk ransomware attack will lead to a loss of between C40 million and C50 million. The Group's insurance coverage for cyber risks totals C30 million (35,599,500 USD).

organization.name: Sorenson Impact Center
organization.industry: Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services

incident.description:
At some point after Holland and Knight, LLP (H&K) received Sorenson Impact Foundation's (SIF) wire instructions to their bank account with Zions Bank, a malicious third-party accessed the emails between them, got their business email compromise and caused falsified emails and documents to be delivered between the various parties, including to Continental Transfer & Trust Company and Holland & Knight, LLP.

On or about January 31, 2020, the malicious third party fraudulently sent an email to H&K asking if the payout account for SIF could be changed to an international account in Hong Kong.

H&K responded in an email addressed to the Plaintiffs on February 3, 2020 stating its compliance folks needed to verify the account based on the name Wemakos Furniture Co. Limited. However, this email was intercepted by the malicious third party and it was never received by SIF.

On or about February 7, 2020, the malicious third party fraudulently sent an email to H&K enclosing a Letter of Transmittal, Stock Certificates, and authorization letter with the updated account information for the Hong Kong account.

Pursuant to the Letter of Transmittal and paragraph 4 of the Instructions, H&K and Continental were required to contact SIF and have them provide a Medallion Guarantee by a Bank or Trust Company in the United States or by a member of any registered national securities exchange or of the National Association of Securities Dealers. However, H&K and Continental did not contact SIF and request the required Medallion Guarantee.

As a result of the failures, SIF have not received the agreed consideration under their merger agreement in at least the sum of $3,124,940.26.

On September 3, 2020, a class action complaint was filed by Kimberly Benedetto (Plaintiff) in the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia County against Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (Defendant) for failure to properly safeguard and protect employees' personal data from unauthorized access.

According to the complaint, in August 25, 2020, Defendant sent a letter informing its employees and the public of a previously unreported attack on its network that may have exposed their sensitive personal information to a malware attack. Defendant first learned the unusual activity on August 10, 2020. Defendant's investigation revealed its network had been infiltrated by a malware attack and that its inadequate cyber and data security systems and measures allowed cybercriminals to obtain files containing a treasure trove of thousands of Defendant employees' personal, private, and sensitive information including employees' names, addresses, Social Security numbers, benefits enrollment information, salary or hourly rate, and for those employees who used direct deposit bank accounts and routing numbers.

The attack caused Defendant to halt access to employee email and stop sharing real-time travel information with riders. Upon information, Defendant notified roughly 9,300 employees about the incident. As a result of Defendant's poor cyber and data security systems and measures, Plaintiff and the Class have suffered loss and damages including out-of-pocket expenses, loss of privacy, anxiety, and emotional distress.

Plaintiff brought the action individually and on behalf of all persons Defendant sent direct-mail notification to about the August 2020 Data Breach Incident regarding the potential compromise of their personal information.

Plaintiff sought for a class certification, actual, compensatory, and consequential damages, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest, and other relief as the Court deems just and proper.

On November 18, 2021, Plaintiff filed her second amended class action complaint.

On January 18, 2023, Plaintiff filed her third amended class action complaint adding Keysha Capers as Plaintiff.

On February 2, 2023, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary approval of the class action settlement. In which, Defendant has agreed to settle the case to resolve claims that it failed to prevent an August 2020 data breach that compromised employee data.

Under the settlement, Settlement Class members will receive credit monitoring at no cost if they elect to enroll that will last for one year. Second, Settlement Class members a chance to claim losses from the breach, including lost money or time. Members may claim 'economic losses' up to $1,000 for losses resulting from the breach, including identity theft, fraud, and costs spent mitigating those risks. Third, Defendant will pay the entirety of the Costs to administer the settlement. And last, Defendant has confirmed it implemented 'security enhancements' since its data breach, detailing those enhancements in the agreement.

The total payments to Settlement Class Members shall not exceed $350,000.00, which will include all monetary compensation to be paid to the class as part of this settlement.

In addition, Class Counsel will receive an award for attorney's fees and costs in the amount up to $275,000. Plaintiffs will also receive service award in the amount of $2,000 each.

On March 15, 2023, the Court granted the preliminary approval of the class action settlement.

A pair of habitual offenders behind one of the biggest data breaches in Santa Barbara County history pleaded guilty to multiple felony counts that will send them to prison for a combined 33 years.

San Diego residents Gordon Welterlen, 37, and Nicole Milan, 31, admitted to hacking a computer network belonging to the Wolf & Associates Property Management company and stealing the identities of more than 9,000 clients. They used the information to file over 300 unemployment claims with the state and as a result collected more than $2 million that they spent on cars, including a Mercedes and two Jaguars, swanky apartments, and drugs.

On March 19, 2020, Welterlen, who has a lengthy criminal history of fraud and theft and extensive illegal dealings on the 'dark web,' will be sentenced to 18 years in prison. Milan, also with a long rap sheet, will be sentenced to 15 years. Their codefendant, a 40-year-old Santa Barbara woman named Rosa Bradley, will be given probation for two years for receiving some of the stolen money.

Court records reveal the brashness with which Welterlen carried out the scheme. He boasts in text messages to a fourth accomplice named William Gormley, who remains at large, how easy it was for him to steal identities and create fake driver's licenses.

When San Diego police, accompanied by Santa Barbara detectives, arrested Welterlen and Milan at an apartment complex in the Pacific Beach neighborhood, they noticed a computer at the residence was actively hacking an unknown server. Police were ultimately able to recover the evidence, which included fraudulent cashier's checks and a laptop with files that further incriminated Milan.

On June 4, 2020, NetWalker ransomware operators had reportedly added the University of California at San Francisco to their website where they name victims who have not paid their ransom demands.

On June 1, 2020, UCSF IT staff identified and stopped an unauthorized access of a limited part of the School of Medicine's IT environment while the intrusion was occurring. Out of an abundance of caution, they immediately isolated a wider range of the School's servers than what the intrusion targeted and engaged a leading cybersecurity firm to assist in our response.

They determined that their overall UCSF network was not affected, and there is no impact to patient care delivery operations.

They quickly launched an investigation to determine what information, if any, may have been impacted, and are cooperating with the FBI. Their assessment has determined that the vast majority of the School's IT environment has not been impacted.

NetWalker ransomware operators have persuaded the University of California San Francisco to pays over $1.14 million in an extortion scheme using data-encrypting malware. The attack, UCSF officials say, didn't even target the institution.

Upon information, Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins, a NetWalker affiliate, was responsible for the attack.

Sophisticated hackers, identity thieves and overseas criminal rings stole over $11 billion in unemployment benefits from California last year, but the extent of the fraud might grow far larger: billions more in payments are under investigation.

California Labor Secretary Julie Su told reporters in a conference call Monday that of the $114 billion the state has paid in unemployment claims, about 10% or $11.4 billion have been confirmed as fraudulent.

Nearly $20 billion more another 17% is considered suspicious, and a large part of that could be found to be fraud, she said.

'There is no sugarcoating the reality,' Su said. 'California did not have sufficient security measures in place to prevent this level of fraud, and criminals took advantage of the situation.'

Nearly all the fraudulent claims were made through the federally supported Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program. The program was approved by Congress to provide unemployment benefits to people during the coronavirus pandemic who are usually ineligible to receive them, such as independent contractors. But, officials say, its broad eligibility requirements made it an easy target of criminals, including from Nigeria and Russia.

While conceding the state was unprepared, Su also faulted the Trump administration for failing to provide the state with the guidance and support needed to foil sophisticated fraud rings. She said an array of safeguards put in place last year had blocked billions of dollars in potential fraud schemes.

Su described an agency struggling to keep up with a flood of new jobless claims as the pandemic shuttered businesses and sent unemployment rates soaring. And that reservoir of new money was also a lure for criminal enterprises.

'It should be no surprise that EDD was overwhelmed, just like the rest of the nation's unemployment agencies,' Su said. 'As millions of Californians applied for help, international and national criminal rings were at work behind the scenes working relentlessly to steal unemployment benefits using sophisticated methods of identity theft.'

The state also has been trying to clear a persistent backlog of claims more than 940,000 as of Jan. 20.

Officials noted the fraud problems were widespread in the U.S.

The Swedish Data Protection Authority imposes an administrative fine of 200,000 Swedish kronor (approximately 18,700 euro) or ($20,303.2) on the National Government Service Centre for failing to notify affected parties as well as the Data Protection Authority about a personal data breach in due time.

The Data Protection Authority (DPA) initiated an investigation against the National Government Service Centre (NGSC) upon having received a number of personal data breach notifications concerning an error in the IT system for salary administration. The error entailed the possibility of unauthorized access to personal data of both personnel of authorities using the system and of the personnel of the NGSC.

The DPA noted that it took almost five months for the NGSC to notify the concerned parties and close to three months before the DPA received a data breach notification.

On May 18, 2020, Mark Aussieker (Plaintiff) filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California against Stewart Marketing LLC et al (Defendants) on grounds allegedly violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

Defendants has been placing automated telemarketing calls towards Plaintiff from April 14 to May 15, 2020 in a total of 5 calls, despite Plaintiff being in a Do Not Call registry 2003. All calls made by Defendants were without Plaintiff's prior express consent nor had he provided them his number and the calls were not made for emergency purposes.

Plaintiff is seeking for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On September 24, 2020, the court ordered Defendant to pay Plaintiff the total sum of two thousand five hundred one dollars and one hundred dollars ($2,501.00) in accordance with the final judgment in favor to Plaintiff.

On March 26, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Michael Parker (Plaintiff), individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated in the United States District Court Middle District of Florida Tampa Division against Stoneledge Furniture, LLC and Southwestern Furniture Of Wisconsin, LLC d/b/a Ashley Furniture (Defendants) for violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

According to the complaint, starting on or about May 15, 2020, Defendants sent multiple marketing text messages to Plaintiff's cellular telephone, from the phone number (747) 223-6341, without Plaintiff's prior express written consent. Plaintiff is not currently a customer of Defendants, nor does Plaintiff recall ever providing Defendants with Plaintiff's cellular telephone number. In addition, Plaintiff never provided Defendants with prior express written consent to receive any automated telephone calls or text messages. The text messages sent by Defendants to Plaintiff's cellular telephone contained no method for Plaintiff to instruct Defendants to stop sending Plaintiff the unwanted text messages. Defendants sent or transmitted, or had sent or transmitted on its behalf, unsolicited text messages to hundreds of thousands of customers' cellular telephones nationwide.

Plaintiff sought for an award of statutory damages, post-judgment interest, order declaring Defendants' conduct and any other further relief.

On February 2, 2022, Plaintiff and the class respectfully moves for an order granting preliminary approval of the class action settlement. On February 17, 2022, Plaintiff 's Unopposed Motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement and Settlement Class Notice granted.

On May 6, 2022, Plaintiff and the Class moves for an order granting final approval of the class action settlement and award of attorney's fees and expenses. The Settlement required Defendants to make available for the Settlement Class a minimum of approximately $4,179,810.00 in cash and a minimum of approximately $10,449,725.00 in vouchers.

On June 17, 2022, unopposed Motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement and Award of Attorneys' Fees and Expenses granted.

On July 6, 2022, the cased was dismissed with prejudice.

Federal agents have detained individuals suspected to have carried out a cyber fraud scheme that stole $206,000 from the Sumter County School Board in Florida.

Investigators revealed that the criminal fraud involved hackers fooling a school official into entering school board banking information on a fake website.

On May 12, 2022, the Danish Data Protection Agency (DDPA) have informed the National Board of Health and Welfare to the police and imposed a fine of DKK 100,000 (approx. 13,440). DDPA assesses that the National Board of Health and Welfare has not complied with the requirements for an appropriate level of security violating the Article 33 of the Data Protection Ordinance.

The DDPA became aware of the case when a complainant's party representative complained about the Danish Civil Agency's handling of complainant's information. It appears from the case that the National Board of Health and Welfare v / Erstatningsnaevnet returned a USB connector for complaints, which contained more than 800 pages of information about complaints of a sensitive and confidential nature, which had been lost when the complainant was received. The USB connector was not encrypted, and the agency did not have guidelines targeted at the agency's caseworkers regarding any handling of removable storage devices and portable media. The Danish Civil Agency became aware of the breach on August 26, 2020, but did not report the breach to the DPPA.

In its assessment, the DDPA has emphasized that encryption of removable storage devices that contain personal data (including USB connectors) must be regarded as a necessary and required security measure. In continuation of this, the DDPA has attached importance to the fact that removable storage means with personal data have a sharpened risk profile in relation to the handling of personal data, and that encryption is a measure that is relatively easy for the data controller to implement. In addition, the DDPA has emphasized that the agency did not have guidelines targeted and known by the agency's case officers in relation to any handling of USB connectors, including dispatch.

As a result, National Board of Health and Welfare was fined as a result of its failure to implement adequate security measures in the form of encryption with regards to its portable media devices.

On September 2, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Trevor Miller (Plaintiff) against Syracuse University (Defendant) in the Supreme Court State of New York County of Onondaga for a data breach that exposed the names and Social Security numbers of nearly 10,000 students, alumni, and applicants.

According to the complaint, Plaintiff alleges that inadequate cybersecurity protocols and poor staff training at defendant's left thousands of people's personally identifiable information vulnerable. Plaintiff claimed that an unauthorized charge was made to his checking account following the breach. The breach occurred late on September 25, 2020 after a university employee fell victim to a phishing attack in which the employee clicked a link and exposed their credentials to a malicious actor. Plaintiff alleges that defendant's four-month delay notifying those affected by the breach compounded the actual and potential harm of the security failure.

Plaintiff sought actual damages, compensatory damages, and punitive damages, prejudgment and post-judgment interest, attorney's fees, costs and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On September 29, 2021, the case was transferred from Supreme Court State of New York County of Onondaga to the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York.

On August 2, 2023, Syracuse University settled a proposed class action brought by a student after his personal information was stolen in a 2020 data breach and his bank account was hacked.

Subject to Court approval, Syracuse has agreed not to object to a request by Class Counsel for attorneys' fees, inclusive of any costs and expenses of the Litigation in an amount not to exceed $295,000, to Plaintiff's Counsel for reimbursement of costs incurred. Class Counsel, in their sole discretion, shall allocate and distribute any amount of attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses awarded by the Court among Plaintiff's Counsel. Also subject to Court approval, Syracuse has agreed not to object to a request for a service award in the amount of $5,000 to the named Plaintiff (for a total payment of $5,000).

Accordingly, the settlement will provide payments to people who submit valid claims. Settlement Class Members can claim up to $1,000 (in total) for documented Ordinary Losses. Settlement Class Members can also claim up to $10,000 for documented Extraordinary Losses.

On November 23, 2021, the Enforcement Bureau of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has entered into a Consent Decree to resolve its investigation into whether T-Mobile USA, Inc. (T-Mobile) failed to comply with the Commission's 911 rules.

The rules require wireless providers to reasonably design and operate their networks to ensure reliable transmission of all 911 calls, including providing 911 call back information and 911 location information, to public safety answering points (PSAPs), and to timely notify potentially affected PSAPs of reportable 911 outages.

To settle the matter, T-Mobile agreed to pay a $19,500,000 settlement payment and will implement a compliance plan. Notably, the compliance measures contain new commitments by T-Mobile to improve the 911 outage notices given to PSAPs, including providing PSAPs with a wide array of information about the outages and providing follow-up notices within two hours of the initial outage notifications.

T-Mobile settlement with the FCC was reached over an investigation into the carrier's 911 outage on June 15, 2020.

T-Mobile will pay some $19.5 million as part of a settlement with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) after a 12-hour outage on June 15, 2020 that resulted in the failure of more than 23,000 emergency calls to 911

The FCC announced the agreement that would resolve their investigation into the matter, saying T-Mobile has agreed to pay the multi-million dollar settlement and implement a compliance plan with new commitments to improve the 911 outage notices given to public safety answering points, as well as provide follow-up notices to them within two hours of the initial outage notifications.

On June 15, 2020, a 12-hour and 13-minute outage took place that led to congestion across T-Mobile's 4G, 3G and 2G networks, according to the FCC, and resulted in the complete failure of 911 calls. The outage also resulted in tens of thousands of 911 calls without location or call back information made available.

On August 14, 2024, Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. (CFIUS), a powerful U.S. committee that scrutinizes foreign investment for national security risks, fined T-Mobile $60 million for failing to disclose and properly address data breaches that occurred following its merger with Sprint in 2020.

According to T-Mobile's statement, it experienced technical issues during its post-merger integration with Sprint that affected 'information shared from a small number of law enforcement information requests.' The unauthorized access to sensitive data occurred between August 2020 and June 2021.

T-Mobile's alleged failures to disclose data breaches and take appropriate action violated a national security agreement that was a prerequisite for the company's acquisition of Sprint. Specifically, T-Mobile said to have neglected to promptly report certain data leaks and did not adequately address the breaches of sensitive information, both of which were in direct contravention of the terms of the agreement. Consequently, the CFIUS concluded that these violations resulted in harm to the national security equities of the US.

The penalty, levied by the CFIUS, marks the largest fine ever imposed by the agency, proving the gravity of T-Mobile's missteps and the significance of the national security implications involved.

Tabcorp is considering plans to placate frustrated punters in the wake of the nationwide betting network meltdown which cost an estimated $120 million ($87,092,400) in wagering turnover over the weekend.

Late on Sunday, November 8, 2020, the TAB system was again offline however this time it appeared to be an organized shut down although there was nothing officially released from the TAB at the time explaining to customers why they could not log on.

A source at the TAB said the system had been shut down late in the day to allow for a complete restart on Monday, November 9, 2020.

The computer crash on Saturday, November 7, 2020, is being blamed on a 'smoke and likely fire incident' at a data centre that also impacted the TAB's sophisticated back-up systems.

A thorough investigation continues as TAB attempts to identify the exact cause of the problem.

The TAB said there was no evidence its network had been hacked but cyber security would be 'urgently reviewed'' as part of its investigation.

TAB punters were left furious when unable to place any bets or access their betting accounts through TAB agencies, or via telephone and online outlets.

The TAB system crashed just after 11am on Saturday and remained down until 3pm on Sunday when finally, there was a restoration of the betting network nationwide.

In the wake of the PR disaster, it is expected TAB will look after its customers by providing various betting incentives including bonus bets and odds boosts for those inconvenienced by the betting crash.

The Daily Telegraph understands the computer failure means TAB has lost nearly $120 million in betting turnover.

TAB wagering turnover is the financial lifeblood of the racing industry and the systems crash has cost the racing industry around $10 million in betting revenue.

organization.name: Tecnomedical Srl
organization.industry: Medical, Dental, and Hospital Equipment and Supplies Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On March 4, 2020, Mr. XX, through his lawyer, exercised against TECNOMEDICAL Srl requesting access to his personal data in order to obtain a copy of the medical record and medical documentation related to the osseointegrated dental implant surgery to which he underwent 'in December 2008 and January 2009, at the local unit of Arquata Scrivia (AL) of TECNOMEDICAL Srl.

The request was not followed by any response within the term. Therefore, the interested party, on April 14, 2020, through his lawyer, submitted a formal complaint to the Authority.

On May 26, 2020, the health facility was formally invited by the Office to adhere to the complainant's requests no later than 20 days from receipt of this invitation. By e-mail dated July 16, 2020, the complainant, through his lawyer, informed this Authority that he had not received any feedback within the terms indicated in the aforementioned invitation to join.

On August 10, 2020, the Office then notified the health facility, as data controller. The initiation of the procedure for the adoption of the measures of the Regulations, having ascertained that the health facility had not provided an answer to the request for access to data made by Mr. XX, nor having found the invitation formulated by the Office in the context of the procedure relating to the complaint presented by the interested party of the Regulation.

On March 25, 2021, the Guarantor imposed 7,000.00 euros ($7934.99)as a pecuniary administrative sanction for the violation indicated in the motivation to TECNOMEDICAL Srl and in the event of failure to settle the dispute.

Telefonica de Espana, Sau (Telefonica) was fined by the Agencia Espanola de Proteccion de Datos (AEPD) for unlawfully processing the claimant's personal data by charging them several invoices corresponding to a third person which is a violation of the General data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

On February 13, 2020, the claimant received a call from someone identifying itself as ISFG advisory claiming a debt. The claimant stated that he is not their client, but his name was in the invoices dated April 5 to April 9, 2019.

The claimant contacted the controller in order to try to solve the situation, without success. The controller stated that the invoices charged weren't paid, and that the processing activity was carried out by the bank.

Telefonica was imposed a penalty of EUR 75,000.

Files purportedly stolen from TFI International's Canpar Express leaked onto the dark web on August 24, 2020 after a ransomware attack targeted the Canadian trucking and logistics company's parcel and courier subsidiaries last week.

The leak, consisting of three documents, appears to have come from DoppelPaymer. The hacking group has taken credit for ransomware attacks on high-profile targets including the city of Knoxville and a NASA IT contractor.

A TFI spokesperson declined to comment on the leak. The company's four parcel and courier subsidiaries, all Canadian, reported being targeted in ransomware attacks on Thursday (August 20,2020).

The leak appears to contain a small amount of information related to Canpar's internal operations.

For the three-months ended September 30, 2020, revenue increased by $8.4 million or 5%, from $154.8 million in 2019 to $163.2 million in 2020. This increase in revenue is attributable to a 5.1% increase in revenue per pound (excluding fuel surcharge) partially offset by a 0.6% decrease in tonnage. The decrease in tonnage was the result of a 2.4% decrease in average weight per shipment offset by a 1.9% increase in number of shipments. This combination is the result of a higher volume of B2C shipments in 2020. Also, during the three-month period ended September 30, 2020, the Package and Courier segment experienced an IT security breach that had a negative impact on the segment's revenue estimated at $8 million.

location.street: Legal Depertment, Block A Maynooth Business Campus

incident.description:
On December 2, 2021, the Data Protection Commission imposed a EUR 60,000 fine to the Teaching Council after the personal data of more than 9,735 people was leaked via a phishing scam.

The initial breach occurred when two council staff members opened a suspicious email, which facilitated the creation of an auto-forward rule allowing for emails to be forwarded from the council's servers to a malicious Gmail address.

Some 323 emails, containing the personal data of 9,735 people and the sensitive personal data of one person, were automatically forwarded from the compromised accounts between February 17 and March 6, 2020, when the problematic rule was eventually discovered.

In addition to the fine and the official reprimand, the commission said the Teaching Council must bring its processes into line with the EU's GDPR data protection legislation.

organization.name: The Jersey City Municipal Utilities Authority

incident.description:
The Jersey City Municipal Utilities Authority (JCMUA) has hired a law firm to investigate a cyberattack that blocked access to vital water and sewer service information and led to an emergency condition.

The ransomware attack, which occurred on September 30, 2020, caused the agency to lose access to vital information and documentation related to the provision of water and sewerage services to the citizens of the City of Jersey City

It's unclear exactly what data the hackers targeted or how long JCMUA officials lost access to that data. But the authority ultimately determined the incident threatened the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of Jersey City.

It's unclear who was responsible for the attack.

Officials expect the cost of the contract, which will not exceed $25,000, to be covered by the New Jersey Utility Authorities Joint Insurance Fund.

On December 17, 2020 meeting, the MUA Board of Commissioners voted to approve a new $391,000 emergency contract with cybersecurity firm Digital Team Six for technical restoration services, according to a resolution obtained through an Open Public Records request.

organization.name: The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington Inc

incident.description:
The Jewish Federation of Greater Washington reported a hack that drained $7.5 million from its endowment fund and funneled the money into international accounts. CEO Gil Preuss announced the hack to employees in a virtual call Wednesday morning, saying the initial attack targeted an employee using a personal computer while working from home.

The FBI is assisting in an investigation of the incident, according to Joy Jiras, a spokeswoman for the agency's field division in Baltimore. The FBI declined to comment further on the case.

The attack targeted an agency fund within the federation's endowment, said Preuss, who declined to identify the agency, at its request. As of Wednesday, the federation's internal investigation had found that other agency funds and donor information remained unscathed.

'We are very sorry this happened and are doing everything we can to recover the funds and to prevent an incident like this from ever happening again,' said a draft of the letter reviewed by The Washington Post.

Preuss said he hopes the federation can soon shift focus away from the attack to dedicate its energy to the community it serves.

organization.name: The Kroger Co.
organization.industry: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

incident.description:
On March 17, 2021, a class action lawsuit was filed by Ricky Cochran (Plaintiff) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against The Kroger Co. (Kroger) and Accellion, Inc. (Accellion) (collectively, Defendants) for failing to secure clients information.

According to the complaint, on January 23, 2021, Accellion informed Kroger that Kroger's files and information were impacted by the Data Breach. Specifically, Accellion notified Kroger that an unauthorized person gained access to certain Kroger files by exploiting a vulnerability in Accellion's FTA platform. Accellion made headlines in late 2020 and early 2021 following its December 23, 2020 disclosure to numerous clients that criminals breached Accellion's client-submitted data via a vulnerability in its represented 'secure' file transfer application. On February 19, 2021, Kroger publicly confirmed that the Personal Information of Kroger's pharmacy customers, employees, and money service customers, among others, was accessed by and disclosed to criminals without authorization because who were able to exploit vulnerabilities in Accellion's FTA product.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, appoint Plaintiffs as class representative and undersigned counsel as class counsel, actual and statutory damages, attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses, and such other relief.

On June 25, 2021, Ricky Cochran, Alain Berrebi, and Jaramey Stobbe (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed an amended class action complaint.

On June 30, 2021, the parties have reach settlement. Under the Settlement, Kroger has agreed to establish a $5 million Settlement Fund to pay for two years of credit monitoring services and identity theft insurance (Credit Monitoring and Insurance Services), or provide cash payments of up to $5,000 per Class Member for reimbursement of certain Documented Losses (Documented Loss Payment), or provide cash payments to Class Members (Cash Fund Payment). The Settlement Fund will also be used to pay for the costs of the settlement administration, court-approved attorneys' fees and expenses and Service Awards for named Plaintiffs. In addition, Kroger has agreed to undertake certain remedial measures and enhanced security measures that it will continue to implement.

Class Counsel will file a motion asking the Court to award them attorneys' fees and expenses of up to a maximum of 25% of the $5 million Settlement Fund (i.e. $1,250,000). They will also ask the Court to approve $1,500 service awards to each of the three Class Representatives for participating in the action and for their efforts in achieving the Settlement.

On June 30, 2021, Plaintiffs moved for preliminary approval of the class action settlement.

On November 11, 2021, District Judge Edward J. Davila has preliminarily approved the settlement.

On January 14, 2022, a motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement was entered.

On January 19, 2021, Plaintiff Brandon Callier filed a complaint in the US District Court for the Western District of Texas, El Paso against Defendants The Litigation Practice Group, PC, Daniel March, Keeping Capital LLC and David King in violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

Defendants called and text Plaintiff's cell phone at least 13 times from December 15, 2020 to December 18, 2020. Defendants use robocalls and telemarketers to market their professional legal services for debt validation. Plaintiff never consented to receive the calls. Plaintiff had no relationship with Defendants prior to the calls and texts.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On March 31, 2021, Plaintiff filed motion for default judgement.

On April 22, 2021, the Court granted the motion and entered an order in favor of Plaintiff against Defendant in the amount of $13,000.

organization.name: The New London Hospital Association Inc

incident.description:
On May 18, 2021, Tom Steen (Plaintiff) and behalf of people who have similar claims filed a class action lawsuit in the New Hampshire Merrimack County Superior Court against the New London Hospital Association, Inc., d/b/a New London Hospital and Newport Health Center (Defendant or New London). The action arises out of Defendant failure to protect consumer data in a 2020 data breach.

In July 2020, an unauthorized third party allegedly gained access to New London's health systems, which contained no health information but did contain personal information such as names and demographics. The hospital sent notices to affected consumers in March 2021.

Shortly after being informed of the data breach, consumers took legal action against New London Hospital, arguing in their lawsuit that the healthcare provider failed to protect patient information through reasonable cybersecurity measures. Plaintiffs in the case also challenged New London's handling of the data breach and how long it took the hospital to inform affected consumers of the breach.

According to the data breach class action lawsuit, New London Hospital is responsible for the losses and damages experienced by patients following the data breach. The hospital previously attempted to dismiss the class action lawsuit, but the court did not make a ruling before the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint.

A settlement has been reached in a class action lawsuit against New London Hospital Association, Inc. d/b/a New London Hospital and Newport Health Center (New London Hospital) relating to the potential compromise of private information of current and/or former patients of New London Hospital on or about July 30, 2020 (Data Incident).

New London Hospital hasn't admitted any wrongdoing but agreed to pay an undisclosed sum to settle these allegations.

On July 7, 2022, a settlement agreement is entered into by and between the parties.

Under the settlement agreement, New London Hospital or its insurer shall make available the following compensation to Settlement Class Members: settlement class members will be eligible for compensation for unreimbursed ordinary losses, up to a total of $500.00 per claimant, upon submission of a valid Claim Form and supporting documentation, if applicable; Class Members will also be eligible to submit a claim for a statutory benefit; All Class Members who submit a claim shall be awarded $125.00. The total amount of statutory benefits shall be capped at $150,000.00, and payments to the Class Members who make claims shall be reduced on a pro rata basis according to the number of claims made if the total exceeds the overall $150,000.00 cap; Consumers can also claim up to $5,000 for extraordinary losses resulting from fraud or identity theft.

New London Hospital agrees not to oppose an application by Plaintiff's counsel to request the Court for approval of attorney's fees and expenses not to exceed three hundred thousand ($300,000.00). Plaintiff also will seek the Court's approval of a class representative Service Award not to exceed one thousand ($1,000), which shall be separate and apart from any other sums as stated.

On July 11, 2022, Plaintiffs filed an unopposed motion for preliminary approval of the class action settlement.

On September 8, 2022, an order granting motion for preliminary approval of class settlement agreement.

A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Euroseal Windows Limited for making unsolicited calls for direct marketing purposes.

Between 1 January 2020 and 2 December 2020, Euroseal used a public telecommunications service for the purposes of making, on the balance of probabilities, at least 169,830 unsolicited calls for direct marketing purposes.

This resulted in a total of five complaints being made to the TPS and the Commissioner.

The Commissioner is also satisfied that these unsolicited direct marketing calls were made to subscribers who had registered with the TPS at least 28 days prior to receiving the calls and had not notified Euroseal that they did not object to receiving such calls.

On October 3, 2022, Euroseal Windows Limited has been fined GBP 80,000 (89,285.6 USD) by the ICO.

organization.name: Travelers Insurance Company of Canada
organization.industry: Direct Property and Casualty Insurance Carriers

incident.description:
Between May 2020 and January 2021, Netwalker ransomware gang affiliate Sebastien Vachon-Desjardins victimized Canadian entities and others throughout the world by breaching private computer networks and systems, hi-jacking their data, holding the stolen data for ransom, and distributing stolen data when ransoms were not paid.

In August 2020, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) received information from the American Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in relation to a NetWalker ransomware affiliate operating in Gatineau Quebec. FBI advised the RCMP that their suspect was responsible for ransomware attacks in several countries, and he was suspected to have received over a million in ransom payments.

When RCMP searched his home and banks accounts in January 2021, they seized less than 720 Bitcoins of these along with bags of money that came from laundering previous Bitcoin funds. In addition to money, the investigators also found more than 20 Tb of data on his devices that he stole from the hacked organizations, before deploying the ransomware.

On February 1, 2022, Vachon-Desjardins was ordered to pay CAD$2.8 million in restitution to eight victims of ransomware attack including Travelers Insurance Company of Canada in the amount of $417,449.

The University of Utah paid extortionists almost half a million dollars after a ransomware attack on some of its computer servers, and is now telling students, staff and faculty to change their university passwords.

According to a statement issued by the university, it paid $457,059.24 to an 'unknown entity' that hacked the College of Social and Behavioral Science servers on July 19, 2020, rendering them temporarily inaccessible.

While the cyber insurance policy paid part of the ransom, the university covered the remainder. No tuition, grant, donation, state or taxpayer funds were used to pay the ransom, the school said.

A university spokesperson told Threatpost that they have since received the decryption key.

The cyber criminals encrypted about 0.02% of the data stored there before the U.'s Information Security Office detected the attack. The university did not specify the threat, but ransomware attacks involve criminal groups that hack into and steal data; encrypt it so that its owners cannot access it; and demand payment to release the data -- often threatening to release sensitive information if their demands are not met.

The police were contacted, and the university engaged 'an outside consultant with expertise in handling these types of situations.'

The affected servers were isolated from the rest of the university and the internet. The servers were cleaned, and college data was reinstalled from system backups. But because it included employee and student information and after careful consideration, the ransom was paid as a proactive and preventive step to ensure information was not released on the internet.

Ten days after the attack, students, staff and faculty were told to change their university passwords. According to the university, the delay was because there had to be a full understanding of what information may have been stolen and how access was gained as it worked with law enforcement to determine what steps should be taken.

organization.name: The University Of Vermont Health Network Inc

incident.description:
The University of Vermont (UVM) health network is scrambling to recover its systems after a cyberattack led to widespread delays in patient appointments. The cyberattack was first launched the week of October 25, 2020. On October 28, the hospital IT staff noticed abnormal activity, and shut down its online operations. The hack downed hospital phone and email networks, eliminating access to patient records and appointments - including chemotherapy appointments, as well as mammograms and biopsies, and halted access for the hospital to pay employee's overtime.

According to local reports, the attack came through the hospital's main computer server, and impacted its entire system. Since then, the FBI and the Vermont National Guard have been brought in to review thousands of end-user computers and devices, to ensure that they are free of malware. In an update, the UVM health network said that it made significant progress overnight to restore behind-the-scenes components that will aid in the restoration of additional patient-facing systems.

The UVM's electronic medical records system is up and running nearly a month after the hospital fell victim to a cyberattack. According to Al Gobeille, a vice president of operations for the UVM, the hospital tech team restored Epic health records system, giving doctors and nurses full access to patient medical history, appointments, and medication.

According to the reports, the October 2020 ransomware attack on the University of Vermont Medical Center has reportedly cost more than $1.5 million per day in lost revenue and increased expenses, according to hospital president Stephen Leffler, not including the cost of getting its systems back up and running. The attack occurred on October 28, 2020 and 42 days later losses continue to be experienced.

During the breach, nearly 1,300 servers were compromised on more than 5,000 devices across the UVM Health Network. Hospital officials stated that while no patient or employee information was stolen, the process cost them $65 million.

Gentile's reconstruction provided the first glimpse into the cause of the cyberattack, which crippled Vermont's largest hospital for weeks. In the nearly two months following the hack, hospital officials have remained tight-lipped about the perpetrators and methods of the attack, citing an ongoing investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

On August 5, 2021, a UVM Health Network official said that the cyberattack happened after an employee opened a personal email on a company laptop while on vacation.

The email contained an attachment that had the malware. When the employee returned from vacation and logged onto the UVM network through a virtual private network, the attackers were ready and launched the attack.

organization.name: This Is The Big Deal Limited

incident.description:
On August 25, 2023, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) announced it had issued a monetary penalty notice to This Is The Big Deal Limited, in which it fined the same 30,000 for violation of the Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) Regulations 2003 (PECR), following an investigation by the ICO.

In particular, the ICO stated that between June 1, 2020, and May 10, 2021, This Is The Big Deal transmitted or instigated the transmission of a total of 41,417,889 unsolicited direct marketing communications (39,906,342 emails which it had instigated, and 1,511,547 text messages which it had itself transmitted) to subscribers who had not consented to receive such communications. Furthermore, of 1,511,547 direct marketing text messages which were received by subscribers have been transmitted by This Is The Big Deal, 10,132 were sent without the necessary opt-out information. Moreover, the ICO noted that it received over the same period, a total of 1,062 complaints relating to This Is The Big Deal's unsolicited direct marketing and 7,726 spam reporting service.

The ICO found that This Is The Big Deal contravened Regulation 22(2) of PECR for transmitting or instigating the transmission of unsolicited direct marketing communication to subscribers who had not consented to receive such communication. Moreover, the ICO found that This Is The Big Deal contravened Regulation 23(b) of PECR for sending direct marketing text messages without the necessary opt-out information.

organization.name: Thyssenkrupp Materials Na, Inc.
organization.industry: Metal Service Centers and Other Metal Merchant Wholesalers

incident.description:
On February 25, 2021, Darnell Crawford et al (Plaintiffs) filed a class action in the Circuit Court for the City of St. Louis, Missouri against Thyssenkrupp Materials NA, Inc. et al (Defendants) for its failure to protect its employees' Personal Identifiable Information (PII) from disclosure and was served on March 4, 2021.

In September 2020, Conti ransomware group leaked documents from Thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft's Canadian elevator subsidiary, as part of a ransomware attack. In December of 2020, the Mount Locker ransomware group started publishing data it had procured from ThyssenKrupp System Engineering, another subsidiary of Thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft, via a second ransomware attack.

On or about December 28, 2020, ThyssenKrupp's servers and workstations were hijacked in a ransomware attack that compromised the PII of its current and former employees. ThyssenKrupp notified victims of the Data Breach one month later, on January 28, 2021.

The compromised PII includes but is not limited to current and former employees' names, addresses, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, direct deposit information, health information and contact information.

Plaintiffs are employees of Defendants that are victims of Defendants' negligence and insufficient data security practices. Plaintiffs have suffered a tangible and concrete injury-in-fact. Upon belief, there are at least 4,000 persons affected.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On April 2, 2021, the case was transferred to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.

On October 18, 2021, it was ordered that Plaintiff's Motion to Remand was granted.

On December 28, 2022, Defendants will pay all valid claims of Class Members for Lost Time, Ordinary Loss, and Extraordinary Loss, up to an aggregate total not to exceed $750,000 for all Class Members. Defendants will also pay to Class Counsel attorneys' fees and expenses approved by the Court in an amount not to exceed $435,000 and will pay service awards approved by the Court in an amount not to exceed $3,500 to each Class Representative and not to exceed $7,000 in aggregate to all Class Representatives.

The final approval hearing for the settlement is scheduled on February 27, 2023.

Tillamook County officials revealed that a $300,000 ransom was paid to regain data access after a January cyberattack.

The ransom amount was disclosed during the Tillamook County Board of Commissioners meeting Wednesday (March 11).
