The county's rapid and aggressive response to the incident mitigated the compromise and contained the encryption to 17 of 55 servers and five of 280 county workstations.

The attack was reportedly carried out by an international cybercriminal organization known to law enforcement. The county's statement said the computer system was disabled for around two weeks, adding that new security measures were being implemented.

Baertlein said the $300,000 loss would have a significant impact on the rural county's coffers. He compared the cyberattack to being shaken down by a bully and called on the federal government to act against cybercrime.

The county's server, internal computer systems and website went down in the Jan. 22 attack, and phone systems and email networks were affected. County computer network connections were disabled to contain the spread of malware.

A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against The Money Hive Limited for making unsolicited direct marketing messages to subscribers without valid consent.

Between 12 March 2020 and 8 September 2020, a total of 752,425 unsolicited direct marketing messages were received by subscribers, having been sent by The Money Hive Limited without valid consent.

On February 17, 2022, The Money Hive Limited has been fined GBP 50,000 (67,821.5 USD) by the ICO.

Toledo Public Schools (TPS) suffered a massive data breach that resulted in the online publication of sensitive information, including students' addresses, dates of birth, test scores, and Social Security numbers.

The hackers posted sensitive information online that was obtained in conjunction with a ransomware attack that shut down virtual education in Toledo Public Schools during the first day of online classes on September 8, 2020.

The district on September 10 entered into an agreement with Tetra Defense, Inc. - a computer security service corporation located in Madison, Wisconsin - for a complete forensic analysis of the potential cyber security incident. TPS will pay a cyber security contractor roughly$75,000 to investigate a suspected ransomware attack.

The school district has released a few other details about the incident, stating that an investigation into the matter is ongoing. The district's contract with Tetra Defense shows the firm is tasked with - among other matters - figuring out how the cyber attack occurred, eliminating any possible persistent threats, and preserving evidence in the investigation. For its work with the school district, Tetra Defense will charge$295 per hour, records show. The firm's analysis is expected to require 260 hours of work, bringing the estimated cost of the contract to $76,700.

Wyndham Destinations has paid the fine of $159,600 ($109,210.29) following an Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) investigation into breaches of the telemarketing rules, and the issuing of an infringement notice to the company.

ACMA Chair Nerida O'Loughlin said an investigation found Wyndham Destinations was unable to demonstrate it had consent for calls made to numbers on the Do Not Call Register and failed to terminate calls after recipients indicated they did not wish to continue.

O'Loughlin said telemarketers must be aware of their responsibilities when making calls to numbers on the Do Not Call Register.

Wyndham Destinations was found to have breached the Telecommunications (Telemarketing and Research Calls) Industry Standard 2017 (Telemarketing Industry Standard) and the Do Not Call Register Act 2006.

Blackbaud, Inc. (Blackbaud), one of the world's largest providers of financial and fundraising technology to nonprofits, was hacked and paid a ransom to have the hijacked data destroyed by the cybercriminals.

On July 16, 2020, Blackbaud notified Trinity Health and other customers of a cyber-attack involving Blackbaud's network, including ransomware, that impacted certain donor database backup files maintained by Blackbaud, including Trinity Health's donor database.

Blackbaud reported that based on its investigation, the cybercriminals responsible for the attack could have obtained access to various types of information in the client backup files. The breach occurred between February 7, 2020 and May 20, 2020.

Upon receiving this notice, Trinity Health took immediate steps to begin its own investigation to determine what, if any, sensitive Trinity Health data was potentially impacted. The forensic investigation determined that some data fields were encrypted and would not be accessible to the cybercriminals. However, personal information may have been accessible to the cybercriminals including information such as: donor relation to patient, patient discharge status, patient insurance and patient department of service. This database information spans from 2000 to 2020.

According to court documents, Trinity Health along with its insurer, Aspen Specialty Insurance Company, incurred $2,317,432.39, plus interest, and continue to accrue because of the ongoing fallout of the incident. This cost includes implementation of new data retention protocols and build a new process to handle patients and donors opting-out from future contact.

The Personal Data Protection Authority ('KVKK') published, on 23 June 2020, its decision of 16 April 2020, fining a gaming company a total of TRY 1,100,000 (approx. C142,980) ($160,673.78) for data breach notification violations. In particular, the Decision concerns a data breach suffered by the gaming company in which hackers were able to gain access to the company's player data affecting 39,995 individuals in Turkey.

Specifically, the Decision highlights that the company was fined 1,000,000 TRY (approx. C129,980) for violations of Article 12 of the Law on Protection of Personal Data No.6698 and not having taken the necessary technical and administrative measures to ensure the appropriate level of security. Furthermore, the Decision notes that the gaming company was fined an additional TRY 100,000 (approx. C13,000) for failures to report the breach within the 72-hour period required.

On August 23, 2020, Tuckers Solicitors were victim to a significant cyber-attack, by an organized criminal group that have previously targeted many small, medium and large companies from around the world, as well as public authorities. Fortunately, their IT team was resilient to the attack, which means that they have been able to operate largely unaffected.

The most significant disruption to their systems resulted from the impact to their Microsoft Exchange server, where they lost emails for two days, but those systems were restored as well.

However, the data that was extracted from their systems had been uploaded on the dark web of the criminal cyber hacking group that extracted client data from part of their server infrastructure. Possible customer information, accounts, credential or password may have been accessed. No other information has been made available.

They discovered that data relating to only about 60 clients was extracted from their systems. They also increased their efforts to try and contact relevant individuals directly - but where the material was particularly old, it may not be easily possible to contact relevant people.

On March 10, 2022, the Information Commissioner announced that they issued Tuckers a monetary penalty of GBP 98,000 under General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Data Protection Act (DPA).

On September 29, 2020, Tyler Technologies Inc. (Tyler) filed a Current Report on Form 8-K reporting a security incident involving ransomware disrupting access to some of their internal IT systems and telephone systems. There is no evidence that the environments where they host client applications were affected, and their hosting services to those clients were not interrupted. There is also no evidence of malicious activity on client networks associated with the Incident. They contained the Incident and recovered from it, resuming normal operations with their clients.

They promptly notified their clients of the Incident and provided timely updates to their clients through direct communications and updates to their website.

Although Tyler believe they have contained and recovered from the Incident, and that they have taken and will continue to take appropriate remediation steps, they are subject to risk and uncertainties as a result of the Incident.

Tyler believe they are in the final phases of their investigation, but there can be no assurance as to what the ongoing impact of the Incident will be, if any. The Incident caused an interruption in parts of their business.

Tyler estimate that as a result of the Incident, revenue (primarily software services) for the year ended December 31, 2020 was reduced by approximately $1.5 million; however, insurance reimbursements pertaining to lost revenue represent a contingent gain and any recovery of these revenues will be recorded when received. They incurred $4.2 million in costs associated with the Incident as of December 31, 2020. As of December 31, 2020, they have recorded $1.1 million of accrued insurance recoveries and received $2.4 million of insurance recoveries related to the Incident.

The recorded costs consisted primarily of payments to third-party service providers and consultants, including legal fees, and enhancements to their cybersecurity measures. It is expected that they will continue to incur costs related to their response, remediation, and investigatory efforts relating to the Incident. Tyler maintain cybersecurity insurance coverage in an amount that they believe is adequate.

For the six months period ended June 30, 2021, they have recorded $336,000 of expenses and recorded approximately $637,000 of accrued insurance recoveries. The recorded costs consist primarily of payments to third-party service providers and consultants, including legal fees, and enhancements to our cybersecurity measures.

On August 7, 2020, James Barr (Plaintiff) filed a class action in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against Drizly LLC (Defendant) for its failure to safeguard and protect its customers' highly sensitive and personal customer information as the result of a Data Breach that has exposed Drizly's customers' information on the 'dark web'.

On July 28, 2020, the online alcohol delivery service Drizly notified customers, including Plaintiff, that it had 'recently identified some suspicious activity involving customer data' and that an internal investigation had determined 'that an unauthorized party appears to have obtained some of our customers' personal information' (the 'Data Breach'). According to Drizly's account of the Data Breach in their email notification, the information acquired by hackers included only customer email addresses, dates of birth, passwords, delivery addresses, phone numbers, IP addresses and geolocation data associated with the user's billing address.

However, despite Drizly's claims, reporters at the leading technology industry news source TechCrunch quickly found that the scope and nature of the Data Breach was much broader than what Drizly had disclosed and admitted. According to TechCrunch as many as 2.5 million Drizly accounts are believed to have been stolen.

TechCrunch also identified customer information from the Drizly Data Breach for sale on the dark web, where cyber criminals can purchase the information to commit fraud and identity theft, as well as other financial crimes. The post was made on February 13, 2020. Even though Drizly claimed that no customers had their financial information compromised as a result of the Data Breach, the dark web listing includes users' credit card numbers and order histories. TechCrunch's findings confirm that not only did Drizly allow a data breach to occur, but Drizly has failed to discover, and disclose, the full scope and extent of the Data Breach.

Moreover, Drizly failed to identify the breach until July 28, 2020, even though its users' sensitive customer data has been available on the dark web since at least February 13, 2020.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On July 13, 2021, a motion for final approval of the 7.1 million settlement was submitted.

On September 10, 2021, a motion for extension to September 27, 2021, to file the declaration of the Settlement Administrator by James Barr.

On November 22, 2021, the settlement was approved.

On November 24, 2021, the case was terminated.

On November 8, 2021, Julie Kesner and Dennis O'Brien (Plaintiffs) individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, filed a class action lawsuit in the Massachusetts Superior Court for Worcester County against UMass Memorial Health Care Inc. (Defendant) for alleged failure to implement adequate and reasonable data security procedures and protocols necessary to protect PII and PHI.

UMass Memorial Health has been notified of a data breach involving the health system's email system exposing the personal information of 2,967 Massachusetts residents. Some of the emails accessed by hackers included patient information, such as Social Security numbers and medical-related data.

UMass Memorial Health, in an October 15, 2021, notice to patients, said an unauthorized person accessed the accounts between June 24, 2020, and January 7, 2021.

On August 25, 2021, the health care completed the process of identifying individuals with the information contained in the accounts. For patients, the data involved included names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, health insurance information, and clinical or treatment information, such as dates of service, provider names, diagnoses, procedure information, and/or prescription information. For health plan participants, the data involved included names, subscriber ID numbers, and benefits election information. For some individuals, a Social Security number and/or driver's license number were also involved.

Plaintiff and the Class members sought an award for statutory damages, actual damages, cost, reasonable attorney's fees, and all other relief as may be just and proper.

On October 17, 2022, UMass Memorial Health Care agreed to pay $1.2 million including the attorney's fees in the amount of $400,000 and a service award of $3,000 for each of the two Class Representatives.

Umea University has processed sensitive personal data about sexual life and health and stored in a cloud service without protecting the data sufficiently. As a result, The Swedish Data Protection Authority issued a fine of SEK 550,000 (approximately $65,000) against the university.

On December 11, 2020, the Swedish Data Protection Authority has now completed an audit of Umea University, concluding that the University has violated the General Data Protection Regulation by processing special categories of personal data without applying appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect the data.

A research group at the university has requested preliminary investigative protocols from the police concerning rape of men and has subsequently scanned the documents released by the police. The preliminary investigation protocols contain information on, among other things, suspicion of crime, name, social security number and contact information, but also sensitive information on sexual life and health.

The Swedish Data Protection Authority's investigation shows that the research group stored over a hundred scanned preliminary investigation reports in an American cloud service, despite the University having informed via its intranet that special categories of data should not be stored in the cloud service in question.

On December 13, 2020, Unisys Corporation (Unisys) identified one computer in its network that had a version of SolarWinds Orion software, which a likely nation-state threat actor infected with malicious code that could have allowed for unauthorized activity on affected computers and their networks (SolarWinds Compromise).

Unisys also received notifications about and discovered compromises of its environment likely by the same threat actor. The compromises of Unisys's systems took place over a combined span of at least sixteen months starting in January 2020 and were persistent and impacted several parts of its corporate network and non-customer facing cloud environment.

Specifically, the activity involved the compromise of at least seven network credentials and 34 cloud-based accounts, including those with administrative privileges, repeated connections into Unisys's network with at least 33 gigabytes of data transferred, and access to cloud-based shared files and mailboxes, including those of senior IT personnel. Unisys was aware that its investigations of the compromise involved significant gaps in its ability to identify the full scope of the unauthorized activity due to the lack of availability of the forensic evidence.

On October 22, 2024, the Securities and Exchange Commission imposed the company a penalty in the amount of $4,000,000 for data security violations.

location.street: Universal Corporate Center, 367 South Gulph Road, PO Box 615

incident.description:
2020 was a particularly bad year for healthcare industry ransomware attacks, with one of the worst suffered by the King of Prussia, PA-based Fortune 500 healthcare system, Universal Health Services (UHS).

As previously disclosed on September 29, 2020, Universal Health Services (UHS) experienced an information technology security incident in the early morning hours of September 27, 2020. As a result of this cyberattack, UHS suspended user access to its information technology applications related to operations located in the United States.

The phone system was taken out of action, and without access to computers and electronic health records, employees had to resort to pen and paper to record patient information. In the early hours after the attack occurred, the health system diverted ambulances to alternative facilities and some elective procedures were either postponed or diverted to competitors. Patients reported delays receiving test results while UHS recovered from the attack.

Restoring its IT infrastructure resulted in significant increase in labor costs, both internally and externally. Cash flows were also affected as certain administrative functions such as coding and billing had to be delayed until December 2020.

UHS has reported total pre-tax losses of an estimated $67 million in 2020 due to the ransomware attack, mostly because of the loss of operating income, reduction in patient activity, and increased revenue reserves because of the billing delays. UHS believes it is entitled to recover the majority of the $67 million in insurance payouts.

On June 8, 2020, Universal Logistics Holdings, Inc experienced a ransomware cyber-attack affecting certain of the company's network systems. During the attack, the company experienced limited disruption and rapidly deployed backup systems or implemented temporary procedures to maintain operations. The company is investigating the attack, including the scope of transferred or extracted data. Based on the company's best estimate of the liability, the company has recorded an accrued liability of $0.5 million. While the company cannot predict with any certainty the outcome of the matter, management does not believe the ultimate resolution will have a material adverse effect on their business, financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows.

The company's General and administrative expense for the twenty-six weeks that ended July 4, 2020, was $0.5 million in professional service fees associated with the June 2020 cyber-attack.

University Hospital New Jersey (UHNJ), a state-owned independent teaching hospital with over 3,500 employees established in 1994, has experienced a ransomware attack. The attack occurred on September 10, 2020 by a ransomware gang known as SunCrypt. Prior to the use of ransomware, the attackers exfiltrated around 48,000 documents, some of which were published on the ransomware operator's data leak site.

The attack appears to have started with a phishing email that resulted in the TrickBot Trojan being downloaded. SunCrypt ransomware was delivered as a secondary payload.

The UHNJ were more concerned about the releasing of patient data, and we're willing to pay a ransom to prevent it from being released any further as they had only two servers encrypted.

The hospital contacted the ransomware operators via their Tor payment site, and the initial demand was $1.7 million. The threat actors we're open to a negotiation of the ransom 'due to COVID-19 situation.'

On September 19, the two parties agreed to pay $672,744 ransom, approximately 61.90 Bitcoins.

SunCrypt ransomware operators gave UHNJ a decryptor, a security report, the stolen data and an agreement not to reveal any stolen data or attack UHNJ again.

The data leak includes patient information release authorization forms, copies of driving licenses, Social Security Numbers (SSNs), date of birth (DOB), and records about the Board of Directors.

The University of Kentucky and UK HealthCare conducted a major reboot of their computer systems early morning on March 8, 2020, Sunday, to end a month-long cyberattack.

According to Eric Monday, UK's executive vice president for finance and administration, the unidentified threat actors infiltrated Kentucky's largest university system in early February 2020 from somewhere outside the United States and installed malware that utilized UK's vast processing capabilities to mine cryptocurrency, such as Bitcoin.

According to university spokesman Jay Blanton, the protracted intrusion, which the university believes it resolved early Sunday morning during a campus-wide network outage, has repeatedly caused a slowing or temporary failure of computer systems used by students and employees, an effect that was likely 'most acute' on the health care side.

The university's remediation efforts culminated early morning on March 8, when UK information technology services powered down the entire system and severed Internet access in order to kick the attackers out and further harden the system against anyone who tries to reenter. Investigation efforts, including beefing up the network's security software, has cost up to $1.5 million.

Patient safety and access to care was never compromised and there is no evidence personal information or other sensitive data was accessed or downloaded.

University of Miami was investigating a data breach that may have exposed the information of patients belonging to the Coral Gables, Fla.-based university's health system, according to a March 26 South Florida Sun Sentinel report.

The breach was part of a nationwide hack on Accellion, a data file transfer services provider, from earlier that year. Healthcare insurer Centene, Kroger pharmacy and Arizona Complete Health plan have all also reported being affected by the incident.

Hackers accessed patient information from UHealth, according to the university's website. After discovering the breach, University of Miami launched an investigation, which is ongoing.

'Based on our investigation to date, the incident was limited to the Accellion server used for secure file transfers and did not compromise other University of Miami systems or affect outside systems linked to the University of Miami's network,' the university said in the statement.

University of Miami was allegedly hacked by CL0P ransomware group.

Upon information, the breach occurred on December 16, 2020 and January 20, 2021, after threat actors targeted Accellion's File Transfer Appliance (FTA) as a means of committing an unauthorized access and theft of confidential information. The University of Miami used Accellion's FTA software to transfer large files including confidential information and PHI. During the breach, University of Miami's confidential information was accessed and stolen by threat actors. As a result, University of Miami incurred damages to remediate the effects of the breach and loss of confidential information, including protected health information.

As a result of the incident and direct result of Accellion's breach of contract, University of Miami incurred damages and loss in the amount of approximately $1,066,507.52, which its insurer, AIG Specialty Insurance Company covered the costs to remediate the university's loss of confidential information and other fallout from the breach.

In 2021, Michael Bowen (Plaintiff) filed a complaint against University of Pittsburgh Medical Center and Charles J. Hilton, PC (collectively, Defendants) in the Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County. The action arises out of Defendants' failure to safeguard sensitive data, violated current data security industry standards, and failed to establish adequate firewalls to handle a server intrusion.

According to the complaint, the Defendants discovered suspicious activity on their employee email system in June 2020. Further investigation revealed that an unauthorized actor had accessed several Defendant CJH email accounts between April 1 and June 25, 2020. The breach potentially impacted 36,000 UPMC patients and exposed protected health information (PHI), including health insurance information, diagnoses, prescription information, Social Security numbers, and more.

On June 10, 2022, the Defendants agreed to pay $450,000 to resolve claims.

organization.name: Uppsalahem AB
organization.industry: Lessors of Residential Buildings and Dwellings

incident.description:
On December 14, 2021, the Data Inspectorate fined Uppsalahem AB a 300,000 SEK as administrative sanction for processing personal data in breach of Data Protection Regulation.

On March 9, 2020, the Data Inspectorate received a complaint from an individual about the camera surveillance of Uppsalahem AB. The Data Inspectorate claimed that Uppsalahem AB conducted camera surveillance of common areas in an apartment building and parts of dwellings in the same house between February 25, 2020 to May 14, 2020 when the interest in monitoring does not outweigh those registered interests as well as fundamental freedoms and rights on the ground.

organization.name: Us Fertility, LLC
organization.industry: Offices of Physicians (except Mental Health Specialists)

incident.description:
On February 4, 2021, Riley Fadness, Laura Maxwell and Laura Peterson (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland against US Fertility LLC (Defendant) on their failure to secure their customer's data that was compromised in the breach.

US Fertility LLC is a national fertility-clinic network headquartered in Rockville, Maryland. Defendant provides IT platforms, as well as administrative, clinical, and business services to 55 fertility clinics in 9 states, plus Washington D.C., making it responsible for the most fertility-related healthcare data in the United States.

On November 25, 2020, Defendant publicly announced it had experienced a ransomware attack months earlier, resulting in a data breach affecting 27 of its 55 clinic locations. The Data Breach resulted in 'an unauthorized actor' acquiring 'files' of 'individuals' protected health information.' The Data Breach occurred between August 12, 2020, and September 14, 2020.

Plaintiffs learned their PHI was compromised in the Data Breach through a letter Defendant sent to patients dated as late as January 8, 2021.

Defendant's conduct in allowing the Data Breach to occur was negligent, and Defendant breached its duty to protect the confidentiality of Plaintiffs' PHI and violated consumer protection privacy laws, resulting in concrete harm to Plaintiffs and the Class. As a contractor to providers of health care, Defendant is also subject to the requirements for preserving the confidentiality of medical information set forth under California's Confidentiality of Medical Information Act (CMIA).

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

On November 15, 2021, Plaintiffs filed their First Amended Consolidated Class Action Complaint. On November 22, 2021, Defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs' First Amended Consolidated Class Action Complaint and Motion to Strike.

On December 22, 2021, Plaintiffs filed a Response in Opposition to Defendants' Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs' First Amended Consolidated Class Action Complaint and Motion to Strike.

On April 28, 2022, the Court heard oral argument from the Parties on Defendants' Motion to Dismiss Plaintiffs' First Amended Consolidated Class Action Complaint and Motion to Strike.

On October 4, 2022, Judge Denlow provided the parties with a mediator's recommendation as to certain settlement terms. On October 10, 2022, counsel for the parties reached a tentative agreement with regard to certain material terms of the settlement. The parties did not discuss attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses, or Service Awards for the Class Representatives prior to reaching an agreement as to the material terms of the relief for the Settlement Class. The Parties now agree to settle the action in its entirety.

On August 21, 2023, a settlement agreement was filed. The Settlement will provide $5.75 million to compensate individuals whose personal information was compromised in the data breach incident, pay notice and administration fees and attorneys' fees and expenses subject to court approval.

Class Counsel will ask the Court to approve payment of up to 33.33% of the Settlement Fund for attorney's fees and reimbursement of up to $75,000.00 in litigation expenses they incurred in the case. The attorney's fees would pay Class Counsel for investigating the facts, litigating the case, and negotiating the Settlement. After attorney's fees and costs, Service Awards (up to $2,500 for each of the 20 class representatives) and expenses for the Settlement Administrator (up to $779,500) are deducted, the Settlement Fund will be used to pay the benefits to the Settlement Class Members. The Settlement also provides for data security practice enhancements and commitments by US Fertility (and some of its subsidiaries and partners).

On November 22, 2023, the Court granted Plaintiff's motion for Preliminary Approval of Class Action Settlement. The Final Fairness Hearing is scheduled for April 18, 2024.

Fraudsters have conned Norfund, a private equity investment firm based in Oslo, Norway, out of more than $10 million in what the company calls an advanced data breach. But the incident bears the hallmarks of a business email compromise scam.

Scammers spent months within Norfund's internal IT network, gaining access to emails and other communications between the company executives and the partners and businesses in which the firm has made investments, CEO Tellef Thorleifsoon told the Norwegian newspaper Aftenposten. This provided fraudsters with knowledge of documents and other data, which enabled them to falsify payment details.

The $10 million theft, which occurred on March 16, went undetected until April 30, when the fraudsters attempted a second, unsuccessful scam, according to a company statement.

Although investigators are still piecing together just how the scam worked, it appears that after gaining access to Norfund's IT network and email communications, fraudsters began posing as a legitimate microfinance institution in Cambodia, sending emails and other financial and payment documents back to the investment firm, according to Norfund's statement and the Aftenposten account.

Because both Norfund and the Cambodian company believing they were receiving legitimate emails and documents from each other, Norfund sent the $10 million, which instead of going to the Cambodian firm was transferred by the fraudsters to an account in Mexico and disappeared before Norfund executives realized the payment was missing, according to the company statement.

Vard Group, a Norwegian unit of shipbuilder Fincantieri SpA, was attacked in June 2020. But what happened next? It sounds like the company was snookered by a firm who took advantage of REvil's standard offer to decrypt one archive to obtain a decrypted archive to show Vard as 'proof' that they could recover their data for them, I think?

The fact of fraudulent recovery company is there! After encryption of all files and servers inside the company Vard Group AS with all their affiliates (screenshot of all their servers are attached), the owners of Vard Group AS paid $5,500,000 to fraudulent recovery company which asked from Revil Ransomware Team for a test decryption of encrypted archive (encrypted and decrypted archives are attached). That's why we publicly give 72 hours to the owners to contact with us directly, or the price will be doubled.

On August 22, 2020 the claimant filed a claim with the Spanish Data Protection Agency. The claim is directed against VASCO ANDALUZA DE INVERSIONES, SL. The claimant states that her data has been communicated to third parties and she has not received no information. You do not know who is now responsible for your data and their treatment. On May 20, 2021, the Director of the Spanish Agency for

Data Protection agreed to initiate a sanctioning procedure for the complained party, by the alleged violation of Article 6 of the RGPD, typified in Article 83.5.a of the GDPR. That is why it is considered appropriate to graduate the sanction to be imposed on the claimed and set it at the amount of 2,000 for the violation of article 6 of the RGPD.

The State Data Protection Inspectorate (SDPI) imposed an administrative fine in the amount of EUR 15,000 ($17,704) on Vilnius City Municipality Administration (Municipality Administration) for infringements of the Articles 5(1)(d) and 5(1)(f) of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) for improperly processed personal data of the parents of an adopted child.

An applicant applied to the Municipality Administration with regards to the education of an adopted child. However, under the agreement concluded between the Municipality Administration and the State Registry, the information in the IT system was automatically updated once a month according to the data available in the State Registry. Due to this, the applicant's email was automatically replaced by the email of a biological father of the adopted child.

The SDPI held that the Municipality Administration did not have a right under the GDPR to unilaterally change the applicant's email address according to the data provided in the State Registry. Furthermore, there are no grounds to believe that the information received from the State Registry belongs to the applicant, since the data was updated based on the child's data rather than the applicant's data in the State Registry. Hence, having processed personal data of the biological father of the child, the Municipality Administration performed a breach of principles of accuracy as well as integrity and confidentiality established in the Articles 5(1)(d) and 5(1)(f) of the GDPR respectively.

A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Virgin Media Limited for instigating direct marketing emails containing the Marketing Preference Reminder received by subscribers.

The ICO finds that on or around 4 August 2020 there were 451,217 direct marketing emails containing the Marketing Preference Reminder received by subscribers. The ICO also finds that Virgin Media transmitted those direct marketing messages.

On December 8, 2021, Virgin Media Limited has been fined GBP 50,000 (66,265.1 USD) by the ICO.

Virtu Financial Inc. said it lost $6.9 million to hackers who seized control of the email account of one of its executives and used fake emails to send two fraudulent wire transfers to bank accounts in China.

Although the loss from the hack is relatively small for Virtu, it is an embarrassment for the firm, which has a reputation as one of the world's most technologically sophisticated electronic trading operations. It shows how even tech-savvy firms can fall victim to 'social engineering' attacks in which hackers impersonate trusted people to trick employees into performing actions harmful to their companies.

In mid-May 2020, Virtu's computer systems were successfully hacked, and, as a result, the hackers obtained unauthorized access to the email account of a Virtu executive. A day later, the hackers logged into the Executive's mailbox via Outlook Web Access and were able to view and read messages in the mailbox to and from the Executive.

Approximately 13 days later, the hackers created inbox rules that automatically hid certain messages sent from or received in the Executive's inbox. Later, beginning on the same day, pretending to be the Executive, the hackers sent a series of emails from the Executive's email account requesting that Virtu's accounting department issue two wire transfers to overseas banks, one in the amount of approximately $3.6 million, the other in the amount of approximately $7.2 million, for purported capital calls which totaled $10.8 million. Believing the requests to pertain to legitimate, ordinary-course business transactions, Virtu's accounting department complied with the requests.

After extensive efforts, Virtu's legal team was able to obtain an injunction freezing approximately $3.6 million; and approximately $287,474 in two accounts held within the Bank of China. However, Virtu believes it unlikely that the remaining funds (approx. $6.915

million) will be recovered.

Accordingly, Virtu Financial Inc. was a victim of a business email compromise incident.

Vodafone's Italian business is facing a fine of over C12.25 million ($14,532,500) over aggressive telemarketing practices.

Falling under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), the fine is the third-largest to be given by the Italian Data Protection Authority (Garante) in 2020, and the first violation by Vodafone in the country.

The Garante investigation came after it received hundreds of complaints of nuisance calls from Vodafone's sales networks. It found that Vodafone's customer information storage system had multiple flaws and that the company had purchased contacts lists from external providers - with the information of up to 4.5 million people secured without user consent.

Vodafone justified the unwanted communication as human error, but this was not deemed an appropriate excuse by the regulator, with other factors including the 'significantly negligent nature' and recurrence of the calls.

While it is Vodafone's first GDPR violation in Italy, the company's Spanish business has received 29 fines.

On February 11, 2020, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator Vodafone Romania SA and found that it violated the principles of personal data processing established by the provisions of art. 5 para. (1) lit. d) and f) corroborated with art. 5 para. (2) of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator of Vodafone Romania SA was sanctioned with a fine of 14308.8 lei, the equivalent of 3,000 euros or $3,280.87.

The sanction was applied to the controller because it incorrectly processed personal data of a natural person in order to resolve its complaint, which subsequently led to the transmission of the operator's response to an incorrect e-mail address, not taking sufficient security measures against illegal data processing. personal data of the respective person, in violation of the processing principles provided by art. 5 para. (1) lit. d) and f) in conjunction with art. 5 para. (2) of the General Data Protection Regulation.

Thus, the controller was obliged to ensure compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation of the operations of collection and further processing of personal data, by implementing efficient methods of data accuracy, including in the case of data collection, such as e-mail address. In this regard, it was ordered to implement adequate and effective security measures from a technical and organizational point of view, including through regular training of data controllers under the authority of the operator, within 30 days from the date of communication of the minutes.

In October 2021, the National Supervisory Authority completed an investigation at the operator VODAFONE Romania SA and found a violation of the General Regulation on Data Protection (RGPD), as well as the violation on the processing of personal data and the protection of privacy in the electronic communications sector.

The operator was fined 7,421.25 RON (1,500 EUR) for violating the RGPD and 7,000 RON for violating the Law no. 506/2004.

With regard to security breaches reported under the RGPD, the National Supervisory Authority found that the operator did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure that any natural person acting under the authority of the operator or the person authorized by the operator and having access to personal data shall be processed only at the request of the controller unless this obligation is under Union or national law and to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the processing, including the ability to ensure the confidentiality of data.

This situation has led to unauthorized disclosure and / or unauthorized access to the personal data of 6 individuals, between November 16, 2020, to May 18, 2021, these includes the transmission of service contracts to erroneous e-mail addresses, unauthorized access of the employees of the operator to the personal data of Vodafone customers without any requests from them.

The National Supervisory Authority found that the operator did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of the processing of personal data, ensuring that personal data can be accessed only by persons authorized for the purposes authorized by law and protect personal data stored or transmitted against unlawful processing, access or disclosure.

Thus, the operator processed the personal data of 64 individuals by unauthorized access to their data by the employees of the operator between November 4, 2020, to June 22, 2021.

On November 12, 2020, the Italian data protection supervisory authority (Garante per la protezione dei dati personali) ordered Vodafone to pay a fine of more than Euro 12,250,000 on account of having unlawfully processed the personal data of millions of users for telemarketing purposes. As well as having to pay the fine, the company is required to implement several measures set out by the Garante to comply with national and EU data protection legislation.

The decision marks the final step in a complex proceeding that Vodafone had initiated following hundreds of complaints and alerts submitted by users against unsolicited phone calls made by Vodafone and/or the company's sales network to promote telephone and Internet services.

More specifically, one of the most worrying findings of the investigations was the use of fake telephone numbers or numbers that were not registered with the ROC (i.e. the National Consolidated Registry of Communication Operators) in order to place the marketing calls. This practice is under Vodafone's own spotlight and is seemingly related to a shady set of unauthorized call centers that carry out telemarketing activities in utter disregard of personal data protection legislation.

Additional violations could be established for the handling of contact lists purchased from external providers. Those lists had been obtained by Vodafone business partners from other companies and had been transferred to Vodafone without the users' required free, informed, and specific consent.

Faking account of the infringements found in the course of the proceeding, the Italian Garante imposed a fine amounting to Euro 12,251,601.00 ($13,918,431.32)

Finally, the Garante banned Vodafone from further processing data for marketing or commercial purposes where such data are acquired from third parties that have not obtained the users' free, specific, and informed consent to data disclosure.

The National Supervisory Authority completed on November 4, 2020 an investigation at the operator Vodafone Romania SA and found the violation of the provisions of art. 12, art. 15 and art. 17 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

The operator of Vodafone Romania SA was sanctioned with a fine in the amount of 19468.8 lei, the equivalent of the amount of 4000 Euro or $4,675.99.

The sanction was applied as a result of complaints claiming that the operator did not respond to requests to exercise the rights of access and deletion provided by art. 15 and art. 17 of the General Data Protection Regulation.

During the investigation, Vodafone Romania SA could not prove the settlement of the requests for exercising the access and deletion rights within the term provided by art. 12 of the Regulation.

organization.name: Monetise Media Limited
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
A fined was filed by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) against Monetise Media Limited for making unsolicited direct marketing calls.

Between 28 July 2020 and 28 July 2021, Monetise Media Limited engaged in the transmission of a total of 3,506,157 direct marketing emails and text messages. These subscribers had not provided valid consent, contrary to the regulation 22 of PECR.

On December 14, 2022, Monetise Media Limited has been fined GBP 125,000 (154,005 USD) by the ICO.

In 2020, West Feliciana Parish Law Enforcement District learned that i3-Software & Services, LLC's (S&S) products and services acted as vectors of compromise that delivered malicious malware directly into their networks, exposed personally identifiable information (PII) of thousands of Louisiana citizens, and substantially jeopardized the operational capability of Louisiana's first responders.

The Law Enforcement District claimed that S&S stored their sensitive information in an unencrypted status, in random locations throughout their employees' workstations, contrary to commercially reasonable standards.

The Law Enforcement District purportedly spent $700,000 for return of purchase prices, potential additional expenses related to remediation and any obligation to notify parties of the data breach.

organization.name: Execupharm Inc.
organization.industry: Administrative Management and General Management Consulting Services

incident.description:
On July 10, 2020, Jennifer Clemens (Plaintiff) filed a class action complaint against ExecuPharm, Inc. and Parexel International Corp (collectively, Defendants) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The action arises out of data breach incident that affected the Defendants.

According to the complaint, on March 13, 2020, Defendant ExecuPharm, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Defendant Parexel, suffered a serious data breach whereby third-party hackers gained access to troves of sensitive information maintained on Defendant ExecuPharm's servers and demanded a ransom in exchange for not releasing the information. The stolen information included, among other sensitive information, full names, home addresses, social security numbers, taxpayer IDs, credit card numbers, banking information (including copies of personal checks for direct deposit), driver's licenses, dates of birth, names of spouses and beneficiary information, including their social security numbers, payroll tax forms (such as W-2 and W-4 forms), and in some cases, copies of passports of Defendant ExecuPharm's current and former employees, as well as certain of Defendant Parexel employees whose information was stored on Defendant ExecuPharm's servers. After Defendant ExecuPharm failed to meet the hackers' demands, this information was posted to a dark web website associated with a well-known ransomware group, along with thousands of emails, financial and accounting records, user documents, and database backups.

Plaintiff brought the action on behalf of all persons whose personal Information was compromised as a result of the data breach and who entered into an employment agreement with Defendant ExecuPharm in which Defendant ExecuPharm promised and agreed to take appropriate measures to protect the confidentiality and security of the employee's personal data.

Plaintiff sought for class certification, equitable reliefs, damages, including nominal and statutory, attorneys' fees, costs, litigation expenses, prejudgment interest on all amounts awarded and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

On September 4, 2020, the Defendants moved for the dismissal of the complaint for Plaintiff's failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted.

On February 25, 2021, the Court ordered the dismissal of the case without prejudice.

On March 16, 2021, Plaintiff filed a notice of appeal in the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

On November 1, 2022, the parties jointly moved the Court to stay the case pending settlement discussions. However, on November 2, 2022, the Court denied the motion to stay.

On June 22, 2023, counts two, five, six and all claims against Defendant Paraxel was dismissed without prejudice.

On September 6, 2023, Plaintiff her first amended class action complaint.

On March 15, 2024, Plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Under the terms of the settlement, Class Members may receive reimbursement of documented out-of-pocket expenses, not to exceed $10,000. Class Members can also submit a claim for reimbursement for documented time spent remedying issues related to the Data Breach for up to five (5) total hours at a rate of $25 per hour capped at $125 ('Documented Lost-Time Claims'). Lastly, Class Members that reside in the state of California as of March 13, 2020, can submit a claim for a one-time payment of $100 in lieu of a claim for reimbursement for Documented Out-of-Pocket Expenses and Lost Time. There will be no cap on total payments made.

Furthermore, Class Counsel will ask for attorneys' fees award in the amount of $607,910.96, plus expenses of $67,089.04. Plaintiff will also receive service award in the amount of $5,000.

On April 25, 2024, the Court granted the motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement.

Westfield State University fell victim to a $1.75 million cyber theft earlier this month, university president Ramon Torrecilha announced in a statement.

Student, faculty and staff data were not compromised by the breach. The theft was an isolated incident that occurred on or around February 14, and the money stolen was intended as a payment to a state agency.

A university spokesman declined to specify which state agency the payment was intended for, or whether officials have information on why Westfield was targeted.

The Office of the Treasurer and Receiver General, the Office of the Comptroller, and Westfield State University immediately took steps to ensure the integrity of the state and university financial systems and all are working with banking offices and state and federal law enforcement.

According to Torrecilha, an investigation remains ongoing, who noted, given the investigation, we were not able to announce this sooner.

On February 28, 2020, an employee of Worksmartly Pte. Ltd. (Worksmartly) uploaded a file on the company's GitHub account. When doing so, the employee changed the setting of the GitHub account from 'private' to 'public' under the mistaken belief that the File would only be accessible to other members of Worksmartly. In fact, the change in setting had resulted in the File being accessible to the public.

The file contained the personal data of 308 individuals, which comprised Roche Singapore Pte Ltd's (Roche) current and former employees. The information includes name, NRIC/FIN/Passport number, address, date of birth, race, citizenship, employee ID, Roche email address, role title, employment commencement date, salary, bank account name and numbers and name of bank.

On 2 April 2020, Roche informed the Personal Data Protection Commission.

On November 24, 2020, a financial penalty of $5,000 was imposed on Worksmartly for breaches of the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA).

organization.name: TikTok Inc.
organization.industry: Internet Publishing and Broadcasting and Web Search Portals

incident.description:
French CNIL (Commission Nationale Informatique & Libertes) has fined TikTok EUR 5 million (($5,416,100) for violating cookie consent rules.

French data protection watchdog claims that users are not able to refuse cookies, as easily as they accept them, TikTok also failed to sufficiently inform of the purposes of the different cookies.

Between May 2020 and June 2022, the CNIL conducted multiple audits on the 'tiktok.com' website and on the documents requested from the company by the CNIL. The CNIL only assessed the website in an unauthenticated space, while the mobile app was not scrutinized.

The Restricted Committee considered that making the refusal mechanism more complex actually amounts to discouraging users from refusing cookies and encouraging them to favor the ease of the 'Accept all' button.

It was concluded that this process violated the freedom of consent of Internet users and constituted a violation of Article 82 of the Data Protection Act since it was not as simple to refuse cookies as to accept them at the time from online control in June 2021 until the implementation of a 'Refuse all' button in February 2022.

A federal investigation was launched after threat actors accessed Yazoo County School District's information technology system without authorization. The school became aware of the cyber-attack on Monday, October 12, 2020. Barron did not state how the attackers had gained access to the system or what information had been compromised as a result of the incident.

Following the attack, the school took its IT systems offline and engaged a cybersecurity firm to help recover data encrypted by threat actors. Classes at the school are operating as normally as possible under existing COVID-19 restrictions.

The school board voted to pay a company $300,000 to recover the data that was encrypted by malware.

'In an abundance of caution, we are deploying advanced cyber-security tools throughout our environment to ensure devices can be used without issues and to allow us to resume normal IT operations as quickly as possible. We are also taking measures to unlock the encrypted files.'

Barron said that staff payroll, cafeteria transactions, and the school's phone, fire alarm, and burglary systems were not impacted by the attack.

On September 27, 2021, The Spanish data protection authority (AEPD) imposed a fine of 50,000 to Vodafone Espana, S.A.U., for violations of Article 6(1) of the General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) ('GDPR'), following a complaint regarding the processing of personal data without a legal basis.

After receiving messages from Vodafone in September 2020 claiming a debt derived from services contracted on its behalf with Vodafone, the claimant discovered that these services were not contracted in his name and that the billing address corresponded to an old house where he lived with his ex-partner. Moreover, according to the ruling, Vodafone ruled out any identity theft and verified that the occurrence was caused by a data crossing in their system, which caused the claimant's data to appear as the data of his ex-owner partner's account.

Furthermore, the resolution emphasizes that Vodafone took the necessary steps during the investigation to cancel the claimant's debt, specifically by issuing a credit note for the amounts that had been invoiced to him, and that once the debt was cancelled, the claimant's personal data was unlinked from his ex-client partner's account, and the claimant's personal data was deleted from Vodafone's system once the debt was cancelled.

The AEPD noted that the documentation in the file offers evidence that Vodafone had violated Article 6(1) of the GDPR, since it processed the claimant's personal data without having any legitimacy to do so. Furthermore, the AEPD highlighted that, by acknowledging the computer error, Vodafone did not take necessary precautions to prevent these events from occurring.

Based on the mitigating and aggravating factors, the AEPD deemed it appropriate to impose on Vodafone a penalty of 50,000, for the violation of Article 6(1) of the GDPR. Moreover, the resolution provides that, on November 9, 2021, Vodafone proceeded to pay the final sum of 40,000, making use of the reduction of voluntary payment.

Slovak cryptocurrency exchange ETERBASE disclosed a security breach, the hackers stole Bitcoin, Ether, ALGO, Ripple, Tezos, and TRON assets worth $5.4 million.

The company disclosed the hack on Thursday, threat actors have stolen various cryptocurrencies from its hot wallets, it also suspended all the transactions until September 10.

The company notified law enforcement authorities that are investigating into the incident, it also informed its users that it has enough capital to meet all our obligations.

The company announced the hack on Twitter and through a series of messages posted on its Telegram channel.

ETERBASE revealed it has tracked the fraudulent transactions and is following the stolen funds and informed exchanges where they were moved to avoid that attackers could cash them out.

On March 30, 2020, Robert Cullen (Plaintiff) filed a class action lawsuit against Zoom Video Communications, Inc. (Zoom or Defendant) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. The action arises out of Defendant's violation of the California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 (CCPA) which protect consumers' personal information from collection and use by businesses without appropriate notice and consent.

According to the complaint, Zoom users can host or participate in a Zoom videoconference through several means, including the use of the Zoom App for iOS (Apple) devices, an app for Android devices, an app for MacOS, or through a web browser. Zoom boasts its appreciation for the importance of maintaining its users' privacy. However, Zoom has failed to properly safeguard the personal information of the increasing millions of users of its Zoom App and video conferencing platform. Upon installing or upon each opening of the Zoom App, Zoom collects the personal information of its users and discloses, without adequate notice or authorization, this personal information to third parties, including Facebook, Inc. invading the privacy of millions of users in violation of CCPA.

Plaintiff brought the action on behalf of himself and all persons and businesses in the United States whose personal or private information was collected and/or disclosed by Zoom to a third party upon installation or opening of the Zoom video conferencing application (Class).

Plaintiff sought for class certification, statutory damages, punitive and treble damages, enjoining Defendant from continuing the illegal activities, reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses, pre- and post-judgment interest, and further relief as this Court deems just and proper.

On May 21, 2020, Plaintiff Cullen filed a stipulation to consolidate Case No.5:20-cv-02155-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-02170-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-02376-LHK, Case No.4:20-cv-03078-LHK, Case No 5:20-cv-02520-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-0259 2-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-0259 1-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-02620-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-0269 1-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-02861-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-0289 3-LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-029 39 -LHK, Case No.5:20-cv-03042-LHK, and Case No.5:20-cv-03252-LHK.

On May 28, 2020, a stipulation to consolidate actions was granted by the Court and on July 30, 2020, a consolidated amended class action complaint. On July 31, 2021, Zoom agreed to pay $85 million (Settlement Fund) and bolster its security practices to settle a lawsuit. Under the terms of the settlement, class members who used the free version of Zoom can claim a $15 class action rebate. Those who paid for a subscription can claim a $25 award or 15 percent of their fees. Class counsel sought attorneys' fees up to 25% of the $85 million Settlement Fund, or $21.25 million, plus out-of-pocket expenses of $130,842.24. Plaintiffs will receive service payments of $5,000 each.

On October 21, 2021, the Court preliminarily approved the class action settlement. On January 28, 2022, Plaintiffs filed their motion for final approval of class action settlement.

On April 21, 2022, the Court granted Plaintiffs' motion for final approval and their motion for attorneys' fee and expense award. Accordingly, the Court closed the case.

On April 21, 2020, Plaintiff Ryan Odom filed a class action complaint on behalf of himself and others similarly situated in the US District Court for the Central District of California, Riverside against Defendant ECA Marketing, Inc. in violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA).

At no point did Plaintiff inquire Defendant about its services or provide authorization to receive autodialed calls or prerecorded messages on his cellular telephone from Defendant. Nonetheless, on or around March 8, 2020, Defendant called Plaintiff's cellular telephone. There are thousands affected.

Plaintiff sought for actual compensatory damages suffered, statutory damages, Plaintiff's attorneys' fees and cost.

Defendant has agreed to a $990,000 settlement benefiting consumers who claim the company placed pre-recorded calls to their cellphones without their permission. A final fairness hearing in the case settlement is Dec. 6, 2021.
